webTitle: Rae set for debut in Scotland midfield

fields.headline: Rae set for debut in Scotland midfield
fields.trailText: Gavin Rae of Dundee is set to make his Scotland debut after a rib injury ruled the Rangers midfielder Barry Ferguson out of tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against San Marino at Hampden Park.
fields.body:
Gavin Rae of Dundee is set to make his Scotland debut after a rib injury ruled the Rangers midfielder Barry Ferguson out of tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against San Marino at Hampden Park.

Rae, who has six Under-21 caps, is one of the few Scottish players to survive the Dens Park multinational revolution led by the Dundee manager, Ivano Bonetti. He joined the squad at their hotel in Troon in midafternoon, amid the disappointment of the much anticipated midfield pairing of Ferguson and Paul Lambert being halted in its tracks after only one competitive airing and one friendly appearance in 10 months.

Scotland have won each of their five previous matches against San Marino, but rarely without a struggle. When the teams met on World Cup qualifying business in October, the tiny republic held out until the 71st minute before losing two quick-fire goals to Matt Elliott and Don Hutchison.

Ticket sales for the game are around 25,000, said a spokesperson for the Scottish Football Association.

Mark Pembridge could be facing a long lay-off with another of the crippling thigh injuries that have wrecked his season. The Everton midfielder is out of Wales's clash with Ukraine in Cardiff, and could miss a crucial month of the Goodison Park side's battle to avoid relegation.

He took the risk of reporting for Wales having played only 79 minutes after two months out with a damaged calf muscle in his right leg. But in rain-swept Yerevan, Pembridge damaged his left thigh.

"I'm gutted," he said. "I'd only just got back into action following a similar injury in my other leg. Now it looks like I'm back to square one again."

Wales need to beat Ukraine to maintain a realistic chance of qualifying for the 2002 finals.

 Four of the Wales Under-21 squad have been sent home for a breach of discipline while in Armenia. Three of the shamed players are from Cardiff City: the goalkeeper Lee Kendall, defender Kevin Evans and the former Arsenal defender Rhys Weston, who won his first full cap in Portugal last season. The fourth player is the Crystal Palace full-back Stephen Evans.

The four broke an 11.30pm curfew at the team's hotel in Yerevan on Friday.

fields.headline: Lines to live by
fields.standfirst: The Duchess of York revealed this weekend that she always carries a copy of Rudyard Kipling's poem If with her, and is a firm believer in its 'philosophy'. But what, exactly, is its philosophy? And, while we're about it, what are people who declare their love for Rupert Brooke's The Soldier trying to tell us? Emma Brockes reads between the lines
fields.trailText: If | Stop All the Clocks | Still I Rise | The Soldier | He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven | The Prophet | The Bells of Heaven
fields.body:
If | Stop All the Clocks | Still I Rise | The Soldier | He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven | The Prophet | The Bells of Heaven

If Rudyard Kipling

Who likes it
Sarah Ferguson, John Major, Margaret Thatcher and the Russian nationalist leader Alexander Lebed

Remind me?
If you can keep your head when all about you
Are losing theirs and blaming it on you
If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you
But make allowance for their doubting too.

What the critics say
"In multicultural Britain, Kipling is an embarrassment. He would not today win the Nobel Prize for literature. More likely, he would be banged up at Her Majesty's pleasure and writing polemical poetry for the Spectator. His chauvinism, racism and misogyny is constant evidence of a deep-rooted anxiety about everything foreign." (Iain Finlayson, the Times)

What it says about you
Although I like to be photographed road-testing military hardware/negotiating inflatable obstacle courses/delivering the Budget, I am often out of my depth. I survive by reminding myself that essentially, I am superior to everyone else, if not by birth then by race, marriage and the volume of my voice.

Where you will find it
Orated by the head boy of a minor public school on speech day/a sergeant major on passing out parade/a moribund Des Lynam over the closing credits of Euro '96. (A CD was released of Lynam reciting If - Time to Stand and Stare - or, as the Sun put it, Time to Stand and Stare in Disbelief.)

Further reading
Closing Doors, Opening Worlds, Looking Beyond the Retirement Horizon, by Vern Drilling; The Life of Field Marshal Rommel, by David Irving.

Stop All the Clocks WH Auden

Who likes it
Des Lynam

Remind me?
Stop all the clocks, cut off the telephone,
Prevent the dog from barking with a juicybone,
Silence the pianos and with muffled drum
Bring out the coffin, let the mourners come.

What the critics say
"Auden commits most of the lecturer's traditional crimes. He uses big words he can't explain... he combines the smart-arse and the parsonical, armchair psychoanalysis and wayside-pulpit, Anglo-Catholic wisdom."
(Eric Griffiths, Evening Standard)

What it says about you
Although educated in the classics, I am broad-minded enough to allow the odd modern poem into my canon of personal favourites. Either that, or I'm impressionable enough to buy poetry on the back of a passing reference to it in a hit romantic comedy.

Where you will find it
Recited over solemn music during a televised public health warning, at a funeral, or on the bookshelf of a teenage misanthropist, who when she reads it while playing the Four Weddings soundtrack/anything by REM, can bring on an enjoyable flood of tears.

Further reading
The Nation's Favourite Poems, Pam Ayres - A Collection, any piece of literature that has appeared in a movie, eg the works of Herodotus, as seen in The English Patient.

Still I Rise Maya Angelou Trevor McDonald, Bill Clinton.

Who likes it
Trevor McDonald, Bill Clinton

Remind me?
You may shoot me with your words
You may cut me with your eyes
You may kill me with your hatefulness
But still, like air, I'll rise.

What the critics say
"Just the thing for a progressive school assembly." (the Independent)

What it says about you
Whoever you are, I feel your pain. Heightened powers of empathy have liberated me from the white, middle-class perspective through which my neighbours see the world, and I commune on a deeper plane. In my poetry group I write haiku apologising for my privileged background.

Where you will find it
Recited at the inaugural meeting of the Goddess Moon Circles women's forum (Newton-le-Willows chapter); embroidered on to a cushion; recited by the author at the inauguration of a Democratic US president.

Further reading
Alice Walker, Toni Morrison, bell hooks, Sylvia Plath, Adrienne Rich, Anne Sexton.

The Soldier Rupert Brooke

Who likes it
Tony Blair

Remind me?
If I should die, think only this of me:
That there's some corner of a foreign field
That is forever England

What the critics say
"Mawkish old chestnut." (Daily Telegraph)

What it says about you
I'm only dull because nothing has come along to challenge me yet. A war, for example, would bring out a side of me that my friends would find surprising. When I nod off during Newsnight, I dream of falling heroically in battle, to take my place, with the other unsung heroes, "under an English heaven".

Where you will find it
GCSE exam paper, university lecture on the cultural jingoism of the war poets, old soldiers' reunion at the Kettering branch of the British Legion.

Further reading
Wilfred Owen, Churchill's diaries

He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven WB Yeats

Who likes it
Vanessa Feltz gave her teenage daughter Allegra a copy and told her to memorise it, so inspiration would always be to hand

Remind me? But I, being poor, have only my dreams;
I have spread my dreams under your feet;
Tread softly, because you tread on my dreams

What the critics say
"Yeats? That old fairy." (Shane MacGowan)

What it says about you
I am very vulnerable, although the "being poor" line refers less to my pecuniary than to my emotional state. I am not thrown by words like "enwrought" and try to slip them into conversation for the enlightenment of friends not sufficiently impressed by my Cambridge degree.

Where you will find it
Cross-stitched on to sampler cloth using two strands of floss for the cross stitch and one strand for backstitch and French knots; then framed and hung in the downstairs cloakroom.

Further reading
You Can Feel Good Again: Commonsense Therapy for Releasing Depression and Changing Your Life, by Richard Carlson; You Mean I'm Not Lazy, Stupid or Crazy?! : A Self-Help Book for Adults With Attention Deficit Disorder by Kate Kelly, Peggy Ramundo.

The Prophet Kahlil Gibran

Who likes it
Reggie Kray, Ned Sherrin

Remind me?
Love one another, but make not a bond of that love.
Let it rather be like a moving sea between the shores of your souls.

What the critics say
"A prime specimen of transcendent guff" (Gilbert Adair, London Evening Standard)
"Trite, sentimental and lightweight." (the Guardian)

What it says about you
When people ask me for my address, I say" Planet Earth." I don't say much - and what I do say is often dismissed as the waste product of substance abuse - but if you could see what's going on in my mind, you'd be too intimidated to approach me. My creativity levels are, like, out of this world.

Where you will find it
On a wedding sampler, a door blessing or a leather bookmark and presented to a couple on the occasion of their marriage. Initially touched, they sling it in a box from whence it is retrieved, 40 years later, by their grandchild, who hangs it up at college because it's "way deep and cool".

Further reading
The Apache Blessing or the Cherokee prayer, numbers one and two in the wedding speech top 10 ("Now you will feel no rain/For each of you will be shelter to the other/Now you will feel no cold/For each of you will be warmth to the other.")

The Bells of Heaven Ralph Hodgson

Who likes it
Meg Mathews.

Remind me?
For tamed and shabby tigers
And dancing dogs and bears
And wretched, blind pit ponies,
And little hunted hares.

What the critics say
"Evokes little more than a tinny racket." (Sunday Telegraph)

What it says about you
Small, fluffy mammals make me cry. I can't read the line "blind pit ponies" without thinking of the time poor Merrylegs fell at the final jump and lost me the gold medal at gymkhana.

Where you will find it
Enacted for parents at a junior school's end of term entertainment, in which little Bobby, with Quasimodo histrionics, plays the blind pit pony, and the school bully uses his role as the tiger to maul his classmates.

Further reading
Harvey Nichols catalogue, British Airways in-flight magazine, Enid Blyton.

fields.headline: World markets bounce back
fields.trailText: Global stock markets recovered their poise yesterday as bargain-hunting dealers pushed share prices higher all around the world.
fields.body:
Global stock markets recovered their poise yesterday as bargain-hunting dealers pushed share prices higher all around the world.

Trading curbs were introduced in New York to cap the rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which was up by more than 200 points at lunchtime. The Dow's turnaround followed gains in Tokyo and London, with the FTSE 100 index showing its biggest one-day points gain for more than two years.

However, with anxiety persisting over the prospects for the US economy, attention was last night focusing on a speech due to be delivered today by Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Dealers are also hoping that the European Central Bank will follow the lead of the Fed and the Bank of Japan and deliver a cut in interest rates for the 12-nation eurozone when it meets on Thursday.

Despite yesterday's rally - which followed a pick-up in share prices on Friday - analysts were cautious about the prospect of the year-long bear market coming to an end.

"Nobody is dancing on the casket of the bear market yet, but at least investors are trying to bury the bear market," said David Sowerby, a market strategist at Loomis Sayles, which oversees $65 billion. "Investors are believing there is a greater likelihood that March will mark the bottom. Two days don't make a long-term trend, but it's certainly a more positive than a negative sign."

Markets were also cheered yesterday by more encouraging news from Argentina, where there were signs that the country's newly-appointed economic strong-man, Domingo Cavallo, will be successful in pushing through a package of spending cuts.

In London, the FTSE 100 Index closed up 174.3 points at 5576.6 while the Techmark, the City's index of leading technology shares put on more than 3% on the day to close just below the 2000 level.

The West's leading economic think tank, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, said yesterday that technology shares in the European Union should not be ranked as lowly as their post-bubble counterparts in the US. "Since Europe has seen much less of a mark-up of stock prices - especially hi-tech stock - in the 1990s than the US, and the medium-term outlook for the EU countries looks healthier, there is no fundamental reason why technology media and telecommunications prices in Europe should drop in unison with the US ones."

Mr Greenspan will today make his first public appearance since the Fed's decision last Tuesday to cut US interest rates by only 50 basis points unnerved global markets, which were hoping for a bigger reduction.

Last night, there was still widespread caution about how solid yesterday's rally would prove. "I think it could just be a short-term rally in a bear market," said Thierry Rojat of Weavering Capital's Montblanc hedge fund. He expected a rate cut by the European Central Bank on Thursday. If not then, at the next meeting.

webTitle: Persistence shows retailers are driving down inflation

fields.headline: Persistence shows retailers are driving down inflation
fields.trailText: Extra pressure was piled on the Bank of England yesterday to cut the cost of borrowing after a new study by one of its economists showed that ferocious competition among retailers was driving down core inflation in the UK.
fields.body:
Extra pressure was piled on the Bank of England yesterday to cut the cost of borrowing after a new study by one of its economists showed that ferocious competition among retailers was driving down core inflation in the UK.

Price wars among Britain's big four supermarkets and the leading clothing retailers will result in the government's key measure of the cost of living -inflation excluding mortgage interest payments (RPIX) - remaining below its target of 2.5% for the next six to 12 months, research found.

The work conducted by Bank economist Joanne Cutler will add weight to the arguments of the "dove-ish" faction on the nine-strong monetary policy committee and is certain to intensify the debate about whether base rates should be cut from 5.75%.

Ms Cutler's study was commissioned by MPC member DeAnne Julius, who fought a successful campaign last year to ensure that those appointed from outside the Bank to set interest rates had access to their own sources of research.

The Bank said Ms Cutler's work was an attempt to find a new measure of core inflation for Britain. Economists say that by stripping out components that move erratically, such as oil prices or the cost of seasonal food, they can more easily assess the underlying trend.

The study used the same basket of goods and services that make up RPIX but weighted them according to the stability of their inflation rates rather than their importance to the budgets of households in Britain.

"The new measure, RPIXP, is a good predictor of RPIX six months and 12 months ahead," Ms Cutler concluded in her paper. "It outperforms most other core inflation measures - as well as current RPIX itself - in terms of predictive ability.

"RPIXP suggests that disinflationary pressures were more intense in the second half of the 1990s in the UK.

"It has been consistently below RPIX since the autumn of 1996, reflecting the weakness of non-seasonal food, and clothing and footwear - prices where competitive pressures were intensified by the strength of sterling, the Asian crisis and global oversupply.

"These items have a high weight in a persistence-based core inflation measure."

fields.headline: Sizzla
fields.body:
Signs are taped across the venue where, at 11.15pm, people are still queuing: "No search, no entry." Whatever the security guards are looking for, it's not marijuana: the smell hits you the moment you walk through the door. The embrace of ganga as God's gift to His people is one tenet of Rastafarianism - perhaps the only one - that Sizzla's audience gladly holds dear.

But Sizzla is here to change that. The twentysomething Jamaican - born Miguel Collins - has made it his mission to instruct the black diaspora in the articles of Rastafarian faith. His songs are invigorating, preaching peace, the pursuit of wisdom and respect for black women and their children. But songs aren't enough. Every few minutes he stands at the front of the stage and embarks on an animated sermon. "Rastaman do everything for you, the black nation," he announces. Later he explains that Haile Selassie is the black Christ, in a tone that suggests his argument is incontrovertible.

Central to his doctrine is returning to Africa, a recommendation that has a particular piquancy in this east London venue, where many in the audience are the children of immigrants from Britain's former colonies. "Repatriation is a must for free children of the earth," he states. Many raise lighters in the air in agreement, but his words are also met by a pensive silence.

Such lectures just aren't what you expect, or perhaps even want to hear, in the midnight hour on a Saturday night. But Sizzla pulls it off, partly because it's so rare to come across a musician with strong beliefs, but mostly because he is an electrifying performer, so magnetic that you barely notice or need the blur of dancehall bass and drums glugging behind him.

From the moment he stalks on stage he's a blur of energy, dancing and gesticulating to stress every lyric. And his voice is astonishing: incomprehensible at times, words churning from his mouth like mushed meat from a mincer, but dulcet too. His tone is particularly honeyed when he sings about women; it's a shame that his admiration for them boils down to the assessment: "That's what girls are for, to keep me and to care me." Whatever the security guards are looking for, it's not marijuana: the smell hits you the moment you walk through the door. The embrace of ganga as God's gift to His people is one tenet of Rastafarianism - perhaps the only one - that Sizzla's audience gladly holds dear. But Sizzla is here to change that. fields.headline: A&L moves into home improvements
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester will this week introduce a new name to the high street when it unveils the first in a planned chain of outlets aimed at home-buyers and DIY enthusiasts.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester will this week introduce a new name to the high street when it unveils the first in a planned chain of outlets aimed at home-buyers and DIY enthusiasts.

The bank has chosen the name "movingimproving" for its new venture, which it said was the first initiative of its kind by a mortgage lender.

The stores will offer financial advice on Alliance & Leicester mortgages, personal loans and credit cards and will also offer a range of information services aimed at those planning a move or who in tend to carry out home improvements.

The first two movingimproving branches will open in Banbury, Oxfordshire, and Leamington Spa, Warwickshire on Thursday. Alliance & Leicester has not said how much it is spending on the venture.

The launch of moving improving coincides with the start of the traditional spring house-hunting season.

A spokeswoman said the two stores would be running as a pilot and the plan is to roll the concept out nationwide. The stores have been designed to provide an "informal and relaxed" atmosphere.

webTitle: Vodafone signals higher prices for pre-pay phones

fields.headline: Vodafone signals higher prices for pre-pay phones
fields.trailText: The price of Vodafone's cheapest pay-as-you-talk package is likely to rise from £50 to £70 after it announced cuts in the bonuses paid to distributors. By David Teather.
fields.body:
The price of Vodafone's cheapest pay-as-you-talk package is likely to rise from £50 to £70 after it yesterday announced cuts in the bonuses paid to distributors of pre-pay mobile phones for every new customer.

One2One, the smallest of the four UK mobile phone networks, last week almost doubled the price of its entry level pay-as-you-go handsets to £70.

The moves are a tacit acknowledgement from the mobile phone networks that they have been paying too much to attract often low spending customers. Vodafone disclosed two weeks ago that 9% of its customer base had neither made nor received a phone call for three months.

Both Vodafone and One2One have underlined their strategy of pushing customers on to subscription packages with monthly rental fees.

Peter Bamford, Vodafone's chief executive for the UK, Middle East and Africa, said: "These changes in Vodafone's commercial policies reflect the move of the UK market in to a phase of greater maturity and our recognition of the need to reduce the levels of expenditure on customer acquisition."

Although Vodafone has a cleaner balance sheet than many of the large European telecoms companies, it has also built debt from the acquisition of third generation mobile phone licences.

One2One, owned by Deutsche Telekom, described the high level of subsidies as unsustainable.

Vodafone is reducing the bonuses it pays to distributors for activating accounts by £12 from May 1, on top of a £6 reduction last month. The company is also scrapping its All in One mobile packages which included a handset, one year's line rental and bundled monthly minutes.

"We aim to reward our distribution channel for quality customers, rather than the quantity of customers, thereby ensuring the increasing focus on customer retention and development across the business," Mr Bamford said.

BT Cellnet said last week it had no plans to follow the example set by One2One although it is phasing out its cheapest phone, at £30. French-owned rival Orange said it was reviewing its options.

 Tempus Group, recently appointed by Vodafone as its global lead marketing agency, yesterday reported a 29% increase in pretax profits to £21.5m. Revenues were up 64% to £151m.

The Vodafone account is being handled by Tempus Partners, a new business unit formed to advise on co-ordinated marketing campaigns including the appointment of advertising, design and direct marketing agencies.

fields.headline: Russian opera stars strut their stuff
fields.standfirst:
Gorchakova/ Leiferkus
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Gorchakova/ Leiferkus
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Recitals of operatic chunks with piano accompaniment are precarious exercises at best. Orchestral effects lose their clout when transcribed for the keyboard; there is the constant threat that the musical impact will be undermined. Things came dangerously close to it on this occasion, with pianist Semyon Skigin battling to convey the orchestral impetus of Verdi, Tchaikovsky and Puccini while Russian stars Galina Gorchakova and Sergei Leiferkus strutted their formidable stuff.

The effort and difficulty were more than once apparent. The string tremolandos and the baleful, buzzing woodwind that introduce Verdi's Macbeth and Iago respectively sounded like the accompaniment to a tacky melodrama. The muted yet disturbing interplay of woodwind, brass and harp that tracks Tchaikovsky's Tatiana as she writes her catastrophic letter to Eugene Onegin makes for monochrome pianism, however sensitive Skigin's playing.

The power of this recital lay ultimately in the thrill of the voices - two of the greatest in the world today - and in the dramatic cut and thrust between them. Gorchakova's appearances have been few of late. She has sung both Tatiana and Tosca at Covent Garden, but we haven't heard her Verdi live at all. This is a shame, for here she proved a breathtaking interpreter of his music. There's a voluptuous opulence in her voice, a sumptuous warmth in the upper registers, a whiff of mezzo darkness down below.

She unfurled the long lines of Leonora's final aria from La Forza del Destino with rapturous ease. She joined Leiferkus for the Act Three duet from Il Trovatore, where her coloratura flowed with heady abandon. There is no one else around to equal Gorchakova in this music - you have to go back 20 or 30 years, to Leontyne Price and Renata Tebaldi, to hear anything comparable.

It was in Verdi, too, that Leiferkus proved most revelatory. His Iago is already familiar, but he reminded us of it again, leaning against the piano with a malign smile playing across his face as he intoned his blasphemous creed. He also gave us Macbeth's final soliloquy, capturing the world-weariness, terrible solitude and moral obloquy resulting from his own infamy.

A handful of Russian songs kicked the programme off, with Leiferkus particularly fine in Rachmaninov's Fate - snide, menacing, edging towards sneering malevolence.

To close, they gave us extracts from Onegin - an aria each, then the final duet. For the latter, the Barbican platform was transformed into a theatre, as music stands were pushed aside and the pair of them acted their socks off. At the end, as Tatiana finally dismisses the man who has emotionally destroyed her, Gorchakova slipped from Leiferkus's insistent grasp and fled off-stage to the artist's room, all the while holding a rock-steady top B. It's hard to beat either of them in Onegin, and this was a performance to leave you in tatters.

webTitle: Liffe and Nasdaq join drive to cooperate

fields.headline: Liffe and Nasdaq join drive to cooperate
fields.trailText: London's derivatives market, Liffe, has signed a limited alliance with New York's Nasdaq in a move that underlines the growing importance of cooperative agreements alongside consolidation among the world's exchanges.
fields.body:
London's derivatives market, Liffe, has signed a limited alliance with New York's Nasdaq in a move that underlines the growing importance of cooperative agreements alongside consolidation among the world's exchanges.

The partnership between the British and US exchanges covers single stock futures, a recent innovation from Liffe which it is hoping to sell into the US, the world's biggest capital market.

The link-up between Liffe and Nasdaq follows a similar alliance between the American Stock Exchange and Euronext, the exchange formed from the merger of the Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris bourses.

Single stock futures are contracts linked to an individual company rather than an index and some 30 such contracts, covering the likes of Cisco, Microsoft and AT&T, are already traded on Liffe's electronic trading system, Liffe Connect. The exchange plans to increase the number in the coming months.

At present, US investors are prevented from trading single stock futures but changes to the regulatory regime are expected to remove the prohibition by the end of this year. The new joint venture will still have to come under US regulators, however.

"The strength of Nasdaq's brand and its pre-eminent position in the US equity market will make our single stock futures offering a compelling choice for both retail and institutional customers in the US as well as in Europe and beyond," according to Liffe's chief executive, Brian Williamson.

Nasdaq chairman Frank Zarb said US regulators were sympathetic towards the initiative by the two exchanges.

"This transatlantic partnership opens new opportunities for both Nasdaq and Liffe. It gets us to market faster and positions us well to offer state-of-the-art electronic trading to investors in both the US and Europe."

The US exchange is keen to increase its presence in Europe. Last year it sought a role in the plans to merge the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges which were thwarted by the hostile bid for the London exchange from Sweden's OM.

It has also held talks with the London exchange which have so far come to nothing and is tipped to be about to take a controlling stake in the pan-European exchange, Easdaq.

fields.headline: The down turn
fields.standfirst:
Another Wall Street slide could set off worldwide deflation. And Japan shows where that leads

Special report: Japan
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Another Wall Street slide could set off worldwide deflation. And Japan shows where that leads.
fields.body:
"We need to tame deflation and make it benign. To do so we need not just different policies but a different economic philosophy." The Japanese banker who told me this a week ago in Kyoto was not speaking only of Japan. Unlike most western observers, he understood that the world is returning to a condition it has not known since the late 19th century, when globalisation first got under way. Deflation is built into the global economy that has emerged in the wake of the cold war. The question is whether we can prevent it from spiralling out of control.

While the stock market continued to defy gravity few people took seriously the idea that we may be returning to a world of steadily falling prices. Deflation might be entrenched in Japan, but there was no reason to think that it could spread. The vast destruction of wealth we have seen in stock markets over the past few weeks has shattered that complacent consensus. As in Japan, the risk is that a further collapse in the stock market will rebound on the real economy and reinforce the deflationary forces that go with globalisation.

Until only a few months ago, the suggestion that the long boom on Wall Street would end in a Japanese-style crash was treated with derision. With few exceptions, western commentators insisted that it rested on sound economic fundamentals. A surprisingly large number gave credence to the idea that the US had entered a "new era" of crisis-free growth. This was, of course, sheer tosh. No doubt it owed something to gains in productivity from restructuring and new technologies, but America's millennial boom was essentially a classic speculative bubble, fuelled by loose credit and stoked up by vast inflows of foreign capital.

As in the bubbles of the past, investors were assured that "This time it is different". The investment bankers who proclaimed an American economic miracle were fond of quoting Joseph Schumpeter's description of capitalism as an economic system driven by creative destruction. But in the euphoria produced by rocketing stock prices the destructive side of capitalism identified by the great Austrian economist (the decimation of obsolete industries and the recurrent booms and busts in financial markets) was rarely mentioned. Many Americans came to believe that crashes happen only in history books.

As in the 1920s, the belief that the US had arrived on a plateau of permanent prosperity became the basis on which they planned their economic future. Placing their faith in the capital gains they had made in the stock market, they stopped putting money aside for retirement and borrowed as if there were no tomorrow. As could have been predicted, the sunlit upland proved to be a narrow and dangerous crevasse.

Many of the capital gains on which Americans were relying for their security in retirement have now gone up in smoke. Any figure is bound to be imprecise, but the worldwide loss of wealth resulting from the decline in stock markets is estimated to be already five or six times as large as that suffered in the mini-crash of 1987. The danger to the global economy posed by this loss of wealth is significant. In order to avoid poverty in old age, millions of Americans will have to start saving again - and saving hard. If history is any guide, they cannot rely on being baled out by the markets. In 1949, the Dow Jones Index stood at less than half its top in 1929. In 1982, when the last great bull market in American stocks began, the index was still more than 20% lower than its peak in 1966 - 16 years earlier. Contrary to the claims of brokers and financial advisers, equities are risky even when they are held long-term. After a meltdown of the sort we are seeing, it can take decades for investors to recoup their losses. Many will find their standard of living reduced permanently.

The danger that economic activity will contract throughout the world as Americans curtail their spending is well understood among bankers and policy makers. The deflationary impact of globalisation is less widely comprehended. But the fact is that virtually every aspect of that complex process works to drive prices down. The internet has brought about a huge transfer of value from producers to consumers. By comparison with the past, information is now virtually cost-free. An enormous variety of services can now be accessed directly, without the need for expensive intermediaries. With new technologies, production can be sliced into segments and sited in places all over the world. At the same time, the collapse of communism and the emerging economies of Asia and Latin America have injected billions of new workers into world markets.

Taken together, these developments have catapulted us back in time. The world economy at the start of the 21st century bears a striking resemblance to the last quarter of the 19th century, when underwater telegraph cables started to link up markets around the world. Then, as now, new technologies and global free trade exerted a powerful downwards effect on price levels, with some parts of the world languishing in prolonged depression.

The risk we face at present is that a further slide on Wall Street will tip the world economy into outright deflation. We can be sure that Alan Greenspan will do all he can at the US Federal Reserve Bank to prevent such a disaster. Interest rates will be cut aggressively in an effort to boost confidence.

But the Japanese example is not reassuring. Zero interest rates there have failed to lift the country out of 1930s-style deflation. The economy is still contracting, and the stock market has retreated to a level last seen more than 15 years ago. It can be argued that the bubble economy was more extreme in Japan than in the United States, and the response of the Japanese authorities slow and indecisive. But the real lesson to be learnt from Japan is that once deflation is embedded in the economy it is fiendishly difficult to control. Japanese policy-makers have found that lowering interest rates in these circumstances is - as Keynes famously put it - "pushing on a string". That is why, partly in response to western advice, they are beginning to accept that the only way out may be to print money.

As the Japanese banker observed, we need a new economic philosophy. But I'm not holding my breath. Perhaps aggressive American interest rate cuts will prevent further market slides and consequent recession in the US and throughout the world. If not, western governments and central banks are likely to follow the course they are urging on the Japanese. In that case, we may avoid late 19th-century deflation only to find ourselves back in the inflation ridden world of the 1970s.

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE.

fields.headline: Keeping it real with Run DMC
fields.standfirst:
Run-DMC
Mean Fiddler, London
***
fields.trailText:
Run-DMC
Mean Fiddler, London
***
fields.body:
"My catalogue's bigger than your bank account," the Reverend Joseph "Run" Simmons brags on Crown Royal, Run-DMC's first album in eight years. Simmons, Darryl "D" McDaniel and Jason "Jam Master Jay" Mizell are hip-hop's village elders, relics from the pre-CD era who remember when you could buy a pair of trainers and an anchor-like gold chain and still have change from $1000. Now in their mid-30s (pensionable in rap terms), they can only watch as younger acts rake it in with records that couldn't have existed without Run's 1986 album Raising Hell - hip-hop's first platinum LP.

Galling as it must be to see the likes of Eminem playing arenas while Run's only UK show is consigned to a basement shoebox, they make the best of it. There's much to be said for having been around for 18 years; the NYC trio work together so fluidly that the usual criticism that live rap is disorganised and dull does not apply.

Tall, stout Run and short, slight DMC are comradely in matching Adidas T-shirts and wide-brimmed black "crowns", which they twirl and swap like props. DJ Jay plays a more visible role than most DJs, frequently stepping out from behind what he quaintly calls "the wheels of steel" to lead chants of "Old-old-old school!" Old-school sums up their bare-bones collision of beats, scratching and old hits.

Run and D trade verses with staccato precision, seamlessly joining voices on choruses, with the instinct of people who have done it at 200 shows a year since high school. A raucous version of their only British number one, It's Like That, recalls the party-time innocence before hip-hop discovered the testosterone rush of thuggery. Swearing is restricted to mild expletives in deference to Simmons, an ordained minister, though the band avail themselves of every cliche from "Wave your hands in the air like you just don't care" to "Say hell yeah!" But they're entitled - they invented most of them.

They also invented the rap-rock crossover in the 1980s when they covered Aerosmith's Walk This Way, and inevitably it's this, with its blaring Joe Perry guitar sample, that provokes the greatest response. Arms companionably draped over shoulders, they leave the stage, genial uncles who will be keeping it real into their dotage.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/ Dohnanyi
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Playing Mozart and Beethoven on modern orchestral instruments is a risky business these days. Without the cachet of period performance style, or an early music specialist as conductor, orchestras can seem conservative and out of touch in this most familiar repertoire.

Christoph von Dohnanyi's programme with the Philharmonia Orchestra paired Beethoven's First Symphony, in C major, with Mozart's Requiem. A conductor steeped in the traditions of romantic music and one of the world's most luxurious orchestras: nothing suggested a hint of interpretative innovation. But Dohnanyi's performances were startlingly invigorating and insightful. His musicality and the Philharmonia's dynamism proved there is still vigorous life in modern orchestral playing styles.

The fascination of hearing Beethoven's earliest symphony, composed in 1800, with Mozart's final, unfinished work, written only nine years earlier, is the great difference between their styles and sound-worlds. The symphony bursts with the revolutionary confidence of Beethoven's maturity, while the Requiem has sombre colours and baroque forms.

The First Symphony is the Cinderella of Beethoven's symphonic canon - often regarded as nothing more than an attractive, Haydnesque joke. But Dohnanyi treated the piece with the seriousness it deserves, making it both the apotheosis of classical style and a precursor to a wilder romanticism.

After the extraordinary, ambiguous opening (Beethoven begins the symphony in the wrong key, only finding C major just before the allegro), the first movement was a study in focus and energy. Dohnanyi's brisk tempos never allowed the second movement to flag, while the swift menuetto was full of violence and daring. The headlong finale capped this fine performance with fiery energy.

With the Philharmonia reduced to chamber forces, and the relatively small forces of London Voices, Mozart's Requiem was a curious mix of intimacy and grandiosity. Where his tempos were sometimes extreme, there was a fastidious attention to detail in the balance and phrasing. And while London Voices may have been small in scale, their sound was full of voluptuous vibrato and vivid drama.

The soloists were also operatic, with Reinhard Hagen's booming bass, Toby Spence's plangent tenor, the outstanding mezzo of Alice Coote and Christiane Oelze's soprano. Their voices matched beautifully in the Tuba mirum and Recordare, but it was Coote's evening: she created a heartrending immediacy in some of Mozart's most exquisite music.

webTitle: UK deficit balloons to highest level since 1990

fields.headline: UK deficit balloons to highest level since 1990
fields.trailText: Last year's record trade gap and a fall in profits from abroad sent Britain's current account deficit ballooning to its highest level since the tail end of the Lawson boom, government figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Last year's record trade gap and a fall in profits from abroad sent Britain's current account deficit ballooning to its highest level since the tail end of the Lawson boom, government figures revealed yesterday.

The shortfall between what the UK spent abroad and what it earned rose by £8bn in 2000 to £16.2bn, the highest deficit since 1990 when the gap was £19.5bn, writes Charlotte Denny.

"The main driver of this deterioration is the widening deficit on goods trade," said Danny Gabay, UK economist with JP Morgan. "That clearly reflects the dichotomy between buoyant domestic demand and weak external demand caused by an overvalued exchange rate."

But there was good news for the government in separate figures which showed that the economy was stronger than initially thought in the final quarter of 2000, while households saved more of their income.

Households saved 5.5% of their income in the final quarter, a sharp rise on the 3.4% rate recorded in the third quarter. Economists fear a collapse in confidence could prompt households to cut back on spending sharply, in order to put more aside for a rainy day. While increase in the current account deficit in 2000 surprised some forecasters, as a percentage of national income, the shortfall is much smaller than a decade ago.

fields.headline: Goldberg's new variations in Manchester
fields.standfirst:
Goldberg Ensemble
RNCM, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Goldberg Ensemble
RNCM, Manchester
****
fields.body:
Modern classical music is the poor relation of the contemporary arts scene. It lacks the glamorous image of visual art or literature, receives meagre media attention and is shunned by the concert-going public. A musical equivalent of the Tate Modern - where the public could hear contemporary works free of charge - simply could not happen. Patiently tolerated in orchestral concerts, new music can also largely be found lurking in university music departments and contemporary-music festival ghettos.

The Goldberg Ensemble's contemporary festival goes some way towards addressing this problem. Slotted invitingly into the Royal Northern College of Music's regular concert schedule, it has run a workshop for local schoolchildren, discussion forums for performers and composers, and showcased four works selected by the Society for the Promotion of New Music.

One fact that emerged strongly from the festival is that tonality - the avoidance of which was de rigueur in the 1950s and 1960s - is no longer the agonised issue it once was. Friday's concert, which featured works written since 1994, illustrated this conciliatory, post-avant-garde spirit with music luxuriating in tonal idioms, completely at ease with itself. Howard Skempton's 1998 Concertante for violin and strings was firmly in the early Tippett mould; Matthew Taylor's 1999 Horn Concerto (in which Richard Watkins was a sensational soloist) belonged in the same conservative English vein. Less overtly conservative was the SPNM premiere of Peter Nagle's Infinite Breathing, which juxtaposed brooding stillness and violent activity: a schema that draws on tonal/non-tonal archetypes to some extent but that successfully avoids the cliches often associated with them.

Paul Patterson's Deviations is another quintessentially English work, its boisterous first movement recalling Britten's Simple Symphony. Colin Matthews's 1982 Divertimento for double string quartet, by contrast, gravitated towards the rich textures and harmonies of Strauss's Metamorphosen. The highlight of Saturday's concert, though, was Gorecki's 1962 Elementi for string trio. Now a classic of avant-garde string writing, this grippingly intense work forces the sonoristic capacity of strings to their limits. The absence of a programmatic title was strangely liberating: this was sonic experience at its purest and most absorbing.

 The festival continues at the Civic Hall, Wolverhampton (01902 552121), from tomorrow until Friday, then at Leeds University (0113-224 3801), April 5-7.

webTitle: Jazz review:  Ray Brown/ Christian McBride

fields.headline: Battle of the double-bass virtuosos
fields.standfirst:
Ray Brown/ Christian McBride
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Ray Brown/ Christian McBride
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Ray Brown, the great double-bassist, bandleader and talent scout (he encouraged the careers of Diana Krall and Christian McBride), effortlessly embodies a largely vanished jazz urbanity. He appeared here on his 75th birthday tour; and when a musician takes the stage who lived and worked with Ella Fitzgerald, for whom Duke Ellington was a contemporary and Miles Davis a shy newcomer, the fundamental things apply.

Brown performed in his favourite format - the song-playing acoustic trio - with Monty Alexander on piano and Russell Malone on guitar. He followed an opening set by McBride's intense, multi-idiomatic contemporary quartet. As such striking contrasts of generation and method often prove, putting these two giants of the double bass in the same show was revelatory.

Brown's music loves insinuation and space, and he uses so little amplification that virtually none of the instrument's unplugged tonality is lost. McBride, a virtuoso in a more upfront and muscular manner on both double bass and bass guitar, gives his work an altogether more attacking sound and a great deal more volume. His music is a typical confection of the fusion and post-bop methods of ensembles, from early Weather Report to today's Michael Brecker band.

Camille Gainer, the remarkable hailstorm-emulating drummer in McBride's band, provided exactly the unbroken torrent of percussive sound the style demands. But it was the tiptoeing Brown who brought the house down, his meticulous musicality appealing to the several generations present. A breezy stroll through an assortment of standards confirmed the condition of the leader's elegantly unfolding counter-melodic lines and irresistibly propulsive beat (But Not For Me had a bassline like a string of subtle drumbeats). And Malone's exquisite guitar virtuosity was a blend of ecstatic vibrato and improvised melody.

Monty Alexander, a sometimes overwhelmingly ornate technician in many piano styles, turned down all that power to suit the prevailing dynamic. His account of Caravan was not only a stand-out of the night but of many nights.

McBride's set was comparable in terms of a quite different type of virtuosity, and Geoff Keezer's piano and Ron Black's quirkily diffident-sounding sax-playing gave the band plenty of width. But, as on the recent McBride album Sci-Fi, there is a hollowness in the themes that makes some powerful improvising appear cut adrift. Sci-Fi itself, the Weather Reportish funk blast that closed McBride's set, had exactly that perplexing quality.

webTitle: Geldof sells travel site in 'crazy money market'

fields.headline: Rearranging the deckchair
fields.standfirst:
Geldof sells travel site in 'crazy money market'

More net news
fields.trailText: Bob Geldof yesterday added some showbiz sparkle to an AIM-listed travel company by selling it the internet travel firm he co-founded two years ago.
fields.body:
Bob Geldof yesterday added some showbiz sparkle to an AIM-listed travel company by selling it the internet travel firm he co-founded two years ago.

Deckchair.com, dreamed up in a pub by Geldof and former Eidos executive James Page, is being taken over by World Travel Corporation, chaired by Jonathan Biles, above, for £3.2m in shares and loan notes, which could later rise by£6m.

Deckchair, forced to cut one third of its staff, was worth more than £20m at the height of dot.com boom.

The Live Aid organiser is likely to receive around £500,000 for a shareholding that once looked like netting him millions.

"This deal could never have happened in the recent crazy money market," he said. "But in a collapsing market, whole new opportunities present themselves for lean and nimble operators like us."

World Travel plans to relaunch the Deckchair website. Geldof, who has secured a three year employment contract worth £100,000 per year, will front the publicity.

fields.headline: Buyers shun Isas
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Recent stockmarket turmoil has crushed confidence among small investors, with figures published yesterday revealing a 38% slide in sales of Isas, the tax-advantageous individual savings accounts.
fields.body:
Recent stockmarket turmoil has crushed confidence among small investors, with figures published yesterday revealing a 38% slide in sales of Isas, the tax-advantageous individual savings accounts.

Sales of share-based Isas fell to £647m in February from £1,029m in the same month last year. Figures for March are expected to show an even steeper decline, with some fund management companies privately admitting that sales have slumped by 60%.

The advertising spend on Isas for the 2001 sales season - running from January to the end of the tax year - has turned into a marketing flop. Fidelity director Paul Kafka said: "In common with the rest of the industry, our sales are down 25-30%, but we did not major on technology funds last year. The companies that did must be the ones suffering most."

Aberdeen Asset Management admitted that its sales for February and March will be down more than the market average - but that it comes after a 300% increase last year. Managing director Gary Marshall said: "We are seeing a fluctuation from one extreme to another; last year there were too many people piling in when the market was too high, now too few are buying Isas when the market is low."

But the flipside to poor sales of share-based Isas is strong inflows into cash Isas, with the major beneficiaries expected to be Halifax, Abbey National, Nationwide and HSBC.

webTitle: Hi ho Silvio rides to Milan's rescue

fields.headline: Hi ho Silvio rides to Milan's rescue
fields.trailText: Imagine if Rupert Murdoch managed to buy Manchester United, and then ran for No 10. Behold the latest chapter in the Silvio Berlusconi story.
fields.body:
Silvio Berlusconi has a lot going on. The owner of AC Milan, Italy's most powerful individual also has fingers in almost every sector of the Italian pie through his Mediaset group - three national TV stations, newspapers and magazines, supermarkets, banks and industry.

Come May 13 he'll probably be head of the Italian government too. It's quite a thought - imagine if Rupert Murdoch managed to buy Manchester United, and then ran for election (directly this time) as Prime Minister of the country.

Curiously, the majority of Italians don't see Berlusconi's ubiquity as a problem; for them, the more interests he has the better at his job he clearly is, ergo he'll do a fine job of running the country.

This month has seen Berlusconi bring his moneyed touch back to his beloved but beleaguered Milan, after two years of taking a back seat. You'll have spotted that of late the formerly invincible Milan have rather hit the skids - two weeks back they failed to qualify for the Champions League quarter-finals, and after a three-month stretch with just two victories they're way out of touch in the domestic league too. Thus, hi ho Silvio, the magnate has come riding to the rescue.

His first step was swift: live on television, he fired the clubs' slumping manager Alberto Zaccheroni. Next came word of massive new investments on the transfer market. "Just like 15 years ago, I've given the go ahead to buy the best in the world," says generous uncle Silvio. The figure for a forthcoming spree of £70m pounds has been floated around - just like the old days.

Now, the timing of all this is no coincidence: Italian elections are looming, and Berlusconi as mentioned is bidding for Government once more. What better way to remind us all of his leadership skills than step in and save the sinking ship?

A quick footnote: Berlusconi's rise to Citizen Kane status began back in the 70s, when the entrepreneur acquired massive financial backing - from where is still unclear. Equally important were the astute friendships he made among Italy's leading politicians.

Berlusconi swiftly became in fact the leading ally of Bettino Craxi - the figure who ruled Italy through a variety of coalitions for over a decade before fleeing corruption charges in the early 90s to die in exile in Tunisia.

Such connections helped Berlusconi set up his empire - and in particular his TV networks. It was the disappearance or arrest of many political allies that in the mid-90s pushed Berlusconi into politics himself. That, some would add, and the promise of parliamentary immunity.

An intriguing CV. Still, thanks to his huge footballing success at Milan, for most Italians Berlusconi's image remains firmly positive.

Backed by his fortune and a considerable nose for the game, he took over the club on the verge of bankruptcy in 1985 and led them to their greatest period ever: six Scudettos, three Champions Cups, two inter-continental cups and countless other trophies.

In those days, Berlusconi was everywhere pulling off coup after theatrical coup. Who swooped wunderkind Gigi Lentini away from Juventus with a helicopter ride for him and his dad, plus a price tag so big even the Pope had to speak out? The Milan president. Who serenaded a signature out of Ruud Gullit by singing 'La Vie en Rose' at the piano of a hotel bar? Our Silvio again.

Such flashness may have put the burlesque in Berlusconi, but come the mid-90s it also allowed him another remarkable coup: sweeping to the head of the Italian government just six months after starting his own party.

Which brings us back to his current interest in rescuing the club.

There are an estimated 7m Milan fans out there across Italy, a constituency that Berlusconi and co can't afford to leave disgruntled. Moreover, there's the danger of damage to the candidate's winning image - make of it what you will, but Milan leaving Europe coincided with a three-point drop for the politician in the polls.

The team celebrated their first game back in Berlusconi's bosom with a 4-0 thrashing of bottom of the table Bari. For their part, Milan's fans didn't look too impressed - banners in the crowd ranging from the jealous to the jaundiced: "For a few years in politics, you've thrown away a mythic team," said one. "Berlusconi absent until the election campaign," proclaimed another. The freshly dismissed Zaccheroni meanwhile was remembered with a grateful salute.

Luckily for Silvio, not everyone is proving so unreceptive. Straight after he'd retaken the reins at the Rossoneri, a satirical TV show raised old questions about where his prodigious finances originally came from. Citing excerpts from the many judicial inquiries into his businesses, the show also mentioned connections between the Milan president and known members of the Mafia. Within days, Berlusconi had the offending series pulled off the air. Perhaps Milan fans should be thankful he's on their side once more.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Curiously, the majority of Italians don't see Berlusconi's ubiquity as a problem; for them, the more interests he has the better at his job he clearly is, ergo he'll do a fine job of running the country. This month has seen Berlusconi bring his moneyed touch back to his beloved but beleaguered Milan, after two years of taking a back seat. You'll have spotted that of late the formerly invincible Milan have rather hit the skids - two weeks back they failed to qualify for the Champions League quarter-finals, and after a three-month stretch with just two victories they're way out of touch in the domestic league too. Thus, hi ho Silvio, the magnate has come riding to the rescue. His first step was swift: live on television, he fired the clubs' slumping manager Alberto Zaccheroni. Next came word of massive new investments on the transfer market. "Just like 15 years ago, I've given the go ahead to buy the best in the world," says generous uncle Silvio. The figure for a forthcoming spree of £70m pounds has been floated around - just like the old days. Now, the timing of all this is no coincidence: Italian elections are looming, and Berlusconi as mentioned is bidding for Government once more. What better way to remind us all of his leadership skills than step in and save the sinking ship? A quick footnote: Berlusconi's rise to Citizen Kane status began back in the 70s, when the entrepreneur acquired massive financial backing - from where is still unclear. Equally important were the astute friendships he made among Italy's leading politicians. Berlusconi swiftly became in fact the leading ally of Bettino Craxi - the figure who ruled Italy through a variety of coalitions for over a decade before fleeing corruption charges in the early 90s to die in exile in Tunisia. Such connections helped Berlusconi set up his empire - and in particular his TV networks. It was the disappearance or arrest of many political allies that in the mid-90s pushed Berlusconi into politics himself. That, some would add, and the promise of parliamentary immunity. An intriguing CV. Still, thanks to his huge footballing success at Milan, for most Italians Berlusconi's image remains firmly positive. Backed by his fortune and a considerable nose for the game, he took over the club on the verge of bankruptcy in 1985 and led them to their greatest period ever: six Scudettos, three Champions Cups, two inter-continental cups and countless other trophies. In those days, Berlusconi was everywhere pulling off coup after theatrical coup. Who swooped wunderkind Gigi Lentini away from Juventus with a helicopter ride for him and his dad, plus a price tag so big even the Pope had to speak out? The Milan president. Who serenaded a signature out of Ruud Gullit by singing 'La Vie en Rose' at the piano of a hotel bar? Our Silvio again. Such flashness may have put the burlesque in Berlusconi, but come the mid-90s it also allowed him another remarkable coup: sweeping to the head of the Italian government just six months after starting his own party. Which brings us back to his current interest in rescuing the club. There are an estimated 7m Milan fans out there across Italy, a constituency that Berlusconi and co can't afford to leave disgruntled. Moreover, there's the danger of damage to the candidate's winning image - make of it what you will, but Milan leaving Europe coincided with a three-point drop for the politician in the polls. The team celebrated their first game back in Berlusconi's bosom with a 4-0 thrashing of bottom of the table Bari. For their part, Milan's fans didn't look too impressed - banners in the crowd ranging from the jealous to the jaundiced: "For a few years in politics, you've thrown away a mythic team," said one. "Berlusconi absent until the election campaign," proclaimed another. The freshly dismissed Zaccheroni meanwhile was remembered with a grateful salute. Luckily for Silvio, not everyone is proving so unreceptive. Straight after he'd retaken the reins at the Rossoneri, a satirical TV show raised old questions about where his prodigious finances originally came from. Citing excerpts from the many judicial inquiries into his businesses, the show also mentioned connections between the Milan president and known members of the Mafia. Within days, Berlusconi had the offending series pulled off the air. Perhaps Milan fans should be thankful he's on their side once more.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: World Cup round up
fields.trailText: Holland warmed up for Wednesday's trip to face the Group Two leaders Portugal with a 5-0 win over Andorra that moved them up to third place and only a point behind the Republic of Ireland, the Pyrenean team's guests in Barcelona that same evening.
fields.body:
Holland warmed up for Wednesday's trip to face the Group Two leaders Portugal with a 5-0 win over Andorra that moved them up to third place and only a point behind the Republic of Ireland, the Pyrenean team's guests in Barcelona that same evening.

Pierre van Hooijdonk, a second-half substitute, scored twice in what was his first game for the coach Louis van Gaal, and Holland now trail Portugal by three points.

"I wanted to give my international career a boost and with these two goals I think I've succeeded," said the Ben fica striker. "I think my quality is well known . . . I hope I've convinced the coach."

Patrick Kluivert, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Mark van Bommel got the others, though Holland's key midfielder Edgar Davids came off at the interval with a knee injury.

Poland 's Nigerian-born striker Emmanuel Olisadebe scored twice in Oslo, where Norway lost 3-2 to find themselves in deep trouble in Group Five, one point behind Wales. It was all very unfortunate for Norway, who fought back through John Carew and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer only for the substitute Bartosz Karwan to head the winner with 10 minutes to go.

Croatia , semi-finalists at France 98, beat Latvia 4-1 in Group Six thanks in the main to a first-half hat-trick from Dynamo Zagreb's Bosko Balaban. The Croatians, who along with the leaders Bel gium have no game until June, trail Scotland by only three points and have a game in hand.

In Northern Ireland's group a hat-trick from Ebbe Sand helped Denmark beat Malta 5-0 in Valletta's steamy 30C conditions and put them in good heart for Wednesday's trip to face the leaders, the Czech Republic. Jan Heintze and Charlton's Claus Jensen got the others whereas Sunderland's Thomas Sorensen, taking over from the retired Peter Schmeichel, barely touched the ball.

Two goals in four minutes from Filippo Inzaghi were enough for Italy to win in Romania and prepare the Azzurri to face Lithuania , who drew 1-1 in Hungary , at Trieste on Wednesday.

Thierry Henry and Silvain Wiltord both scored in France 's 5-0 win against Japan in a home friendly.

webTitle: Defensive blunder spoils McIlroy's big passion play

fields.headline: Defensive blunder spoils McIlroy's big passion play
fields.trailText: Sammy McIlroy, the Northern Ireland manager, remains upbeat about his team's prospects in Wednesday's World Cup tie against Bulgaria in Sofia despite defeat by the Czech Republic on Saturday.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy, the Northern Ireland manager, remains upbeat about his team's prospects in Wednesday's World Cup tie against Bulgaria in Sofia despite defeat by the Czech Republic on Saturday.

The Irish should never have conceded the 11th-minute goal by the Lazio playmaker Pavel Nedved but it was enough to lift the Czechs to the top of the group table with 10 points, two above Denmark with Bulgaria, three adrift, in third place.

"We have only four points but I am more than satisfied with our World Cup campaign so far," said McIlroy, who will be given a new contract by the Irish FA when his current one expires next January.

"This is a young team, players are getting better as they gain experience. Our approach to the Bulgarians will be positive and I reckon they may give us more space than did the Czechs. A repeat of Saturday's show and we can come away with a result."

Northern Ireland, humiliated 4-0 by Norway in a friendly last month, deserved at least a point from this match in which they revealed total commitment, creative skill and what McIlroy called "the passion of the 80s".

Only the post kept out a diving header from the man of the match, the Blackburn winger Keith Gillespie, and in the barnstorming final 10 minutes the substitute Phil Gray hit the bar and saw his rebound effort scooped off the line.

Gillespie, 24, now back in favour at Rovers after almost a complete season in the wilderness, posed a constant threat with his pace and tantalising crosses. Michael Hughes, the Wimbledon winger just back from a broken leg after nine months of inactivity, played a major role in a refreshing performance.

"He has had only 225 minutes of match practice since being given the medical all-clear and to produce such a courageous display for a full 90 minutes against the fourth best team in the world was quite an achievement," said McIlroy.

The team as a whole was organised and disciplined, and heads did not drop when the Czechs scored, unlike in the Norwegian debacle.

But the goal was a defensive disaster for the Irish. An attempted clearance from Colin Murdock hit the giant Czech centre-forward Jan Koller and Aaron Hughes, the Newcastle United defender, flicked it with his toe into the path of Nedved who scored from the edge of the box.

McIlroy will retain an unchanged side on Wednesday provided Gillespie (calf strain), Jim Magilton and Danny Griffin, under treatment for slight groin problems, are passed fit as expected.

At least the applause and the chants of "There's only one Neil Lennon" as the home team left the pitch spelled success for the Irish FA plans and security measures to prevent any repetition of the sectarian abuse heaped on the Celtic midfielder in the Norwegian game.

"Hopefully the scourge of bigotry has at last gone," said Jim Boyce, the Irish FA president.

fields.headline: Keane rips into Ireland's blazers
fields.trailText: When it comes to Roy Keane, the Republic of Ireland will know they sometimes have to take the rough with the smooth. The captain brought a distinct whiff of controversy into the World Cup qualifying equation last night with a scathing rant against the nation's football association, writes Daniel Taylor .
fields.body:
When it comes to Roy Keane, the Republic of Ireland will know they sometimes have to take the rough with the smooth. The captain brought a distinct whiff of controversy into the World Cup qualifying equation last night with a scathing rant against the nation's football association, writes Daniel Taylor .

Doubtless mindful that his importance for the national team makes him almost immune from disciplinary action, Keane refused to pull any punches when he was asked about the Irish training facilities. "They're abysmal and they have been for as long as I have known it," he said.

But it was what he perceived as a major slight to the players before Saturday's World Cup qualifying tie in Cyprus that incensed the captain so much that he even made a veiled threat of retiring from international football.

"I was fairly critical of the seating arrangements on the flight over when the officials took up the first- class seats with the players sat behind them," he said. "It's not just because I play for Manchester United. No, for me it's just not right. The priority has to be the team."

Asked if it was the sort of thing that would make him consider early retirement from the international scene, Keane warmed to his theme. "Yes," he replied. "I'm not pointing the finger at anyone but if there was anything to make me say to myself 'I can't be arsed' or 'I'm going to spend a week with my wife and kids', that will be it.

"I understand they [the Football Association of Ireland] can't afford to change a lot of things but there is a lot of room for improvement."

It is not the first time Keane has decided to speak his mind - "people can like it or lump it," he added - and in all likelihood it probably will not be the last.

Earlier this season the Manchester United's captain accused Old Trafford supporters of being too engrossed in eating prawn sandwiches to give vocal support to the team.

fields.headline: Colossus reaches new heights
fields.trailText: There have been too many disappointments in recent years, too many acts of self-destruction, for Ireland to allow optimism to cloud realism, but as Mick McCarthy and his players analyse their World Cup qualifying campaign so far they are entitled to feel a certain amount of smugness.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the GSP Stadium
fields.body:
There have been too many disappointments in recent years, too many acts of self-destruction, for Ireland to allow optimism to cloud realism, but as Mick McCarthy and his players analyse their World Cup qualifying campaign so far they are entitled to feel a certain amount of smugness.

This afternoon they will leave Aphrodite's island for Wednesday's encounter with Andorra at Barcelona's Mini Estadi knowing that should they emphasise the gulf in status there as they did against the Cypriots here in Nicosia they could reach the midway point of Group Two at its summit.

Looking further ahead, McCarthy said: "I still think Portugal are the best team in it but if we can take full points against Andorra in the next two games - as we should - our clash with them in Dublin in June is the big crunch."

Ever since they showed the audacity to outpass Holland at the Amsterdam Arena last September there has been a steely resolution about McCarthy's side and, inspired once again by their captain Roy Keane, this was another triumph for the composed and determined football they have exhibited over the past six months.

Certainly with Keane in this mood the Irish will feel that for all the panache of the Portuguese and the dash of the Dutch, they have every chance of making it to next year's tournament. Plaudits are bestowed upon the Manchester United captain so often that there is a tendency almost to take them for granted but it would be remiss for his contribution ever to be underestimated and, for Ireland, this is his era.

Deploying the unfortunate Panagiotis Pounnas as a man-marker was something akin to asking a karaoke fan to out-sing Pavarotti and, ignoring the quality of the opposition for a moment, Keane's 50th international will be remembered as one of the most polished performances in an Irish shirt for years.

"I looked at the poor fellow trying to get near Roy and thought to myself: 'I pity you,'" said McCarthy. "Roy was abso lutely immense. I wouldn't swap him for anyone in the world. It's not just how he influences our team, it's how he influences the opponents. For me, he's the best in the world at what he does."

Keane returned the compliment. "Mick deserves a lot of credit .He has shown this week just how professional he is. He didn't let what happened with his father affect his work with us."

McCarthy's father, Charlie, died three days before the match. The manager flew from Dublin to see him at the family's Yorkshire home at the start of the week. He took an early flight from Cyprus yesterday to be with the family again and will rejoin his squad in Barcelona tomorrow.

Cajoling his team-mates one moment, deflating his opponents the next, Keane instigated proceedings by volleying in Gary Kelly's cross just after the half-hour and, despite plenty of huff and puff from the Cypriots, the outcome was not in doubt after that.

By the time Ian Harte rapped in a penalty nine minutes later, Kevin Kilbane having been bundled over by Georgios Theodotou, the Irish fans in this Lego-like stadium could have been excused for pondering whether Ireland's record 5-0 away win, over Liechtenstein in 1996, would be emulated, if not bettered.

Instead it was not until the final 15 minutes or so that their keep-ball was converted into a potent threat. A deflected long-range effort from Gary Kelly gave the score a more accurate reflection before Keane, never one to slip into the comfort zone, powered his way into the penalty area with a typically marauding run for the fourth.

There were one or two hairy moments that will have troubled McCarthy but, all in all, this was another rounded per formance and it was only human nature that, as his players were bussed away from this labyrinthine old town, the manager should turn his thoughts to the future.

Portugal host Holland on Wednesday and, though the Cypriot coach Stavros Papadopoulos's assertion that Ireland are now the group favourites may be stretching the truth, if McCarthy harbours serious aspirations of automatic qualification he will doubtless be hoping Luis Figo and co have a bad night.

More realistically, if Ireland are looking at qualifying through the play-offs as one of the group runners-up, it might be handier if Portugal complete a double over their fellow Euro 2000 semi-finalists.

"We've given ourselves the opportunity now," said McCarthy. Optimism may not be clouding realism, but Ireland cannot help but be overcome by a sense of expectation.

webTitle: Welsh slack backs take shine off Hartson heroics

fields.headline: Welsh slack backs take shine off Hartson heroics
fields.trailText: The Wales defence that lined up in the Armenian capital comprised a Third Division left-back and a central partnership plucked from the First. To the right stood Mark Delaney, who is more familiar this season with the Aston Villa treatment table and reserve-team grounds than he is with the Premiership.
fields.body:
The Wales defence that lined up in the Armenian capital comprised a Third Division left-back and a central partnership plucked from the First. To the right stood Mark Delaney, who is more familiar this season with the Aston Villa treatment table and reserve-team grounds than he is with the Premiership.

Such is the material from which Mark Hughes must fashion adequate cover for his goalkeeper Paul Jones. When Kevin Ratcliffe was at the top of his powers and Eric Young was proving wrong those who doubted his international credentials, Wales had a defence worthy of the name. Those days have long gone.

On Wednesday it will be the turn of Adriy Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov, strikers of some repute in the global game, to pick at the stitching. If those at the back on Saturday could not restrain Armenia's finest and protect the lead afforded them by John Hartson, then what hope against Ukraine?

It was the second time in this qualifying competition that Wales had ventured deep into the territory of the former Soviet Union and conceded two goals. It is also the second time - Norway being the first - that they held a precious lead only to grant the opposition the opportunity to come back again.

For their manager the bitter disappointment he shared with the press here in the Republican stadium can only have been heightened by the memory that his hard-pressed rearguard had stayed intact in Poland, the group leaders, on their last outing.

"I have a bunch of players now who are very disappointed," said Hughes. "We have scored twice away from home and that should be enough. But the goals we have conceded are bad ones for us. If you give players at this level opportunities like we did, then they will punish you."

Armenia led with a goal that exposed the poverty of Welsh discipline as Andy Legg found himself the last defender with four players bearing down. His despairing tackle merely pro vided an easy far-post chance for Artak Minasyan.

Armenia's equaliser after Hartson's seven-minute brace was admittedly a ferocious strike but Andrey Movsisyan should have been closed down and denied the space to take aim for his spectacular shot.

"We sat back at 2-1 and invited them on to us," said Hartson after a night of personal glory had been denied him. He had led the fightback by looping a shot high into the net immediately after an unlucky attempt by Dean Saunders, who on his 74th appearance became Wales' longest-serving outfield player. The Coventry forward's second, a glancing header, arrived three minutes after half-time following a free-kick from the substitute Matthew Jones.

A first win in the group, and a first World Cup win since August 1996, seemed at hand but Armenia had other ideas. Despite being reduced to 10 men for the last eight minutes after Albert Sargsyan's dismissal they claimed their point and left Wales to reflect on a third successive draw and another missed opportunity.

So the plot moves on to the Millennium stadium and the visit of Ukraine, whose 0-0 stalemate at home to Belarus has given Wales hope. At least Hughes will have Ryan Giggs fit to play his first serious match since February 20 after hamstring touble, and Robbie Savage is back in the reckoning. John Robinson, though, misses out after his booking on Saturday and Mark Pembridge is out with a thigh injury.
