The Coventry forward's second, a glancing header, arrived three minutes after half-time following a free-kick from the substitute Matthew Jones. A first win in the group, and a first World Cup win since August 1996, seemed at hand but Armenia had other ideas. Despite being reduced to 10 men for the last eight minutes after Albert Sargsyan's dismissal they claimed their point and left Wales to reflect on a third successive draw and another missed opportunity. So the plot moves on to the Millennium stadium and the visit of Ukraine, whose 0-0 stalemate at home to Belarus has given Wales hope. At least Hughes will have Ryan Giggs fit to play his first serious match since February 20 after hamstring touble, and Robbie Savage is back in the reckoning. John Robinson, though, misses out after his booking on Saturday and Mark Pembridge is out with a thigh injury.

webTitle: Brown finds a silver lining after dark finale

fields.headline: Brown finds a silver lining after dark finale
fields.standfirst: World Cup qualifiers
fields.trailText: Time being the great healer, the loss of two precious qualifying points to an injury-time equaliser is probably already beginning to press less heavily on Scottish hearts. But only just. Belgium's last-gasp draw condemned the Scots to their most dramatic emotional collapse in years. After 30 minutes, Scotland were 2-0 ahead and one man up following Eric Deflandre's 28th-minute sending-off for handball.
fields.body:
Time being the great healer, the loss of two precious qualifying points to an injury-time equaliser is probably already beginning to press less heavily on Scottish hearts. But only just. Belgium's last-gasp draw condemned the Scots to their most dramatic emotional collapse in years. After 30 minutes, Scotland were 2-0 ahead and one man up following Eric Deflandre's 28th-minute sending-off for handball.

Everything was going Scotland's way. On the hour, elation was turning into edginess following Marc Wilmots's 58th-minute header to make it 2-1. By full-time, the substitute Daniel van Buyten's header from a cross from a fellow substitute, Sven Vermant, felt like a knife in the heart.

"We are walking away with a draw feeling like it was a defeat," said the Scotland coach Craig Brown, who had seen Billy Dodds re-direct a low cross from Craig Burley to put Scotland ahead after only 70 seconds and then double the advantage when Deflandre handled a Colin Hendry header, an indiscretion that led to a red card and a penalty rammed high into the net.

Scotland at least can make amends sooner rather than later, with San Marino visiting Glasgow on Wednesday. For the moment they must rue the missed opportunity to go top and take a three-point lead over the Belgians. As it is, Robert Waseige's Red Devils maintain a massively superior goal difference.

Yet Brown said: "In a month's time, when we are three points clear [assuming a win over San Marino] and Belgium have to go to Croatia, it won't feel so bad. Had we won, I would have been saying, unusually, 'we are on our way'.

"We've got a lot to do now. But that's the Scottish way. But the Scottish way usually ends up with us getting there in the end."

There were two key moments that came within inches of delivering the three points for Scotland. In the 57th minute, Dominic Matteo continued a beautifully flowing Scottish move with a pass that bisected two defenders and gave Barry Ferguson a gilt-edged chance to make it 3-0. But the midfielder's shot was too close to Geert de Vlieger, his miss compounded by Wilmots's goal at the other end a minute later. And in the 73rd minute, Didier Dheedene restored his reputation with a brave, saving tackle on the surging Burley.

The added disappointment of Saturday was that it came off the back of three good results, all away. Scotland's form on the road has been far superior to that at the recently revamped Hampden Park and leads Brown to believe his side are capable of winning in Brussels. He also thinks Belgium may become complacent on the back of their unlikely draw - a notion that, frankly, seems preposterous.

As for the Belgians on Saturday, Brown likened Wilmots, who got on to the end of Bob Peeters's cross, to Celtic's Swedish striker Henrik Larsson. "He is always a problem with the way he arrives late and powers in headers. You know what he is going to do but, like Larsson, stopping him is another thing."

Whereas Scotland's opening goal revealed weakness down the Belgian left, Belgium's two goals each found the Scottish defence guilty of standing off their man. Still, David Weir, on the left side of the Scottish defensive trio, had an outstanding match. Celebrating his 25th cap, as was the midfielder Paul Lambert, the Everton defender covered and read the game expertly.

Colin Hendry looked awkward on that Peeters cross but the captain otherwise gave a reasonably commendable performance, especially in the first half.

Hendry is passionate about his country and could not have had a more auspicious occasion for his 50th cap. But this morning he will still be some way this side of downcast.

webTitle: Owls find a perfect enough pitch

fields.headline: Owls find a perfect enough pitch
fields.trailText: A curious subplot is developing in a city fast becoming a wasteland of footballing achievement: whose pitch more resembles a patch of waste ground, Aston Villa's or Birmingham City's?
fields.body:
A curious subplot is developing in a city fast becoming a wasteland of footballing achievement: whose pitch more resembles a patch of waste ground, Aston Villa's or Birmingham City's?

Arsène Wenger breezed out of town eight days ago declaring Villa Park the home of the worst surface in the Premiership, an opinion with which John Gregory fully concurred. Across the second city a procession of managers have left St Andrew's echoing similar sentiments.

And after City's third defeat in four games and second on the bounce at home, the manager Trevor Francis joined them. "Football is all about passing and movement and that's what we tried to do today," said Francis. "But that's impossible on that pitch."

Wednesday's recovery has coincided with Peter Shreeves becoming caretaker manager and his subsequent recruitment of Carlton Palmer from Coventry City.

"We've got 45 points and have seven games left, so I think we're safe now," added Palmer.

But Shreeves is not quite so sanguine. And it is a view born out by Wednesday's not too distant experiences under their former manager Ron Atkinson.

"Ron rang me and reminded me that when he was at the club Wednesday needed just one point from three games to stay up," Shreeves said. "They never got them, so I won't be taking anything for granted until we're mathematically safe."

It's still mathematically possible, of course, for City to be promoted automatically. Their recent results and that pitch have done them no favours, which is why Francis is probably grateful that his side have only three home games left.

A more tangible explanation for City's decline appears to be an unexplained loss of confidence: witness Darren Purse's 60th-minute penalty kick that resulted in the equaliser.

Purse hacked the ball straight at Kevin Pressman but Geoff Horsfield was on hand to capitalise on the rebound. City's relief evaporated when substitute Michele Di Piedi beat the offside trap to settle matters three minutes from time with what was effectively his first touch.

The Italian teenager had replaced Gilles de Bilde, who had demonstrated an equally assured touch to put the visitors in front.

webTitle: All smiles again as Taylor strikes

fields.headline: All smiles again as Taylor strikes
fields.trailText: The "smiling prohibited" signs were removed yesterday after West Brom took advantage of their meeting with last-placed Tranmere to breathe new life into their play-off challenge.
fields.body:
The "smiling prohibited" signs were removed yesterday after West Brom took advantage of their meeting with last-placed Tranmere to breathe new life into their play-off challenge.

Two defeats had given rise to suggestions that the club's nickname should be changed from Baggies to Glums. Their manager Gary Megson had read the riot act to Lee Hughes, spotted committing the heinous crime of sharing a joke with his marker Des Walker during the defeat by Sheffield Wednesday. And what punishment he would have imposed on anyone guilty of the quietest titter after a woeful derby display at Wolves eight days ago does not bear thinking about.

But Bob Taylor's contribution yesterday ensured that further drastic measures were not necessary. The 34-year-old stirker, selected in preference to the younger and much more expensive Jason Roberts, scored the goals that keep Albion on track for the play-offs.

In doing so Taylor not only justified his inclusion at the expense of Albion's record signing but also relieved some of the frustrations he experiences as a semi-permanent substitute.

"I want to play, especially at my age, because time is running out," he said. "So it does get very frustrating sitting on the bench, although I appreciate the younger players are first in the queue.

"Obviously I was delighted to start today and even more delighted to score both goals. They take my tally for the season to five, which is nothing to shout about when compared with the number Lee Hughes and Jason Roberts have scored. But the two goals could prove vitally important come the end of the season."

They could also prove damaging to Tranmere's fading hopes of survival. A win or even a draw would have lifted them off the bottom, but with Fulham waiting on Friday and only eight other games remaining their immediate future could hardly be more daunting.

Nevertheless their acting manager Kevin Sheedy remains optimistic. "It's still very tight at the bottom of the table and if we put a couple of wins together then we've still got a chance. We showed today that we're not as bad as our position suggests. And our current situation was summed up by our failure to take chances and gift-wrapping them the second goal."

That failure in front of goal was all too apparent in the 10th minute. Jason Koumas delivered a low cross from the right that found Wayne Allison, but the striker, two yards out and with the goal at his mercy, failed to connect.

Taylor followed suit in the 31st minute by wasting a perfectly flighted diagonal cross from Ruel Fox by heading over. Albion's Dutch midfielder Richard Sneekes was also wayward in the 40th minute when his attempt at a first-time shot to a square pass from Hughes resulted in a miskick.

His embarrassment was to last only seconds, however, as Taylor seized on the loose ball and fired it past John Achterberg from 18 yards. Then a misunderstanding between Achterberg and Graham Allen allowed Taylor to chip over the stranded goalkeeper and into the unguarded net.

But Albion were severely tested in the five minutes that remained after Koumas fired a free-kick through the wall.

webTitle: Leader:  Football ballet is an inspiration

fields.headline: The goal is art
fields.standfirst: The football ballet is an inspiration
fields.trailText: The news that Archie Gemmill's moment of footballing glory - his logic-defying chip into the net for Scotland against Holland in the 1978 World Cup - is to be rendered as a piece of modern ballet is inspiring.
fields.body:
The news that Archie Gemmill's moment of footballing glory - his logic-defying chip into the net for Scotland against Holland in the 1978 World Cup - is to be rendered as a piece of modern ballet is inspiring. For one thing, it will surely succeed in choreographer Andy Howitt's aim of encouraging young Scottish lads to take up dance. If Billy Elliot hadn't already done the trick, surely this will: after all, school playgrounds the world over have long resonated with the sound of kids re-enacting moments of football greatness (usually with the lad providing his own commentary). Now the chance to do the same in the name of art will surely be a winner.

Mr Howitt's project is also bound to inspire the Scottish nation to yet another round of meditation on the place the game has played in its national psyche. Why just this weekend, Craig Brown's team staged another of Scotland's trademark, nearly-but-not-quite results by allowing a two-goal lead over Belgium to slip out of their grasp. Even as dance, the Gemmill classic will stir all those bittersweet memories anew.

But the idea also inspires another thought. Why should Mr Howitt end there? Surely there are many flashes of soccer heartbreak and genius that deserve the balletic treatment. We hear he has his eye on Michael Owen's triumphant goal against Argentina in 1998. But what of Geoff Hurst's iconic 1966 hat trick against West Germany?

And shouldn't other artists follow his lead? Diego Maradona's "hand of God" goal against England would make a wonderful, Michelangelo-style fresco. And football need not be the only sport so honoured. Boxing has produced great literature and some pretty good movies. But wouldn't the life story of Muhammad Ali make a first-class opera, perhaps in the hands of John Adams? And what of the story of Posh and Becks? Surely that is crying out to be written - as a fairytale for our times.

webTitle: Captain leads the man by man marking

fields.headline: Captain leads the man by man marking
fields.trailText: David Seaman
fields.body:
David Seaman

Rescued England by blocking Jari Litmanen's header in the dying moments and made other important stops, notably from Jonatan Johansson at 0-1. Had no chance with Finland's goal.

Training tip: Kicking. Twice might have landed England in trouble with poor clearances from the floor.

Mark: 7

Gary Neville

Solid in defence and occasionally overlapped to good effect, not least when providing the cross for Michael Owen's equaliser. Could not be faulted for deflecting in Aki Riihilahti's header.

Training tip: Keep coming forward to exploit understanding with Beckham.

Mark: 7

Sol Campbell

Strong and assured, making one shuddering challenge and an important interception when Johansson threatened near the end. Key figure in repelling Finland's late pressure.

Training tip: Needs greater understanding with Ferdinand.

Mark: 7

Rio Ferdinand

Commanding in the air but not at his most adventurous or fluent on the deck. Caught out when Finland scored and lost Johansson shortly after but made crucial late header.

Training tip: Concentration. Twice caught out.

Mark: 6

Chris Powell

Far less convincing than against Spain, particularly early on. Nerves settled as England improved and he made one dangerous break forward.

Training tip: Positioning. Stood off his man too much in the first half.

Mark: 6

David Beckham

So much for Beckham's demise. At the heart of England's best moments, playing a part in Owen's equaliser and scoring the winner. Managed four other shots, offered some dangerous crosses and drifted off the flank to good effect.

Training tip: More of the same please, cap'n.

Mark: 8

Paul Scholes

Busy, aggressive and tidy, barely misplacing a pass, but only occasionally made the thrusts forward which make him so dangerous. Showed his threat around the penalty area by laying on Beckham's goal and setting up Andy Cole.

Training tip: Adventure. Get forward and drop a few more hand grenades, as Kevin Keegan would say.

Mark: 7

Steven Gerrard

Highly impressive after the interval, winning challenges, making interceptions and playing punchy passes. Not bad for a man who woke up feeling stiff and thought he wouldn't play. Will be missed in Albania.

Training tip: Sort out that back problem. Your country needs you.

Mark: 7

Steve McManaman

Unfortunate to be subsituted after a bright start to the second half during which he beat his marker several times and set up the winner with a surging run. Eager but less effective before the interval.

Training tip: Work on left-foot crosses.

Mark: 7

Michael Owen

By his own admission not his best performance but confirmed his knack of scoring vital goals for England. Also hit the bar with a header and worked tirelessly in his deeper role until taken off in the final minute.

Training tip: First touch - undoubtedly improving but let him down on occasion.

Mark: 7

Andy Cole

Left all wondering if he will ever score for England after wasting a perfect chance in front of the Kop. A few nice touches and a good early shot but was largely unimpressive.

Training tip: Look for barn door and a football in Tirana. Practise until perfect.

Mark: 5

Emile Heskey

Again used by Eriksson in a wide role when he came on for McManaman. Showed his pace and strength with run which earned a free-kick on the edge of the penalty area but had too little time to impose himself.

Training tip: Replay video of Cole's missed opportunities in front of Eriksson and hope for starting place on Wednesday.

Mark: 6

Robbie Fowler

Given a warm welcome by the Anfield crowd and showed his instinct for goalscoring by getting himself into a fine position in the eight minutes he had as a replacement for Cole. Put through by Gerrard, his shot was well saved by Antti Niemi.

Training tip: Slip something into the tea of Owen, Cole and Heskey. Unlikely to start on Wednesday otherwise.

Mark: 6

Nicky Butt

Thrown on for final few minutes and barely had a touch.

webTitle: Archie's artful dodging dances into posterity

fields.headline: Archie's artful dodging dances into posterity
fields.trailText: Choreographer Andy Howitt has created a dance copying Gemill's nifty footwork round the Dutch defence, the graceful chip into the net, and the player's exuberant celebration.
fields.body:
You put your right boot in, you put your right boot out, you put your left boot in and you score a famous goal.

So goes the Gemmill - a celebratory jig choreographed to commemorate the greatest Scottish goal that ever was, scored by Archie Gemmill during the 1978 World Cup match between Scotland and Holland in Argentina.

Choreographer Andy Howitt has created a dance copying Gemill's nifty footwork round the Dutch defence, the graceful chip into the net, and the player's exuberant celebration.

It is designed to attract more boys to modern dance and will be performed this summer at a "dance the goal" event at Hampden Park in Glasgow, part of a celebration of football's finest moments.

Howitt, artistic director of the Scottish Youth Dance company, told a Sunday newspaper that he had already shown the dance to children and they had been very enthusiastic. "This goal is helping get hundreds and hundreds of young men who would never think of dance and movement," he said. "It's a vehicle."

Howitt, who gave up his own ambition to be a professional footballer in favour of dance, said the goal has a very personal link. His grandfather, who had been watching the match with Howitt, then 13, died of a heart attack three minutes after Gemmill scored.

"He had already had two heart attacks and this goal went in, and he cheered and told me, We will win the World Cup. The shock was so great for him."

The goal was voted best ever by a Scottish footballer in a poll last year and is number eight on a list of the top 10 best World Cup goals. Dribbling his way into the penalty area, the diminutive Gemmill zig-zagged past three Dutch defenders with the ball at his feet before lifting it neatly over the goalkeeper's head and into the net.

With Gemmill's help, Scotland eventually won 3-2 but it was not enough to put them through to the next round.

Gemmill, 54, one of the best players Scotland has produced and now a scout for Derby County FC, said he was flattered by the all-dancing tribute to his efforts.

So goes the Gemmill - a celebratory jig choreographed to commemorate the greatest Scottish goal that ever was, scored by Archie Gemmill during the 1978 World Cup match between Scotland and Holland in Argentina. Choreographer Andy Howitt has created a dance copying Gemill's nifty footwork round the Dutch defence, the graceful chip into the net, and the player's exuberant celebration. webTitle: Gerrard out with yet more back trouble

fields.headline: Gerrard out with yet more back trouble
fields.trailText: Steven Gerrard will play no part in England's World Cup qualifier in Albania on Wednesday because of a recurrence of the back problems which continue to stunt his career.
fields.body:
Steven Gerrard will play no part in England's World Cup qualifier in Albania on Wednesday because of a recurrence of the back problems which continue to stunt his career.

The Liverpool midfielder woke up yesterday with a sore back after playing 90 minutes against Finland on Saturday and was sent home after consultation with the England medical staff. Nicky Butt is expected to replace him in the starting line-up in Tirana.

Sven-Goran Eriksson was clearly disappointed to lose a player who performed so impressively during the second half of the 2-1 win at Anfield but the England coach can hardly have been surprised.

Gerrard has struggled to regularly play two games in quick succession for Liverpool and said he felt "very, very tired and very exhausted" after completing a match against Finland which he had doubted he would even start.

"When I woke up in the morning I didn't think I was going to play," the 20-year-old said. "I was still feeling a bit sore and a bit stiff, but I worked hard with the physio and pulled through the 90 minutes."

Gerrard had hoped an intake of the right food and fluid on Saturday night would help him to make the trip to Albania, but he has succumbed to a familiar foe which has forced him to pull out of 11 of the 14 England matches for which he has been selected.

"It's a pity when you miss players that you can count on," Eriksson said, "but that's life. At this moment the most important thing for Liverpool and England is that he gets rid of his problem so that he can play normally. We need him like Liverpool need him."

Gerrard had made it clear he would not travel to Albania unless he felt 100% fit, aware that he otherwise risked not only letting down himself and his team-mates but also affecting his season at Liverpool.

"I have to be honest with myself," he said. "If I go out to Albania and pull a muscle, I could be out for six weeks and Liverpool have a lot of big games coming up." On Saturday they entertain Manchester United and they also have FA Cup and Uefa Cup semi-finals on the horizon.

Gerrard has been visiting a specialist in France to solve the injury problems, which relate to his posture and seem to have been caused by a rapid growth spurt and playing too much football as a teenager.

"It's a bit of a nightmare not knowing each morning whether I'm going to be fit to play or not," the said, "but it's getting better and it will keep getting better."

Butt will win his 11th cap and should have no difficulty settling in alongside his Old Trafford team-mates David Beckham and Paul Scholes.

"Nicky Butt did extremely well against Spain and I know all about his defensive qualities," Eriksson said. "He's a ball player, a very tough player. I would imagine he is a little bit unpleasant to play against as he is always there."

webTitle: Mowlam to join International Crisis Group

fields.headline: Mowlam to join International Crisis Group
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, Tony Blair's most popular cabinet minister, is poised to join the board of the high-powered International Crisis Group, the Brussels-based body which promotes conflict resolution on three continents, when she retires as an MP at the next general election.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, Tony Blair's most popular cabinet minister, is poised to join the board of the high-powered International Crisis Group, the Brussels-based body which promotes conflict resolution on three continents, when she retires as an MP at the next general election.

Though neither Downing Street, the Foreign Office nor the Cabinet Office - where the former Northern Ireland secretary is now the minister in charge - will confirm the appointment, it is regarded in Whitehall as a done deal which will give full rein to what one insider called "Mo's touchy-feely goodness."

The ICG, set up by her old peace process ally, Senator George Mitchell, with US and European support, is a $6m a year, privately-funded body whose board already includes former presidents, premiers and foreign ministers. General Wesley Clark, Nato commander in the Kosovo conflict is also a member.

Along with the Congo, Indonesia and the republics of central Asia, former Yugoslavia is one of the conflicts, actual or potential, where the ICG's 55-strong team of political analysts work on the ground to provide "practical recommendations" for action by the international community.

The part-time appointment will also allow the soon-to-be-ex-MP for Redcar time to juggle other potential commitments and her publishing contract to write what are expected to be best-selling memoirs of a mercurial career at the centre of New Labour politics and the Good Friday agreement in Belfast.

Ms Mowlam, aged 51, has remained determined to prove she is back on top of her ministerial duties since recovering from a brain tumour which developed before the 1997 election. She recently visited such difficult countries as Iran and Colombia - in her efforts to curb the flow of cocaine into western Europe. Since Ms Mowlam announced her decision to give up domestic politics, some reports have suggested she might be appointed to succeed the former Irish premier, Mary Robinson, as UN high commissioner for human rights. She announced her decision to quit last week. But insiders suggest that Ms Mowlam would not want such a demanding job at this stage when she has her book to write - and that, despite UN secretary general Kofi Annan's high regard for her, the post would be unlikely to go to a woman from Northern Europe twice in succession. Though Ms Mowlam has sometimes been an awkward colleague for Mr Blair - both by virtue of her popularity and her outspoken, informal habits - No 10 is keen to see she finds an outlet for her talents. On a practical note, it knows voters would take her side if it did not.

The current chairman of ICG is Martti Ahtisaari, former president of Finland and a player in the Northern Ireland peace process. The president is Gareth Evans, the former Australian foreign minister. Lady Shirley Williams, the ex-Labour cabinet minister, serves on the board, as does George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist, Graca Machel of Mozambique ( now Nelson Mandela's wife) and a clutch of EU ex-ministers like Volker Ruehe of Germany and France's Michel Rocard.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Katy
fields.trailText: I spent 10 months in New Zealand last year so if you want any tips just ask. We bought a car and stayed in hostels, which I would definitely recommend, as it gives you a lot more freedom than the coach tours. The hostels are generally nicer than the ones in Australia.
fields.body:
Hi Sue -

Congratulations on your dive, I'm so glad you enjoyed it! Watch out, you'll probably get addicted now!

I spent 10 months in New Zealand last year so if you want any tips just ask. We bought a car and stayed in hostels, which I would definitely recommend, as it gives you a lot more freedom than the coach tours. The hostels are generally nicer than the ones in Australia. You can pick up a car for a few hundred dollars but you get what you pay for - as a lone traveller you might be better off renting. Lots of people hire camper vans which is worth investigating too. Places I'd recommend: Waitomo (N Island), Taupo (N Island - Tongariro National Park is supposed to be worth a visit if you enjoy walking), Milford Sound (S Island) is a must, Abel Tasman National Park (S Island), Kaikoura (S Island), and lots more besides.

All the best,

Katy

webTitle: Pigswill at root of foot and mouth

fields.headline: Pigswill at root of foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: The recycling of waste food as a method of feeding pigs is the official cause of the current crisis and should be abolished as soon as possible, writes Paul Brown
fields.trailText: The recycling of waste food as a method of feeding pigs is the official cause of the current crisis and should be abolished as soon as possible, writes Paul Brown.
fields.body:
Swill, the preferred method of feeding pigs since the animals were first domesticated thousands of years ago, is the official cause of the foot and mouth outbreak.

Superficially attractive as a method of recycling waste food, it is a practice that should be abolished as quickly as possible.

There has long been official nervousness about pigswill as a feeding method. The greatest potential for infecting or carrying disease is in waste meat.

The most dreaded viruses in the pig industry, classical swine fever and foot and mouth can both survive for long periods in meat - only the heat of proper cooking or boiling can kill it.

Many farmers have abandoned using it already because of the risks, and only 80,000 pigs (1.4% of the UK pig population) now eat swill.

In some countries in Europe use of pigswill has been banned already but the practice has remained legal in the UK because the Ministry of Agriculture believed that they could regulate it properly.

Swill has to be boiled for an hour and each of the premises that use it is licensed and inspected to make sure there is proper compliance.

However, the system has clearly failed with such disastrous consequences that they were unimaginable only five weeks ago - since then nearly 600,000 animals have been condemned.

Despite this, the practice of feeding swill continues and is still being allowed. Although banning it is under consideration, no decision has yet been reached.

The reason swill is so dangerous is due to the current pattern of trade in food. In the past, food used as swill was locally produced and recycled.

Now, waste meat in pigswill could come from the other side of the world, eg from South Africa, where there has been epidemic of Type O strain - exactly the same type as infected the Northumberland pig farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall, the centre of the outbreak.

Technically it is illegal to import meat from an infected country or region; it has to be certified as being free of foot and mouth. Airline and ship food all has to be destroyed or landfilled and cannot be fed to pigs.

However, with the globalisation of trade, it was only a matter of time before the defenses were breached. That they have been in such a terrible fashion is very bad luck and there will be many lessons to learn about modern agricultural practice.

The first and most obvious is to abolish the practice of feeding pigs waste food.

fields.headline: Countrytown blues
fields.standfirst: From the early days of the foot and mouth outbreaks Guardian Unlimited has been following developments in and around Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire as seen by a small panel of interviewees directly affected by the crisis. Here is the latest dispatch from the front line, by Derek Brown
fields.trailText: From the early days of the foot and mouth outbreaks Guardian Unlimited has been following developments in and around Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire as seen by a small panel of interviewees directly affected by the crisis. Here is the latest dispatch from the front line, by Derek Brown.
fields.body:
It is quiet, in the best and worst senses of the word. Quiet in the farmland around about, because foot and mouth has not arrived in our area.

Quiet in the town, because humans are not coming either. Chipping Norton, to be brutally frank, is not at the top of the must-see list for tourists and shoppers. It's a pretty little town; the sort of place that outsiders pass through and mentally note for a future visit.

More importantly, it's a market town, serving the needs of not just its 6,000-odd residents, but a much greater number in its natural hinterland of villages and hamlets.

They are still coming, though an indeterminable number are using the newish Tesco superstore at Stow, or else the slew of supermarkets in Banbury. It's the passing trade that has dried up, with potentially disastrous effects on local businesses.

The restaurateur

Roy Sparry, temporarily in charge of the Stones bar-restaurant in the town centre, had a half-way decent weekend. Half way, because although Saturday night and Sunday lunchtime saw a healthy Mother's Day trade, the rest of the time the place was barely ticking over. "It was just a blip, I'm afraid. I can't see it getting any better for a long while yet," said Roy.

The farmer

Mothering is also the theme at Mill Farm, Church Enstone, where Marilyn and Ted Ivings have a small herd of suckler cows, now going about their springtime business as usual.

Five calves have arrived so far, one of them sadly stillborn. It is a busy time, but also quiet in the sense that the farm has few visitors now and no deliveries. All supplies are being picked up from the local countryside farmers store by Marilyn and Ted.

The indomitably energetic Marilyn is exchanging a flurry of emails with the National Farmers' Union (NFU) and fellow farmers about ways to streamline and speed up the sclerotic system of inspection and slaughter that is supposed to contain the spread of foot and mouth.

"It's still taking around four days from the time they are diagnosed, to the time they are killed, and during that time the animals are still pumping out the virus. I know if I had infected animals next to my farm and they passed it on to my cattle, then ye gods! I would be jumping up and down. This is what's making me so cross," said Marilyn.

Another thing that gets Marilyn cross is the rising tide of imported meat in the supermarkets, some of it with the country of origin unmarked.

The supermarket manager

Tony Hatch, at the Co-op store in Chipping Norton, has had good news from headquarters: further supplies of British meat are on the way. Even now, a fair proportion of goods on his shelves are labelled as being home produced, though they share space with New Zealand lamb and European pork.

Most customers, he says, are less concerned about the source of the meat, than with its quality and price.

"Let's face it, most people buy with their eyes. Providing we are providing something which looks pleasing, they are happy," he said.

With prices and supplies stable, there is little evidence of changed buying patterns at the Co-op. "Things are moving along very smoothly," said Tony. "I am pleased that we are more than holding our heads up above the water. It's just a shame that so many people are suffering from this thing."

The butcher

John Kench the high street butcher, believes his customers are doing more than "buying with their eyes". All of his meat is British produced, and his windows are festooned with certificates of origin. A new notice proclaims that today's beef is from John's favourite supplier in the Orkneys.

"It's definitely busier than before this thing started. I'm sure I'm getting new customers now from the supermarkets. The quality aspect is far more important in people's minds, which suits me fine," he said.

Even now, a fair proportion of goods on his shelves are labelled as being home produced, though they share space with New Zealand lamb and European pork. Most customers, he says, are less concerned about the source of the meat, than with its quality and price. "Let's face it, most people buy with their eyes. Providing we are providing something which looks pleasing, they are happy," he said. With prices and supplies stable, there is little evidence of changed buying patterns at the Co-op. "Things are moving along very smoothly," said Tony. "I am pleased that we are more than holding our heads up above the water. It's just a shame that so many people are suffering from this thing." The butcher John Kench the high street butcher, believes his customers are doing more than "buying with their eyes". All of his meat is British produced, and his windows are festooned with certificates of origin. A new notice proclaims that today's beef is from John's favourite supplier in the Orkneys. "It's definitely busier than before this thing started. I'm sure I'm getting new customers now from the supermarkets. The quality aspect is far more important in people's minds, which suits me fine," he said. What's going on? fields.headline: ITV in the dock again
fields.trailText:
4pm: ITV has come under fire from the ITC for a second year running over the quality of its factual programming, writes Jessica Hodgson .

Mar 26: ITV loses audience share
Mar 26: Misleading adverts on the increase
Table: top 10 most complained about ads
fields.body:
ITV has come under fire from the ITC for a second year running over the quality of its factual programming.

And Channel 5 has been condemned once again for some of its late-night erotica which was branded unsuitable for anything other than a "non-specialist or non-adult channel".

In its annual performance review, the TV regulator said ITV "showed little evidence of improvement" following some damning criticisms made in the Annual Report for 1999.

The remarks are a sign that the regulatory body wishes to play hardball in the run-up to a government overhaul of the communications regulation infrastructure.

Last year's report chided ITV for "a narrowing range of subject matter in factual and a homogeneity in treatment, calling for greater distinctions between the different factual genres".

"2000 provided little evidence of improvement," said the ITC in a carefully worded report.

It said the main daytime shows, Trisha, This Morning, and Live Talk, "shared similar editorial interests".

And it was unhappy that the number of Real Lives documentaries had been reduced from 12 in 1999 to just seven in 2000.

ITV also received a slapped wrist over its approach to international coverage.

Tonight with Trevor McDonald was praised for its domestic news coverage and for "becoming well-established and familiar to viewers, with the potential to provide its regular mainstream audience with more strong and original popular journalism".

However, the ITC noted it "was much lighter on international affairs and some major foreign events were not covered such as the Israeli/Palestine conflict".

The remarks echo claims made last year that Tonight with Trevor McDonald "relies too heavily on celebrity interviews and lightweight social affairs issues".

And the ITC noted that only two documentaries - Paying the Price - the Killing of the Children of Iraq and Jonathan Dimbleby's Kosovo Journey - had been "ITV's only substantial documentary treatments of current international issue".

Other single-issue documentary programmes were singled out for praise such as Christie's Story, about the treatment of a clinically obese woman.

However, the ITC complained that too often the topics in these one-off documentaries were restricted to those similar to the main peaktime series - 'misbehaviour' of one kind or another, crime being a central preoccupation.

"ITV has proved it can deliver memorable documentary material and more landmarks in this genre would be welcome."

ITV also came under fire over This Morning, with the ITC noting that its "educational" slots were "overly preoccupied with leisure".

The ITC's annual report and accounts, with its annual performance review, comes on the eve of a major regulatory overhaul.

The ITC has been criticised in the past for failing to stand up to ITV over a perceived decline in quantity and quality of factual programming.

ITV has come under fire in the past two years for its decision to axe critically acclaimed current affairs programmes such as World in Action and First Tuesday.

However, the network was praised for its continuing drama successes.

"The ability of ITV to satisfy audience appetites for popular quality drama on a consistent basis is one of its greatest strengths," the ITC said.

And ITV bosses were complimented for their "willingness to innovate" in comedy with Barrymore's Bob Martin.

Channel 5, which was notoriously branded Channel Filth by the Daily Mail last summer, came under attack for its X Certificate adult sex films.

Channel 4 has been given fulsome praise for its programming but it was warned to keep separate accounts for any new services on the internet and in digital TV to ensure levels of investment in the station are sustained.

fields.headline: Channels urged to improve current affairs output
fields.trailText:
6.15pm: The ITC has highlighted current affairs as being a 'problem for many broadcasters', reports Jessica Hodgson.Mar 26: ITV in the dock again
Mar 26: ITV loses audience share
Mar 26: ITC backs new C4 services
Mar 26: Channel 5's year tainted by adult shows
Mar 26: GMTV complaints rise
Mar 26: Misleading adverts on the increase

fields.body:
The ITC admitted today British broadcasters have problems with current affairs after issuing ITV with a damning report on its factual programming.

Patricia Hodgson, the ITC's director of programmes, said: "The current affairs genre is problematic for many broadcasters."

The ITC added there was less "event" coverage of big issues on national television now more current affairs coverage was included under the "news" banner.

The ITC said broadcasters: "should not give up on current affairs".

But it added viewers "should recognise some of the burden should shift to news".

"All broadcasters are struggling with current affairs programmes," noted Ms Hodgson.

Her remarks come on the day ITV was criticised by the regulator for failing to provide enough international current affairs coverage.

Ms Hodgson admitted the ever-increasing competition for ratings in multi-channel television meant ITV had little incentive to screen international current affairs programmes.

"ITV gets good audiences for Tonight with Trevor McDonald - and these are much higher for domestic stories than international coverage," said Ms Hodgson.

Under new Ofcom rules, broadcasters must provide their own annual performance review along with promises for the coming year, and these will then be assessed by Ofcom.

webTitle: Two US fighter jets missing over Scottish Highlands

fields.headline: Two US fighter jets missing over Scottish Highlands
fields.trailText: Two US jet fighters went missing this afternoon over a mountain range in Scotland, police said.
fields.body:
Two US jet fighters went missing this afternoon over a mountain range in Scotland, police said.

The F-15 aircraft, which can carry two crew members each, were on a training flight from the US airbase at Lakenheath, Suffolk, when contact with the pilots was lost over the Cairngorm Mountains in the Scottish Highlands, said a spokesman for the Grampian force. They last made radio contact at 1.15pm.

A US air force spokeswoman said: "We can confirm there are two planes missing following training operations over Scotland."

Several police forces were notified by the American air force that the planes were "overdue".

A Grampian police spokeswoman said: "We have been notified that the planes are overdue. The Cairngorm area has been mentioned, but we have had no reports of any planes coming down."

The RAF has sent two Nimrods from RAF Kinloss and three Sea King helicopters - two from RAF Lossiemouth and one from RAF Boulmer - to search for the missing American jets, said an RAF spokeswoman.

They were joined by two RAF mountain rescue teams, from Kinloss and Leuchars, and the Braemar Mountain rescue team.

The RAF said the missing aircraft left RAF Lakenheath at around 12.30pm for a three-hour sortie in the Scottish Highlands.

webTitle: AUT attacks Tory plans for university funding

fields.headline: AUT attacks Tory plans for university funding
fields.trailText: Conservative plans to privatise universities by giving them endowments would cost almost £90bn, the Association of University Teachers said today.
fields.body:
Conservative plans to privatise universities by giving them endowments would cost almost £90bn, the Association of University Teachers said today.

David Triesman, the general secretary of the AUT, said the Tory figures for a massive one-off investment to free universities from dependence on state funding did not add up.

"The true cost of giving universities endowments to bring in enough income to match their present funding for teaching and research would be more than £89bn," said Mr Triesman.

"If this plan is serious Ð that a Conservative government contemplates spending the equivalent of opening over 2000 new hospitals or, indeed about 270 new universities Ð that is remarkable enough. The notion that you can start the job with £3.5bn and top up with sums from the sale of student debt is breathtaking. Either the policy meant nothing or the sums have been studiously ignored."

Launching their election manifesto, the lecturersÕ union appealed to the next government to increase spending on higher education by £1.8bn a year to the level of leading European countries.

Mr Triesman also asked for cuts in red tape and disproportionate bureaucracy, saying it would save nearly £300m in direct and indirect costs and release over 20% of academic time for research, scholarship and teaching.

The government should also establish a commission to see how academic freedom could be strengthened and extended across all universities and to government scientists, he added.

webTitle: Trials seek to counter resistant HIV virus

fields.headline: Trials seek to counter resistant HIV virus
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The UK is to take part in an international trial to find how to combat a possible resurgence of Aids in the west, as resistance grows to the drugs given people who are HIV-positive.
fields.body:
The UK is to take part in an international trial to find how to combat a possible resurgence of Aids in the west, as resistance grows to the drugs given people who are HIV-positive.

While HIV/Aids spreads across Africa, complacency has grown in the US and Europe because of the powerful if expensive medicines that are readily available.

But anti-retroviral drugs only suppress the virus; they cannot destroy it or prevent others getting it. Because the virus is prone to mutate, its resistance to some of the drugs used has steadily grown. If patients do not rigidly comply with the treatment, taking exact doses at precise times and sticking to dietary regimes, the virus mutates, the treatment fails, and the patient may become sick.

A combination of three drugs, known as highly active anti-retroviral therapy or Haart, is the norm. But with growing resistance to the drugs in the west, a major trial called Optima (options in management with anti-retrovirals) is to start in the UK, the US and Canada. It will test w hether using a cocktail of five or more drugs is an improvement on three. It will further examine whether there is any benefit in taking a three month total break from medication, to allow recovery from side effects and see whether the virus resumes responding to the original drugs.

There are an estimated 30,000 people infected with HIV in the UK; each year 2,500 more become HIV positive. Worryingly, it is thought that between a tenth and a quarter of the latter are being infected with a drug-resistant form.

"People are getting resistant virus from day one," said Mike Youle, director of HIV clinical research at the Royal Free centre for HIV medicine in London, who will be one of the investigators in the trial. "I've had four in the last two weeks. Lads turn up on my doorstep thinking [the Aids crisis] is all over and they don't have to worry about HIV, and they are inheriting resistant virus."

Very few now develop drug resistant HIV by not taking drugs properly. "In the last year or so, things have become better in terms of being able to take fewer pills and easier dietary requirements." But there was an atmosphere of denial over drug resistance.

"We are very much in the situation with resistant strains that we were with HIV in 1991-92, when everybody said it was in America but not here," said Dr Youle. "Because it is not in our face constantly that people are ill and dying, there is a belief the treatment will last forever and there is no risk to the individual from catching HIV. We are in a honeymoon period and I believe it is an extended honeymoon period. What I'm concerned about is that people will acquire resistant virus.

"There may be people - and we are already seeing cases of young people with multi-drug resistant virus - coming to us sick and not able to respond to standard combination therapy. It is not something we can deal with effectively now."

Dr Youle's unit is funded by the medical research council, which is running the UK end of Optima. Beginning in June, 1,700 patients will be recruited to the trial, including 400 from the UK.

The difficulties of ensuring people get and take anti-retroviral drugs properly so that drug-resistant virus does not spread has been one argument advanced against provision of cheap Aids medicines in Africa. But simpler forms of the drugs, including pills combining more than one drug in a single dose, are becoming available. With the advent of ever larger combinations of more powerful drugs in the west, the moral pressure on pharmaceutical companies and western governments to get at least basic medication to some of the millions who are dying in Africa will become stronger.

Last week, the World Health Organisation and Unaids - the United Nations organisation fighting the epidemic - met Cipla, the Indian company that manufactures generics (cheap copies of patented drugs). They discussed Cipla's offer to provide a three-drug combination to developing countries at £400 a year per patient (or £230 to volunteer doctors of Médecins Sans Frontières). The same combination would cost £7,000 to £10,000 in the west.

The UN will consider whether to give the offer its approval. Although Merck and Bristol Myers Squibb have dropped prices of brand-name drugs to what they say is cost price or lower, they have not yet matched Cipla.

webTitle: Inquiry urged on fuel plant gases

fields.headline: Inquiry urged on fuel plant gases
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A leading scientist has called for an inquiry into emissions from an oil refinery and a power plant, claiming they could be responsible for cancer, heart attacks and strokes among thousands of Scots.
fields.body:
A leading scientist has called for an inquiry into emissions from an oil refinery and a power plant, claiming they could be responsible for cancer, heart attacks and strokes among thousands of Scots.

Dick van Steenis said he has pinpointed a corridor of sickness between the giant BP Amoco refinery at Grangemouth and the Kilroot power station in Ulster.

Following his own investigations, he believes the effect of pollution from the two plants could be "devastating" within a 44-mile radius.

Representatives for both plants say they have a clean track record when it comes to pollution and comply with legislation on emissions.

Dr van Steenis, who has advised the House of Lords select committee on pollution, said he had mapped the pattern of emissions from the two plants which, he said, carry dangerous chemical particles across a wide area.

"If you look at a map of the patterns followed by plumes from these places it becomes abundantly clear that there's a problem," he said.

"The two plants could be responsible for the bulk of cancer cases in the areas they pollute. Cancer patterns can be di rectly linked to these plants and the line you can draw between them.

"Where the pollution grounds you are always going to have death and illness and in this case that means most of central Scotland."

Dr van Steenis said poor diet and lifestyle were not enough to account for Scotland's appalling record of ill health and the plant emissions might explain health anomalies like a higher than normal incidence of prostate cancer in East Lothian and Glasgow's poor mortality rate.

A spokesman for BP Grangemouth said the company had an open dialogue on issues such as pollution and a clean track record. He said a 10-year air monitoring programme had found nothing dangerous, and the plumes emitting from the refinery were water vapour.

A spokesman for Applied Electricity Services, which runs the Kilroot plant, said: "For environmental emissions from the plant, we have to comply with legislative limits. The plant operates well within these limits and our performance record is readily available in the public domain."

A Scottish executive spokesman said it would study Dr van Steenis's concerns carefully.

webTitle: Cambridge claw home at second attempt

fields.headline: Cambridge claw home at second attempt
fields.standfirst:
Quick-thinking umpire makes history by ordering crews to start again

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: This was the 147th University Boat Race but the very first to require a restart. The opening effort was halted abruptly after a minute on Saturday, when a clash brought Cambridge to a standstill as Oxford were being warned by the race's umpire, Rupert Obholzer. His decision to stop the race was an astute one.
fields.body:
This was the 147th University Boat Race but the very first to require a restart. The opening effort was halted abruptly after a minute on Saturday, when a clash brought Cambridge to a standstill as Oxford were being warned by the race's umpire, Rupert Obholzer. His decision to stop the race was an astute one.

The rerun was a similarly tough, scrappy tussle, in which the light blues clawed back Oxford's slight advantage and locked the door as the crews passed under Hammersmith bridge. In the words of Harry Mahon, Cambridge's finishing coach, it was "a winning row rather than a picture-book performance".

Earlier, Cambridge had won the toss and, perhaps surprisingly, chosen the Surrey station in full conditions where a short-cut on the Middlesex station might have been more advantageous.

Obholzer warned the Cambridge cox Christian Cormack twice as clashing began at the start of the race. However, he then observed Oxford moving further towards Cambridge than they should have under the agreement made with both coxes to steer off the traditional "centre of the tide", even in these flood conditions that rendered the tide practically absent.

Obholzer, who rowed for Oxford in 1990-91, said: "As the words escaped my mouth, I noticed the Cambridge bow-man losing his blade. Oxford got a significant advantage out of that."

The umpire raised his red flag and stopped the race. His options then were to allow Cambridge to sort themselves out and race to the end, to disqualify Oxford there and then, or to restart the race with the crews level.

The first option risked an appeal from Cambridge, which would have resulted in Oxford being disqualified anyway. Nor did Obholzer want to disqualify a crew so early in the race, and thus become the first umpire in the race's history to order a disqualification.

There was another clash soon after the second start, Cambridge receiving two warnings and Oxford four before the mile post was reached. Oxford again led by a couple of seats, but approaching Harrods Depository, Cambridge made a big push and took a half length lead with the prospect of the long Surrey bend in their favour. The stroke Tim Wooge suddenly found his stride while Oxford crouched over their oars, seemingly tight with tension.

Cormack squeezed another half length by deft steering coming out of Hammersmith bridge. Oxford's cox Jeremy Moncrieff crossed to the inside of the bend, and Cormack countered with a move that put Oxford in Cambridge's wash. This went on for some time, with Oxford grimly and untidily hanging on and refusing to allow the light blues to lower their rating.

From Chiswick there was no tide at all from which to take advantage, and both crews hugged the Middlesex bank past Dukes Meadows. They ventured out to pass through the centre arch of Barnes bridge, only to return to the side for the finish. Cambridge had more than three lengths' lead at the Meadows but the dark blues pulled it back to just over two at the finish, where Cambridge joyfully celebrated their recovery of the trophy lost last year.

Sean Bowden, the Oxford coach, thought the umpire's decision to restart the crews level and nullify his team's early advantage was harsh, but he was full of praise for the way Cambridge rowed.

Cambridge's chief coach Robin Williams paid tribute to "a race full of drama and fight. That's what match racing is about - taking blows, giving blows, it was astonishing. Rupert Obholzer made a very quick decision to raise his flag and restart it. We had dropped out a length which we didn't deserve in that clash."

Cormack also praised the umpire. "Rupert had the most difficult job out there and I think he did exactly the right thing. I don't think a disqualification at that point would have helped anyone." The score since 1829 is now Cambridge 77, Oxford 69, with one dead heat.

Boat Race times (Cambridge first, from restart) : Mile post: 2min43.20sec, 2.43; Hammersmith Bridge: 6.04, 6.06; Chiswick Steps: 10.17, 10.23. Barnes Bridge: 14.26, 14.33. Finish: 17.44, 17.51; margin 2 lengths.

webTitle: National Union of Students conference opens - in the red

fields.headline: National Union of Students conference opens - in the red
fields.trailText: The revelation that the National Union of Students is £300,000 overdrawn - nearly 10 per cent of its annual budget - has prompted accusations of financial mismanagement on the first day of its national conference in Blackpool.
fields.body:
The revelation that the National Union of Students is £300,000 overdrawn - nearly 10 per cent of its annual budget - has prompted accusations of financial mismanagement on the first day of its national conference in Blackpool.

The head of NUS finance, Helen Aspell says the claims are political, intended to prevent her being elected president on a leftwing platform and that students have nothing to be concerned about.

The current president, Owain James, said there was no impropriety and the union had unusually large strains on its finances, but laid the blame for the deficit firmly with Miss Aspell, saying he only recently became aware of it.

"I didn't want to make an election issue out of this, but there's a problem with our finances. There's been a lot of increased spending on the liberation movement, but I think more could have been done earlier to avoid our current problem," said Mr James.

Miss Aspell said the overdraft was the result of a cash flow problem and would not exist by the end of the financial year, which for the NUS ends in June.

"More student unions are paying fees in instalments which puts our cash flow in a more volatile position. We do have a problem, we have not raised the affiliation fee for eight years and cannot survive for the ninth, so we have had to raise the affiliation fee.

The decision not to discuss a proposed full-time black students officer post until late on Wednesday has provoked anger among supporters of the move.

Denis Fernando, the current part-time holder called it a "slap in the face for black students" which sent out the a terrible message. "When the murdered Ricky Reel's mother told me how upset she is students didn't do more, I just thought there wasn't enough I could do part-time."

Carli Harper, University College London's welfare officer, running to be NUS' vice president welfare at this year's conference, said it was a disgrace. "The creation of a full time black student officer should have been at the start of the conference, but a NUS committee passed on the motion late and so instead it's only being discussed late Wednesday."

The executive member most involved with the application, Ben Monks, was criticised when the motion became an amendment, but thinks any damage will be overcome if the proposal is passed.

"There were accusations levelled at me personally, but the issue is going to be discussed at conference and it should be a right humdinger. The NUS has a policy to create a full time black students member of the executive and I think conference will agree with that," he said.

webTitle: Cudgels taken up over Bayeux Tapestry replica

fields.headline: Cudgels taken up over Bayeux Tapestry replica
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Over 900 years after the bloody events portrayed, a new battle is rumbling over a unique copy of the Bayeux Tapestry. Leek in Staffordshire made it, Reading in Berkshire has it, and Leek wants it back.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Over 900 years after the bloody events portrayed, a new battle is rumbling over a unique copy of the Bayeux Tapestry. Leek in Staffordshire made it, Reading in Berkshire has it, and Leek wants it back.

"This is our equivalent of the Elgin Marbles" a Leek councillor, Sybil Ralph, said, of the 230 feet of Norman propaganda which the town's needlewomen laboured over in 1885, but which since 1895 has been the pride of Reading.

"Reading museum service is proud to have cared for the only full-size copy of the Bayeux Tapestry in the world for over 100 years," said Jon Hartley, of Reading cultural services. "The tapestry is beautifully displayed in its 70 metre entirety in the free Museum of Reading, and is hugely popular with general visitors and school groups."

The Leek-Reading tapestry is a near replica - but Victorian modesty defeated historical accuracy. When it came to the little naked figures among the wounded and dead in the borders of the scenes of the Battle of Hastings, the ladies of the Leek Embroidery Society felt obliged to give them woollen shorts. The original was made so close to the Battle of Hastings in 1066, probably within a decade, that it may have been based on eyewitness accounts.

Legend said it was made by William the Conquerer's queen, Matilda, but historians believe it was probably commissioned by his half-brother, Odo, for his new cathedral at Bayeux, possibly from nuns at Canterbury or Winchester who were noted for needlework.

It was included in an inventory of the Bayeux cathedral treasures in 1476. In the French revolution it was taken out and used to cover a wagon load of ammunition, but rescued by a local lawyer, who gave the rebels a waterproof canvas cover in return. For most of the last two centuries it has been on display in the bishop's palace in Bayeux, apart from a trip to Paris with the Nazis, which may have protected it from the bombardment of the town just a few miles inland from the Normandy beaches.

The replica had an equally eventful life. It was the brainchild of Elizabeth Wardle, wife of a Staffordshire silk millionaire, Thomas Stafford, who founded the embroidery society using his silks to make goods sold at his shop in Bond Street. She was inspired by a set of full scale photographs of the original at the Victoria and Albert, took tracings, and recruited a team of 35 women, who made the replica in a year.

It was displayed to huge crowds all over England, and toured to Germany and the US. But by 1895, when the tour reached Reading, the committee seems to have been running out of steam and money, and was glad to sell it for £300 to Arthur Hill, mayor of Reading. It was one of the first exhibits in the town's new art gallery and public museum.

Mr Hartley said that as far as he is concerned it has found its final home."We answer inquiries from all over the world, including many from people in Leek," he said, adding that its Staffordshire roots are acknowledged.

In Leek, Sylvia Ralph, a member of Moorland district council, accepted the sale was valid, but described it as "misguided". Morally, she said, it belonged to Leek. Failing permanent repatriation, the town hopes to borrow it back for the reopening this summer of the refurbished Nicholson Institute. Reading Museum said that no formal application had been received.

webTitle: Laboratory cells could help restore hearing

fields.headline: Laboratory cells could help restore hearing
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Future deafness could be checked - or hearing restored - by transplants of ear cells grown in the laboratory, a London conference will be told today.
fields.body:
Future deafness could be checked - or hearing restored - by transplants of ear cells grown in the laboratory, a London conference will be told today.

Matthew Holley, professor of sensory physiology at the University of Sheffield, has used embryo tissue to culture the cells of the inner ear that convert sound into signals which can be transmitted to the brain. So far, the research has only been conducted with mice embryo cells.

Professor Holley has experimented with an "immortal" line of mouse embryo cells to deliver both sensory and non-sensory ear cells. Sound enters the ear, and is transmitted first through three tiny bones to the inner ear. Thousands of tiny hair cells, lined up in the inner ear like a piano stringboard, begin to move according to the frequency of the sound and send messages to the brain along the cochlear nerve: this is the first stage of hearing.

"The sensory hair cells convert sound into nerve signals. The nerve cells then take those signals to the brain. We would like to make both of those," he said. "We are convinced that we have managed to instruct the formation of hair cells."

He will tell a national conference on genetics and deafness, organised by the charity Defeating Deafness, that he and colleagues have yet to transplant the cultured cells to mice, and human trials could be years away. But cell transplants could be used in tandem with cochlear implants - tiny electrodes in the inner ear.

webTitle: Adventure seekers 'run risk of being kidnapped'

fields.headline: Adventure seekers 'run risk of being kidnapped'
fields.trailText: Tourism to dangerous regions continues to grow, but people lack the knowledge they need to be able to protect themselves.
fields.body:
Adventurous Britons travelling abroad risk being kidnapped because they are unprepared for the inherent dangers, according to a report due out today from independent thinktank the Foreign Policy Centre. Tourism to dangerous regions continues to grow, but people lack the knowledge they need to be able to protect themselves.

Backpackers in hot spots often fail to realise they are targets, according to the study, called The Kidnapping Business. It is no longer only diplomats and employees of multinational companies who were in jeopardy.

The report comes just days after the release of a British engineer who was kidnapped and held captive for a month by guerrillas in Bangladesh. Tim Selby, 28, from Jesmond, Newcastle, was kidnapped along with two colleagues while working on a road project for Danish company Kampsax.

The rise of gap-year travelling and adventure tourism has led to a 15% increase in visits to remote and unstable regions, the report says. More companies are also sending employees to dangerous regions.

Confusion also remains over who is responsible for the safety of Britons abroad, as there are no clear rules on where the responsibilities of employers, governments and individuals end. The report therefore sets out a series of recommendations for reducing risks.

webTitle: Heads wary of Tory plan for slow pupils

fields.headline: Heads wary of Tory plan for slow pupils
fields.standfirst:
Stress on basic maths and English 'misconceived'

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Conservative plans to allow youngsters who fall behind in the "basics" of English and mathematics to skip other subjects in order to catch up were yesterday given a cool response by headteachers.
fields.body:
Conservative plans to allow youngsters who fall behind in the "basics" of English and mathematics to skip other subjects in order to catch up were yesterday given a cool response by headteachers.

In a speech in which he fleshed out the education policies to feature in the Tories' election manifesto, party leader William Hague accused Labour of treating teachers like "recalcitrant incompetents" and said it was time to stop the "bullying" they had suffered under Labour.

As well as setting out details of how schools could simplify use of the national curriculum, Mr Hague reiterated Tory plans to allow every state school to become a "free school", receiving its funding direct from government and deciding how to spend it.

Mr Hague told the annual conference of the Secondary Heads Association (SHA) in Newport, south Wales, it was wrong to force the youngsters to do the rest of the national curriculum while they were struggling with the basics.

Mr Hague said: "It is crazy ... that pupils who are struggling to read, write and add up are forced by the national curriculum to move on to other lessons, when the teachers who know them best think that it would be most useful to consolidate their literacy.

"That is why we would allow schools to exempt children who have not yet reached basic standards of literacy and numeracy from other requirements of the national curriculum, at least until they have caught up."

He said it was extraordinary that a government which had put education at the top of its priorities should have helped to create the worst teacher shortages and recruitment in recent memory.

John Dunford, general secretary of the SHA, criticised Mr Hague's proposed curricu lum cuts for lower achievers. He said: "I think that is a misunderstanding of the nature of secondary education. I would not want them to be denied the richness and breadth of all the national curriculum subjects, particularly up to the age of 14."

Other delegates at the conference agreed that it was important that youngsters were given variety, rather than being force-fed a limited range of subjects.

Education secretary David Blunkett attacked Mr Hague's "half-baked, ill-considered proposals", saying they would leave another generation of youngsters on the scrapheap.

 Seven out of 10 students in the first year of sixth form are taking four AS levels and 55% are taking new key skills qualifications, according to a survey by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service. Ministers said the poll showed students were responding to the new, broader-based post-16 qualifications.

fields.headline: John Sutherland
fields.standfirst: From the land of pestilence to dark California: the horsemen of the Apocalypse are on the gallop
fields.trailText: From the land of pestilence to dark California: the horsemen of the Apocalypse are on the gallop.
fields.body:
I'm off to California next week, for my annual semester in the sun. It's a source of some friction between me and my colleagues. I'll be waxing my surfboard under the palms while they are still wondering whether to cast their winter clouts. Not to mention the dollars.

This year the Golden State is less inviting than usual. First, the good news. The story, flashing round the world's newswires, that travellers from the UK ("Unclean! Unclean!") are required to take off their shoes and dump them in baths of Clorox turns out to be Channel 7 ("Eyewitless News") hype, my friends over there tell me. Urban legend. Brits need not wade barefoot through sheepdip to get into God's country.

Now the bad news. Pasadena (where I teach) suffered its first "rolling blackout" (a "stage-three alert") last week, along with a 90C heatwave. The mercury went up, the air conditioners went down. It is ominous. Sacramento warns that the state must expect an energy crisis "affecting both gas and electricity, for possibly as long as four years". The future is dark and sweaty.

Californians were expecting a crunch. But when it came, they were all looking the wrong way. Living (on borrowed water) in arid desert, on the San Andreas fault, and dependent entirely on the automobile, they were braced for drought, the big one, or gasoline price hikes. No one anticipated having to eat supper by candlelight two nights a week until 2005.

The official explanation for the crisis is paralysingly technical: all to do with the break-up of the old monopoly supplier, SoCal-Ed, regulation, and the environmentalists' well-meaning campaign to block nuclear power after the Three Mile Island scare in 1979, when a reactor was close to meltdown.

The real reason is simpler. It's not an energy shortage: it's a people surplus. Surplus people with surplus cash to burn. America has enjoyed an unprecedented 12 years of boom. California, home to Silicon Valley, has crested the wave, sucking in immigrants. Millions of Americans (led by pointy-headed computer nerds) have come west to strike it rich. California's infrastructure is creaking under the weight of new, rich, free-spending Californians.

For the 1984 Olympics, Los Angeles built a state-of-the-art airport. LAX has seven double-decked terminals, each with its huge parking structure.

It used to be a joy to use. You could cruise down the new Century Freeway (it starred, you'll recall, with Keanu Reeves in the movie, Speed) and park 50 yards from the arrival lounge. No problem.

The last time I drove to LAX, I had to stop-start round the airport circuit for two hours before I could find a parking space. As it happened, the plane I was aiming for was also stacked up, waiting for a runway. It's still the best designed airport in the world, but sclerotic with too many passengers and too much traffic. The solution's on the bumper sticker of the car stuck in front of you: "Leave California: and take a friend with you."

The problem with London's underground is not lack of investment or the desperate need for an American tsar's know-how. It's too many Londoners. And, on the principle that what happens in America happens here two years later, don't think we'll escape power cuts. And after that, what?

You don't have to be an economist to work it out. It's quarts and pint pots. You have economies growing at 4% a year. Consumption always outstrips investment in infrastructure. Prosperity is great - but not when everyone's prosperous. The "leave London (or wherever) and take a friend with you" solution won't work. The empty spaces of the world are already crammed full.

Two weeks ago, a dry bulletin from the World Health Organisation projected that at present rates of growth, the world's population will reach 11bn by 2050. By then, commuters will be booking their morning seats on the Central line six weeks ahead of time.

Planet earth cannot sustain twice as many people, with 10 times the spending power. We all know that. We also know (at the back of our minds) what's coming. A cataclysmic slump which will siphon all our money away, and some great Malthusian check which will siphon us away: war, famine or plague.

Which is why headlines at the moment are dominated by two stories: Wall Street's woes and foot and mouth. Two images prophesy the future. The big board plunging below 10,000 into free fall and those pyres of burning animal flesh.

With which happy thoughts, California here I come (where's my flashlight?).

fields.headline: Morecambe and Wise give BBC1 ratings sunshine
fields.trailText: A Morecambe and Wise repeat and an Antiques Road Show repeat proved the best performers of BBC1's peaktime line-up yesterday, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A Morecambe and Wise repeat and an episode of the Antiques Road Show proved the best performers of BBC1's peaktime line-up yesterday, a sign that Sunday nights on BBC1 are going from bad to worse.

The concluding episode of the ambitious John Cleese documentary the Human Face pulled in just 3.9m viewers, less than half the 10.1m notched up by London's Burning in the same slot on ITV.

And the BBC's decision to axe whimsical Irish drama Ballykissangel was vindicated when the show attracted just 4.4m viewers to give it an 18% share.

ITV achieved a landslide victory in the Sunday evening ratings with its line-up of soap and popular drama.

Both Coronation Street and police drama Heartbeat pulled in 12.7m viewers to give ITV well over 50% of the viewing between 7.30 and 9pm.

But Saturday evening proved more successful for the BBC. The National Lottery broadcast at 7.40pm helped BBC1 get off to a successful start by pulling in 8.4m viewers to take a 38% share of the viewing.

The BBC lost its lead to ITV during Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on ITV at 8.15pm, but regained it at 9.10pm as viewers returned to experience the twin delights of veteran actor Sir John Mills and 70s pop stars the Bee Gees on Parkinson.

Elsewhere the last of BBC2's I Love the Eighties series pulled in an impressive 3.4m viewers, showing that there's still a place in the nation's hearts for soft rock and stonewashed jeans.

fields.headline: Italians eye Mirror internet
fields.trailText: The Mirror's internet service ic24 could be sold to the Italian firm Tiscali, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror has been approached by Tiscali, the pan-European internet service provider with a view to buying ic24.

A spokeswoman confirmed that "several offers" including one from the Italian firm have been made by prospective buyers, since it put ic2 up for sale.

Analysts estimate ic24, with its subscription base of around 250,000 users, would fetch around £25m for Trinity Mirror.

The media group put its Internet Service Provider on the market earlier this month in a bid to shed non-core businesses.

The move lead to 60 redundancies from the Trinity Mirror Digital arm on 15 March, and the departure of ic24 managing director David Clarke last week.

The fate of the remaining 240 remains uncertain until 15 April, when an announcement is expected.

Reports suggest Tiscali is about to embark on a ISP buying spree in the UK, with the hope of building on the minuscule audience it inherited after it acquired pan-European provider World Online last summer and French outfit Liberty Surf in January.

The giant is said to have its eyes on LineOne, put up for sale late last year by joint owners BT and United Business Media. It is also suggested it is interested in Excite UK, jointly owned by BT and US website Excite.

Tiscali bought a 70% stake in Excite Italia last month.
