fields.headline: ITC backs new C4 services
fields.trailText: The ITC said it supported Channel 4's move to launch new services so long as they were costed and accounted for separately, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission said it supported Channel 4's move to launch new services, so long as they were costed and accounted for separately.

"If successful, they will strengthen the core channel, add value for viewers and build assets for the future," the ITC said.

"It will be important, however, to sustain Channel 4's distinctive remit and the level of investment supporting it.

"In particular, separate accounts are important and safeguards to ensure that the costs of new services are clearly identified and borne by them."

Overall, the regulator praised Channel 4 for building its audience year-on-year from 10.3% to 10.5%, and also "delivering its remit for programmes that are diverse and distinctive".

Drama Longitude and documentary Elisabeth were singled out in particular for recording "some of the highest indices of audience appreciation on Channel 4".

On Big Brother, the ITC said: "Opinions may vary on whether this reality TV format was exploitative or merely good fun. No serious complaints were received by the ITC, and none from participants."

The number of breaches of the ITC programme code by Channel 4 rose from six in 1999 to 11 last year.

Two involved unfairness to individuals in entertainment shows that, if repeated, would require sanctions to be considered, the ITC said.

fields.headline: Channel 5's year tainted by adult shows
fields.trailText:
Channel 5 has been criticised again by the ITC for breaching its programme code with 'unsuitable' adult programmes, writes Jessica Hodgson
Mar 26: ITV in the dock again
Mar 26: ITV loses audience share
Mar 26: Misleading adverts on the increase
Table: top 10 complained about ads
fields.body:
Channel 5 was slapped down again by the ITC in its annual performance review for breaching its programme code with "unsuitable" adult programmes.

And the channel was warned that the rise of programme code breaches must not continue.

Channel 5 received five interventions from the ITC in respect of three programmes, a rise of two on last year.

The ITC warned that "Channel 5 must take care that this upward trend does not continue".

The regulator singled out the late night series X Certificate, which was judged to have included inappropriate images from "pornographic" films.

Dark Knight, Family Confidential and Movie Chart Show, were among shows deemed unsuitable for screening before the watershed.

However, the ITC noted that Naked Jungle in particular had provoked more "press comment" than actual programme complaints.

It also observed that Channel 5 had addressed the watchdog's concerns about a concentration of adult programming in the late evening after consultation with the regulator during the year.

But the ITC added that it was still not entirely happy with the broadcaster's factual programming.

"A return to too much late night 'adult' programming was arrested but factual programming at times concentrated unduly on human interest, disasters and dysfunctional behaviour," it said.

The ITC noted an example of "undue prominence" of Holsten Pils in an edition of a drama, Headless, in which very clear branding was visible.

A spokesman said: "These news themes dominate the agenda of national newspapers and it seems odd that we are criticised for reflecting this.

"In terms of adult programming, the ITC is referring to a small period in the channel's history. The channel and our audience have moved on since then. Unfortunately the ITC hasn't."

webTitle: Dozens killed in Kenyan school blaze

fields.headline: Dozens killed in Kenyan school blaze
fields.trailText: A murder investigation was under way in Kenya today after 58 pupils died and another 28 were injured in a fire in a school building.
fields.body:
A murder investigation was under way in Kenya today after 58 pupils died and another 28 were injured in a fire in a school building.

Detectives said they suspected arson by students to be the cause of the fire that swept through a crowded school dormitory early this morning.

"We have a strong suspicion of arson. There was a smell of petrol yesterday," police spokesman Peter Kimanthi said outside the charred walls of one of two dormitories at Kyanguli secondary school near Machakos, a farming town 30 miles southeast of the capital, Nairobi.

There were unconfirmed reports that a student was seen running from the dormitory shortly before the fire broke out.

President Daniel arap Moi, a former primary school teacher, emerged visibly shaken after a visit to the ruined dormitory where Mr Kimanthi said 130 boys between the ages of 15 and 19 had been sleeping. Several piles of bodies could be seen inside the building.

"This is a ghastly incident that has never been seen in these parts before. The doors should have been open. These children could have escaped easily," he said, adding that he had ordered a thorough investigation into the causes of the fire. Mr Kimanthi said officials at the provincial secondary school for boys smelled gasoline in the dormitory yesterday but, having checked it, found nothing. He said a police forensics team would investigate.

Mackenzie Waema, 19, a student who was sleeping in the second dormitory about 330 feet away, said gasoline had been spread throughout the other building, and it was burning in the centre of the dormitory when he was awoken by screams and pounding noises.

Looking through the building's 10 windows, all of which were covered by iron bars that prevented escape, reporters counted 48 bunk beds. No school officials were available to comment how 96 beds could accommodate 130 boys.

Mr Waema said one of the dormitory's two doors was always kept open; the other was padlocked. Those who managed to escape from the fire did so through the open door. The flames in the middle of the building prevented those at the end with the locked door from getting to the open exit.

Mr Waema said: "There was a misunderstanding between the administration and the students. They [the students] had grudges. Some of the students don't have good relations with the teachers. That could have brought this calamity."

Peter Wanyoro said his son - who suffered burns over 90% of his body - had told him that the students had been planning to march to the district education office in Machakos on Friday to protest against conditions at the school, but teachers and school guards stopped them.

"I don't know if this is the reason why they were burned. Boys who survived said some of their colleagues went to the dormitory with petrol in small jerry cans," he said.

fields.headline: Sharp rise in GMTV complaints
fields.trailText: The number of complaints by viewers about GMTV almost doubled in 2000, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The number of complaints by viewers to the ITC about GMTV almost doubled in 2000 to 420, with impartiality complaints rising to 197 from just two the previous year.

A number of these complaints about impartiality related to "political interviews about the fuel and rail crises".

But the ITC concluded: "This may well be a reflection of GMTV's more rigorous style of interviewing key political figures from the government and opposition."

The ITC did not identify any breaches of its programme code.

More generally, GMTV maintained a high level of quality and authority in its service, according to the ITC.

It reported live from around the country during autumn flood and fuel crises; while big international stories covered live on location included the Concorde crash, Mozambique floods and the plight of the trapped Russian submariners.

The introduction of GMTV Cafe summer programme with co-presenter Donna Bernard, and children's event Diggit Beach Tour were also praised.

fields.headline: ITV loses audience share
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: ITV is losing its grip on the terrestrial TV market because of the growth in multi-channel television, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITV is losing its grip on the terrestrial TV market because of the growth in multi-channel television.

The network's total share of the audience, including digital homes, fell from 31.2% in 1999 to 29.3% last year.

Peaktime share also fell from 36.9% to 35.3% after a poor performance in the first half of the year, although an increase in popular programming spurred a recovery in the autumn.

But the stand-out statistic was ITV's audience share in digital homes, which was 19% - a stark contrast to its overall audience.

The digital figure underlines the importance of ITV's recent deal with Luxembourg-based Societe Europenne des Satellites.

SES will broadcast ITV's programmes on a digital satellite platform, immediately boosting the digital reach and potential audience.

Because ITV is not available on the digital platform outside ONdigital, viewers had been loath to switch from Sky Movies or the Discovery Channel to ITV on analogue.

A low digital viewing figure has also worried advertisers, coming at a time when the network is experiencing an outright recession in advertising revenue.

fields.headline: Shelley and Maconie tipped for Mirror job
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The race is on to replace Charlie Catchpole as the Mirror's TV critic and Jim Shelley and broadcaster Stuart Maconie are being tipped as front-runners. By Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express
fields.body:
Music journalist and broadcaster Stuart Maconie and Jim Shelley, the former Guardian Guide critic are believed to be in the frame to replace Charlie Catchpole as the Mirror's TV critic.

Mr Catchpole, one of Fleet Street's most respected TV columnists, has defected to the Daily Express and Mirror bosses have reportedly moved fast to find a replacement.

Mr Maconie, a former NME journalist, came to public acclaim when he co-presented a Radio 1 comedy programme with Andrew Collins.

He has become ubiquitous on modern music television as a pundit, with regular appearances on youth and lifestyle programming, and writes a column in the Times.

Mr Shelley, who created the Tapehead column in the Guardian Guide, now works as a freelance writer for a variety of newspapers and magazines, including the Mirror, the Mail on Sunday and James Brown's Hotdog. He writes soaphead once a month for the Guardian's guide.

It is believed both have been approached on an informal basis about the role, a key one on the Mirror.

But it is thought unlikely the new recruit will command the sort of wage that Mr Catchpole, a Fleet Street stalwart and former News of the World journalist, enjoyed.

Mirror insiders say the post, which is a key role on the paper, is likely to be filled in the next two weeks.

He writes soaphead once a month for the Guardian's guide. It is believed both have been approached on an informal basis about the role, a key one on the Mirror. But it is thought unlikely the new recruit will command the sort of wage that Mr Catchpole, a Fleet Street stalwart and former News of the World journalist, enjoyed. Mirror insiders say the post, which is a key role on the paper, is likely to be filled in the next two weeks. Related story Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express

fields.headline: Frottage,  Freeloading, and  Fuel
fields.trailText: WE SUPPOSE WE HAVE TO MENTION ENGLAND
fields.body:
WE SUPPOSE WE HAVE TO MENTION ENGLAND

What a successful weekend for England it was. As everyone expected, Sven-Goran Eriksson's team thrashed minnows Finland out of sight by two goals to one. Not only that, they broke the wrist of the opposition's best player into the bargain (Jari Litmanen is out for six weeks and will miss Liverpool's big games against Manchester United, Barcelona, Wycombe and, er, Everton). Well done lads! In fact, with the team purring louder than a kitten tucking into a big plate of Sheba directly after indulging in a spot of frottage, moves are being made to tie down Sven's backroom staff to ensure continued success.

Shoo-ins are Tord Grip (best mate), Ray Clemence (nothing better to do) and Dave Sexton (he won the FA Cup once over 30 years ago so he must know something). That leaves Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren. Taylor is likely to continue, because he's the big man at Leicester and can do what the hell he likes. But McClaren has a chippy Scotsman calling the shots at his club and, as the FA's agreement with United for his services runs out after the Albania game on Wednesday, needs his acquiescence if he is to continue in his role. Adam Crozier will meet Manchester United's Peter Kenyon at the end of the week to bag his man for the games against Mexico, Greece, Germany and Albania. And Greece.

Meanwhile, visitors to Albania will be forced to walk on wet carpet when they turn up for the World Cup qualifier. Initially, the Fiver thought this was the "backward" country's zany way of getting its own back for being patronised by people who haven't even been there whining on about the state of their economy. But, in fact, it's all to do with preventing the spread of foot and mouth instead. "They will all walk on disinfecting carpets and they will be searched for food," ministry spokesman Artur Galanxhi said. "They will not be allowed to take any food into Albania." That should give certain tabloid journalists an excuse to work some thinly veiled racism into their "articles", if nothing else.

BIG CUP BUSINESS AS USUAL

Beep! Beep! Everybody loves a free ride, which is why the Fiver is hot-wheeling it around town in a car which isn't, strictly speaking, our own. Why, what nasty scoundrels we are! But are we any worse than those cruel journalists who erroneously suggested that Leeds could be given a bye to the semi-finals of Big Cup? Of course not. And we'll mow down any sucker that says otherwise.

All too predictably, today came news that Deportivo La Coruna will not be kicked out of this season's competition - even if Emerson, Helder, Jacques Songo'o and Aldo Pedro Duscher are found guilty of passport irregularities. "If the investigation in Spain finds the players are ineligible then they will have to be removed from Deportivo's squad," thundered Uefa's Mike Lee, briefly raising Leeds' hopes of a bye into the semi-finals. And then, like a classy lap-dancer (yes, there is such a thing), he quickly deflated their expectations. "But there is no question of Deportivo being thrown out of the competition. The weekend news reports were simply inaccurate."

Uefa's decision means that Leeds's key stage-four (OK, quarter-final) Big Cup appointment with Deportivo will go ahead next Wednesday, much to the complete non-surprise of chairman Pious Peter Ridsdale. Today he attacked the weekend reports as "nonsense" before adding: "We want to get through to the semi-finals by winning against Deportivo. We're all geared up for the game now and we are preparing for the tie in the normal manner." Which the Fiver takes to mean a week of hard and rigorous training - and not a Mule and Bacardi Breezer-fuelled trip to the Majestyk.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I think one for Andy would be enough to set him on his way and I'm sure the whole country hopes he gets it. Eriksson should stick with the in-form strikers and I believe Cole has shown for Manchester United and in his build-up play that he is an in-form striker" - At last! After the hostile headlines, the Fiver finds an expert - Kerry Dixon (eight England caps, two goals) - to stick up for Andy Cole.

COURAGE BEST

It's a crucial time for poor old Georgie Best. According to his agent Phil "it up with booze" Hughes, the former Fulham, Hibernian and Bournemouth legend is back on the bottle. And after being recently treated for a serious liver complaint and warned to lay off the sauce for good, that's worrying news. Hughes claims Best was unmistakably tanked up during phone calls made last week, which is why the "worried sick" agent blew the lid on Bestie's soup shame in an admirable display of tough love.

"I'm worried sick!" Hughes said over the weekend in an admirable display of tough love. Best, who was to have provided commentary for the BBC on Northern Ireland's World Cup game against the Czech Republic but pulled out citing continued ill health, was later spotted on "a triple bender" in pubs in Ballyhalbert and Donaghadee on the (drunk)Ards peninsula. Some reports even suggested that Best, the best player you never saw who wasn't Robin Friday, was even prepared to face death rather than give up the ale.

But luckily, it seems these reports are a touch sensational. George has indeed been out on a massive session, but there is more optimistic news. "George is not a stupid man. He will stop drinking. He has to - and he knows it," Hughes explained, before telling the press to bugger off and leave Bestie be. His wife Alex is presently nursing George's sore head, but she did take time out to publicly beg him to cease. "He realises now he cannot go on like this," she announced outside the family home in Portavogie, Co Down. "He knows people are desperately worried and I just hope he is going to stop," Alex continued, before explaining that her errant hubby is feeling a lot better today: "He had an early night, but is still in bed." Presumably lying on a half-eaten kebab.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Trevor Francis, Graeme Souness, Glenn Hoddle, Ruud Gullit and Alan Curbishley are the five names on the shortlist to replace George Graham at Tottenham, according to the London Evening Standard.

Arsenal are ready to make a £2m summer move for French goalkeeper Ulrich Rame, who plays for Bordeaux.

Stefan Effenberg has admitted he fancies a move to England when his contract with Bayern Munich runs out in 2002. "Playing in England is always in my thoughts," he said. "The club must be in London. Arsenal is a good club, but Spurs have always fascinated me."

Patrick Vieira has dropped hints about moving to Juventus. "I can't say I would never move to a side including Zidane and Trezeguet," he told Tuttosport. "My return in Italy is possible, but never to Lazio. I know that Juventus is a serious club, a club which protects the players."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers midfielder Barry Ferguson has been ruled out of the Scotland team to face San Marino at Hampden Park on Wednesday. Ferguson suffered a recurrence of a rib injury in the 2-2 draw against Belgium at the weekend.

The Republic of Ireland have passed on to Fifa an anonymous tip that six members of the Andorra squad they are due to face in a World Cup qualifier on Wednesday are ineligible. Bernard O'Byrne, chief executive of the FAI, said: "This information has been sent to us anonymously by fax to Dublin and my initial suspicion is that it is a complete red herring. I would be absolutely amazed if it were true. But we feel we are obliged to pass it on to the Fifa commissioner and let him deal with it before the game because we certainly do not want to become embroiled in anything afterwards." Andorra have denied the allegations.

Shares in Chelsea Village plc have fallen after chairman Ken Bates warned that an early exit from Europe and stadium redevelopment costs would lead to a wider full-year loss. The group's shares now stand at 29p - less than a third of their 98.5p peak price in March last year.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: On Side (10.35pm) Brian Clough does his tiresome old-school-manager-tells-it-like-he-sees-it routine. There's a reason why Tommy Docherty's never on the telly any more, you know.

ITV: Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) What's the point? There was no action last week, there's no action this week.

Nationwide League Football Extra (12midnight) The only Football League round-up with an unhealthy obsession with the Manic Street Preachers.

Channel 5: Style Tribes - Football (3.10am) Not sure what this is.

Dutch Football (4pm) It's Dutch.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm, 11pm) The only Football League round-up with an unhealthy obsession with that crappy big beat tune by the group with the drummer from Pop Will Eat Itself in it.

World Football Show (7.30pm) The only football round-up with a wider brief than the pair Jack Dee made on Celebrity Big Brother for Vanessa Feltz.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am) Get off my screen, you angular tool.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Charlie George. Again.

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) He's no Mark Pougatch, is he?

Talksport: Football First with Steve Bower from Manchester (7pm) He's no Ian Payne, is he?

fields.headline: Tories to play race card
fields.standfirst:
See the leaked fax
Page 1
Page 2
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader William Hague has sanctioned a party political broadcast depicting a group of eastern European immigrants attempting to enter Britain.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader William Hague has sanctioned a party political broadcast depicting a group of eastern European immigrants attempting to enter Britain.

The broadcast, which is being filmed in secret this week, calls for an unspecified number of "eastern European" speaking actors, aged between 25 and 70.

Leaked papers from Conservative central office, seen by Guardian Unlimited, also demand a more British-sounding cast to play roles representing target Tory voters.

They include a male sales rep in his 30s who drives a car, three elderly people and a "warm and friendly" female nurse in her 20s.

Intriguingly, the script also calls for a male fruit vendor in his 30s, possibly based on a real-life model - Steve Thoburn, the Sunderland grocer who was adopted by the Tories as a cause celebre over his refusal to sell fruit and veg in metric measures.

The filming requires a "French-looking" barman, suggesting that the plot of the party political broadcast will start on the continent before following the "eastern European" speakers to Britain.

The party political broadcast is all the more remarkable since it is only two weeks since William Hague, along with the other leaders of the main political parties, signed a pledge promising not to use "the race card" during the election campaign.

The pledge card, organised by the Commission for Racial Equality, committed the parties to discipline any activist or candidate who acts in a way "likely to stir up racial prejudice." It was signed by the PM, Charles Kennedy, William Hague and the leaders of the Scottish National party and Plaid Cymru.

That pledge appears now to be under pressure from the very first election broadcast by the Conservatives.

Conservative MP Ian Taylor said today that he hoped his party was not going to "repeat the error of Harrogate", where William Hague warned the Tory spring conference that Britain under a second Labour government would become a "foreign land".

"Mingling asylum seekers, illegal immigrants and hostility to the EU is standing on the wrong of the dividing line in the sand. If the Tory party wants to get re-elected we must realise the UK's problems are not the fault of asylum seekers."

The leaked documents also reveal that all actors must consent in advance to appearing in an advertisement for the Conservative party. It states "Please check that all suggestions are happy to play a character in a PPB for the Conservative party prior to suggesting them."

Actors will be paid a flat fee of £1,000 for a day's filming. Each character is apparently only needed for one day's work, although actual shooting will last from March 26 to April 1.

The major parties are allowed five broadcasts during the election campaign of five minutes each.

Labour MP Fraser Kemp said: "We need to know whether this election broadcast has been agreed by Michael Ancram, the party chairman, and in particular whether Andrew Lansley has been involved in its planning."

Andrew Lansley, now the shadow cabinet office minister, wrote a piece for the Observer newspaper in 1995, which said: "Immigration, an issue which we raised successfully in 1992 and again in the 1994 Euro-elections campaign, played particularly well in the tabloids and has more potential to hurt. So does the issue of identity cards. If Labour lines up with the civil liberties lobby, then Blair's efforts as shadow home secretary to remove crime as a Labour negative will be reversed."

A Labour party source said: "The Tories are always exploiting immigration on the one hand, while refusing to back Labour measures to restrict illegal immigration like the penalties for road hauliers and the voucher system for asylulm seekers."

Conservative central office refused to confirm details of the broadcast but an unapologetic statement was issued on behalf of Ann Widdecombe.

"Labour's appalling failure to tackle the problem of bogus asylum seekers is one of the biggest stains on their four years in power," it said. "The cost of handling this problem has doubled to £800m a year since the Conservatives left office.

"We make no apologies about our efforts to highlight the government's mismanagement of this criminal-inspired trade in human lives."

webTitle: Macedonian army vows to drive out insurgents

fields.headline: Macedonian army vows to drive out insurgents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian leaders vowed today that the country's army, which pierced Albanian rebel lines yesterday, would continue its offensive until the insurgents are driven out of the country.
fields.body:
Macedonian leaders vowed today that the country's army, which pierced Albanian rebel lines yesterday, would continue its offensive until the insurgents are driven out of the country.

An overnight calm was holding today after the former Yugoslav republic's ragtag infantry punched through rebel positions during a battle yesterday that raged in the hills just outside Tetovo, Macedonia's second-largest city.

The Macedonian forces sprayed houses with bullets and forced the guerrillas to pull back in the most intense fighting in six weeks of conflict.

The army broke through a roadblock and moved into the ethnic Albanian village of Gajre, 4km northwest of Tetovo, setting fire to the homes of those suspected of sheltering rebels. Two helicopters strafed the thickly forested hillsides.

With the calm continuing, a handful of peasants ventured back to their homes in Gajre, walking along the main road littered with spent cartridges and pocked with mortar craters. Dead sheep and other livestock lay on the ground, while smoke billowed from a house and scattered brush fires.

After taking Gajre, the troops regrouped and set up positions overlooking Lavce, another rebel-held village just north of Gajre.

The army said it had also taken Tetovo Kale, an ancient Turkish fortress cresting a hill that it said had been a rebel stronghold.

Two soldiers, one police officer and four civilians were slightly injured, government spokesman Antonio Milososki said. Police spokesman Stevo Pendarovski said the four civilians were a family riding in a taxi that entered an area of intense combat. He said the army had "captured several terrorists".

While not suggesting all-out victory, the Macedonian prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, said government forces were doing well, asserting that the thrust to "clear the terrain of terrorists ... is being carried out successfully, and already key positions have been taken".

However, the army acknowledged that the rebels, who have ties to ethnic Albanian militants in the neighbouring Yugoslav province of Kosovo, were formidable and well-armed opponents.

The rebels in Macedonia say their aim is limited to more rights for ethnic Albanians within Macedonia, who are outnumbered by Slavs three to one. The government accuses them of seeking independence and drawing on Kosovo for fighters and weapons.

Although ethnic relations with the majority Slavs had been relatively trouble-free, substantial numbers of the ethnic Albanian minority feel that they are being treated as second-class citizens. The struggle appears to have radicalised a large segment of Macedonian Albanians.

Two soldiers, one police officer and four civilians were slightly injured, government spokesman Antonio Milososki said. Police spokesman Stevo Pendarovski said the four civilians were a family riding in a taxi that entered an area of intense combat. He said the army had "captured several terrorists". While not suggesting all-out victory, the Macedonian prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, said government forces were doing well, asserting that the thrust to "clear the terrain of terrorists ... is being carried out successfully, and already key positions have been taken". However, the army acknowledged that the rebels, who have ties to ethnic Albanian militants in the neighbouring Yugoslav province of Kosovo, were formidable and well-armed opponents. The rebels in Macedonia say their aim is limited to more rights for ethnic Albanians within Macedonia, who are outnumbered by Slavs three to one. The government accuses them of seeking independence and drawing on Kosovo for fighters and weapons. Although ethnic relations with the majority Slavs had been relatively trouble-free, substantial numbers of the ethnic Albanian minority feel that they are being treated as second-class citizens. The struggle appears to have radicalised a large segment of Macedonian Albanians. fields.headline: ITC reports rise in misleading adverts
fields.standfirst: Table: the 10 most complained-about adverts
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: Misleading advertising is on the increase and the government is a culprit, according to the ITC, writes Claire Cozens.
Table: 10 most complained-about adverts
fields.body:
Misleading advertising is on the increase and the government is one of the biggest culprits, according to the Independent Television Commission's 2000 performance review.

The ITC said over the course of last year there had been a marked rise in the number of adverts it considered to be misleading.

And one of the worst offenders was a nursing recruitment advert put out by the government.

The commercial, which claimed the average nurse earned £20,000 a year, attracted 155 complaints, almost all of them from nurses.

The ITC found the claim gave a misleading impression of nurses' salaries, with a substantial proportion of nurses earning considerably less than £20,000.

But the ITC upheld complaints about just four of the 10 most-criticised commercials.

The commercial that attracted the most complaints was an advert for the energy drink Red Devil, in which footballer-turned-actor Vinnie Jones was shown luring a robin to its death.

The ITC cleared the advert in spite of complaints from 390 viewers, who said it was in bad taste and encouraged cruelty to animals.

The haka, the dance made famous by the New Zealand All Blacks national rugby team, was the focus of 116 complaints from viewers after it was parodied in an advertisement for the alcoholic drink Reef.

The ITC upheld the complaints on the grounds the commercial could cause offence to Maoris because it associated the tribal dance with alcohol and showed it being performed by women, which goes against the Maori tradition.

The total number of complaints upheld rose to 154 from 113 in 1999.

The ITC said this was due mainly to the increase in misleading advertising, with 94 advertisers being censured for this reason.

webTitle: Arts: New documentary on Stanley Kubrick

fields.headline: The truth about Kubrick
fields.standfirst: He wasn't a recluse, didn't shoot at strangers and was loved by all. So says the man who knew him best.  Derek Malcolm  reports
fields.trailText: He wasn't a recluse, didn't shoot at strangers and was loved by all. So says the man who knew him best. Derek Malcolm reports.
fields.body:
Jan Harlan thinks he must have had about 50,000 phone calls from Stanley Kubrick in a quarter-century as his executive producer. The director could be demanding, even difficult. But if the experience left him scarred, it doesn't show.

"Yes," Harlan says with a smile. "He could be a bit of a dictator. But then he was also a genius. That surely means he had every right to be on occasion. And you could argue with him. It was sometimes like a ping-pong match. He generally won, as the better player usually does. But not always. And he was a surprisingly good loser. To me and to many others, he was a very warm and decent friend." Though Harlan doesn't mention the fact, Kubrick was a little more than that: for over 40 years they were brothers-in-law.

Which is one reason Harlan was more furious than Kubrick when rumours went around about the film-maker's "secretive", "hostile" nature. Especially the one that had him taking potshots at inquisitive tourists wandering in his patch, then bribing them not to tell anyone.

He isn't happy about the way the British press treated Kubrick over the last 10 years or so of his life - a kind of resentful hostility that sometimes pitched into outright aggression. But he admits that Kubrick may have brought it on himself by not dealing with the press at all. And he positively hated being asked why he chose his subjects or what his films were really about. "For him it was like asking why he loved his wife." (The wife, by the way, is Harlan's sister Christiane, whom Kubrick married in 1957.)

Harlan, who became Kubrick's executive producer on the 1975 movie Barry Lyndon, has now made a three-part documentary called Stanley Kubrick: A Life in Pictures. He rather agrees with Jack Nicholson, one of the many stars and movie-makers who pay Kubrick tribute in the film. "He was the man. And I'm inclined to think that underrates him." He is anxious that his film should not be seen as a hagiography, although one of the few critical remarks is Woody Allen's statement that he was utterly baffled by 2001: A Space Odyssey the first time he saw it.

Introducing a new 70mm copy of the film in London earlier this week, Harlan tried to help out. "On a bad day Kubrick wouldn't answer the question. But on a good day I think he might have said the film was made by an ignoramus about the unknowable. He might have said - if he didn't think it was too pompous - that he wanted to take the audience into a place that he actually couldn't imagine himself all that well. He was really a self-taught and very learned man and he guessed that, even then, he knew very little. He wasn't at all religious but he had a very strong sense that there were mysteries, within and outside our world, that he could never begin to solve."

This was Kubrick's modesty. His conceit was an obsessive desire to solve the mystery of making films, which was why he frequently took so long to shoot them. But though he often went wildly beyond schedule, notably with Eyes Wide Shut, he seldom went badly over budget. That was why Warner trusted him. They knew he would in the end provide something exceptional and that he would never abuse them financially.

Actors felt the same way. He had the complete support of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman on Eyes Wide Shut. They never once complained, despite the length of the shoot. "You see," Harlan says, "actors invariably liked him, and I think he liked them. He gave them room to improvise and think their own thoughts about the part. OK, it's tiring doing 25 takes, but the point is that he was trusted."

He hated bad films, but his enthusiasms could be boundless. He loved Tarkovsky's Solaris, a kind of metaphysical relation to 2001, but also the totally different films of the Spanish director Carlos Saura, particularly Blood Wedding, which he sat through again and again.

His favourites included Heimat, Edgar Reitz's vast 15-hour film about the inhabitants of a remote German village, and Kieslowski's 10-part Decalogue. He was even persuaded to write the foreword to a book about the Polish director. The point is, Harlan says, he seldom stood as a judge on others, just on himself.

What about those 50,000 telephone calls? "Well, he was certainly no pushover. On the other hand, it's good to work for someone who actually wants to get things absolutely right. He'd often give you a whole list of questions and, if you couldn't answer one of them, he'd go on at you till you did. But you couldn't resent it, because you knew he should have asked them. He was the boss, and I was there to help him. If that sounds boring, I must say I had an amazingly good time working for him."

German-born Harlan started working with the American Kubrick in 1969, despite having no knowledge of the film business. Kubrick invited him to join him in Romania, where he was scouting locations for Napoleon - a subject the director had researched for years. But the film was never made because no one wanted to risk another historical flop after Sergei Bondarchuk's 1970 epic Waterloo. Both then came to live in England. Harlan says Kubrick fell in love with the country and wasn't simply attempting to escape from the constraints of Hollywood. "That's why he was so upset when the press seemed to turn against him."

So what's Harlan going to do next? "Well, people say I should make my own films, but they forget one thing. You have to be talented - and I don't think I am. Whatever they say, film-making can't be done by committee. There has to be an autocrat around, and if he or she is no good, the film won't be either. But I do want to make another documentary, this time about young classical musicians. My son is a pianist and it's a fascinating world. But features after Kubrick? I don't think so."

 2001: A Space Odyssey is out on Friday. Stanley Kubrick: A Life in Pictures will be broadcast and released on DVD in the summer.

webTitle: A guide to Swede bashing and other fun with Finns

fields.headline: A guide to Swede bashing and other fun with Finns
fields.trailText: Is there anything funny, I wonder, about the Swedes? I have seen several Ingmar Bergman films without ever worrying I might rupture a major muscle laughing. Woody Allen, it is true, used to joke about the Swedes' alleged liberal attitude towards sex, picturing American cops surrounding the country, shouting through a loud-hailer: "We know what's going on in there. Cut it out." But, by and large, I should have said there is limited fun to be had at their expense.
fields.body:
Is there anything funny, I wonder, about the Swedes? I have seen several Ingmar Bergman films without ever worrying I might rupture a major muscle laughing. Woody Allen, it is true, used to joke about the Swedes' alleged liberal attitude towards sex, picturing American cops surrounding the country, shouting through a loud-hailer: "We know what's going on in there. Cut it out." But, by and large, I should have said there is limited fun to be had at their expense.

Now, though, I find there is a whole book of Swedish jokes. The revelation arrives courtesy of Sema Vutanen, one of the two commentators enlisted by Sky to provide us lucky digital viewers with a different perspective on the England-Finland match.

On Sky Sports Extra, those of us who have invested in the new technology can select the Fanzone, where the balanced views and sober analysis of Martin Tyler and Andy Gray are replaced on our soundtrack by the "commentary" of two fans. On Saturday, there was an international line-up, with Sema representing Finland alongside the England supporter Andy Binstock.

Actually, it was not so much commentary as cheerleading, unless you can derive enlightenment from such apercus as "go on my son, have a dig" and "come on ref, he's tripped him."

If you feel you can, by the way, and you are not tooled up with the requisite equipment, do not worry. Jonathan Pearce will be at the Albania-England match for Channel 5 on Wednesday.

Of all the pointless interactive services Sky provides, the Fanzone is usually the most resistible, although Playercam runs it a close second, providing close-up pictures of a key player taking a quiet moment to scratch his backside or evacuate his nasal cavities, while the action goes on down the other end of the pitch. On Saturday, however, the opportunity to get a Finnish view of the action made Fanzone worth dipping into, which is how I caught Sema's bombshell.

As the camera moved in on Sven-Goran Eriksson looking particularly anguished and Swedish (like Victor Sjostrom in Wild Strawberries), Sema commented, "Ha, the famous Swede" - implying, I think, that the Swedes' contribution to international celebrity was less than impressive (unlike the Finns, of course, who have given us Sibelius, Mika Hakkinen and Alvar Aalto, the famous architect and furniture designer). "Don't you like the Swedes, then?" asked Andy. "We hate them. We have joke books about them," revealed Sema.

I should like to see some of these Swedish jokes. What, particularly, is it about the Swedes that their neighbours find risible? Maybe it is their unique capacity for self-torment. Even after a victory that kept England on course for World Cup qualification there was an air of melancholy about Sven.

"We suffered a lot at the end," he said. "Finland is a very good team. You can't just go out and win, you have to suffer, and we suffered together." Self-flagellation, you see. Very important to the Swedes; the birch-twig mentality. Sven paid routine tribute to England's team spirit, before adding, "But what does it all mean anyway in a godless universe?"

In any case, Sven's post-match interviews do not seem likely to do much to shift foot and mouth and S Club Seven's activities from the front pages. Nor can we scandal-mongering jackals look to Sven's captain for help in filling our miserable rags. Beckham was only slightly more communicative with Sky's Clare Tomlinson than he was last week with Ali G. The atmosphere, he said, was "brilliant", the character the players showed was "brilliant", and the fans were, guess what?

Still, who's complaining? After his captain's innings Becks is clearly a rare example of someone who does do his talking on the pitch.

Both captain and manager will no doubt have missed the University Boat Race in the build-up to the international, which is a pity as it was the sort of event Sven would probably have enjoyed. "Pain, Commitment, Intensity and Passion," read the caption over a moody little film the BBC had made of rowers, all straining sinews and pained expressions, in training. It looked like the kind of suffering Sven would relish, and about which our Finnish friends could no doubt come up with at least half a dozen rib-ticklers.

It did nothing for me, though, as usual. My favourite moment is when they stick Steve Rider on the towpath with a gang of rowers. These chaps, lovers of hearty breakfasts, which we always see footage of them eating ("tucking into" as the commentary invariably puts it) in the build-up to the race, tend to be large men, whereas Steve is constructed on more compact lines.

The juxtaposition has the effect of making Steve look like a toy ; My Little Commentator. Or something you might take home to clip on a charm bracelet. Makes me laugh every year. The famous English sense of humour, I like to call it. Beat that Finland.

webTitle: John Patterson on new US movies

fields.headline: Funny peculiar
fields.standfirst: Sigourney does comedy and the Farrelly Brothers strike again.  John Patterson takes his weekly look at new US movies
fields.trailText: Sigourney does comedy and the Farrelly Brothers strike again. John Patterson takes his weekly look at new US movies.
fields.body:
Three comedies this weekend: one white, one blue, one black, all weak. The first is Heartbreakers, apparently an experiment to prove that comedies can be made by people with no sense of humour. Its stars, Sigourney Weaver and Jennifer Love Hewitt, are a mother-daughter con-woman duo. After stinging a series of credulous businessmen - Sig marries them, Jen beds them, Sig and Jen split divorce settlements - they find themselves broke and decide to go Gene Hackman's gin-blossomed, amber-toothed, half-dead tobacco billionaire.

Hackman's amorality and disturbing personal habits ("He's the world's leading phlegm-producer") are a relief after half an hour of wan banter from Weaver and Hewitt. Weaver's Ivy League bone structure and emotional coolness work in her favour when she's flame-broiling aliens for Ridley Scott, but when it comes to comedy she looks antsier than Wasp princesses such as Ali McGraw and Katherine Ross. Hewitt, the pampered teenage star of Party of Five, is on career probation here; her last success was 1999's I Still Know What You Did Last Summer. Her attempts here to be funny-amoral just make her look bratty-sullen.

With this pair in almost every scene, the proven comic performers - Hackman, Jeffery Jones, Jason Lee - have nothing solid to bounce against. Only Ray Liotta really shines as a New Jersey mini-mobster devoted to Weaver. When he's on screen he forces the others to sharpen up, but whenever he disappears everything slackens off again.

Say It Isn't So is billed as being "from the guys who brought you There's Something About Mary", though the Farrelly Brothers are listed only as producers. No matter: their name is now a recognisable comedy brand, so any product bearing the Farrelly imprimatur will feature young innocent lovers (Chris Klein and Heather Graham in this instance) and mean-minded toilet humour.

America came late to toilet humour, an art in which Britain can boast pre-eminence. When I first saw Kingpin and Mary, I felt the brothers had opened Pandora's high school locker and unleashed upon puritan America the spirit of the wedgie, the shit-based practical joke and the peephole in the girls' showers.

There was an endearingly naive quality to There's Something About Mary that had disappeared by the time they made the heartless Me, Myself and Irene last year. Say It Isn't So, directed by JB Rogers, is a Farrelly franchise all the way, but the effect has been dulled by familiarity. Most of it takes place in Beaver, Oregon, and that sets the tone for a cavalcade of tit-piercing, road-kill, earlobe amputations, jungly bikini-waxings and that other Farrelly trademark, a faint tinge of racial animosity. The Friday night audience I saw it with was subdued and underwhelmed.

The last of the movies, The Brothers, is a bourgeois drama about settling down from writer-director Gary Hardwick. It purports to address issues about the African-American middle-class experience but settles for "positive black images" and dubious sexual politics. In this flat account of four friends and their relationships with women, nothing's at stake, all will be resolved with a hug or a high-five, and every minute feels faked. With the same budget, an ambitious African-American director such as Charles Burnett might have given us a worthwhile movie - and probably a couple of others with the change.

When I first saw Kingpin and Mary, I felt the brothers had opened Pandora's high school locker and unleashed upon puritan America the spirit of the wedgie, the shit-based practical joke and the peephole in the girls' showers. There was an endearingly naive quality to There's Something About Mary that had disappeared by the time they made the heartless Me, Myself and Irene last year. Say It Isn't So, directed by JB Rogers, is a Farrelly franchise all the way, but the effect has been dulled by familiarity. Most of it takes place in Beaver, Oregon, and that sets the tone for a cavalcade of tit-piercing, road-kill, earlobe amputations, jungly bikini-waxings and that other Farrelly trademark, a faint tinge of racial animosity. The Friday night audience I saw it with was subdued and underwhelmed. The last of the movies, The Brothers, is a bourgeois drama about settling down from writer-director Gary Hardwick. It purports to address issues about the African-American middle-class experience but settles for "positive black images" and dubious sexual politics. In this flat account of four friends and their relationships with women, nothing's at stake, all will be resolved with a hug or a high-five, and every minute feels faked. With the same budget, an ambitious African-American director such as Charles Burnett might have given us a worthwhile movie - and probably a couple of others with the change.

webTitle: Brown makes international plea for vets

fields.headline: Brown makes international plea for vets
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A worldwide appeal for vets went out today as the government announced plans for speeding up the foot and mouth cull.
fields.body:
A worldwide appeal for vets went out today as the government announced plans for speeding up the foot and mouth cull.

As wagon loads of dead sheep were tipped into the first mass grave dug by the army, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said more needed to be done to contain the disease quickly.

He was speaking just 10 miles from an airfield at Great Orton in Cumbria, where a total of 1,200 carcasses were being buried. The disease has now spread to the heart of the Lake District, where park managers fear it could wipe out both the dramatic landscape and the farming and tourism industries.

There are now 613 cases of foot and mouth after six more were confirmed today, said the ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food (Maff).

Mr Brown made the appeal for vets during his visit to Cumbria, where he was heckled by demonstrators as he arrived in Carlisle for a meeting with farmers and their leaders.

He said: "We have already disposed of more animals in this disease outbreak than in the 1967 outbreak. There has been an enormous amount of work done already.

"We have been discussing how we can get the time from reportage to slaughter on the farm improved. That is a question of resources, especially veterinary resources," he added.

Calling on vets worldwide to help Britain resolve the crisis, Mr Brown said the priority was to speed up the disposal process.

As part of this, Maff has also changed the rules on the valuation of animals. Waiting for a valuation has often held up the slaughter process but, from now on, farmers will be given the option of receiving payments at a standard flat rate instead.

The government is also considering the use of vaccination, but Mr Brown said this policy would only be pursued if it was recommended by Jim Scudamore, the chief vet.

The army was also today being used in Wales for the first time, in an effort to stop the spread of foot and mouth disease.

60 soldiers have been called in to stop infected sheep mixing with healthy animals on common land at Hay Bluff, near Hay-on-Wye, close to the English border.

A Welsh assembly spokesman said: "Soldiers are patrolling the area to keep infected sheep within infected areas and keep uninfected sheep out of the area."

fields.headline: Is this the face of Christ?
fields.trailText:
3.45pm update: The BBC used 2,000-year-old Jewish skulls and ancient religious images to generate what it claims is the first 'true-to-life' picture of Jesus Christ, writes Jason Deans.
Click here for large image
Mar 26: Life of Christ leads BBC1 schedule
Mar 26: EastEnders star lands drama role
Mar 26: New BBC1 schedule
Talk about it
fields.body:
The BBC used a combination of 2,000-year-old Jewish skulls and ancient religious images to generate what it claims is the first "true-to-life" picture of Jesus Christ.

The first pictures, reminiscent of a police e-fit, were released today as part of a promotional push for a major new BBC1 religious series, Son of God.

The BBC hopes the computer-generated images will become a major talking point and that the series will finally bury criticism by church leaders last year that the corporation had marginalised serious religious discussion.

"The image of Jesus we have today dates back to sixth century religious portraits," said producer Jean Claude Bragard.

"We also looked at Jewish faces from the first century to come up with this, " he added.

The image is strikingly different to the traditional idea of Jesus with long hair and a beard.

"The reconstruction provides the closest image of what this remarkable man may have looked like, " said the BBC.

Son of God, a three-part series, begins this Sunday at 9pm.

The primetime scheduling will delight the critics who last year branded as "trite" the corporation's coverage of religion.

The series also looks at the evidence to support other stories relating to Jesus's life including the last supper and the betrayal by Judas.

"It's not the face of Jesus, but how he is likely to have looked given the scientific information we've got," said Lorraine Heggessey, controller of BBC1.

"That's what people from that area of the world looked like at that time."

Mr Bragard said there was evidence to support the myth of Jesus sweating blood on the cross, for instance.

"There are over 100 reported cases of people under extreme pressure who know they're going to die, on their way to the gallows or the gas chamber, they're sweating blood, " he added.

"We looked at the scientific and archaeological evidence for the stories in the Gospels."

The series will also look at the virgin birth and the betrayal of Jesus by Judas.

The series will also feature computer-generated reconstructions of how places Jesus visited, including Jerusalem, would have looked in his time.

Ms Heggessey said she might consider looking at other bible figures, including Moses, Joseph and King Herod in the same way.

Ms Heggessey said she was running so many new dramas because she was looking for two or three "long running franchises".

"We hope to find two or three that can become long running franchises like Silent Witness. We'll keep trying until we find them.

"In two years' time we want more stronger returning series, just as ITV have now.

"There's a lot of police drama because we're trying to develop long running franchises. I don't make any excuses for crime drama - a lot of people like reading crime fiction and like watching it on TV."

fields.headline: Pakistan revels in nuclear power
fields.standfirst: The chants of 'atom bomb, atom bomb' on national day provide a disturbing backdrop to the ongoing dispute with India over Kashmir, writes Luke Harding
fields.trailText: The chants of 'atom bomb, atom bomb' on national day provide a disturbing backdrop to the ongoing dispute with India over Kashmir, writes Luke Harding.
fields.body:
For all those worried about nuclear rivalry between India and Pakistan, it was not exactly a reassuring sight. Trundling down Islamabad's main boulevard on Friday, as part of a massive parade to mark national day, were two of Pakistan's latest nuclear-capable missiles.

Thousands of ordinary Pakistanis had climbed trees, or pushed towards stick-wielding policemen to watch. As the Shaheen I and Shaheen II ballistic missiles moved into view, the crowd burst into wild applause.

"Atom bomb! Atom bomb!" was the chant. "Atom bomb! Atom bomb!"

The missiles continued their stately journey to the far end of the boulevard, past Pakistan's defunct white marble parliament, to the podium where Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, was waiting. He saluted crisply.

"The Shaheen can hit India in six minutes," one of the ordinary Pakistanis in the crowd told me. "It is anti-Bharat [India]. We can also hit Israel with it."

The fact that the giant green-and-brown missile shown off three days ago was probably only a huge dummy was of little consolation. As my new companion explained: "The real thing is on the border with India. Can hit more targets that way."

Pakistan's annual national day parade held every year is not exactly a new spectacle. It commemorates a 1940 resolution that led to the creation of Pakistan seven years later as a homeland for the subcontinent's Muslims.

It was not just Pakistan's short and intermediate range missiles that were on display: Puma helicopters, Russian-made T-80 tanks, and F16 bombers also took part, as well as assorted cultural troupes and military bands.

However, the ceremony has been given new piquancy by the fact that the army is once again in charge in Pakistan, following a coup 18 months ago, and by the country's new nuclear status.

Pakistan declared itself a nuclear power in May 1998, following tit-for-tat tests between with India. It is now the world's seventh nuclear power, and the first Islamic country to have - as the jubilant crowds put it - "atom bomb, atom bomb".

Peace talks, meanwhile, between India and Pakistan have foundered. The sticking point, as always, is Kashmir, a subject that provokes passionate reactions from ordinary Pakistanis, but arouses little interest - verging on boredom - from ordinary Indians.

"It is all your fault. You British people should sort it out," one man in the crowd told me. Fifty years on it was a bit late for that, I replied. As if to reinforce his point, the boulevard was decorated with yellow banners that declared: "Kashmiris too have a right to live."

Nevertheless, the prospect of a meaningful dialogue over Kashmir in the near future is, to put it mildly, remote. Kashmir has an overwhelming Muslim majority, which is Pakistan's main grievance. India refuses to discuss Kashmir until, it says, Pakistan puts an end to "cross-border terrorism".

By cross-border terrorism, India means the procession of often fanatical young men who move illegally into Kashmir, having received military training at religious camps in Pakistan. They then attack Indian army posts in the name of jihad.

Pakistan, by way of response, says India has no interest in bringing about peace in the region. As Pakistan's president, Mohammad Rafiq Tarar, put it on Friday: "We have taken several positive steps to create a congenial atmosphere, including a partial pullback of troops from the Line of Control [the de facto border between India and Pakistan]  But it is a matter of great regret that a positive response to our efforts is not forthcoming."

Somewhere in this the views of ordinary Kashmiris get lost. Many, undoubtedly, favour cession with Pakistan. But others merely want the restoration of normality that the valley used to enjoy - and the withdrawal of Indian security forces.

The Kashmir problem - longstanding, complex, and intractable - is not going to go away. Nor are the nuclear weapons, paraded through downtown Islamabad three days ago.

What happens next in one of the trickiest sagas brought about by colonialism is a matter of uncertainty, to most people at least. Except, perhaps, to the faithful, that is. "When Pakistani troops go into battle they are assured of victory," one man told me. Why is that, I asked? "Because they have the support of Allah," he replied serenely.

 When it comes to VIP culture, Pakistan can match India in every respect. Sitting on a restaurant terrace in the hills high above Islamabad, enjoying the sunset and a cup of iced coffee, I was approached by a Pakistani police officer.

"You'll have to leave," he said. The reason, it transpired, was that Senegal's president, Abdoulaye Wade, had decided to drop in too, with a few friends. In honour of his official visit, army officers closed off not only the restaurant but also the hills themselves.

President Wade had a quick look at Islamabad's geometric skyline, before heading inside for a cold, non-alcoholic drink.

fields.headline: Housing profession in flux
fields.standfirst: The impetus behind a review of the training courses for housing professionals is partly a result of criticisms, but also a realisation that the profession is in the midst of a profound change, writes Anna Minton
fields.trailText: The impetus behind a review of the training courses for housing professionals is partly a result of criticisms, but also a realisation that the profession is in the midst of a profound change, writes Anna Minton.
fields.body:
Two years ago Jeremy Killinray completed a certificate in housing at the University of Westminster. But he says that although he enjoyed the course it didn't help to equip him for work as a tenant participation officer at the Royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The course he attended was constructed around the three core elements of housing: regeneration, housing finance and the history and context of housing management. "I really enjoyed it but it didn't help me do my job any better or any differently. Knowing about policy is not something I touch on in my daily work. It didn't teach you how to deal with people on a day-to-day basis," he said.

His comments are the latest in a long line of criticisms levelled at training and qualifications for housing professionals over the last few years. The government's policy action team on housing management called for improvements in training and professional standards as one of its eight main recommendations, while ministers Hilary Armstrong and Nick Raynsford have both been vocal in expressing concerns.

Meanwhile, in January, the publication of the government's strategy for neighbourhood renewal included a pledge to set up a new national centre for neighbourhood renewal which would "improve the training of public sector professionals and practitioners working in disadvantaged neighbourhoods". Implicit is the charge that what is currently on offer isn't good enough.

In fact, although the Chartered Institute of Housing denies that its accredited courses and training programmes haven't been up to scratch in the past, it clearly has been listening to the need for change and is nearly at the end of a two-year review of its professional qualification. The review, which will be completed next month, is being accompanied by an overhaul of the occupational standards which form the nuts and bolts of the courses, and promises to fundamentally alter the nature of what it is to be a housing manager.

The impetus behind the review is not merely the ongoing criticism of the courses, but the realisation that the profession is in the midst of a profound change. The main drivers for this, according to Tim Taylor, visiting lecturer in housing at the University of Westminster, are the shift towards neighbourhood management and joined-up working emphasised by the government, combined with an increasing business focus among many housing professionals. In fact, said Mr Taylor, "The big issue in housing is to what extent a strict housing qualification is going to become irrelevant in the future as we get into new agendas."

Paul Smith, of the National Training Organisation for Housing, the body in charge of occupational standards, explained: "The main changes are related to joined-up government. It's got to the point where the housing qualification can't be looked at on its own. In the past the housing manager did just that, managed housing - dealt with tenants, collected rent and looked after repairs. Now the onus is much more on tenant involvement and consultation as well as an expectation to work across disciplines and think about the environment, health and education."

Martin Winn, head of the institute's education department, says the review was kicked off by the government's social inclusion agenda, which brought with it the introduction of neighbourhood managers and a greater emphasis on community regeneration.

"It's about getting local agencies to work together with the housing department, from the police to local schools. For example, the housing department should work with the police if properties on an estate become the focus for local drug dealers," he said.

As a result, the new professional qualification will introduce new core units for inter-agency working and community regeneration, and will focus far more on project management, networking and empathising and understanding where other agencies are coming from.

Greater weight will also be given to business management skills - essential, Mr Winn said, for a profession where even local authorities have to adhere to a more business-orientated approach to housing, driven by the introduction of the best value regime.

However, now the issue for many in the profession is whether these changes will be sufficient to safeguard the role of housing manager, as that of neighbourhood manager gains in importance. At the same time, other changes in the job, both at the higher and lower end of the scale, are chipping away at the role. "The idea that there's a standard job of housing manager will disappear," Mr Smith said.

For example, at the bottom end the more onerous administrative tasks - such as dealing with the reporting of repairs - have been automated or are being dealt with by call centres. Meanwhile, at a more senior level the shift towards a business focus is beginning to attract a different type of professional, and often one without a housing background but one who has taken the MBA route instead.

Mr Smith believes that the growing emphasis on neighbourhood managers will in many cases replace the purely housing function, with the neighbourhood manager acting as a housing manager who can also undertake a variety of other roles related to the local environment. But rather than a threat, he believes this can be an opportunity for housing managers, and sees them as well placed to step into the more challenging and high-status job of neighbourhood manager.

As the institute tussles with the uncertain future role of the housing manager, doubts also remain over whether the changes in the professional qualification will answer the long-standing criticism that the degrees simply do not train students for the day-to-day problems they will encounter on the ground.

Although Mr Winn said the new courses will focus more on communication skills and customer care, Gerard Lemos, from housing research consultancy Lemos and Crane, fears the degrees will continue to fall down on the people front. For him, despite the changes, the emphasis remains on accumulating a body of knowledge which has little bearing on how the newly-qualified housing graduate deals with tenants in stressful situations.

"This is driven by high level policy concerns rather than the ground level practical worries of frontliners, and it won't deal with the current interpersonal aspects which have been badly neglected. It's not going to make an impact on the day-to-day practice of being a housing manager," he said.

If, as Mr Lemos warned, the new degrees merely replace a focus on one group of policy areas with a look at another, graduates' criticisms that the courses have little bearing on the job appear here to stay.
fields.bodyText: Two years ago Jeremy Killinray completed a certificate in housing at the University of Westminster. But he says that although he enjoyed the course it didn't help to equip him for work as a tenant participation officer at the Royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea. The course he attended was constructed around the three core elements of housing: regeneration, housing finance and the history and context of housing management. "I really enjoyed it but it didn't help me do my job any better or any differently. Knowing about policy is not something I touch on in my daily work. It didn't teach you how to deal with people on a day-to-day basis," he said. His comments are the latest in a long line of criticisms levelled at training and qualifications for housing professionals over the last few years. The government's policy action team on housing management called for improvements in training and professional standards as one of its eight main recommendations, while ministers Hilary Armstrong and Nick Raynsford have both been vocal in expressing concerns. Meanwhile, in January, the publication of the government's strategy for neighbourhood renewal included a pledge to set up a new national centre for neighbourhood renewal which would "improve the training of public sector professionals and practitioners working in disadvantaged neighbourhoods". Implicit is the charge that what is currently on offer isn't good enough. In fact, although the Chartered Institute of Housing denies that its accredited courses and training programmes haven't been up to scratch in the past, it clearly has been listening to the need for change and is nearly at the end of a two-year review of its professional qualification. The review, which will be completed next month, is being accompanied by an overhaul of the occupational standards which form the nuts and bolts of the courses, and promises to fundamentally alter the nature of what it is to be a housing manager. The impetus behind the review is not merely the ongoing criticism of the courses, but the realisation that the profession is in the midst of a profound change. The main drivers for this, according to Tim Taylor, visiting lecturer in housing at the University of Westminster, are the shift towards neighbourhood management and joined-up working emphasised by the government, combined with an increasing business focus among many housing professionals. In fact, said Mr Taylor, "The big issue in housing is to what extent a strict housing qualification is going to become irrelevant in the future as we get into new agendas." Paul Smith, of the National Training Organisation for Housing, the body in charge of occupational standards, explained: "The main changes are related to joined-up government. It's got to the point where the housing qualification can't be looked at on its own. In the past the housing manager did just that, managed housing - dealt with tenants, collected rent and looked after repairs. Now the onus is much more on tenant involvement and consultation as well as an expectation to work across disciplines and think about the environment, health and education." Martin Winn, head of the institute's education department, says the review was kicked off by the government's social inclusion agenda, which brought with it the introduction of neighbourhood managers and a greater emphasis on community regeneration. "It's about getting local agencies to work together with the housing department, from the police to local schools. For example, the housing department should work with the police if properties on an estate become the focus for local drug dealers," he said. As a result, the new professional qualification will introduce new core units for inter-agency working and community regeneration, and will focus far more on project management, networking and empathising and understanding where other agencies are coming from. Greater weight will also be given to business management skills - essential, Mr Winn said, for a profession where even local authorities have to adhere to a more business-orientated approach to housing, driven by the introduction of the best value regime. However, now the issue for many in the profession is whether these changes will be sufficient to safeguard the role of housing manager, as that of neighbourhood manager gains in importance. At the same time, other changes in the job, both at the higher and lower end of the scale, are chipping away at the role. "The idea that there's a standard job of housing manager will disappear," Mr Smith said. For example, at the bottom end the more onerous administrative tasks - such as dealing with the reporting of repairs - have been automated or are being dealt with by call centres. Meanwhile, at a more senior level the shift towards a business focus is beginning to attract a different type of professional, and often one without a housing background but one who has taken the MBA route instead. Mr Smith believes that the growing emphasis on neighbourhood managers will in many cases replace the purely housing function, with the neighbourhood manager acting as a housing manager who can also undertake a variety of other roles related to the local environment. But rather than a threat, he believes this can be an opportunity for housing managers, and sees them as well placed to step into the more challenging and high-status job of neighbourhood manager. As the institute tussles with the uncertain future role of the housing manager, doubts also remain over whether the changes in the professional qualification will answer the long-standing criticism that the degrees simply do not train students for the day-to-day problems they will encounter on the ground. Although Mr Winn said the new courses will focus more on communication skills and customer care, Gerard Lemos, from housing research consultancy Lemos and Crane, fears the degrees will continue to fall down on the people front. For him, despite the changes, the emphasis remains on accumulating a body of knowledge which has little bearing on how the newly-qualified housing graduate deals with tenants in stressful situations. "This is driven by high level policy concerns rather than the ground level practical worries of frontliners, and it won't deal with the current interpersonal aspects which have been badly neglected. It's not going to make an impact on the day-to-day practice of being a housing manager," he said. If, as Mr Lemos warned, the new degrees merely replace a focus on one group of policy areas with a look at another, graduates' criticisms that the courses have little bearing on the job appear here to stay.

fields.headline: No 1846
fields.standfirst: Forty
fields.trailText: Forty.
fields.body:
Bingo! I beg your pardon?

Four-0, blind 40! What do I win? Nowt lad. This isn't the Mecca. I'm talking about 40 years.

Like a ruby wedding anniversary? Well, actually, I'm referring to a 40th birthday. Which is a bit like a ruby wedding anniversary all of your own ... William Hague turns 40 today.

Does he, by jove? Yup. He is now over the hill.

Ah right. Which hill is that then? The metaphorical hill.

Oh yes, near Cardiff, isn't it? No, I was speaking met-a-phor-i-call-y, you idiot.

Right, yes, of course. But - just for the record - is it, metaphorically speaking, sort of a little grassy knoll, or you know, a big Ben Nevis beast of a hill? Well I'd wager it's a fairly steep hill. The point being that one is "over" the hill, and therefore in decline. Do you see?

So it's like tobogganing? Yes. Just like tobogganing.

Sounds like fun. Well, not really. I mean, after 40 you sort of start to feel a bit past it, to be honest. You get wrinkles and liver spots, and you start to lose your hair ...

Hague's got a head-start there, though, eh? Tony Blair's got some catching up to do. So this hill, will I be needing sensible shoes? Oh yes. All old people have sensible shoes. And you'll be wanting some Crimplene trousers and an anorak before long too.

Will I really? It's inevitable. You will also start to like trifle and Murray Mints.

Oh dear. And how is William going to celebrate this milestone. He's going for a nice pub meal with Ffion.

That's a bit sedate, isn't it? Well, you don't like a lot of fuss when you're old. And he had a party a few weeks ago. His constituents gave him a broom, and his family gave him a pair of binoculars.

Don't you mean bi-focals? It's only a matter of time.

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: by John Kampfner
fields.trailText: by John Kampfner
fields.body:
Foot and mouth rumbles on. Farmers and hoteliers suffer the trauma of shattered businesses; politicians and journalists suffer the trauma of uncertain election dates. But while countryside misery continued to dominate airwaves and newsprint, three core political stories raised their sleazy heads.

There were more shenanigans around Keith Vaz, the embattled Europe minister; there was Tom Bower and the Daily Mail versus Geoffrey Robinson and Stephen Byers, and there was a renewal of hostilities between the Times and the Tory party. This was media- politics warfare at its most internecine.

Usually newspapers that have paid large amounts for book rights trumpet their serialisation in advance. Not so last week with the Mail. It kept Bower's offerings under wraps until late on Sunday evening. David Hughes, the paper's political editor who had written the page one "write-off", phoned the Downing Street duty press officer, as well as Robinson, as the first edition went to bed, to alert them in the vaguest terms. Late that night, receiving the first editions at home, Alastair Campbell decided on the outlines of a rebuttal strategy. This was to be a heavy infantry response.

On Monday, just before the lobby, Campbell discussed the issue with Byers, and they agreed to send in the lawyers. What isn't clear is what happened earlier that morning. According to some at the Mail, and as alleged by Stephen Glover in his latest Spectator media column, Campbell phoned the BBC to rubbish the story and warn them about the impending legal action. Glover suggests this cowed the Today programme, and they played down the story.

The BBC is such a multi-headed beast that Campbell could have called the Today programme, the political team at Four Millbank, a bulletins' editor or even one of the "time lords", as the managers are known. All receive dark warning messages from spin doctors of all colours, trying to put them off the scent. Nobody I have spoken to at the corporation remembers getting a call. Indeed, Rod Liddle, the Today editor, who wasn't on early duty that day, was worried the programme might have gone in too hard with its sequence at 8.20am with Andrew Marr and the Liberal Democrat sleaze-busting MP, Norman Baker. Certainly when Campbell talked of a writ against the Mail at the 11am lobby meeting, that was news to the assembled hacks.

The Mail pressed on with its list of questions for Byers to answer. Hughes phoned Mike Snowdon at the DTI press office several times a day to check whether they had been answered. It was only on Wednesday morning that the Mail's solicitors received a letter but - according to some at the paper - it didn't have the "killer paragraph" imposing a deadline for redress, with a lawsuit automatically following. The Mail claims it is comfortable with its story; the government says it will press ahead with action. Who will buckle first, or will a compromise be reached?

One such truce was agreed last year between the Times and Michael Ashcroft, the Tories' treasurer, over his Belize connections. But bad blood remains. It spilt over into open hostilities again last week with Michael Gove's attack, in the lead story on Wednesday in Times 2, on Amanda Platell, William Hague's chief of spin.

The politics revolves around the various rival camps at Conservative Central Office with some seeing Platell as a liability to the party leader. The media politics, however, provides an interesting sub-plot. The Times didn't want a member of its Westminster team, for obvious reasons, to do the piece. Nor did it want any of its more New Labour-minded writers. So the word at Wapping was that Gove, the home editor and a columnist not known for his leftwing sympathies, should wield the knife. However it then proved difficult for Gove to dispel accusations that his role as Michael Portillo's biographer was purely coincidental.

So battle was joined - by proxy. The following day the Telegraph's media page had a long piece detailing what it said was the Times' pro-Labour and pro-Portillo agenda. It was the Telegraph - with its very close links to the Hague circle - that in January did a number on Portillo by suggesting that he was thinking of giving up top-flight politics. Glover, who is also a columnist on the Mail, the only other paper on which Central Office can rely, followed up in his Spectator piece in similar vein.
