fields.headline: Global firms eye Premier League
fields.trailText: The sale of the Premier League's overseas pay-per-view TV rights has generated fresh interest in the league's title sponsorship, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The sale of the Premier League's overseas pay-per-view TV rights has generated new interest in the league's title sponsorship.

Individual pay-per-view deals with BSkyB, ONdigital, Telewest and NTL are expected to be completed within the next month, raking in about £180m.

The deals have caught the attention of international companies interested in the title sponsorship, according to a Premier League spokesman.

However, he said the league was still locked in negotiations with two companies bidding for the title sponsorship.

The spokesman refused to either confirm or deny that the Premier League was considering splitting the title sponsorship between a domestic sponsor and a global sponsor.

The move would allow one company to be title sponsor in the UK and another to hold the title sponsorship abroad.

Pepsi and Budweiser are among the companies that have withdrawn their interest in lending their name to the league.

Industry insiders believe existing sponsor Carling may have gone back to the negotiating table, having earlier pulled out, and that Sony was still interested.

The league's club chairmen have given the Premier League until the end of the footballing season to tie up the title sponsorship.

webTitle: Young set to quit S Express

fields.headline: Young set to quit Sunday Express
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Simon Young, the Sunday Express's assistant editor, news, is believed to be negotiating his departure, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 23: Express sports chief quits
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Simon Young, the Sunday Express's assistant editor, news, is believed to be negotiating his departure from the newspaper.

The news follows last week's announcement that 145 editorial jobs will be lost.

Mr Young is the second high-profile journalist on the Express Newspapers newsdesk to have held talks with the management about voluntary redundancy.

Earlier this week it was revealed news editor Sean Rayment has also discussed "fast track" redundancy with the management.

It is believed Mr Young will leave the Express in four weeks.

Mr Young is effectively the only staff journalist working exclusively for the Sunday Express newsdesk.

He was not available for comment.

The Express's managing editor, Lindsay Cook, said she would not comment on the situations of individual staff members.

Late last week it emerged that Mike Allen, the paper's long-time head of sport, is also to leave the paper.

webTitle: Peace, love and understanding the Academy

fields.headline: Peace, love and understanding the Academy
fields.standfirst: Xan Brooks  weighs up this year's winners and losers
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks weighs up the rights and wrongs of last night's Oscar ceremony
fields.body:
Speaking live via satellite link-up, Bob Dylan (a winner for best original song) wished "peace, tranquillity and goodwill" upon the celebrity throng gathered inside LA's Shrine Auditorium for the 73rd Academy Awards. Some hope. For all the public smiles and gushing speeches, this was one of the most torrid and tension-filled Oscar nights in years. Marching up the red carpet, the primary players must have known that there was all to play for. Marching back out again, many will be haunted by how close they may have come to the big awards. If not quite as controversial as last year's presidential stand-off, Oscars 2001 still threw up its fair share of surprises.

Spare a thought, for instance, for Kate Hudson, the perky favourite to win best supporting actress who lost out to rank outsider Marcia Gay Harden (until tonight barely a household name in her own household). Or consider what sour thoughts may have run through the mind of Ridley Scott. Nominated as best director, he must have considered Taiwanese auteur Ang Lee his closest rival. In the event both were pipped to the post by Steven Soderbergh, who won for Traffic.

Insiders had predicted that Soderbergh's two best director nominations (for Traffic and Erin Brockovich) was bound to split the vote and mean that Soderbergh would come away with nothing. But displaying an all too rare example of impeccable taste, the Academy decided otherwise. Soderbergh's handling of Traffic's multiple plot strands was a virtuoso exercise; at once beautifully coherent and impressively experimental. The man has long been seen as one of American cinema's most talented artists. The Oscar affords him the mainstream recognition he deserves.

Elsewhere, the night came down to the predicted stand-off between the Roman action blockbuster Gladiator and the martial-arts epic Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. For much of the evening, the films switched back and forth in their hunt for the most Oscars, with both in contention for the crowning best picture award that traditionally brings the show to its glittering climax.

But a key to the eventual outcome came when Crouching Tiger took the statuette for best foreign language film - a sure sign that the night's biggest honour was set to fall to its rival. In the end, Gladiator finished ahead by a nose. The final scores have it with five Oscars (for film, actor, sound, costumes, and visual effects). Crouching Tiger and Traffic tied in second place with four nods apiece.

The night's other big winners were Russell Crowe - best actor, and an emotional Julia Roberts who seemed to be the only person surprised by her best actress award. Benicio Del Toro was named best supporting actor (for Traffic), while Cameron Crowe walked off with the best original screenplay gong for his 70s rock fable Almost Famous. None of these awards were a travesty; yet neither were they particularly ambitious.

In an ideal world Kenneth Lonergan would have won for his script for You Can Count on Me, while the film's star Laura Linney would have edged out Roberts as best actress.

In terms of sheer acting weight, Ed Harris's performance in Pollock was surely the better of Crowe, who was so much more impressive in last year's The Insider. But having passed Russell over last year, the Academy probably wanted to make amends. This, after all, is how the Oscars are generally decided. Politics rule the day. Peace, tranquillity and goodwill finish a distant second.

fields.headline: Guardian Unlimited's alternative Oscars
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited's alternative Oscars
fields.body:
Best "We Done Good" Award
Let's be honest, this was not a vintage year for the Brits. Thus we're left raising a desultory glass to the refined Janty Yates (who knocked up the costumes for Gladiator), and harking back to the former glories of legendary cinematographer Jack Cardiff. Ah well... maybe next year.

The Gwyneth Paltrow award for the most emotional acceptance speech
It can only be Julia Roberts, whose acceptance speech was one long hyperventilation ("I love it here! I love the world!"). The trouble is that the world and his wife already knew that Jules was a shoo-in for the best actress Oscar. Her sheer shell-shocked surprise marks her out as an actress of remarkable talent.

The most ungracious loser award
On the one hand you had Kate Hudson, flashing a brittle little smile that didn't stray anywhere near her eyes. On the other you had Ridley Scott, who appeared to be chewing on an angry wasp. In the end Ridley just nips it. It takes age and experience to glower as impressively as that.

The ubiquity award
With last year's runaway winner Jack Nicholson notable by his absence, the award falls to Catherine Zeta-Jones. Despite missing out on a nomination, Zee-Jay still managed to hog centre stage outside the auditorium and then grab a seat in the front row, all but blocking out the bona-fide contenders seated behind her. Such celebrity manoeuvring requires a rare guile and genius.

The best film you've never heard of award
The ironically tagged Everybody Famous. From Belgium. Not coming soon to a cinema near you. Chances are its makers would have trouble telling you what it's about.

The James Cameron 'King of the World' award
A tough call, this. True, the producers of Gladiator managed a few gung-ho moments. But none took the stage with quite the same flourish as the venerable Dino De Laurentiis, opening up with a heavyweight-champ salute before sinking into a supremely self-aggrandising speech. Small wonder this is the man who counts Conan the Barbarian among his numerous film credits.

The where-was-your-stylist? award
Oscar 2001 was annoyingly short of style crimes this year. OK, so Ashley Judd managed a fair approximation of an ant with her scraped-back hair, while Juliette Binoche's flapper-style headgear and multiple strands of pearls that seemed to be making a bid to escape left us bemused at best. But the nod must go to dishevelled presenter Winona Ryder, whose tousled blond locks made it look as if she'd arrived after crawling through a privet hedge.

The d'oh award
No contest. Presenting the award for best original song, Goldie Hawn appeared captivated by her own ineptitude in reading her lines. Seated in the audience, daughter Kate Hudson whooped indulgently. The rest must have wished they had a few rotten eggs handy.

The you-were-robbed award
OK, so you've got Cameron Crowe's complacent, rose-tinted script for Almost Famous and Ken Lonergan's rich, textured, truthful screenplay for You Can Count on Me. Which do you hand the Oscar to? The Academy voters should take reading lessons.

The best Steve Martin gag
"The police have found a suspect in the plot to kidnap Russell Crowe," quipped the Oscar night host. "Tom Hanks, you should be ashamed of yourself." A funny line, and weirdly prophetic - Hanks did indeed go on to lose out to his Gladiator rival. Had Crowe been chained up somewhere, the night might have panned out rather differently.

The worst Steve Martin gag
A ribald line about Russell Crowe "hitting on" sixty-something nominee Ellen Burstyn went down like the veritable lead balloon. Crowe's face radiated such thunder that one worried that Martin was about to be asked outside.

webTitle: Gladiator defeats Crouching Tiger in a close fight

fields.headline: Gladiator defeats Crouching Tiger in a close fight
fields.standfirst:
Oscars 2001: full coverage
Picture gallery: all the winners
fields.trailText:
Oscars 2001: full coverage
Picture gallery: all the winners
fields.body:
Gladiator, the Roman epic directed by British director Ridley Scott, took the best picture Oscar in Los Angeles, thus winning a tussle with Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. The film picked up a total of five Oscars to Crouching Tiger's four on a night when most of the favourites won.

Steven Soderbergh, nominated as best director for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich, won for the former and offered his thanks to "anyone who spends part of their day creating", adding that life would be "unliveable without art."

Julia Roberts, the hottest favourite in any category, duly won the best actress award for playing Erin Brockovich and in an effusive speech thanked "everyone I've ever met in my life... I love the world."

Russell Crowe took the best actor Oscar for his part in, and as, Gladiator. He said that the award represented the fulfilment of a dream that, for someone who grew up in the suburbs, must seem "vaguely ludicrous." He added: "for anybody who's on the downside of advantage and relying purely on courage - it's possible."

The first surprise of the evening came when Marcia Gay Harden won the best supporting actress award for her much acclaimed performance in Pollock, the film about painter Jackson Pollock. Kate Hudson had been heavily tipped for her role in Almost Famous. British actors Dame Judi Dench and Julie Walters, who were both present in the Shrine, had also been nominated.

Benicio Del Toro won best supporting actor as predicted in the category in which Albert Finney was also nominated for his Erin Brockovich role, Finney's fifth academy award nomination. Cameron Crowe won the prize for best original screenplay for Almost Famous, while Stephen Gaghan won the best adapted screenplay award for his work on Traffic from the original British television series.

The producer of Gladiator, Douglas Wick, paid tribute to Ridley Scott as embodying the old Noel Coward song "Mad dogs and Englishmen."

On the fashion front, commentators decided that this year orange was the new black but that "nature's fabric" - better known as skin - was the most striking item on display.

Bjork, nominated for best song, said outside the ceremony that acting was "great to try" but she still preferred music. She wore a spectacular swan dress and sang her nominated song from Dancer in the Dark. But it was Bob Dylan who won the award for original song for Things Have Changed in the Michael Douglas film Wonder Boys. He accepted the award by satellite while on tour in Australia.

There was an honorary Oscar for the Yarmouth-born Jack Cardiff, the 84-year-old British cinematographer who won an Oscar back in 1947 for Black Narcissus. Starting as a child actor, he went on to work both as director of photography (on The Red Shoes, Fanny, The African Queen, The Vikings, War and Peace) and as director (Sons and Lovers, Girl on a Motorcycle). It was the first time that an honorary award had been given to a cinematographer and after receiving it from Dustin Hoffman and a standing ovation from the audience, Cardiff said: "This one tonight is a biggie... I'm not dreaming but it's mighty close."

Producer Dino De Laurentiis won the Irving Thalberg Award for his lifetime's work, receiving his award from Sir Anthony Hopkins. Best documentary went to Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport.

Russell Crowe appeared unworried by all the kidnap rumours surrounding him and Steve Martin got one of the loudest laughs of the night by suggesting that the FBI had named Tom Hanks as a chief suspect. Hanks obligingly hammed up a look of due shame.

Outside, the crowds had been queuing since Wednesday for a chance to sit on one of the 400 free seats adjoining the red carpet. They were rewarded with high-fives from an exuberant Joaquin Phoenix as he arrived.

One fan, Tina Hernandez, had hoped that Wilson, the basketball with whom Tom Hanks conversed in Cast Away, would win best supporting actor. Like a lot of things last night, it was not to be.

The 73rd academy awards ceremony, the last that will take place at the Shrine, was over. It was time for the guests to tuck into the caviar and roasted veal at the Governor's party or head across town for the post-Oscar parties.

webTitle: Review: The Story of Spanish Football

fields.headline: Morbo: The Story of Spanish Football by Phil Ball (London: WSC Books, 2001)
fields.trailText: Sid Lowe on how Phil Ball's lively combination of history, politics, analysis and anecdotes does much to get under the skin of Spanish football.
fields.body:
Never mind the bullocks, here's the fútbol. After the gallons of ink that have been spilt over bullfighting, Spain's real passion has finally been recognised in Phil Ball's entertaining book, Morbo: The Story of Spanish Football - a lively combination of history, politics, analysis and anecdotes.

Most of the stories hinge on "morbo", a word which defies easy translation. It's not exactly rivalry, it's more the stuff that fuels it - edge, perhaps. Or needle. The thing about morbo, says Ball, is that it never dies. Instead, it grows ever bigger - each encounter adds yet more morbo. Paul Gascoigne's flute playing in an Old Firm game is a good example of the phenomenon, suggests Ball - Spaniards immediately understood it as a classic act of morbo.

For Ball, morbo is rooted in Spain's extensive regionalism; in the different cultures, politics and identities of the Iberian peninsula. The importance of local, regional, and national identity for Spain's football clubs goes far beyond anything in England - Athletic aren't just Bilbao's team, they're the Basque national side, while Barcelona represent the nation of Catalonia (although Real Sociedad and Espanyol fans would certainly have a thing or two to say about that). Real Madrid, meanwhile, are a powerful symbol of centralism, and of Spanish nationalism against the independence of the periphery.

Real Madrid versus Barcelona is, of course, the classic case of morbo, invested with a political significance greater than any match in the world. The two clubs' experiences are intimately tied to Spain's twentieth-century history, and they emerged from the civil war and the Franco dictatorship - or so it seemed to many - with fundamentally opposed, totally irreconcilable identities: Madrid as the friends of fascism and the pet of the Franco régime; Barça as the embodiment of liberty and democracy.

These "identities" are deeply flawed, of course, and Ball's chapters on Barça and Real come as a timely corrective to Jimmy Burns' book "Barça: A People's Passion". Impressively researched though Burns's book was, it accepted these characterisations at face value. Indeed, it might as well, says Ball (and he is right), have been called "Barça good, Madrid bad".

Ball is more convincing. He highlights some of the ways in which Real Madrid's success was utilised by Franco, and those occasions when the régime did indeed interfere to tilt the balance in Real's favour. But he rejects that favourite Barça allegation that the success of Madrid was built solely upon coercion, and pokes fun at the culés' triumphalist self-perception. "Barça fans labour under the touchingly innocent belief," he says, "that everyone else in the world is happy to accept that their club is quite simply the bees' knees."

The Big Two aren't the only ones more realistically re-evaluated. Ball also explains how Athletic Bilbao's exclusively Basque tradition has only been maintained at the expense of the other clubs in Euskadi, which can no longer pursue such a policy and are more than a little aggrieved by Bilbao's monopolisation of Basqueness. And anyway, reveals Ball, back in 1901 Bilbao's vice-captain was an Englishman called Alfredo (Alfred?) Mills. So much for a Basque-only history.

As well as chapters on Barça, Real and the Basque Country, Ball visits Recreativo Huelva - the oldest club in Spain - and Seville, where the morbo between Betis and Sevilla hinges not on regional identity, but social class (something which is also true of Real, Atlético, and Rayo Vallecano in Madrid). There's also an entertaining summary of the external symbols of football identity in Spain, and a brief history of the national side. Many of the fault lines here also opened up along regional boundaries - not least under Javier Clemente, whose favouritism towards Basques particularly riled the centrist football paper Marca.

Morbo is an excellent account of Spanish football - the opening chapter in particular is a superb introduction to the game. It's nicely written, entertaining and insightful, but sometimes you wish Ball would go that little bit further (especially during his brief trip to Seville, where you sense his own disappointment at not personally encountering the morbo that undoubtedly exists). There's disappointingly little on the current champions Deportivo La Coruña and Champions League finalists Valencia, and it would also have been interesting to have included some other incidents of morbo. Like Asturias, for example: when Oviedo play in Gijón, their fans travel in blue workman's helmets. Not because they're Village People fanatics, either - this curious attire is an unfortunate necessity as the riot-police march fans from the station to the ground, a mile or so way, under a shower of bricks, bottles and stones.

Perhaps most importantly, Ball doesn't really do justice to one of the most striking indications of Real Madrid and Barcelona's centrality. "In some areas Real Madrid are warmly welcomed", he says (in others, it's Barça), but he doesn't take this observation quite far enough. Just about every football fan in Spain, however much they love their own club, has an in-built preference for one of the Big Two. This is one of the most interesting manifestations of the relationship in Spain between football, politics, identity and (attitudes towards) regionalism, but it remains peripheral to the book. Examining this would have further underlined the extraordinary morbo-quotient of the Barça-Real clash which, as Ball impressively demonstrates, has never been just a game.

fields.headline: Mirror editor denies Goldman talk
fields.trailText:
3pm update: Mirror editor Piers Morgan has denied speculation that Jane Goldman is to take over as TV critic on the paper, writes Jessica Hodgson.

Mar 26: Goldman tipped for Mirror job

Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express
fields.body:
Mirror editor Piers Morgan has dismissed office talk that Jonathan Ross's wife Jane Goldman is a hot favourite to take over from Charlie Catchpole as TV critic on the paper.

Senior insiders said her name was discussed as a possible successor to Mr Catchpole, who is quitting to join the Express.

However, Mr Morgan told MediaGuardian.co.uk that Ms Goldman wasn't in the running for the job.

"Jane Goldman has never and will never be considered for the job," said Mr Morgan.

fields.headline: Labour backbenchers support May election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Election countdown
fields.trailText: A rearguard action to keep May 3 open as a possible election date was launched today, with the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party urging the prime minister to go for the widely-predicted date.
fields.body:
A rearguard action to keep May 3 open as a possible election date was launched today, with the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party urging the prime minister to go for the widely-predicted date.

Clive Soley, who - as chairman of the PLP - speaks on behalf of the government's backbenchers, has told Mr Blair that 70% of the PLP still wants a May poll, despite the restrictions imposed by the foot and mouth epidemic.

According to Mr Soley, just 10% of Labour members, mostly from rural constituencies, want a postponement.

The move comes as Britain's two leading tabloids, the Sun and the Mirror, both splashed their front pages with calls for the election to go ahead as planned in just over five weeks time.

They claim - echoing the government's line to date on the local elections - that to cancel them would send out the message the Britain is closed for business, further crippling the already struggling tourism business.

Mr Soley, who is charged with informing the PM of backbenchers views, said: "The whole feeling was that calling off elections - and remember the local elections term is set - would be a very serious thing to do. It is in the interests of our political opponents to drag it out.

"The wider interest of the country is that we should not make our tourist industry suffer, we should not send out a very clear signal to the rest of the world that Britain is closed down, because it isn't and it won't be, and we have to have some degree of normal life continuing."

He added that he was confident that the prime minister would still opt for a May 3 date at the end of his ten-day window of opportunity.

The Conservatives are still calling for a delay in any contest, with the former prime minister, John Major querying how Mr Blair can devote his full energies to the government's response to the foot and mouth crisis while masterminding an election campaign.

Today the Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "How can you get a grip on a national crisis if you are in the middle of fighting an election? The two don't go together."

fields.headline: Voting by post
fields.standfirst:
With Tony Blair showing no sign of dropping his intention to call a general election on May 3, people in rural Britain could face problems getting to polling stations due to the foot and mouth crisis. The government believes postal votes will solve the problem. So how do you get one? Matthew Tempest explains
Special report: Election countdown
fields.trailText: March 26: With Tony Blair still planning to call a general election on May 3, people in rural Britain could have to vote by post due to the foot and mouth crisis. So how do you get one?
fields.body:
Isn't postal voting really complicated to organise?
Not any more. Until last month, people who wished to vote by post had to give a special reason to qualify - most postal voters were travelling salesmen, the disabled and ex-pats living abroad. Now the government has dropped the need for a reason - opening up postal votes to all voters.

So how do I go about voting by post?
First of all, like all voters, you must be on the electoral roll. This is held at your local council. Under new rules brought in to simplify things, you can now register with your local council at any time during the year on their rolling register, or find out more on the internet at rollingregistration.co.uk. But be quick - it takes two to seven weeks to process your details before you're registered to vote.

Then to register for a postal vote, either get the form from your local council electoral register office or by filling in the form at postalvotes.co.uk. When a general election is called, forms will also appear in the national press.

How long does a postal vote last for?
There are three types of postal vote available. Firstly, a one-off postal vote. If you want to vote this way, you must get your form into the electoral registration office at least six working days before the election.

Secondly, a fixed-term postal vote. This is available for a set period such as a year (for example, if you are working abroad for 12 months), or three years (suited to students who are starting a university course away from home but still want to vote in their home constituency.)

Lastly, a permanent postal vote. Specify that you want the arrangement to be fixed, and you can vote by post for as long as you like. To end the arrangement, contact your local council.

Once registered for a local elections, what happens next?
When an election - either general or local - is called, you will be sent a vote form, with a pre-paid return envelope. Put your cross in the box and send it back. Simple. Except if you're living abroad - then you'll have to pay for your own postage, and allow longer for the post to arrive.

Do I get confirmation that my vote has arrived?
No. But if you leave it too late to post, you can just hand it in on the day.

What if my vote arrives after election day?
Unfortunately, it won't count. Be better organised next time.

Are postal votes confidential?
Yes. They are mixed in with all the other vote papers.

Any other ways of voting?
At the moment, you cannot vote on the internet, although the Home Office is studying proposals on how to organise web voting. Until then you could of course turn up in person at your local polling station on election day, and vote in person.

open.gov.uk

fields.headline: Medical schools in disrepute
fields.standfirst: Almost half the medicine students at the University of Toronto say they have participated in inappropriate clinical procedures, says Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Almost half the medicine students at the University of Toronto say they have participated in inappropriate clinical procedures, says Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
Recent revelations that almost half of the medical students at one of the country's top universities felt pressured to perform unnecessary pelvic exams on unconscious women and other unethical procedures has scandalised many Canadians.

A study, done at the University of Toronto and published in the British Medical Journal last week, provided a disturbing glimpse into life behind the scenes at teaching hospitals.

It found that 47% of students had felt they had no choice but to practice unnecessary procedures on comatose or unconscious patients or had been in other clinical situations that made them uncomfortable.

Some reported being left to close wounds when they didn't know how, or being asked to lead psychotherapy sessions alone when they didn't have proper training.

More than 60% reported watching their teachers behave in an unethical fashion, including secretly given a woman who wanted a drug-free labour and delivery intravenous narcotics.

But while members of the public may have been surprised by the findings, which was front-page news, members of the medical profession say it has been part of the hierarchical culture of hospitals for years, not just in Canada, but in the United States and the United Kingdom as well.

"This not just the University of Toronto. This is not just Canada. This is something most teaching hospitals have to deal with," said Margaret Somerville, a medical ethicist at Montreal's McGill University.

An accompanying article in the British Medical Journal by two British doctors makes the same point.

"A while ago the practice of students performing vaginal or rectal examinations on anaesthetised patients who had not been given proper consent was discussed in the literature and condemned, but it still continues."

David Roberton, the Canadian sociologist who helped prepare the study, says it is difficult for medical students to stand up to doctors, who act as their mentors and are also responsible for evaluating their performance. He and four doctors carried out the survey three years ago.

Since then, the University of Toronto has implemented several changes to rectify the situations, says Richard Frecker, associate dean of medicine.

Students now take an ethics course, where they are taught they should question a doctor if they are uncomfortable about what they have been asked to do. Physicians have also been reminded that they must get informed consent from their patients for all procedures that may be performed by the medical team.

Experts say the problem is that many doctors still view patients as objects or teaching tools, although the problem was much worse 15 or 20 years ago. In 1984, for example, a faculty member of Queen's University in Ontario pleaded guilty after requiring students to do unnecessary rectal exams on mentally handicapped boys.

Universities across the country concede they are not immune to the problems that were uncovered at the University of Toronto. There have been calls for new ethical codes that define the rights of patients at teaching hospitals.

The Royal London School of Medicine and Dentistry has implemented such a policy, which defines what is expected of medical students and their teachers when dealing with patients.

fields.headline: Running in father's footsteps
fields.trailText: Carl Barrowclough was handed the chance to follow in his father's footsteps yesterday and made his mark within minutes.
fields.body:
Carl Barrowclough was handed the chance to follow in his father's footsteps yesterday and made his mark within minutes.

The 19-year-old son of the former Barnsley and Newcastle winger Stewart Barrowclough emerged for his debut from the bench on 71 minutes and, 120 seconds later, he found himself being saluted by the Oakwell faithful when his surging run into the penalty area won the Tykes a crucial penalty.

With the game perfectly poised at 1-1, the tricky Barrowclough was felled by Marcus Browning and Neil Shipperley promptly obliged from 12 yards for his 13th goal of the season.

It was an amazing introduction to first-team football for the Barnsley-born youngster whose dad made 219 appearances for Newcastle United in the 70s.

In many ways, that huge turning point almost overshadowed the fact that the born-again Christian Bruce Dyer helped himself to another double to take his recent haul to seven goals in five games.

Dyer, who is still stalling on the offer of a new contract at Oakwell, has been in devastating form since the arrival of manager Nigel Spackman.

He scored his first on nine minutes, steering home Isaiah Rankin's right-wing cross, and sealed the victory seven minutes from time when he crept in on the blind side to volley home Lee Jones's delivery.

"The ball is in Bruce's court," Spackman said, "and we hope that he is happy here and enjoying his football."

Perhaps more importantly, Spackman reckons his side are now safe from any relegation fears. "That's 50 points and it should be enough," he said.

"My main aim when I took over was to keep the club up, and now we have reached that total I believe we should stay up, but today's was not our best performance."

Indeed, the scoreline flattered Barnsley, who were troubled throughout by the gallant Gills. All the same, it was the Yorkshire outfit's sixth win in seven games and that has to be a huge relief for Spackman.

"All credit to the players," he added. "I think we have achieved that safety target quite quickly and everyone has worked very hard to get there.

"We still want to finish as high as possible, but we can relax a bit now and look to build a stronger squad for next season.

"I may even decide to hand a few more youngsters a chance in the first team."

Marlon King's perfectly executed header from Browning's cross levelled matters on 23 minutes, but Kevin Miller was in sparkling form and pulled off three stunning saves.

"I thought we did enough to get something out of the game," admitted the Gills player-manager Andy Hessenthaler. "But we didn't perform to our capabilities, which was disappointing.

"The game could have gone either way and I didn't think their second goal should have been a penalty. Both my players are saying they didn't touch the player. If the referee didn't give it who knows what might have happened?

"I don't think we are safe yet, but 50 points should be enough for us."

Miller, who was a team- mate of Hessenthaler at Watford, denied Gillingham on a number of occasions. But his flying save from King after seven minutes was the pick of the bunch.

Iffy Onuora's right-wing cross was met by King, whose powerful header had seemed destined for goal. Miller, however, had other ideas, and his reflex stop low to his left was outstanding.

fields.headline: Waste transport fuels anti-nuclear protest
fields.standfirst: 'Germany's biggest security operation since the war' is in place to protect six shipments of nuclear refuse coming from France, says Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: 'Germany's biggest security operation since the war' is in place to protect six shipments of nuclear refuse coming from France, says Kate Connolly in Berlin.
fields.body:
An estimated 15,000 protesters are gathered today in northern Germany to block the transport of reprocessed nuclear waste from France.

The train carrying six vast containers of waste left Valognes in northern France at dawn today and is expected to arrive at the German border between 7pm and 11pm GMT tonight.

Up to 30,000 police officers from around the country have been drafted in to protect the shipments, with water cannons and tear gas at the ready, in what has been described as Germany's biggest security operation since the war. They are lined up along the route of the transport which ends its journey at the salt mines of Gorleben in northern Germany, which for years has been Germany's nuclear dumping ground.

Yesterday concrete blocks were thrown across the railway line, with protesters staging sit-ins at various points en route. Over the past few weeks core members of the protest group have attempted to sabotage rails and overhead power cables in an attempt to disrupt the transport. Last week the Berlin offices of German rail were laid to waste by militant activists with 20 firebombs.

But demonstrators have said their biggest protest action will take place in the town of Dannenberg, over Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. At Dannenberg the waste is due to be unloaded onto flatbed lorries and taken by road to Gorleben.

Locals from Gorleben make up a significant proportion of the anti-nuclear protesters who have come from all over Europe and include a strong lobby of local farmers who have said they are prepared to use force. Yesterday they staged a tractor convoy, which came on the back of a major demonstration which was went off peacefully in the town of Lüneburg on Saturday.

Both police and demonstrators are braced for a repeat of clashes four years ago when scores of people were injured. Then, protesters terrified the police protecting the transport by distributing leaflets which linked radiation to impotence.

This year's anti-nuclear protest, the first to be held under a government which includes the Greens, has greatly embarrassed and vexed the Green party which has its roots in the anti-nuclear movement. Despite ecological issues currently being at the top of the agenda in Germany, the Greens fared extremely badly in regional elections this weekend.

The protests are a further headache for the Greens and risks splitting the party. Green environment minister Jürgen Trittin has permitted the transports and is part of the government that will order a break-up of the protest. Protesters have dubbed him the "Judas from Berlin".

A hard-fought deal secured last year between the government and the power industry which would phase out all German reactors in the next 20 years is dependent on the waste being brought back into Germany.

Energy chiefs have warned that the protest is in danger of derailing the deal. The newly-elected joint leader of the Greens, Claudia Roth, addressed protesters on Saturday stressing Germany's moral duty to accept the waste.

The waste was generated by Germany's 16 nuclear power plants and sent to France for reprocessing. Shipments to Germany were suspended three years ago under the government of Helmut Kohl due to safety concerns. But after safety rules were tightened, the present Socialist Green coalition government agreed to resume them.

Before it crosses the border into Germany tonight, the waste transport will be disinfected to prevent it from carrying foot and mouth disease into the country.

fields.headline: BBC1 lines up computer Jesus for £253m spring schedule
fields.trailText:
2pm update: A computer-generated image of Jesus has been created by the BBC for a new programme about the life of Christ.

Mar 26: EastEnders star lands drama role

Mar 26: BBC1's £253m spring/summer schedule
fields.body:
A computer-generated image of what Jesus may have looked like has been created by the BBC for a new programme about the life of Christ.

The documentary series on BBC1, Son of God, uses the latest scientific technology to bring the story of Jesus Christ to life.

Detailed historical research aided by computer graphics reconstruct the life and times of Christ and re-examine some of the traditional Christian stories.

The programme is part of the channel's £253m spring and summer season, which was announced today.

"Son of God is one of the most exciting projects with which to launch the spring summer season," said Lorraine Heggessey, controller of BBC1.

"In some ways it is the epitome of my new BBC1 - it is accessible, modern in its approach and it is not afraid to challenge some cast-in-stone beliefs about what makes a mainstream popular programme.

"It also harnesses the strengths of the BBC in computer technology, strong journalism and landmark programming, dares to ask some surprising questions of the traditional Christian stories and comes up with some unexpected conclusions."

Related stories

webTitle: NHS avoids repeat of the winter crisis

fields.headline: NHS avoids repeat of the winter crisis
fields.trailText: Hospitals experienced a massive increase in admissions over the winter but staff coped more effectively with demand than last year, according to a government report. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Hospitals experienced a massive increase in admissions over the winter but staff coped more effectively with demand, according to a government report.

The NHS avoided a repeat of last year's winter crisis partly because there was no serious outbreak of flu - thanks to a 40% increase in the number of people vaccinated.

Good joint working between health and social care and the extension of NHS Direct also contributed towards effective management of demand.

The report, by NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp, published last week, compared the pressure on the NHS and social services during a 22-day period over Christmas and the New Year this year with the same period a year earlier.

Mr Crisp found that, despite low levels of flu, the NHS was just as busy as in previous years and even busier at times. On 18 of the 22 days this year, there were more admissions to hospitals than in the same period last year. On 15 days, more people went to accident and emergency departments, while on 14 days there were more 999 calls.

Overall, during 14 of the 17 weeks between November 200 and February, there were more emergency admissions this year than last year.

Despite this, there was a 75% reduction in the number of patients waiting more than 12 hours for admission to hospital.

The amount of cases where hospitals had to transfer critically ill patients for non-clinical reasons also fell by 19%.

However, more than 10m people received flu vaccinations, including nearly two-thirds (65%) of people aged over 65. This meant that fewer people in this age group had flu than in the population as a whole.

NHS Direct dealt with more than 1.23m calls since December, including 20,000 on Christmas Eve - its busiest day ever. The helpline gave 30% of callers self-care advice. This led to there being fewer NHS beds blocked by patients who could not receive adequate treatment elsewhere.

NHS capacity also rose, with an increase of 1,337 general and acute beds, 900 intermediate care beds, 523 critical care beds and 77 high dependency beds. There was also greater use of spare capacity in the private sector, with more than 10,000 operations paid for by £20m given to health authorities in November.

However, the report still identified several winter planning problems. It warned that too many patients still have their operations cancelled on the day of surgery; that there were significant shortages of nursing homes in some parts of the country and that staff immunisation was patchy in areas.

Mr Crisp called for more research into the causes of emergency admissions and better planning to reduce the number of patients waiting "shorter but still unacceptable lengths of times for admission".

Nevertheless, prime minister Tony Blair, speaking at the Royal College of General Practitioners last Monday, praised NHS staff for the "huge amount of personal effort and commitment" they made to avoid a winter crisis.

"Despite the notion that this year was somehow far easier than last year, on the contrary the pressures were every bit as great, if not greater," he said.

However, he admitted that some hospitals had struggled to cope.

"There have been particular hot spots around the country. Staff shortages are a particular problem in certain areas, and if you are one of those patients who did wait too long, or you had your operation cancelled, then of course it is no consolation to you to know that the majority of people were not in that position."

This led to there being fewer NHS beds blocked by patients who could not receive adequate treatment elsewhere. NHS capacity also rose, with an increase of 1,337 general and acute beds, 900 intermediate care beds, 523 critical care beds and 77 high dependency beds. There was also greater use of spare capacity in the private sector, with more than 10,000 operations paid for by £20m given to health authorities in November. However, the report still identified several winter planning problems. It warned that too many patients still have their operations cancelled on the day of surgery; that there were significant shortages of nursing homes in some parts of the country and that staff immunisation was patchy in areas. Mr Crisp called for more research into the causes of emergency admissions and better planning to reduce the number of patients waiting "shorter but still unacceptable lengths of times for admission". Nevertheless, prime minister Tony Blair, speaking at the Royal College of General Practitioners last Monday, praised NHS staff for the "huge amount of personal effort and commitment" they made to avoid a winter crisis. "Despite the notion that this year was somehow far easier than last year, on the contrary the pressures were every bit as great, if not greater," he said. However, he admitted that some hospitals had struggled to cope. "There have been particular hot spots around the country. Staff shortages are a particular problem in certain areas, and if you are one of those patients who did wait too long, or you had your operation cancelled, then of course it is no consolation to you to know that the majority of people were not in that position."

fields.headline: Geldof jumps out of deckchair with £100,000 windfall
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: Bob Geldof, will pick up £100,000 a year after selling online travel company deckchair.com in a £10m deal, writes Wale Azeez.

Feb 27: Deckchair axes staff
fields.body:
Bob Geldof, will pick up £100,000 a year after selling his online travel company deckchair.com to World Travel Holdings in a £10m deal.

But he laughed off the windfall, claiming it was a "giveaway price" for such a "fabulous" company.

Under today's deal Geldof will pocket £100,000 a year until the end of 2003 for continued promotions and consultancy with the company

Deckchair has been sold for £3.2m, but Geldof and its other shareholders will be paid a further consideration of up to £6m depending on the future performance of the company, according to a World Travel Holdings spokesman.

"The logic of the deal was that World Travel Holdings has really great travel and call centres; we've got the name and the customers. They have got the guns, we have got the numbers and the marketing," Geldof said of the sale.

"It's a very good marriage and when we realised that was going to be the case that is when we started laying off the technical people.

The former popstar turned internet entrepreneur will stay on as a figurehead at the company to promote the site around the world.

"As for getting £100,000 for being fabulous. I think it is an absolute giveaway price."

Geldof's sale of Deckchair coincides with the closure another internet company his invested in.

Wapworld, a mobile portal in which his broadcasting company 10 Alps has a 4% stake, has closed its web and wireless internet phone services, as it struggles to find second round funding.

Today's deal comes a month after Deckchair cut a quarter of its workforce as part of a "streamlining" process.

Thirteen staff were axed from the IT department of the former Boomtown Rat's website.

After today's deal, World Travel - which is valued at around the same amount as Deckchair - will add Deckchair's 250,000 users to its own 85,000.

Deckchair's name will remain and will be launched in North America, Asia and Europe.

Following the tie-up, World Travel will own 90% or more of Deckchair, which in addition to the travel website includes London travel agency Soho Travel and traveller information provider Kasbah.com.

Deckchair's shareholders will pick up £3.2m in World Travel shares and options, while the remaining £6m will be a deferred payment based on Deckchair's performance over three years.

Sir Bob will join the board of World Travel as non-executive director and part of his duties will be marketing the group's businesses.

webTitle: You bet your life: week 30, the expert's view

fields.headline: You bet your life: week 30, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: With two of our punters winning, new Blue Square expert the Camel is reasonably impressed. For a change. Check last week's bets here
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £155.54
Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £48.46
Sean Ingle = £19.82
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £155.54
Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £48.46
Sean Ingle = £19.82

Scott Murray: England v Finland - Finland to win £5 @ 10/1

Sometimes it's hard being a disciplined value scout in the never-ending battle with the bookmaker. You find a bet which has everything in its favour, see it prosper for at least half a match and then flounder near the end.

Bookmakers know that most punters bet the way they want a result to finish. Most punters want England to win, and back their hopes at whatever price the bookmaker chooses to offer. Therefore England and often the more glamourous clubs in the Premiership are rarely a good betting proposition, as the bookmaker knows he will take plenty of money on them, regardless of the price.

To balance the book, the bookie will often offer generous prices about England's opponents. In searching for value bets during a weekend of international football, a close look at England's foes will often pay dividends. In this instance Finland at 10/1 were undoubtedly value. No one can realistically argue that a team packed with quality players, who ply their trade in England and on the continent could possibly have only a 9% chance of winning this fixture against an England team whose victory over Spain had been glorified to such an extent, some sections of the press would have us believe they had a chance of winning the World Cup.

The hoards of punters who lumped their money on England at odds of 2/9 can celebrate this time. Although how they felt when Jari Litmanen bore down on goal with seconds remaining is a matter they will try to forget. When you make selections such as this you will back a lot of losers, but you are also likely to win money in the long run. It takes a lot of 2/9 winners to compensate for one loser, while when you back a winner at odds of around 10/1, you can really celebrate in style.

The Prince of Punts: England v Finland - Draw half time/England to win full time £10 @ 4/1

I am going to have to do some research in the very near future. As I intimated last week, half time/full time betting is not usually the first thing I look for when I reach for my Racing Post on a Saturday morning.

But, backing heavy favourites to be drawing at half time and winning at the final whistle does seem to have some merit, especially at 4/1. England/England at 4/7 is clearly no value, and when the game means so much to both teams, the underdog will often perform with dogged defence for long periods before they are breached. If I had to back England for this match, this is the market I would have looked at.

A good bet by the Prince for sure (although this is the first time I've been able to say that!) and a nice payout. Well done.

Richo: Cyprus v Republic of Ireland - Four or more goals in the match £15 @ 15/8

A strange selection methinks. You won, but that doesn't mean you had a value bet. Personally, I couldn't quite see the logic behind this choice. I would agree Cyprus are a tough proposition at home, but criticising the Irish defence was somewhat baffling. They have averaged conceding just a single goal per game during the last six outings, and this included tough trips to Portugal and Holland.

The Cyprus rearguard is certainly creaky, but the question I would have needed to answer before betting on four or more goals in this game was just how many times can I expect the Irish strikers to prosper here.

The supposed minnows of European football no longer lay down before teams from more recognised countries, and defeats by six and more goals are a rarity these days. Personally, I would have foreseen Ireland trying to score one or two goals and sitting on the lead and trying to hit Cyprus on the break. I was wrong, but I still think this bet wasn't value.

Sean Ingle: £5 double: Luxembourg v Faroe Islands: Faroe Islands to win @ 11/8 and Armenia v Wales: Wales to win @ 6/4

I am impressed. Week after week the bookmakers bank accounts are swollen from punters who are trying to pick 10 or 15 winners at short odds for one good priced accumulator. Yet with alarming regularity one of these supposed "good things" fails to deliver, and leaves the sorry punter with a tale to tell in the boozer.

Picking one good value single is far preferable, and much more likely to give you a winning return. I know you finally settled on a double, but your thinking was along the right lines.

Opposing the teams with big reputations but poor recent form, in your case Russia and Norway, often provide great value bets.

But you steered clear of those two, offering Wales and Faroe Islands as a double. Now, I'm sure my colleague Patrick Murray told you of the pitfalls of doing multiple bets rather than singles. The bookmakers edge is multiplied and finding more than one value bet is extremely difficult. I am no expert on the current state of Luxembourg and Armenian football so I can't pass comment on the validity of your selections. Although when the minnows of European football meet, the results tend to be too random for my taste and I try to avoid these games for punting purposes.

The results of your selections were one winner, one loser. Does this suggest two singles might have been a better alternative?

fields.headline: Bauer women's title launches next week
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Publisher H Bauer has revealed its new fortnightly women's magazine will launch on April 3 with the title Real, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
After months of secrecy, publishing giant H Bauer has finally revealed its new fortnightly women's magazine will launch on April 3 with the title Real.

In a sign that it has high ambitions for the magazine, H Bauer has said Real will launch with a print run of 900,000.

The launch is being backed by a £10m marketing campaign that will include a national television and poster blitz through Real's advertising agency, Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy.

Real is the first glossy women's magazine to be launched as a fortnightly in the UK.

It is modelled on the hugely successful German magazine Brigitta, which sells more than 900,000 copies a fortnight.

H Bauer said the magazine will not compete directly with any existing UK magazines but will be aimed at Daily Mail-reading 25 to 45-year-old women.

It will be launch edited by former That's Life editor Janice Turner.

Real has been shrouded in secrecy during its development, operating under the code name Project Helena.

The Real office at H Bauer has until now been sealed off from the rest of the building to keep the details of the launch from its competitors.

fields.headline: And the winner is...
fields.standfirst:
The best quotes from the night
Oscars 2001: full coverage Picture gallery: all the winners
fields.trailText: Quotes from the night
fields.body:
"During my out-of-body experience earlier tonight, I didn't acknowledge her, shamefully. And really, she is the centre of the universe which was our movie . . . So, with great humility, I acknowledge her profusely."
Best actress winner Julia Roberts on the real Erin Brockovich

"Put down that stick, I'm going to be here for a while . . . I love it up here! I love the world! I'm so happy, thank you . . . A girl's got to have her moment. Everybody tries to get me to shut up. It didn't work with my parents and it didn't work now." Julia Roberts rebels against the 45-second limit on acceptance speeches

"Thank you, Academy, for this special recognition for non-English movies."
Best foreign-language film director Ang Lee brings some dignity to the occasion

"My music is to dream without boundaries. Tonight, with you, I see boundaries being crossed. As a classic musical composer, I am thrilled to be honoured here."
Tan Dun, winner of the best original score Oscar for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

"I want to thank the members of the Academy who were bold enough to give me this award for this song, which, obviously, is a song that doesn't pussyfoot around or turn a blind eye to human nature. God bless you all with peace, tranquillity and good will. Thanks."
Bob Dylan accepting the best original song Oscar for Things Have Changed, from Wonder Boys

"It's nice to see Bob Dylan from Australia - an 18-hour time difference - which is normal for Bob."
Steve Martin

"If they say, 'I don't like your movie,' it's kind of like saying, 'I didn't like your life.' And then they say, 'By the way, it was a little too long.'"
Cameron Crowe, best original screenplay winner for the semi-autobiographical Almost Famous

"I won and I get to scream and jump a little. But I got to go back to work tomorrow.''
Traffic co-star and best supporting actor Benicio Del Toro.

"You know, I swore that if I ever won an Oscar, that I would say thank you to all the waiters and waitresses who used to cover my shift for me so I could run downtown on the subway and audition. I wish I'd said something to the waiters."
Best supporting actress Oscar winner Marcia Gay Harden.

"Julia Roberts told me the other day that she admired me. How do you think I'm feeling right now?'
' Gladiator composer Hans Zimmer.

"She says tomorrow's another day and you're going to be looking for another job.''
Almost Famous best supporting actress nominee Kate Hudson on the advice she received from her mother, Oscar winner Goldie Hawn.

"Suddenly, going to work tomorrow doesn't seem like such a good idea.''
Steven Soderbergh on winning the best director Academy Award for Traffic.

"I love the world. I'm so happy. Thank you.''
Julia Roberts onstage accepting her the best actress Oscar for Erin Brockovich.

"I want to thank the members of the Academy who were bold enough to give me this award for this song which, obviously, is a song that doesn't pussyfoot around or turn a blind eye to human nature. God bless you all with peace, tranquility and good will. Thanks.''
Bob Dylan on accepting the Oscar for best original song for Things Have Changed, from Wonder Boys.

"By the way, be sure to stay tuned for the whole show because at the end of the night we are going to vote somebody out of show business.''
Host Steve Martin.

"If they say, 'I don't like your movie,' it's kind of like saying, 'I didn't like your life.' And then they say, 'By the way, it was a little too long.'''
Cameron Crowe, best original screenplay nominee for Almost Famous, when asked about the possibility of losing for the 1970s rock epic, based partially on his life as a teen journalist.

"Thank you. Well, thank you Academy for this special recognition for non-English movies.''

Director Ang Lee on accepting the best foreign language film Oscar for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon sounds like something Siegfried and Roy do on vacation.'' Steve Martin.

"I saw the trailer for Dude, Where's My Car? and it ruined it for me. Maybe that's not fair because I had read the book.''
Steve Martin.

"I learned on my own face, that's why I look like this.''

Rick Baker, Oscar-winning make-up artist for Dr Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas, when asked how he learned his craft.

"Where's the Oscar? For God's sake, don't take him anywhere.''
Cinematographer Jack Cardiff receiving an honorary Academy Award. Presenter Dustin Hoffman had put the statuette to one side as Cardiff prepared to speak.

"My music is to dream without boundaries. Tonight, with you, I see boundaries being crossed. As a classic musical composer, I am thrilled to be honoured here."
Tan Dun on winning the best original score Oscar for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

"If anyone said when we were doing the film, you'll be nominated for an Oscar, I would have said 'No'. I would have told them 'You must be talking about someone else'.'' Billy Elliott actress Julie Walters.

webTitle: Smith bounces back to push Rangers deeper into their hole

fields.headline: Smith bounces back to push Rangers deeper into their hole
fields.trailText: A total of five goals in eight seasons suggests that the idea of the Burnley midfielder Paul Smith scoring twice in eight days is at best far-fetched.
fields.body:
A total of five goals in eight seasons suggests that the idea of the Burnley midfielder Paul Smith scoring twice in eight days is at best far-fetched.

But Smith, who has recovered from injuries sustained when he fell down a manhole one dark night in October, has come up smelling of roses. Within minutes of scoring his first goal this century he set his sights on another - in Sunday's televised derby against Blackburn Rovers.

Earlier this season Smith missed the first meeting in 17 years between the Lancashire clubs because he was still recovering from his mishap. He needed 14 stitches in his shin and was out for six weeks, losing bonus money and cutting short a loan move to Oldham. However the solicitors are on the case, Smith is back in the Burnley team and things are looking up.

"I've forgotten how to celebrate," he confessed after his 13th-minute opener helped the Clarets to a brittle victory. "Hopefully the gaffer won't change the team, because I want to play at Blackburn.

"I missed the first derby game but the return won't be the last because they won't go up. It's a big game and people in the town are already talking about it. That was my first goal in three years but who is to say I won't score in that one as well? I'd love that to happen."

Burnley do not possess Blackburn's resources but they do have plenty of grit. The on-loan striker Gareth Taylor put them in the comfort zone against struggling Rangers with his second goal since joining from Manchester City but they needed resilience as QPR responded feverishly to a half-time roasting from their new manager Ian Holloway.

Rangers twice hit the post with efforts from Ian Baraclough and Peter Crouch before Marcus Bignot scored his first goal for the club. But the deficiencies that have dragged down the Londoners this season - soft defending and woeful finishing - were in plentiful evidence again.

Rangers squandered a dozen chances and left Holloway still waiting for his first victory since taking charge five matches ago and his team running out of time in their bid to beat the drop.

"The manager had a real go and we deserved it," said Crouch. "The second half was totally different but you can't start games the way we did and expect to win. It's not looking good."

webTitle: Manny from heaven but Oxford still in wilderness

fields.headline: Manny from heaven but Oxford still in wilderness
fields.trailText: David Kemp put his side's first victory in 10 attempts down to everything coming right on the day; his opposite number Ronnie Moore felt that his own top-of-the table team had been outfought. But this upset probably had more to do with the game of brinkmanship Oxford's owner is playing with the local council than anything else.
fields.byline: Mark Tallentire at the Manor Ground
fields.body:
David Kemp put his side's first victory in 10 attempts down to everything coming right on the day; his opposite number Ronnie Moore felt that his own top-of-the table team had been outfought. But this upset probably had more to do with the game of brinkmanship Oxford's owner is playing with the local council than anything else.

Oxford were a revelation, but following recent remarks by Firoz Kassam - who had said "there may not be a football club here this time next week" after refusing to hire a keeper before deadline day, forcing Kemp to pick the youth-team prospect Phil Wilson for the bench despite a dislocated finger - a team who had won just three home games were well and truly galvanised.

It was all a pleasant throwback to the pre-Bosman era, when effort and application were maintained until the end of the season as players fought to secure new contracts and their livelihoods. Indeed for all of Oxford's goalscorers it was a case of first time ever for the club while in Manny Omoyimni, who due to Phil Gray's absence with Northern Ireland began only his second game since September, they had the game's outstanding player.

The striker, unable to re member when he had scored previously - it was in December 1999 when on loan at Scunthorpe, where he fled after West Ham's League Cup eligibility row - made the opener with a neat cross for Robert Quinn, scored two from distance, had a third disallowed and gave Rotherham the complete runaround.

"Manny was superb," said Andy Scott, who got the fourth with a header. "He showed today exactly what he can do. Sometimes when we lose a goal our heads drop but today when they scored, we kept fighting.

"I was given assurances when I came here that the [new] ground was going ahead, more players would be coming in and that things would be looking up. But when you see something like that [Kassam's remarks], you wonder whether you were being told the truth or not. But unless things go completely wrong, I'm happy to be here."

Scott will be as interested as any in the upshot of tomorrow's local council meeting, where what Kassam described as "the legal fights" that have hindered progress at the half-finished Minchery Farm will be discussed. Although the Manor site has been sold, the club's owner has threatened to pull the builders off the new site and withdraw financial support unless he gets the all-clear for the £15m project which includes his baby, a multi-screen cinema, by Wednesday.

For Rotherham a win would have put them 10 points ahead of third-placed Reading and a long way towards a second straight promotion. Instead they were forced into playing catch-up but left themselves too much to do despite close-range goals from Mark Robins, Guy Branston and Alan Lee.

"Our back three have been our strength this season but today we were really vulnerable," said Moore. "We've got a similar game next week, Swindon at home, and if we go out with the same attitude we're going to get turned over."

Oxford next feature at Cambridge tomorrow and while they probably care little for avenging the Boat Race result, a win would delay the inevitable relegation and perhaps belatedly help focus minds in the council chamber.

fields.headline: Heavy traffic ends in gridlock
fields.trailText: There were times when the soggy pitch seemed as congested and patternless as the M4, littered with obstructive cones and fraught occupants, which separates these two clubs of lowly status.
fields.byline: David Foot  at the Memorial stadium
fields.body:
There were times when the soggy pitch seemed as congested and patternless as the M4, littered with obstructive cones and fraught occupants, which separates these two clubs of lowly status.

Maybe the traffic imagery was not lost on Garry Thompson, the Rovers caretaker manager, who said there was too much stopping and starting, and no real flow. Swindon's Andy King said: "Once they were like sheep on the field [not the most apposite of comparisons these days]. Now they're showing passion."

The teams did their best to donate success to the opposition. Swindon's generally strong no-frills defence left itself painfully exposed in the first half and a right-wing cross from Nathan Ellington tantalisingly slithered along the tacky goalline before being belted away.

After the interval there was one inexplicable lack of rapport between the Bristol defence and its goalkeeper. The substitute Danny Invincible should have scored, and he would have but for one of several invaluable, if despairing, recovery saves by Nick Culkin, who is expected to return to Old Trafford shortly after a season's profitable loan to the west country.

Simon Bryant, one of the home side's young emerging midfielders, had a bad first 45 minutes, then improved and summoned up the best shot of the game, from 25 yards. But by the 73rd minute he had picked up his second booking, after a challenge on Ian Woan, and was on his way. That meant rapidly revised tactics for Bristol, for the third time in the match.

Swindon, in their own pragmatic fashion, are noticeably better than they were in mid- season. They are capable of hauling themselves away from the thoughts of relegation that not long ago was something of an obsession at the Country Ground.

Rovers needed more than a draw and remain fourth from bottom in the relegation zone.

fields.headline: Centaur drops flotation plans
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Centaur Communications, publisher of Marketing Week and the Lawyer, is believed to have abandoned plans to float. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Centaur Communications, which publishes Marketing Week, the Lawyer and Money Marketing magazines, is believed to have abandoned its plan for a flotation in favour of a private sale.

The group announced its intention to float last November. But sources say the company has ditched the idea following a downturn in the global advertising market.

Centaur's largest shareholder, US investment firm Veronis Suhler, said in November it wanted to sell its 22% stake in the company.

Centaur is reported to have attracted the attention of US equity company Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which is also thought to be in talks with Emap about a purchase of its business magazines division, Emap business media.

Insiders said Centaur's board was scheduled to meet tomorrow to discuss the possibility of a sale.

A Centaur spokeswoman was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Syrian rehabilitation is in the pipeline

fields.headline: Syrian rehabilitation is in the pipeline
fields.standfirst: The young Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, has proved adept at handling diplomatic relations with the US in talks over illegal fuel smuggling, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The young Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, has proved adept at handling diplomatic relations with the US in talks over illegal fuel smuggling, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
It looks as though Colin Powell, the US secretary of state, has scored an important success in his crackdown on Iraqi oil smuggling by closing the pipeline to Syria. In the process, Syria's young president, Bashar al-Assad, has ingratiated himself with Washington.

The 500-mile pipeline, which runs from the Kirkuk oilfields to the port of Banyas on Syria's Mediterranean coast, was built in 1953 but shut down in 1982 when Syria quarrelled with Iraq. Last November, after a warming of relations between Syria and Iraq, there were reports that the pipeline had reopened and was being used to smuggle around 150,000 barrels of oil a day out of Iraq.

Under sanctions, oil exports from Iraq are illegal unless the revenue from sales is channelled through the UN's oil-for-food programme. Revenue from smuggled oil, on the other hand, goes directly to the Baghdad regime - "to purchase their luxuries and not to the Iraqi people," as the British Foreign Office puts it.

Syria and Iraq apparently thought they had found a loophole in the sanctions rules, because the plan was not to sell the Iraqi oil directly on the open market. Instead, Syria would buy the oil at half price ($10-$15 - £7-£10 - a barrel) and refine it for domestic use. This, in turn, would allow Syria to export an equivalent amount of its own oil at full price to the Mediterranean market.

As a result, Iraq could claim that its arrangements with Syria were no different from those with two other neighbours - Jordan and Turkey - which are already allowed to receive Iraqi oil outside the oil-for-food programme.

Western diplomats would have none of it. They argued that, although the oil supplies to Jordan and Turkey are technically illegal, the quantities involved are small and so nothing has been done to stop them.

The Iraqi-Syrian ploy was a different matter because, if successful, it would have doubled the volume of Iraq's illegal oil exports at a stroke. In fact, neither Syria nor Iraq confirmed that the pipeline had reopened; they maintained that it was simply being tested.

However, they were certainly not testing it with water, and, in the inimitable language of the Foreign Office, the quantities of oil involved were "inconsistent with testing".

Oil industry sources believe that around 150,000 barrels per day (bpd) were passing through the pipeline. The giveaway was Syria's oil exports, which increased dramatically in December and continued to rise through January and February.

According to Petroleum Argus, which monitors oil shipments around the world, loadings at Banyas during February included 340,000 bpd of Syrian light crude (50,000 up on last year) and 160,000 bpd of Suweidi crude (double the customary amount).

Given that Syria produces only about 560,000 bpd of its own oil, this increase could only be accounted for by use of the Iraqi pipeline. Iraq, meanwhile, declared the ageing pipeline useless and said that a new one would have to be built.

There are also claims that Iraq is delivering fuel oil by rail to a new 600-megawatt power station in Syria, east of Aleppo. Running the power station at full capacity would require about 30,000 tonnes of oil per week. The Foreign Office says that it is aware of the reports of rail deliveries from Iraq but cannot confirm them.

At the end of February, Colin Powell met President Bashar in Damascus and challenged him about the pipeline. After the meeting, Mr Powell announced that the Syrians "plan to bring the pipeline and what is going through the pipeline, and revenues generated in that pipeline to be under the same kind of control as other elements of the sanctions regime."

Mr Powell said that Mr Bashar had repeated this undertaking three times but Syria made no public comment whatsoever. The consensus among observers was that if Mr Bashar had indeed made such a promise he probably had no intention of keeping it.

The word "plan" in Colin Powell's statement hinted that Syria might wriggle out of implementation. What nobody (except perhaps Mr Powell) expected was that the pipeline would be shut down immediately. But that is what appears to have happened.

Last Friday, Charlotte Bloom, who tracks Syrian oil for Petroleum Argus, said the provisional export figures for March show a sudden drop - back to last year's levels before the pipeline reopened.

But could Syria simply be stockpiling the Iraqi oil? Ms Bloom thinks not. The Syrians do not have enough storage capacity, she says. The obvious conclusion is that someone has turned the taps off. The intriguing question is why.

From the Syrian point of view it was a win-win situation. Reopening the pipeline was worth a try because, if nobody objected strongly, Syria would gain around $1.5m a day. That is a useful sum for a poor country, though not worth going to the wall over.

If, on the other hand, there were objections, Syria could graciously agree to stop - and claim political rewards for doing so.

President Bashar's handling of the affair has certainly moved Syria along the road to rehabilitation in the eyes of the west, and may help to earn it a rotating seat on the UN security council.

On the economic side, Syria can also look forward to an expansion of its legitimate trade with Iraq once the new "smart" sanctions take effect. In the long run, this will probably be more valuable than any short-term gains from illicit use of the pipeline.

All in all, the episode shows that Mr Bashar is a lot more astute than most people imagined he would be when he suddenly came to power following his father's death last June.

webTitle: RUC security blunder could cost up to £2m

fields.headline: RUC security blunder could cost up to £2m
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The lives of more than 20 top RUC officers are at risk after their personal details were stolen from a colleague's car and passed to the IRA. Upgrading security at their homes could cost up to £2m.
fields.body:
The lives of more than 20 top RUC officers are at risk after their personal details were stolen from a colleague's car and passed to the IRA. Upgrading security at their homes could cost up to £2m.

An RUC press spokesman refused to discuss any matters pertaining to security of individuals. But a source confirmed that a superintendent's unattended car, containing a diary with names, addresses and phone numbers of a retired assistant chief constable and 21 chief inspectors and inspectors, was taken from the Abbeycentre shopping complex on the outskirts of Belfast five weeks ago.

The vehicle was later found burned out in the Poleglass area of the city, and police believe the diary is now in the hands of leading Provisionals. Even though the IRA is on ceasefire and supporting the peace process, the RUC is treating the matter seriously.

"Most police officers, retired or not, remain paranoid about their security," said the source. "The IRA could still pose a serious threat to their safety, and then there is the blurring of lines between some members of the Provisionals and the Real IRA, which is not on cessation. If this information gets to the Real IRA, then there are added fears."
