fields.headline: Michael Meacher is born again
fields.standfirst: He's done his penance, now it's time to let him into the cabinet
fields.trailText: He's done his penance, now it's time to let him into the cabinet
fields.body:
As the general election approaches, junior ministers - who at the best of times hover between grandeur and servitude - will be subject to severe and sudden mood swings. Parliamentary secretaries who wake up in hope will go to bed in despair. And ministers of state who believed that they had the full support of Downing Street will conclude, after a brief word exchanged behind the speaker's chair, that they have lost the prime minister's confidence. The neurosis is easily explained. In the week that follows polling day, three or four junior ministers will be promoted to the cabinet. Many more will be sacked.

The prime minister has to make space for new talent. So the cull will include junior ministers who have done nothing wrong, but have done nothing spectacularly right. The easy way out for the prime minister is to retire everyone over 60. That solution would be palpably unfair to one of the government's greatest successes. For Michael Meacher has been born again.

If the government was running Britain plc - a state of affairs to which I sometimes think the prime minister aspires - Meacher would be promoted to secretary of state, for the simple reason than that he has performed his middle-ranking job ofenvironment minister with both efficiency and élan. But even in the half-world of politics which the prime minister inhabits, some of the old prejudices apply. Past mistakes are not forgotten. And 20 years ago, Michael Meacher was a pain in the neck.

When he was a young back-bencher he specialised in asking complicated statistical questions. No one - including the professional statisticians - could understand them. He became a parliamentary secretary because, in those days, it was thought necessary to accommodate the wet left. I am reminded of his performance whenever my dog whines to be let out into the garden. Meacher was a member of the government but not part of it. Balanced precariously between disloyalty and collective responsibility, metaphorically, at least, he emitted a high-pitched moan.

His attitude - a combination of piety and sabotage - was typified by an incident during the 1970s civil service strike. Ministers had agreed to cross the picket lines but would not "black-leg" by performing the tasks of those who had "withheld their labour". At the time, I was secretary of state for a department which shared premises with two other ministries. It was my turn to take responsibility for the joint services - premises, personnel and the like.

So when John Smith (who headed another of the joint departments) saw Meacher shake hands with the pickets and then turn away from our building, he insisted that it was my job to preside over the court martial. Smith set out the indictment. Meacher lookedlike a recently ordained curate who had just been told that his vicar was a serial killer. "Were they pickets?" he asked. "I thought they were Save the Children flag sellers. And I went away because I suddenly remembered that I had a meeting in the House of Commons." Unusually, John Smith and I were both lost for words.

Socialists believe in an infinite capacity for human improvement. Looking back, I can identify the moment when the big change began. It was at the meeting of the Labour party national executive which preceded the 1984 annual conference. Tony Benn proposed support for a resolution which endorsed Arthur Scargill's decision to strike without balloting his members. Neil Kinnock urged its rejection. The executive was so evenly divided that, when the last name was called, the vote was tied. The last name was Michael Meacher. After a long pause, he voted against Scargill's folly. There was an even longer silence before Tony Benn said, very quietly, "Michael, may you be forgiven."

I say the same now, though in a different spirit. Meacher has done his penance. When Labour took office four years ago, Meacher - a longstanding elected member of the shadow cabinet - was not given his own ministry. That was the price he paid for the reputation he had acquired almost 20 years earlier. If he moaned about his fate, he moaned in private. He took on the junior job and performed it with conspicuous success. Even the old faults - the invincible innocence and the flagrant naivety - worked in his favour. Last week, asked on television if the Treasury was being difficult about financing the assault on foot and mouth disease, he replied: "I don't know." His assailants were speechless, again.

The secret of his success has three ingredients. He is very clever, he is obsessed with politics and he believes in the job he is doing. For those reasons he has done great credit to the Labour party and the government. After the election, protecting the environment should become a cabinet job. And it should be done by Michael Meacher.

webTitle: Leader: Tactical voting crucial to election

fields.headline: Tactically smart
fields.standfirst:
But Labour has delayed the cause of reform

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: Whenever the election is called, one factor will play a decisive role: tactical voting.
fields.body:
Whenever the election is called, one factor will play a decisive role: tactical voting. All sides now agree that in 1997 deliberate switching by anti-Tory voters from Labour to the Liberal Democrats, or vice versa, succeeded in grabbing seats the Conservatives had only held thanks to a divided opposition. Few will forget that evening's defining moment, when the people of Enfield Southgate ended years of division and united behind Labour's Stephen Twigg - thereby ejecting Michael Portillo. If that habit spreads, then the next election could see not only a second defeat for the Conservatives, but another whacking majority for Labour and a fresh, bumper crop of Lib Dem MPs. Liberal Democrat strategists reckon there are at least 50 seats they could grab from the Tories, just so long as they can persuade Labour voters in those areas to switch to them.

What are the obstacles in their way? The first has to be the anti-Tory factor. In 1997, the country wanted to rid itself of the Conservatives: determination to achieve that end was so great, voters paid attention to leaflets and polls showing what they had to do in their constituency. But will they be as determined this time? Or will most regard William Hague, Ann Widdecombe and Co as less of a threat to be stopped than a joke to be ignored? Some in both Labour and Lib Dem ranks almost wish the Tories were punching stronger in the opinion polls: that way, at least fear of a Conservative comeback might persuade people to vote tactically. Otherwise, people might simply follow the old habits and vote along tribal lines - splitting the progressive camp and handing the Tories a bucketful of seats they should have lost.

But a second obstacle has always been distrust between the parties on the ground. Even if an anti-Hague mood is there, it can't be exploited if Labour and Lib Dem fight each other. Tacitly they need to agree to stay out of each other's way, running a non-campaign in those seats where the other party could beat the Tory. That is why last week's agreement between Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy on proportional representation is to be welcomed. If the prime minister had bowed to the anti-reformers in his own cabinet - Gordon Brown, Jack Straw and John Prescott - then Mr Kennedy would have struggled to restrain the Lib Dem foot soldiers whose hostility to Labour, particularly in the northern cities, is deep. As it is, he now has enough of a deal to persuade his troops to maintain the cooperation which is surely their only path to success.

Besides the tactical voting calculation, how will the Blair-Kennedy accord affect the wider cause of Westminster reform? PR advocates will be relieved that the issue has at least been spared the oblivion Mr Prescott and friends clearly wished for it. But there is not much else to celebrate. For all Labour has agreed to is a review in 2003 at the earliest - after the PR systems in Wales and Scotland have run for a full electoral cycle. Then there will be an assessment and only after that a referendum. As with the euro, Labour has built a double fence between now and any change: review, followed by plebiscite. That is quite a hurdle to leap.

What's more, like the single currency, Labour's move delays not only the decision but any campaign. The only way to win a referendum on either the euro or PR is through a sustained campaign for hearts and minds. Such an effort would have to begin now. Instead, it will be delayed. Mr Blair may have won the immediate advantage, ensuring tactical voting in the next election, but reform for our archaic system, still seems very far away.

webTitle: Europe holds the key to success

fields.headline: Europe holds the key to success
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown believes raising productivity is Britain's main economic challenge. He is right, but in pursuing this goal the chancellor should look to Europe as much as to America.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown believes raising productivity is Britain's main economic challenge. He is right, but in pursuing this goal the chancellor should look to Europe as much as to America.

Britain's inflation is now as low and as stable as any country's. Its public finances are sound. We also perform well on employment creation, with one of the highest participation rates in Europe and unemployment at a 30-year low. But on the most fundamental economic objective - creating prosperity - Britain remains 10th out of 15 European Union countries, exactly the same position as in 1980, and over the past three years we have grown per capita income more slowly than either the US or the euro zone.

Agreement on prosperity creation however, is matched by disagreement on how to get there. One school of thought, represented by McKinsey's 1998 Treasury report, proposes further deregulation as the key to success and looks to the US as the model. That model also exerts a strong fascination over our chancellor. But it is to the best of Europe that Britain should look.

Over the past 20 years America and Europe have grown prosperity at almost exactly the same rate (the US at 1.81%, the EU at 1.89%), but the US was about 20% ahead of the European average 20 years ago and is ahead by almost the same amount today. Almost all of this advantage stems from more hours worked not from greater efficiency. Some of those extra hours worked result from lower American unemployment - and Europe should learn from the US ability to create jobs for low-skill employees. But much of the difference stems from a different social trade-off between income and leisure. The purpose of economics is to understand such trade-offs and to help make them as efficiently as possible, not to deny their possibility. The best measure of efficiency is productivity per hour worked, and on that measure France, Germany and several other European countries perform as well as the US.

That performance is achieved despite two fundamental US advantages - low population density and a large single market. Low population density makes possible looser planning rules, lower land prices and more expansive physical development, and that in turn has a pervasive effect on attainable productivity. It is far easier to achieve high productivity on greenfield sites connected by free-flowing roads than in brownfield sites linked by congested roads.

Europe's higher population density imposes an economic cost which it can chose to accept either in lower productivity or in a degraded environment, but which it cannot avoid. America's homogeneous culture, single language and single currency make it possible for an American company to serve a market of 270m consumers with one advertising campaign, one set of sales literature, one accounting system, etc. Take the two advantages, and America ought, if other factors are equal, to achieve productivity significantly above European levels.

Other factors, however, are not equal, for European countries tend to offset America's inherent advantages in two ways. First through high levels of capital investment both within private business and in public infrastructure. Both the US and leading European countries have much larger capital stock per employee than Britain, and Britain cannot match their productivity without increased investment. For all the fashionable talk of knowledge-based economies productivity growth depends on investing in machines which automate previously manual processes. But French and German capital stock per employee is above even US levels.

Secondly continental countries tend on average to have better workforce skills. The US performs well in international comparisons of elite education, but along with Britain, suffers from a long tail of low educational attainment. Achieving these higher skills and higher investment entails costs. But it is the only route by which Europe can achieve comparative levels of productivity per hour worked.

The high investment European model is the more relevant one for Britain. That does not deny attractive features of the American approach from which many European countries should learn and already are learning. Its more flexible labour market creates more jobs. Its competitive product markets are being emulated through privatisation and market liberalisation across Europe; and the single currency will help make European markets more intensely competitive.

America invests more than Europe in research and development. But from where Britain stands today the best European economies have more to teach us. Our labour markets are as flexible as needed to deliver American-style job creation, and the limited changes Labour have introduced have not undermined that flexibility. Our planning laws cannot match America's looseness without harmful environmental damage. Our product markets are already extensively liberalised, and the priority now is to put right the botched privatisation of the railways, not to sell the few remaining state assets.

Higher investment not more deregulation is the key to further improvement.

Adair Turner is vice-chairman of Merrill Lynch Europe and a former director-general of the CBI.

His book Just Capital -The Liberal Economy is published by Macmillan. Hardback £20

fields.headline: Minute-by-minute report
fields.standfirst: (Times quoted are local to Los Angeles)
fields.trailText: The news as it happened, live from the 73rd Academy Awards
fields.body:
6pm: The stars congregate outside the Shrine Auditorium, waving in the general direction of the assembled fans, and politely fielding the soft-soap questions of the reporters. The most nervous of the arriving nominees appears to be best actress hopeful Juliette Binoche, resplendent in a retro 20s get-up, who greets each question with a hysterical giggle. Meanwhile Hollywood pros Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts cut calmer figures. An icily efficient Kate Hudson seems barely fazed by the occasion. She admits to having been given some advice by her mum, Goldie Hawn (herself a best supporting actress Oscar winner for 1969's Cactus Flower): "To have fun, and just enjoy every moment of it." Chances are that she will. Hudson is the bookie's favourite to take the best supporting actress for her role in Almost Famous.

6.45pm: The Academy Awards deliver the night's first big surprise as Marcia Gay Harden beats off strongly fancied Kate Hudson to win the best supporting actress Oscar for her role in Pollock. Moments earlier Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon won what could prove the first of numerous awards when Tim Yip picked up the statuette for best art direction.

7pm: Russell Crowe presents the Oscar for best editing to Stephen Mirrione for Traffic. No sooner has the stage cleared than Ben Stiller hands the award for best animated short to the Mexican film I Want to Be and the best animated short Oscar to Father and Daughter.

7.15pm: Hollywood shores up its glamour credentials as first Penelope Cruz (dressed in black) and then Angelina Jolie (clad in white) step up to present awards. Britain's Janty Yates wins the Oscar for best costume design for her work on Gladiator. To nobody's great surprise, heavy favourite Benicio Del Toro is named best supporting actor for his role as a Mexican cop battling political corruption in Traffic. In the race for the most statuettes, Traffic now takes the lead with two nods. But the night is yet young.

7.25pm: Ten minutes can be a lifetime on Oscar night. Gladiator pulls back level with Traffic by taking its second award of the night for best sound. The true-ish second world war saga U-571 picks up the cousin award for best sound editing.

7.35pm:Technician Peter Pau pushes his 45-second time limit to the wire in accepting his best cinematography gong for Crouching Tiger, which now sits in a three-way tie on two Oscars apiece with rivals Traffic and Gladiator. Pau's breathless speech wraps up with a last gasp thank you to "Chinese people all over the world".

7.50pm: Hollywood delves into its history to celebrate the achievements of legendary British cinematographer Jack Cardiff (Black Narcissus, The African Queen) by presenting him with an honorary Oscar. "This has to be a dream," Cardiff told the assembled throng. "There's an awesome air about it." Moments earlier a faintly deflated-looking Kate Hudson took the stage to give the Oscar for best make-up to How the Grinch Stole Christmas.

8.05pm: Gladiator edges ahead by taking its third Oscar of the night - a nod for best visual effects. Big Mama wins best documentary short while the acclaimed Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport wins for best documentary feature. Meantime, Steve Martin appears to be relaxing into his role as the event's host. "The police have found a suspect in the plot to kidnap Russell Crowe," he announces with glee. "Tom Hanks, you should be ashamed of yourself." Seated in the audience, Hanks play-acts the guilty man.

8.35pm: Anthony Hopkins presents the Irving Thalberg memorial award to "one of the most fascinating producers of all time", Italian-born Dino De Laurentiis, the mogul behind a string of productions that range from the sublime (La Strada, Nights of Cabiria, Blue Velvet) to the ridiculous (Conan the Barbarian, the remake of King Kong). "I thank you, Tony," quips Dino. "You are a fantastic guy... Let me dedicate this to the Italian film industry." Earlier, Crouching Tiger pulled level with Gladiator (three awards) as composer Tan Dun won best original score.

8.50pm: In what could be a highly significant decision, Crouching Tiger receives the best foreign language film Oscar. The award nudges Ang Lee's Taiwanese epic into the lead with four Oscars, but it could count against it in the long run. Having honoured Crouching Tiger as the best foreign language picture, has the Academy now cleared the way for Gladiator to take the crucial best film Oscar?

9.05pm: A dazed looking Russell Crowe staggers on stage to wild applause to take the best actor Oscar for his turn in Gladiator. "Really folks, I owe this to one bloke and his name is Ridley Scott," says the actor. With Crowe's win, the momentum appears to be slowly swinging behind Scott's Roman saga. Minutes earlier, Bob Dylan materialised via satellite link-up from Australia to accept his Oscar for best original song (Things Have Changed, from Wonder Boys). "God bless you all with peace, tranquility and goodwill," chirruped gravelly Bob.

9.25pm: In the night's most glittering non-surprise, Julia Roberts wins the best actress Oscar for Erin Brockovich. A hyperventilating Ms Roberts pays tribute to her fellow nominees and thanks all those involved with the film, paying particular tribute to director Steven Soderbergh. "Turn that clock off, it's making me nervous," snaps Julia before breaking into wild laughter: "I love it up here... I love the world! I'm so happy!" Needless to say, her speech runs heavily over schedule. Needless to say, nobody seems to mind.

9.40pm: Losing nominee Tom Hanks hands the Oscar for best adapted screenplay to Stephen Gaghan for Traffic. The award for best original screenplay falls to Cameron Crowe for Almost Famous. "I dedicate this to all musicians that inspire us," says Crowe.

9.45pm: In what may rank as the night's biggest surprise, Steven Soderbergh won the best director Oscar for Traffic, beating off joint favourites Ridley Scott and Ang Lee. Many insiders thought that Soderbergh's two best director nominations - the other one was for Erin Brockovich - would split the vote. In the event, he took the stage to the night's most prolonged and enthusiastic applause.

9.50pm: The Academy hands its biggest award to Gladiator as Ridley Scott's Roman actioner takes the Oscar for best picture. The movie's producers pay tribute to "that gentleman genius" Ridley Scott, who conspicuously failed to win the best director gong. "I know what you're thinking," quips Steve Martin. "Just when you're getting into it, it's over." And with that the 73rd Academy Awards ceremony draws to a close. Apart from all the parties and post-mortems, of course.

fields.bodyText: 6pm: The stars congregate outside the Shrine Auditorium, waving in the general direction of the assembled fans, and politely fielding the soft-soap questions of the reporters. The most nervous of the arriving nominees appears to be best actress hopeful Juliette Binoche, resplendent in a retro 20s get-up, who greets each question with a hysterical giggle. Meanwhile Hollywood pros Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts cut calmer figures. An icily efficient Kate Hudson seems barely fazed by the occasion. She admits to having been given some advice by her mum, Goldie Hawn (herself a best supporting actress Oscar winner for 1969's Cactus Flower): "To have fun, and just enjoy every moment of it." Chances are that she will. Hudson is the bookie's favourite to take the best supporting actress for her role in Almost Famous. 6.45pm: The Academy Awards deliver the night's first big surprise as Marcia Gay Harden beats off strongly fancied Kate Hudson to win the best supporting actress Oscar for her role in Pollock. Moments earlier Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon won what could prove the first of numerous awards when Tim Yip picked up the statuette for best art direction. 7pm: Russell Crowe presents the Oscar for best editing to Stephen Mirrione for Traffic. No sooner has the stage cleared than Ben Stiller hands the award for best animated short to the Mexican film I Want to Be and the best animated short Oscar to Father and Daughter. 7.15pm: Hollywood shores up its glamour credentials as first Penelope Cruz (dressed in black) and then Angelina Jolie (clad in white) step up to present awards. Britain's Janty Yates wins the Oscar for best costume design for her work on Gladiator. To nobody's great surprise, heavy favourite Benicio Del Toro is named best supporting actor for his role as a Mexican cop battling political corruption in Traffic. In the race for the most statuettes, Traffic now takes the lead with two nods. But the night is yet young. 7.25pm: Ten minutes can be a lifetime on Oscar night. Gladiator pulls back level with Traffic by taking its second award of the night for best sound. The true-ish second world war saga U-571 picks up the cousin award for best sound editing. 7.35pm:Technician Peter Pau pushes his 45-second time limit to the wire in accepting his best cinematography gong for Crouching Tiger, which now sits in a three-way tie on two Oscars apiece with rivals Traffic and Gladiator. Pau's breathless speech wraps up with a last gasp thank you to "Chinese people all over the world". 7.50pm: Hollywood delves into its history to celebrate the achievements of legendary British cinematographer Jack Cardiff (Black Narcissus, The African Queen) by presenting him with an honorary Oscar. "This has to be a dream," Cardiff told the assembled throng. "There's an awesome air about it." Moments earlier a faintly deflated-looking Kate Hudson took the stage to give the Oscar for best make-up to How the Grinch Stole Christmas. 8.05pm: Gladiator edges ahead by taking its third Oscar of the night - a nod for best visual effects. Big Mama wins best documentary short while the acclaimed Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport wins for best documentary feature. Meantime, Steve Martin appears to be relaxing into his role as the event's host. "The police have found a suspect in the plot to kidnap Russell Crowe," he announces with glee. "Tom Hanks, you should be ashamed of yourself." Seated in the audience, Hanks play-acts the guilty man. 8.35pm: Anthony Hopkins presents the Irving Thalberg memorial award to "one of the most fascinating producers of all time", Italian-born Dino De Laurentiis, the mogul behind a string of productions that range from the sublime (La Strada, Nights of Cabiria, Blue Velvet) to the ridiculous (Conan the Barbarian, the remake of King Kong). "I thank you, Tony," quips Dino. "You are a fantastic guy... Let me dedicate this to the Italian film industry." fields.headline: Charles Kennedy
fields.standfirst:
Ross, Skye and Inverness West (1997- )
Ross, Cromarty and Skye (1983-1997)

Ask Aristotle about Charles Kennedy
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy takes his politics seriously, if not himself. Disguised by his genial manner, he has emerged as the most realistic politician to have led the Liberal Democrats, if we accept politics as the art of the possible. Doubters in his party point out that he also takes this pragmatism to extremes, even to the point of seeming bland.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy takes his politics seriously, if not himself. Disguised by his genial manner, he has emerged as the most realistic politician to have led the Liberal Democrats, if we accept politics as the art of the possible. Doubters in his party point out that he also takes this pragmatism to extremes, even to the point of seeming bland.

At prime minister's questions, Paddy Ashdown could bark out sharper questions at Tony Blair. But unlike Mr Ashdown, or party grandee Roy Jenkins, Mr Kennedy is not gullible about which private promises Mr Blair can deliver against the massed ranks of his cabinet, most Labour MPs and the party machine.

He knows that Labour's partial concessions on proportional representation in Scotland and Wales have provided as much as the Lib Dems can expect, much as he would like Mr Blair to fulfil Labour's manifesto promise of a referendum on voting reform.

Instead of chasing the Lib Dems' elusive holy grail, he prefers to identify with Labour in regenerating the NHS. Nick Harvey, his health spokesman, has collaborated with the health secretary, Alan Milburn. This illustrates Mr Kennedy's crucial strategy: the Lib Dems as friendly rivals of Labour, but deadly enemies of the Tories. "William Hague's Conservatives in government would be an absolute and unmitigated disaster," Mr Kennedy has stated.

He sticks to that message even when temptation to do otherwise crowds in. On the day in January 2001 that Peter Mandelson resigned, Mr Kennedy chose to use his first question at question time to attack the gloating attitude of the Conservative party, rather than champion Norman Baker, the Lib Dem backbencher whose written parliamentary question caused Mr Mandelson to quit.

It was this unstated strategy of anti-Conservatism which underlay the Lib Dems' escape from the minor party laager in May 1997 under Paddy Ashdown's guidance and remains the basis of the Labour-Lib Dem coalition in Scotland. It is only on this basis that Mr Kennedy hopes to persuade Labour-haters in his party that they can better defend their expanded bridgehead of 47 seats against the Tories.

His "friendly rivalry" with Labour does not prevent the occasional shin kicking in public (over benefit cuts for the disabled and the financing of London Underground) or in private (allowing his party to bring down Labour's Alun Michael as leader of the Welsh Assembly).

The Europhile Mr Kennedy knows he has no alternative to an alliance with Labour if he wants to achieve entry into the euro and closer EU ties. His critics claim he is tardy and indolent, taking a taxi rather than walking a quarter mile. But he has won two crucial contests - that of president of the party in 1990 and its leader in 1999 - with the most gruelling campaigns ever on the Lib Dems' "rubber-chicken circuit" stretching from Cornwall to Skye.

Mr Kennedy was born in Inverness, the son of Ian Kennedy, a crofter, engineering draughtsman and semi-professional fiddle player. A successful student, he made his way from Lochaber high school in Fort William - where at 15 he joined the Labour party - to Glasgow University. There he joined the Social Democratic club, a debating society, and became president of the union in 1980. He won an honours degree and a Fulbright scholarship to Indiana University in the US. He seemed set for a career as an amusing lecturer in some obscure American or Scottish university.

But Roy Jenkins' first, failed attempt to win Glasgow Hillhead in 1982 ignited Mr Kennedy's enthusiasm for Europe and the new Social Democratic party. His first act for the SDP was to spend a very wet day outside a polling booth warning voters about a candidate who had changed his name by deed poll to "Roy Jenkins".

For his pains, he was selected by the SDP for the "hopeless" constituency of Ross, Cromarty and Skye where in previous years the Liberals had only won 9% of the vote. He thought victory was so unlikely that he flew off to the US immediately the polls closed. But, at 23, he had scored the most famous of the six seats the SDP won, ousting the Hamish Gray, the former Tory minister.

That September a standing ovation greeted him at the Salford conference of the SDP for a mature speech on poverty and welfare reform. Arriving at the Commons, he hit the ground running as the SDP spokesman on social security, Scotland and health.

Initially the only one of the five SDP MPs to favour a merger with the Liberals, he stood aside as a potential interim leader of the SDP's pro-merger faction to back Robert Maclennan - ruling himself out as well as a possible leader of the newly merged party. When the Liberal Democrats was formed he scorned the tendency of ex-Liberals to formulate detailed policies, as if on the eve of taking over the government.

He was unable to take seriously Mr Ashdown's sudden embrace of Tony Blair and his belief that the Lib Dems would score two cabinet seats if Labour won in 1997. Mr Kennedy had long favoured working with a "healthy modern Labour party", but he objected to secret deals. This clash explains Mr Ashdown's demotion of him, after the Lib Dems had won 46 seats in 1997, to agriculture spokesman.

Although that yielded more time for television appearances and his perceptive columns in the Scotsman newspaper, it ignited an atypical smouldering resentment. This led him to renew his attack on the rubber-chicken circuit with the enthusiasm needed to beat the hyperactive Simon Hughes by 28,425 votes to 21,833 to become leader of the Liberal Democrats at the age of 40.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Michael Meacher is born again

fields.headline: Michael Meacher is born again
fields.standfirst:
He's done his penance, now it's time to let him into the cabinet

Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: He's done his penance, now it's time to let him into the cabinet.
fields.body:
As the general election approaches, junior ministers - who at the best of times hover between grandeur and servitude - will be subject to severe and sudden mood swings. Parliamentary secretaries who wake up in hope will go to bed in despair. And ministers of state who believed that they had the full support of Downing Street will conclude, after a brief word exchanged behind the speaker's chair, that they have lost the prime minister's confidence. The neurosis is easily explained. In the week that follows polling day, three or four junior ministers will be promoted to the cabinet. Many more will be sacked.

The prime minister has to make space for new talent. So the cull will include junior ministers who have done nothing wrong, but have done nothing spectacularly right. The easy way out for the prime minister is to retire everyone over 60. That solution would be palpably unfair to one of the government's greatest successes. For Michael Meacher has been born again.

If the government was running Britain plc - a state of affairs to which I sometimes think the prime minister aspires - Meacher would be promoted to secretary of state, for the simple reason than that he has performed his middle-ranking job ofenvironment minister with both efficiency and élan. But even in the half-world of politics which the prime minister inhabits, some of the old prejudices apply. Past mistakes are not forgotten. And 20 years ago, Michael Meacher was a pain in the neck.

When he was a young back-bencher he specialised in asking complicated statistical questions. No one - including the professional statisticians - could understand them. He became a parliamentary secretary because, in those days, it was thought necessary to accommodate the wet left. I am reminded of his performance whenever my dog whines to be let out into the garden. Meacher was a member of the government but not part of it. Balanced precariously between disloyalty and collective responsibility, metaphorically, at least, he emitted a high-pitched moan.

His attitude - a combination of piety and sabotage - was typified by an incident during the 1970s civil service strike. Ministers had agreed to cross the picket lines but would not "black-leg" by performing the tasks of those who had "withheld their labour". At the time, I was secretary of state for a department which shared premises with two other ministries. It was my turn to take responsibility for the joint services - premises, personnel and the like.

So when John Smith (who headed another of the joint departments) saw Meacher shake hands with the pickets and then turn away from our building, he insisted that it was my job to preside over the court martial. Smith set out the indictment. Meacher lookedlike a recently ordained curate who had just been told that his vicar was a serial killer. "Were they pickets?" he asked. "I thought they were Save the Children flag sellers. And I went away because I suddenly remembered that I had a meeting in the House of Commons." Unusually, John Smith and I were both lost for words.

Socialists believe in an infinite capacity for human improvement. Looking back, I can identify the moment when the big change began. It was at the meeting of the Labour party national executive which preceded the 1984 annual conference. Tony Benn proposed support for a resolution which endorsed Arthur Scargill's decision to strike without balloting his members. Neil Kinnock urged its rejection. The executive was so evenly divided that, when the last name was called, the vote was tied. The last name was Michael Meacher. After a long pause, he voted against Scargill's folly. There was an even longer silence before Tony Benn said, very quietly, "Michael, may you be forgiven."

I say the same now, though in a different spirit. Meacher has done his penance. When Labour took office four years ago, Meacher - a longstanding elected member of the shadow cabinet - was not given his own ministry. That was the price he paid for the reputation he had acquired almost 20 years earlier. If he moaned about his fate, he moaned in private. He took on the junior job and performed it with conspicuous success. Even the old faults - the invincible innocence and the flagrant naivety - worked in his favour. Last week, asked on television if the Treasury was being difficult about financing the assault on foot and mouth disease, he replied: "I don't know." His assailants were speechless, again.

The secret of his success has three ingredients. He is very clever, he is obsessed with politics and he believes in the job he is doing. For those reasons he has done great credit to the Labour party and the government. After the election, protecting the environment should become a cabinet job. And it should be done by Michael Meacher.

webTitle: Moscow doesn't matter any more. And neither do we

fields.headline: Moscow doesn't matter any more. And neither do we
fields.standfirst:
Europe is not the centre of this White House's universe

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Europe is not the centre of this White House's universe.
fields.body:
Now it's down in black and white: for the eyes of George W Bush and the Washington Post only. We (on this side of the pond) aren't so important any longer - because Russia isn't so important, an ex-public enemy number one slipping down the charts. Give the new Great Satan designate, China, a big hand; and set America's hugely refurbished armed forces steaming off into the Pacific sunset.

There seems to be some allied surprise about Donald Rumsfeld's 60-day defence review as now solemnly, if leakily, confided to his president. Forget it. Rumsfeld has come up with a Republican number thought of long before the election. His "review" is only a way of squashing the inevitable protests from warring service chiefs. This tilt - away from Europe - is permanent. Moscow doesn't matter. (That's the real message of last week's casually insolent clearing of the spies.) Moscow is too broke and chaotic and indigent to matter. Therefore, we don't matter either.

Such shifts, of course, can be put too crudely. People like Colin Powell are there - if General Powell is presently there for anything - to apply the balm of nuancing. Fair words and history have their place. Unfolding events will muddy the clear lines of policy. But nobody should kid themselves that something fundamental isn't happening. If defence spending is about fighting wars, then the wars this United States expects to wage, or hopes to deter, will be Pacific specific. Europe, in so far as it furrows foreheads, will have to take care of itself (which is just as well, because the hardware to do much else won't be available).

Put simply, the Pentagon is reprioritising its threat list. The Middle East (standing by that cuddly bear Sharon and raising two fingers at Arafat and Saddam) has salience, because oil is an obsession. Rogue states (Saddam again, but see how North Korea has been shunned since Clinton left office) have their obsessive interest, too. But China, in Rumsfeld's own words, is where the perceived threat lies; China - a burgeoning economy as well as a nation - is at the heart of fresh thinking. The "next world superpower"? No way. George W will sort that out.

Why should that be? The last administration bobbed and weaved with Beijing, getting worked up about human rights then cooling down as the lure of commerce returned. But nobody at Clinton State or Clinton Defence would have dreamed of designating it the principal pending foe. Nor, whatever the march of consumer potential, could anyone discern a continuing Chinese ideology to conquer the globe.

But the people who count for most in the Bush hierarchy - Cheney and Rumsfeld, with attendant seers like Condie Rice and Richard Perle, the prince of darkness long before Peter Mandelson was invented - have a different mind-set. They were there in the 70s and 80s. They believe that their reso lution, their toughness won the cold war. So the sleazebag from Arkansas inherited the spoils - the spoils that were rightfully theirs? Now see what the hard men can do.

Significant psychology. After Oscar night, you might talk Gladiator; but better yet, keep thinking of the young Cassius Clay and "I am the Greatest". Remember the rumble in the jungle and the thriller in Manila? Here we go with the showdown in Shanghai. Boxing analogies work. There are always contenders, always challengers to the champion; there is always a need for one more fight.

That means free trade - the core of Bush philosophy - on US terms. It means economic clout which US com- panies can control. No crouch- ing tigers or hidden dragons, just a cowed sparring partner who knows when to take a dive. The tough way is the only way. Let another American century roll.

Alarmist? We should, indeed, be alarmed because the outing of the Chinese obsession shows what national missile defence is really all about: not neutering Pyong-yang, but blocking and humiliating Beijing. Why else stoke Taiwan tension now with a new missile radar sys tem? But alarm alone makes poor policy.

There is some sense to the Rumsfeld exercise. At least it asks what weapons are needed to counter future threats, not what heavy tanks and creaky carriers made sense against Brezhnev. (As, extrapolating, we might ask ourselves what our Euro-fighter is for?) At least it seeks to engage strategic brain. There's nothing wrong with the exercise itself, just with the attitudes and assumptions revealed.

The obvious temptation is to see this review as a return to cold war postures. Wrong. Look forward, not back. This Washington, for the moment, is not bent on defending the American way against some aggressor who would pull it down. Rather, it seeks to impose that way as a global norm. fields.headline: 'Safety abyss' fears for tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: London Underground has deteriorated so much that safety is now a concern, Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner Bob Kiley told the Guardian yesterday.
fields.body:
London Underground has deteriorated so much that safety is now a concern, Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner Bob Kiley told the Guardian yesterday.

Mr Kiley, speaking after talks on the future of the system collapsed again, said: "There comes a point with the physical deterioration and the level of management distraction where safety rears its head.

"It is getting as bad in a hurry as the New York City subway when I took it over and that was tipping into the abyss of unsafety."

The failure of the government negotiators and Mr Kiley to reach a deal on the plans to part-privatise the tube leaves Tony Blair facing the prospect of a damaging judicial review in the run-up to a general election.

Mr Kiley said that the talks broke down on Friday night when the government withdrew several concessions it had made over its public private partnership plan (PPP).

Mr Kiley - brought in by Mr Livingstone, London's mayor, to turn around the Underground - said: "The government is just not going to move. The problem is there has been no investment in it as far as living memory can recall and that has to change.

"They have a proposal but it is a dumb proposal and we are trying to get it back into the land of the sane."

Under the PPP, private infrastructure companies have been bidding for contracts to renew and maintain the system while the running of the trains remains in the public sector. Mr Kiley has said that without unified management control, and in particular without full management control of maintenance, the PPP would not only be prohibitively expensive but dangerous, repeating the mistakes of rail privatisation which led to the Hatfield disaster.

He told the Guardian that the government had withdrawn concessions which gave him power over appointments to the boards of the private contractors and influence over priorities in maintenance. He said that, contrary to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott's allegations, he had made no new demands in the last 10 days.

"I wish I could understand why they would have offered these things, if they were going to withdraw them, other than perhaps to keep us quiet," he said. He thought his team could wait only until tomorrow before turning to a judicial review.

The cost of the delays also became apparent during the weekend. The private consortiums bidding for the PPP contracts have access to a government "compensation fund" to help meet the costs of bidding - and the Guardian has learned that the fund has now been increased to about £40m.

The Treasury insists that the risk associated with major capital investment projects must be transferred to the private sector. But during negotiations it conceded that public subsidy of an average of £1bn a year will be needed over the next seven and a half years.

Mr Kiley, although strongly opposed to the PPP finance plans, made concessions on those points. "The Treasury had a dream at the beginning of this PPP having no exposure for the government. But of course it's mostly not private money," he said.

Sources close to Mr Livingstone blamed the private bidders for putting the government under intense pressure over the concessions. Mr Kiley said he thought the bidders were frustrated but unlikely to walk away since that would make them ineligible for money from the compensation fund.

Mr Prescott said on Breakfast with Frost yesterday that talks had broken down because Mr Kiley had made new demands and that he was waiting for a letter from Mr Kiley about the state of negotiations.

A government spokesperson said: "We have had nearly 100 meetings over the last six weeks, with very intensive negotiations, and he has bought some things to the table very late in the day that we cannot accommodate."

fields.headline: Views from the summit
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Remember Cool Britannia? There wasn't much to be seen at the EU's Stockholm summit as its worthy goals of economic modernisation and deregulation disappeared in the smoke of livestock carcasses being burnt across the land. Tony Blair was up there with the other big guys around the table, but his mind was on Cumbria and the grim logistics of mass slaughter. Still, at least fellow leaders were supportive over foot and mouth. Even Jacques Chirac said this was no time to be blaming anyone. The PM looked tense and drawn as the crisis deepened and the will-he-won't-he election date question snowballed.
fields.body:
Remember Cool Britannia? There wasn't much to be seen at the EU's Stockholm summit as its worthy goals of economic modernisation and deregulation disappeared in the smoke of livestock carcasses being burnt across the land. Tony Blair was up there with the other big guys around the table, but his mind was on Cumbria and the grim logistics of mass slaughter. Still, at least fellow leaders were supportive over foot and mouth. Even Jacques Chirac said this was no time to be blaming anyone. The PM looked tense and drawn as the crisis deepened and the will-he-won't-he election date question snowballed.

And it was a measure of the seriousness of the crisis that we heard very little about how Britain was winning the European argument, that things were going "our" way, though Blair did do a lot to mould the agenda for last year's Lisbon "dot.com" summit, which set the ambitious 10-year targets that these annual economic gatherings are supposed to monitor.

Stockholm's official message was it's a long haul, things are moving in the right direction, Europe should be a safe haven for investors as uncertainties shake the US and Japan. Measuring progress was never going to produce exciting headlines, yet watching the carefully spun endgame was a useful reminder of how national politics - and alliances - still rule.

Germany's Gerhard Schröder made clear that despite the ructions with Chirac at Nice last December, the Berlin-Paris axis was still vital to keep the union ticking over: that meant he would not press France to open up its electricity and gas markets before next year's elections - a key Lisbon goal. Fritz Bolkestein, the thunderously quotable Dutch internal market commissioner, was furious. "Ideological, banal and cliched," sniped back Hubert Vedrine, the French foreign minister. Romano Prodi looked understandably gloomy. "Looks like the dinosaurs have won again," sighed one eurocrat.

 Swedes run a well-wired summit, as you would expect from the world's leading information economy: even the entertainment, in the soaring elegance of Stockholm town hall, was amazingly hi-tech, with virtual handshakes and electronic polling. (Add in the ice sculptures, a jazz quartet and understated smoked fish catering and you realise how dismal it will be when future EU talkfests are all held in Brussels, a misguided attempt to stop the travelling circus that so exhausted everyone at Nice.) Not everything went Goran Persson's way. With Russia's Vladimir Putin and Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski both in town, the Swedish premier was criticised for being unfocused. But foreign minister Anna Lindh won plaudits for browbeating last year's freedom-fighting Kosovo Albanians into condemning the terrorist violence of their kinsmen across the border. It's a shame that this latest Balkan flare-up has come before the much discussed EU rapid reaction force is ready to do the business instead of Nato. When Yugoslavia began to slide into war in 1991, a now happily forgotten foreign minister declared that Europe's hour had come. It was not true then, and it still isn't true now.

 Stockholm showed that you can flounder through a sea of paper in the EU and still not know very much. So a timely tribute at today's European Freedom of Information Awards in London to Tony Bunyan of Statewatch, working doggedly to advance transparency in Brussels as it launches the great "governance" debate - Prodi's way of describing how citizens and institutions should connect. Jacob Soderman, the EU ombudsman, observed recently that the union's bitterly contested charter of fundamental rights includes the right to good administration. "You don't run that much danger of being tortured in Europe these days," quipped the gloomy looking Finn, "but you do have a good chance of being very badly governed."

 Blair and Jose-Maria Aznar, the Spanish prime minister, get on famously well, but still failed to dispel the clouds that are blotting out the "single European sky", the project that aims to cut air traffic congestion and reduce costs and delays for millions of travellers. The problem is the status of Gibraltar airport. This is a murky tale of national loyalties beating in supposedly supranational breasts. Result: centuries-old colonial anomaly blocks sensible pan-European harmonisation. Blair, say the Foreign Office's finest, singed Aznar's beard by insisting the project stayed firmly in the summit conclusions, increasing pressure for a deal in time for Gothenburg in June. Watch this (air)space.

webTitle: Young Britons out of sync with continental counterparts on EU

fields.headline: Young Britons out of sync with continental counterparts on EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Young people in Britain disagree with their contemporaries in France, Germany and Italy about most of the key issues affecting the future of Europe.
fields.body:
Young people in Britain disagree with their contemporaries in France, Germany and Italy about most of the key issues affecting the future of Europe.

In Britain the under-35s are preoccupied with the state of education and health services, whereas in mainland Europe they are more interested in the environment, global warming, unemployment and immigration.

The younger generation in Britain is more Eurosceptic and less likely to proclaim a European identity, according to an international opinion poll published today by Time magazine.

The survey, carried out by Mori, measured the attitudes of people aged 21 to 35 to establish the mood of "Generation Europe", the first to grow up under a unified Europe. It found that only 21% of the British sample considered themselves to be more European than British, compared with 31% of French, 36% of Germans and 42% of Italians in respect of their own nationality.

Young people in all four countries thought the European parliament would have more power than national governments by 2010, but the British were the least happy with this outcome.

They would prefer their government to have three times more power than the European parliament, while the Italians would be happy with equal shares.

There is a measure of agreement between the British and French on the question of sexual fidelity. Just over half the younger women in both countries said they were certain to remain faithful to their partner for life, compared with 29% of German women and 30% of Italians.

Among younger men, 30% of British and 34% of French express similar certainty, compared with 20% of Germans and 21% of Italians.

In mainland Europe, the issue of greatest long-term concern was pollution, global warming and the environment. This was identified as one of the top three issues by 69% in Italy but by only 48% in Britain, where 52% named both health and education.

Unemployment was mentioned by 27% in Britain, 42% in Germany, 43% in France and 55% in Italy. The British were also much less concerned about immigration and race relations.

Young Europeans supported further research on genetic engineering. On average across the four countries 48% wanted further research, double the number who opposed it. But the British and French were more inclined to want a ban or restrictions on using the technology to decide the gender or genetic make-up of an unborn child.

In all four countries, at least three quarters of the under-35s relied on television and newspapers for information about what was going on in the world.

Perhaps surprisingly for this age group, the internet was mentioned by only 6% in Britain, 3% in Germany and Italy, and 2% in France.

Stewart Lewis, Mori's director, said the survey reflected "the still-divided nature of Europe, in our younger generation, and some surprising opinions.

"These people are tomorrow's leaders and we, not to mention today's leaders, should take very seriously their concerns, issues, aspirations and hopes".

fields.headline: Hospital row fuels independent's challenge
fields.standfirst: After local council success of Health Concern campaigners, a retired consultant sets his sights on parliament
fields.trailText: Richard Taylor spent 23 years working at Kidderminster hospital in Hereford and Worcester. Now he paces its grounds pointing at buildings that are being gutted or mothballed.
fields.body:
Richard Taylor spent 23 years working at Kidderminster hospital in Hereford and Worcester. Now he paces its grounds pointing at buildings that are being gutted or mothballed.

The hospital is being down-sized under NHS plans which promise to raise standards of care. But the plans have evoked fierce resistance from a diehard band of campaigners who call themselves Health Concern.

Two years ago, Health Concern stopped the futile business of raising petitions and took to the ballot box.

It was a last resort and it worked. They won seven seats in elections to Wyre Forest district council, which covers the towns of Kidderminster, Stourport-on-Severn and Bewdley.

"I'll never forget the feeling when the first result came up," Dr Taylor recalled. "We suddenly realised that it was possible. That evening was absolutely electric."

Last year they took another 11 council seats, making them the largest member of the ruling Rainbow Alliance, and reducing the Labour vote to less than 20%.

Now Dr Taylor, 66, a retired consultant, is challenging Labour incumbent David Lock, who took Wyre Forest with a majority of nearly 7,000 in the 1997 landslide. Mr Lock is understandably anxious.

The MP, a junior minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, whose wife practises as a GP locally, accuses Health Concern of distorting the facts to whip up alarm among the voters of Kidderminster.

"Local people are not taken in by campaigners who try to pretend they know more about the health service than doctors, nurses and the health authority," he insisted.

Dr Taylor appeals to tradition, with all the patriarchal dignity of the old-style consultant.

"The hospital is woven into the fabric of Kidderminster life," he said. "There has been a hospital here since 1920. It has been supported by the people all the way through - the [hospital's] League of Friends has raised between £2.5m and £3m in the last decade."

Last September, Kidderminster's accident and emergency facilities were downgraded to a minor injuries unit. Its in-pa tient facilities were closed. This meant that any blue light emergency cases would have to travel 18 miles to Worcester royal infirmary.

In February that decision had fatal consequences when a pensioner, John Jones, who lived five minutes from Kidderminster hospital, had a heart attack.

The ambulance drove past Kidderminster's closed A&E on a 50 minute journey to Worcester, where Mr Jones was pronounced dead after 20 minutes.

The tragedy was grist to Health Concern's mill; a deeply emotive case which appeared to encapsulate the human cost of Kidderminster hospital's demise.

But while the loss of services at Kidderminster has made for politics with instant appeal, not all the facts stack up on Dr Taylor's side.

The reforms turned on axeing in-patient services at Kidderminster in exchange for building a state-of-the-art hospital which will open in Worcester next April.

The second reason was medical. Around 10 years ago, according to a consultant who worked there, junior doctors at Kidderminster were working well over 100 hours a week.

After years of campaigning, moves to reduce junior doctors' hours were brought in. But that made providing cover at the small hospital increasingly difficult.

Supporters of the changes say that providing the kind of intensive staffing levels needed for an accident and emergency department was rapidly becoming impossible.

A bigger regional centre also offered patients a wider choice of specialists familiar with the latest techniques in each field.

James Goodman, chairman of the Wyre Forest GPs' Association, said: "We didn't necessarily fully support the changes at the start of the process. But after a lot of negotiation we had to agree that it was the only effective way forward. It finally came down to staffing; the need to have more specialists, and the increasing problem of junior doctors' hours."

Turning the clock back now is impossible, he believes. The new Worcester facilities will be better and safer than the old Kidderminster hospital.

The case of John Jones was a "terrible tragedy", he concedes. "But these cases do happen. Even if Kidderminster had been open, the outcome might not have been different."

If elected, it will be a rare victory for a candidate without the backing of a big party machine, following in the footsteps of Martin Bell, who is at present Britain's only independent MP.

"I think we have started a revolt against the major party political system. If we achieve an MP we will send a signal to other areas to say that they can do something by having independent people running."

Angela Thompson, a hospital catering worker and Unison branch secretary, threatens to dent Labour's majority by standing as a Socialist Alliance candidate against privatisation.

Back in Wyre Forest, Clive Joyce, editor of the local paper, notes that complaints from readers about the NHS have mushroomed since Kidderminster's A&E department closed.

Letters have flooded in bemoaning long waits on trolleys in the outdated facilities of Worcester royal infirmary.

This hospital's main buildings at Castle Street and Ronkswood in Worcester will also be replaced by the new PFI hospital, when it opens.

He may be over-confident; on the doorsteps of Wyre Forest, the complex arguments for change are difficult to deliver.

fields.headline: Worst offenders face hi-tech crackdown
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The 1,500 most persistent teenage offenders in Britain will from this week be under round-the-clock surveillance and supervision, using the most sophisticated tagging technology, as part of Tony Blair's promise to introduce "zero tolerance of yob culture".
fields.body:
The 1,500 most persistent teenage offenders in Britain will from this week be under round-the-clock surveillance and supervision, using the most sophisticated tagging technology, as part of Tony Blair's promise to introduce "zero tolerance of yob culture".

The £45m programme developed by the government's youth justice board is designed to keep some of Britain's teenage tearaways out of custody and ensure that they get the most intensive programme of education and other activities to prevent them going on to become career criminals.

It will include help with drug and alcohol abuse, mental health problems and support for their parents.

They will also face the most rigorous supervision yet with their movements tracked 24 hours a day using electronic tagging combined with voice verification systems under which the teenagers will have to phone in from predesignated numbers to confirm their whereabouts. If they go out in the evenings or weekends they will have to be accompanied by youth justice staff.

The first phase of the scheme is part of the government's package of reforms of the youth justice system which come into effect this week. It will cover 1,500 teenagers, mostly aged 15 and 16, in 22 of the most deprived parts of Britain.

The new programme will be used for those offenders who have already been charged or warned at least four times in the previous 12 months and now face a serious threat of being locked up.

"This new system of intensive supervision and surveillance programmes will cover the 3% of offenders who we believe commit a quarter of all offences," said the home secretary, Jack Straw. "They will supervise them closely, give them education and training, and oblige them to take part in intensive courses designed to change offending behaviour.

He added: "We will now be able to make sure we know exactly where these offenders are and what they are doing when they are sentenced in the community." The second phase of the scheme covering a further 1,000 young offenders will begin in June.

It will be backed up by two further youth justice schemes to be announced this week. The first will provide an extra £6m to youth inclusion programmes for 3,500 hard-to-reach youngsters who live on 70 of the worst high-crime housing estates. They will be aimed at giving the 50 most high-risk 13- to 16-year-olds on each estate at least 10 hours a week extra support.

The programmes will include educational and cultural activities such as music DJ classes, graffiti art, basketball, martial arts and seminars on drugs, sex and healthcare. While these special programmes will only be open to those children most at risk of drifting into crime, they will be backed up by school holiday schemes open to all young people on each during the easter and summer breaks.

The government is also expected to announce that it intends to double the average amount of education and training received by youngsters locked up by the courts, from 15 hours to 30 hours a week.

Related articles
Escape route from the mean streets

fields.headline: Police doubts over licensed foxhunting
fields.standfirst:
Middle-way option raises problems of enforcement as peers prepare to oppose outright ban tonight

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Moves to ban foxhunting are likely to be rejected by the House of Lords tonight, with peers defying the overwhelming will of the Commons to outlaw the pursuit.
fields.byline: Lucy Ward, Rob Evans and David Hencke
fields.body:
Moves to ban foxhunting are likely to be rejected by the House of Lords tonight, with peers defying the overwhelming will of the Commons to outlaw the pursuit.

As the government's hunting bill moves to the committee stage in the upper house, peers are widely expected to oppose an outright ban in favour of a "middle-way" option, which would allow hunting to continue under licence.

But a police chiefs' letter obtained by the Guardian reveals that the compromise - thought to be gaining the support of government - raises difficulties, particularly about who would enforce licensing.

There will also be strong Lords support for a third option allowing hunting to be self-regulated. That proposal is backed by the Countryside Alliance, although the organisation is fighting an internal battle between hardliners, who oppose any change to the status quo, and those within the leadership who believe it may have to concede that statutory regulation is preferable to an outright ban.

Lady Mallalieu, the Labour peer and alliance president, has written to pro-hunting peers expressing support for self-regulation, but conceding that she will abstain on - rather than oppose - the middle-way option.

Alliance spokesman Simon Hart yesterday said the organisation backed self-regulation but "we would be letting our members down if we didn't consider any political outcome of this process".

Tonight's votes, which are likely to be preceded by prolonged debate, come at a highly awkward time for the government as it attempts to convince the countryside that it understands the pressures caused by the foot and mouth epidemic.

The hunting controversy, which has seen Tony Blair pledge to outlaw the pursuit and MPs repeatedly vote overwhelmingly for a ban, has been a central factor in claims by some in the countryside that the Labour government ignores rural interests.

One of the considerations in favour of a May 3 election for the government is that the bill would then fall, with Labour promising another free Commons vote on the issue in its manifesto, while making clear that did not mean party support for a ban.

Peers, like MPs, are given a free vote on hunting, but they do not split along party lines. Baroness Mallalieu and the broadcaster and fellow Labour peer, Lord Bragg, were among the most vociferous opponents of a ban during the bill's second-reading debate in the Lords this month.

Peers will vote first this evening on the option of a ban on fox and stag hunting, which they are almost certain to reject. They are then expected to vote on the option of self-regulation, and finally on the middle-way compromise in which hunting would be supervised by a regulatory body of landowners, farmers and animal welfare groups.

If the hardline self-regulation option is rejected, pro-hunting peers could choose to back licensed hunting, backed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, and towards which Mr Blair is inclining.

Despite the compromise appeal of the middle way for the government, police chiefs are wary of confusion about their roles, and that of the new regulatory body.

The Association of Chief Police Officers (Acpo) "expressed concern about who would have responsibility for what", in the letter obtained by the Guardian.

The police chiefs warned that there was "a lack of clear powers" for the inspectors appointed by the regulatory body. The option "only talks about 'arrangements' and gives no specific powers to those tasked with inspection, which may prove difficult".

Those who do not obtain a licence could be fined up to £5,000 for illegal hunting. The association believed that police were being given "no powers" under this option to deal with this unlawful activity.

"We feel it needs to be made clear who will have responsibility for enforcing this part of the legislation," the letter said.

Acpo wrote the letter in December after it was shown an early draft of the bill and was consulted about the options.

fields.headline: Further down the tube
fields.standfirst:
London wants it to be accountable

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The last thing Tony Blair wants during an election campaign is to be fighting a war on two fronts. Yet the way things are going that is exactly what will happen.
fields.body:
The last thing Tony Blair wants during an election campaign is to be fighting a war on two fronts. Yet the way things are going that is exactly what will happen. He will be fighting to capture the loyalty of angry voters in the countryside where Labour won around 120 rural seats in 1997, while at the same time trying to curb the wrath of the metropolis over the government's inability to tackle the capital's disintegrating tube system.

Talks between the government and Bob Kiley, London's transport commissioner, broke down on Friday when - Kiley claims - the government withdrew concessions it had made over its public-private partnership plan (PPP). Mr Kiley, who has extensive experience of similar circumstances on the New York subway, claims that deterioration is reaching the point where safety is becoming a concern.

Both sides have made substantial concessions. The Treasury, which is calling most of the shots, has conceded that as much as £1bn a year of public money will have to be injected into the underground for up to seven years, in addition to PPP money. Kiley, for his part, has dropped his insistence on bond finance rather than the PPP alternative. He hasn't dropped his enthusiasm for bonds, but merely admitted that if the government wants to go ahead with a scheme that he regards as wrong and a waste of money, then it has a right to do so.

Where he will not compromise is on strategic control of the project in terms of investment decisions and maintenance. He claims that the government (presumably as a result of protests from the infrastructure companies) has withdrawn concessions giving him power over appointments to the boards of the private contractors and influence over priorities of maintenance.

It is pointed out that two different companies will be operating the two north-south links on the system (involving the Victoria and Northern lines). Suppose both companies decide to make major investments on capital structure or maintenance at the same time: this could bring north-south travel to a halt. Not unreasonably, he wants a big say in those decisions. What Londoners want is two things. First, an efficient railway as quickly as possible and, second, in the light of the Railtrack disasters, they want to know who to praise or blame if something goes wrong. If Mr Kiley gets his way, we will know exactly who to praise or blame and that is how it should be.

webTitle: Andrew O'Hagan investigates the British farming crisis

fields.headline: Bitter harvest
fields.standfirst:
Farming lies at the very core of our British identity. It is what defines us. But in recent years BSE, swine fever and now foot and mouth have brought an industry already in deep financial crisis to its knees. Andrew O'Hagan 's four-part investigation into the decline of the British countryside begins in rural Suffolk ... and Sainsbury's

Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Farming lies at the very core of our British identity. It is what defines us. But in recent years BSE, swine fever and now foot and mouth have brought an industry already in deep financial crisis to its knees. Andrew O'Hagan 's four-part investigation into the decline of the British countryside begins in rural Suffolk ... and Sainsbury's.
fields.body:
British farming hanged itself on the expectation of plenty. One day, not long ago, I was in the Sainsbury's superstore on the Cromwell Road in London. Three of the company's top brass ushered me down the aisles, pointing here, gasping there, each of them in something of a swoon at the heavenliness on offer. "People want to be interested," said Alison Austin, a technical adviser. "You've just got to capture their imagination." We were standing by the sandwiches and the takeaway hot foods lined up in front of the whooshing doors.

Alison swept her hand over the colourful bazaar of sandwich choices. "This is a range called Be Good to Yourself," she said, "with fresh, healthy fillings, and here we have the more gourmet range, Taste the Difference. We have a policy of using British produce where we can. With carrots, for example, we want to provide economic profitability to the farmer, using the short carrots for one line of produce, and the bigger ones for another."

The Cromwell Road branch of Sainsbury's is what they call a "flagship store". It is not only a giant emporium; it is also grander than any other store in the chain, selling more champagne, fresh fish, organic meat and Special Selection food. Six varieties of caviar are available all year round.

"People are gaining more confidence in sushi," said Peter Morrison, manager, trading division. "We have joined forces with very credible traders such as Yo! Sushi, and we aim to educate customers by bringing them here." Alison handed me a cup of liquid grass from Crussh, the fresh juice bar. There was something unusually potent about that afternoon - the thoughts in my head as I tilted the cup - and for a moment the whole supermarket seemed to spin around me. People wandered by. The place was a madhouse of bleeping barcodes. "How do you like it?" one of them asked. I gulped it down and focused my eyes. "It tastes like an English field," I said.

The store manager guided me to the cut flowers. "We are the UK's largest flower sellers," he told me. "The biggest year-on-year increase of any product in the store is in flowers." The bunches before me were a far cry from the sad carnations and petrol-station bouquets that now lie about the country as tributes to the suddenly dead. The ones he showed me had a very smart, sculptural appearance, and they sold for £25 a pop. "We have 40 kinds of apple," Alison said, "and again, we take the crop, the smaller ones being more for the economy bags."

"Someone came in on Christmas Eve and asked for banana leaves," the keen young product manager over in fruit and vegetables told me, "and you know something? We had them."

You would have to say that Sainsbury's is amazing. It has everything - 50 kinds of tea, 400 kinds of bread, kosher chicken schnitzels, Cornish pilchards - and everywhere I turned that day there was some bamboozling elixir of the notion of plenty. Their own-brand products are made to high standards: the fresh meat, for example, is subject to much higher vigilance over date and provenance than any meat in Europe. "Some things take a while," Peter Morrison said. "You can put something out and it won't work. Then you have to think again, about how to market it, how to package it, where to place it, and six months later you'll try again and it might work."

We stopped beside the yoghurts. "Now this," he said, picking up a tub of Devon yoghurt, "is made at a place called Stapleton Farm. We got wind of how good it was: a tiny operation, we went down there, we got some technical advisers involved, and now look, it's brilliant!" I tasted some of the Stapleton yoghurt. It was much better than the liquid grass. "It's about the rural business growing," Peter said. "Real food is what people want. This couple in Devon" - he gestured to the yoghurt pots - "started from virtually nowhere. Of course, they were nervous at first about working with such a major retailer. But these people are the new kind of producer."

Passing the condiments aisle I saw an old man standing in front of the Oxo cubes. He looked a bit shaky. His lips were moving and he had one of the foil-wrapped Oxo cubes in the palm of his hand. "People go to Tuscany," Alison was saying, "and they eat Parma ham and they come back here and they want it all the time. So we go out and find the best."

You are always alone with the oddness of modern consumption. Walking under the white lights of Sainsbury's, you find out just who you are. The reams of cartons, the pyramids of tins: there they stand on the miles of shelves, the story of how we live now. Cereal boxes look out at you with their breakfast-ready smiles, containing flakes of bran, handfuls of oats, which come from fields mentioned in the Domesday Book.

And here you are in the year 2001 - choosing. We went over to the aisle with the cooking oils and Alison did one of her long arm-flourishes: "When I was a child," she said, "my mother used a bottle of prescription olive oil to clean the salad bowl. Now look!" A line of tank-green bottles stretched into the distance. "Choice!' she said.
