(Or, as head office puts it, "in 1992 Sainsbury developed a protocol for growing crops under Integrated Crop Management System principles. Following these principles can result in reduced usage of pesticides by combining more traditional aspects of agriculture and new technologies.")

In the meat department there is much talk of "friendly", "animal well-being", "humane", "safe", "high standards" and "provenance". The executives spent their time with me highlighting what they see as the strength of the partnerships with British farming which keep everyone happy. "The consumer is what matters," said Alison, "and we believe in strong, creative, ethical retailing."

Down at the front of the store again I put one of the gourmet sandwiches on a table and opened it up. The bread was grainy. The lettuce was pale green and fresh. Pieces of chicken and strips of pepper were neatly set out on a thin layer of butter. The open sandwich was a tableau of unwritten biographies: grains and vegetables and meat were glistening there, uncontroversially, their stories of economic life and farming history and current disaster safely behind them.

When I was a boy we had a painting above the phone table. It was the only real painting in the house, and it showed a wide field in the evening with a farm at the far end. The farmhouse had a light in one of the windows. The painting had been a wedding present, and my mother thought it was a bit dour and dirty-looking, so she did the frame up with some white gloss, which flaked over the years. I used to lie on the hall carpet and look at the picture of the farm for ages; the field was golden enough to run through and get lost in, and the brown daubs of farmhouse were enough to send me into a swoon of God-knows-what.

I suppose it was all part of a general childhood boredom, and it meant nothing, but it seemed very heightening at the time. The painting raised my feelings up on stilts, and made me imagine myself to be part of an older world, where people lived and worked in a state of sentimental peace. All rot, of course. But lovely rot. Sometimes I would come downstairs in the night and shine my torch on the painting.

At one time it seemed as if all the farms around our way had been abandoned or pulled down to make room for housing. Past railway lines and beyond the diminishing fields we would find old, dilapidated Ayrshire farmhouses with rusted tractors and old wooden drinking troughs lying about in the yard, and we would play in them for half the summer. Cranberry Moss Farm, McLaughlin's Farm on Byrehill, Ashgrove Farm, the Old Mains - nowadays they are all buried under concrete, except for the farm at Toddhill, which became a home for the mentally handicapped. In my youth they had been like haunted houses. There were echoes in the barns.

Those farms seemed as remote from the daily reality of our lives as the one in the wedding picture. We would never live there: computer factories and industrial cleaners would soon replace them as providers of jobs, and it was these new places, in our Ayrshire, that spoke of the lives we were supposed one day to live. We took it for granted - much too early, as it turned out - that farming was a thing of the past, a thing people did be fore they were sophisticated like us. We never considered the stuff on our plates; we thought the school milk came on a lorry from London. Never for a second did my friends and I think of ourselves as coming from a rural community; like all British suburban kids, we lived as dark, twinkling fallout from a big city, in our case Glasgow; and we thought carports and breezeblocks were part of the natural order.

But, of course, there was plenty of agriculture. It surrounded us. The farms had just been pushed out a wee bit - and wee could seem larger than it was, at least for us, shocked by the whiteness of our new buildings into thinking a thatched roof was the height of exotic. Everything changed for me with the discovery of Robert Burns: those torn-up fields out there were his fields, those bulldozed farms as old as his words, both old and new to me then. Burns was ever a slave to the farming business: he is the patron saint of struggling farmers and poor soil.

But in actual fact, despite our thoughts and our recovery from our thoughts, in the early 70s British farming was in a pretty good state. JGS and Frances Donaldson's Farming in Britain Today, published around this time, just before Britain's entry into the Common Market, expressed the view that a beautiful balance had been struck.

Today, agriculture is one of Britain's most efficient industries. It has a controlled growth of 3.5% a year, and in the last 10 years its labour productivity has increased at twice the rate for industry as a whole. It supplies approximately 50% of the nation's food. Travelling through England today with its trim hedges, arable and ley farming, highly capitalised and intensively used buildings, it is hard to imagine the broken-backed appearance of yesterday.

"Yesterday" meant the 20s and 30s. But now, as I write, the situation of farming in this country is perhaps worse than it has ever been, and the countryside itself is dying. We are at a stage where it is difficult to imagine British farming surviving in any of its traditional forms; and for millions living on these islands, a long-term crisis has been turning into a terminal disaster.

Three years ago, agriculture contributed £6.9bn to the British economy, around 1% of the gross domestic product. It represented 5.3% of the value of UK exports. The figure for 1999 was £1.8bn. The total area of agricultural land is 18.6 million hectares, 76% of the entire land surface. According to an agricultural census in June 1999, there has been a decrease of 5.3% in the area given over to crops, as a result of a decrease in cereals and an increase in set-aside. According to a recent report from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff), the 1999 figures show a drop in the labour force of 3.6%, the largest decrease in a dozen years. "These results," the report continues, "are not unexpected given the financial pressures experienced by most sectors of the industry over the last few years."

Farmers' income fell by over 60% between 1995 and 1999. Despite increases in production, earnings were lower in 1999 by £518m. The value of wheat fell by 6.5%, and barley by 5.4%. Pigs were £99m down on 1998, and lambs £126m down; the value of poultry meat fell by £100m, or 7.4%; the value of milk fell by £45m; and the value of eggs by 10%, or £40m. A giant profit gap has opened up throughout the industry: rape seed, for example, which costs £200 a ton to produce, is selling for £170 per ton (including the government subsidy); a savoy cabbage, costing 13p to produce, is sold by the farmer for 11 pence, and by the supermarkets for 47p.

Hill farmers earned less than £8,000 a year on average in 1998-99 (and 60% of that came to them in subsidies), but late last year, when I first started talking to farmers, many were making nothing at all, and most were heavily in debt to the bank. A suicide helpline was set up and the Royal College of Psychiatrists expressed concern at the increased number of suicides among hill farmers in particular. A spokesman for Maff said that agriculture was costing every British taxpayer £4 a week. After Germany and France, the UK makes the largest annual contribution to the Common Agricultural Policy, and yet, even before the great rise in the strength of the pound, British farmers' production costs were higher than anywhere else in the EU, to a large extent because of the troubles of recent years.

"Everything is a nightmare," one farmer told me. "There are costs everywhere, and even the subsidy is spent long before you receive it. We are all in hock to the banks - and they say we are overmanned, but we don't have anybody here, just us, and children maybe, and an absolute fucking nightmare from top to bottom." The strong pound, the payment of subsidy cheques in euros, the BSE crisis, swine fever, and now foot and mouth disease, together with overproduction in the rest of the world's markets - these are the reasons for the worsened situation.

But they are not the cause of the longer-term crisis in British farming: local overproduction is behind that, and it is behind the destruction of the countryside, too. For all the savage reductions of recent times, farming still employs too many and produces too much: even before the end of February, when diseased livestock burned on funeral pyres 130ft high, some farmers were killing their own livestock for want of a profit, or to save the fuel costs incurred in taking them to market.

In Britain nowadays most farmers are given aid - a great deal of aid, but too little to save them - in order to produce food nobody wants to buy. The way livestock subsidies work - per animal - means that there is an incentive for farmers to increase flocks and herds rather than improve the marketing of what they have got. As things are, subsidies save some farmers, but they are a useless way to shore up an ailing industry, except perhaps in wartime.

The evidence of what is wrong is out in the British land itself. Farming - more even than coal, more than ships, steel, or Posh and Becks - is at the centre of who British people think they are. It has a heady, long-standing, romantic and sworn place in the cultural imagination: the death of farming will not be an easy one in the green and pleasant land.

Rain was running down Nelson's Column and Trafalgar Square was awash with visitors inspecting the lions. An American woman stepping into the National Gallery was worried about her camera lens. "This British weather will be the end of us," she said, as her husband shook out the umbrellas. One group sat around Turner's Rain, Steam and Speed - The Great Western Railway. The instructor encouraged them to express something about the atmosphere of the picture. "Does it make you shiver?" she said. "It's like outside," one of the children replied. But most of them were interested in the hare running ahead of the train. "Will it die?" one of them asked. "Where is it running to?"

The future. You feel the force of change in some of these weathery British pictures. Over the last few months I kept coming back to this room, and sitting here, further up from the Turners, looking at Constable's The Cornfield. We see an English country lane at harvest time where nothing is unusual, but everything is spectacular. Corn spills down an embankment, going to grass and ferns, going to pepper saxifrage or hog's fennel, dandelion and corn poppy, down to a stream. Giant trees reach up to the dark, gathering clouds.

At their foot, a small boy lies flat on his front drinking from the stream. He wears a red waistcoat and has a tear in the left leg of his trousers. A dog with a marked shadow looks up and past him with its pink tongue out. The sheep in front of the dog are making for a broken gate that opens on to the cornfield. A plough is stowed in a ditch; the farmer advances from the field; and in the distance, which stretches for miles, you see people already at work.

The picture has philosophical currency: people will still say it is an important part of what is meant by the term "British" - or, at any rate, "English". This is the country delegates sing about at the party conferences, the one depicted in heritage brochures and on biscuit tins, the corner that lives in the sentiments of war poetry, an image at the heart of Britain's view of itself.

But here's the shock: it no longer exists. Everything in Constable's picture is a small ghost still haunting the national consciousness. The corn poppy has pretty much gone, and so have the workers. The days of children drinking from streams are over, too. And the livestock? We will come to that. Let me just say that a number of the farmers I spoke to in the winter of 2000 were poisoning their own fields. The Constable picture fades into a new world of intensive industrial farming and environmental blight.

The Cornfield is said to show the path along which Constable walked from East Bergholt across the River Stour and the fields to his school at Dedham. Last October I made my way to Dedham. It was another wet day, and many of the trucks and lorries splashing up water on the M25 were heading to the coast to join a fuel blockade. On the radio a newscaster described what was happening: "The situation for the modern British farmer has probably never been so dire, and a further rise in the price of fuel could kill many of them off."

Before leaving I had rung a pig farmer, David Barker, whose farm is north of Stowmarket in Suffolk. Barker is 50 years old. His family has been farming pigs in Suffolk for four generations; they have lived and worked on the present farm since 1957. He owns 1,250 acres and 110 sows, which he breeds and sells at a finishing weight of 95 kilos. Among his crops are winter wheat, winter-sown barley, grass for seed production, some peas for canning, 120 acres of field beans, 30 acres of spring oats and 100 acres of set-aside.

"Five years ago I was selling wheat for £125 a ton, and now it's £58.50," Barker said. "I was selling pigs for £90, and now they're down to £65. And meanwhile all our costs have doubled: fuel, stock, fertiliser. There's hardly a farmer in East Anglia who's making a profit. The direct payments from Europe have declined also because they're paid out in euros.'

"What about swine fever?" I asked, innocent of the epidemics to come.

"There are over 500 farms that haven't been able to move pigs since August," he said. "Immediately, this becomes an agricultural nightmare. The pigs are breeding, the feed is extortionate, and you end up relying on things like the Welfare Disposal Scheme, where pigs are removed for next to nothing. Gordon Brown's bright idea: they give you £50 for a pig that costs £80 to produce."

"What can be done?" The stormy weather was making his phone crackly.

"Well, this government has no interest in farming," he said. "People in the countryside in England feel they are ignored and derided and, frankly, it appears that the government would be much happier just to import food. This is the worst agricultural crisis in dozens of years. We're not making any money anywhere. Take milk: the dairy farmer receives seven pence in subsidy for every pint; it takes between 10 and 12p to produce, and it costs 39p when it arrives at your door. A lot of farmers are giving up, and many of those who stay are turning to contract farming - increasing their land, making prairies, to make it pay."

"Is that the only way to reduce costs?"

"Yes, that. Or by going to France."

David Barker used the word "nightmare" at least a dozen times during my conversation with him. He told me about a friend of his, another Suffolk farmer, who, earlier in the swine fever debacle, had sold his 250 pigs into the disposal scheme, losing £30 on each one. Barker himself was waiting for results of blood tests to see if his pigs had the fever. "If it goes on much longer it will ruin me," he said.

When I arrived at Nigel Rowe's farm near Dedham, only the weather was Constable-like. Out of his window the fields were bare and flat. "European pig meat is cheaper to produce," he said, "because we have higher standards and higher production costs. As soon as foreign bacon gets cheaper by more than 10p per kilo, the housewife swaps. That is the rule."

I asked him if he felt British supermarkets had been good at supporting bacon produced in Essex or Suffolk. "The supermarkets have been very clever at playing the different farming sectors off against each other," he said. "The Danish model is very centralised - they are allowed to produce and market something called Danish Bacon. We are very regional over here, very dominated by the tradition of the local butcher. Supermarkets want the same produce to be available in Scotland as you get in Sussex. Only the Dutch and the Danish can do that, and some of these foreign producers are so powerful - the Danish producers of bacon are much bigger than Tesco."

Nigel has 2,000 pigs. But he is not making money. As well as working the farm, he has a part-time job as caretaker at the local community centre. "In the 70s we were all earning a comfortable living," he said, "and when I was at primary school in the 60s, at least 30 of my schoolmates were connected with farming. Now, in my children's classes, there are three. I had 120 acres and I had to sell it recently to survive. I also had to sell the farm cottage my mother lived in, in order to stay here. That's what I was working on when you came - a little house for my mother."

He looked out of the window at the flatness beyond. "The arithmetic is simple," he said. "When I started in this game it took five tons of grain to buy the year's supply of fuel for the tractor. Now it takes 500 tons. What do you think that means if your acreage is the same? The government seems hell-bent on the old green and pleasant land, but they won't get behind the people who keep it that way." Nigel sat in his living room wearing a rugby shirt and jeans speckled with paint from his mother's new house. "They're not thinking straight," he said. "Our product needs to be marketed - branded, with a flag, which is presently not allowed. It's all wrong. We have to import soya as a protein source for our pigs now because we can't use other animal meat or bone fat. But this country imports tons of Dutch and Danish meat fed on bone fat."

As we walked out of the living room, I noticed there were no pictures on any of the walls. We went outside to the pigsties. The rain was pouring down, the mud thick and sloppy on the ground, and one of Nigel's pigs was burning in an incinerator. As we looked out I asked him what had happened to the land. "The subsidies from the Common Agricultural Policy have got out of hand," he said, "because they are linked to production rather than the environment. Did you know the rivers around here are polluted with fertiliser and crap? We're seeing a massive degradation of rural life in this country. Bakers and dairies have already gone, onions have gone, sugarbeet is gone, beef is pretty much gone, lambs are going."

Before we went into the sty, he asked me if I was "pig-clean". "I'm clean," I said, "unless the fever can come through the phone." Hundreds of healthy-looking pink pigs scuttled around in the hay and the mud. He picked one up. "Farming is passed down," he said, "or it should be. A farm is built up for generation after generation, and when it starts to slip and go - you feel an absolute failure. That's what you feel."

We went around the farm and Nigel explained how things work. The notebook was getting very wet so I put it away. "You feel a failure," he said again, looking into the wind. "The other night I was at a meeting: 140 farmers at a union meeting paying tribute to four hill farmers under 45 who'd committed suicide." He leaned against the side of the barn. "We are no longer an island," he said. "Everything's a commodity."

In Britain nowadays most farmers are given aid - a great deal of aid, but too little to save them - in order to produce food nobody wants to buy. The way livestock subsidies work - per animal - means that there is an incentive for farmers to increase flocks and herds rather than improve the marketing of what they have got. As things are, subsidies save some farmers, but they are a useless way to shore up an ailing industry, except perhaps in wartime. The evidence of what is wrong is out in the British land itself. Farming - more even than coal, more than ships, steel, or Posh and Becks - is at the centre of who British people think they are. It has a heady, long-standing, romantic and sworn place in the cultural imagination: the death of farming will not be an easy one in the green and pleasant land. Rain was running down Nelson's Column and Trafalgar Square was awash with visitors inspecting the lions. An American woman stepping into the National Gallery was worried about her camera lens. "This British weather will be the end of us," she said, as her husband shook out the umbrellas. In the Sackler Room - Room 34 - children with identical haircuts sat down on the wooden floor; they stared at the British weather of long ago, spread in oils with palette knives, and they, too, asked why it was always so fuzzy and so cloudy. One group sat around Turner's Rain, Steam and Speed - The Great Western Railway. The instructor encouraged them to express something about the atmosphere of the picture. "Does it make you shiver?" she said. "It's like outside," one of the children replied. But most of them were interested in the hare running ahead of the train. "Will it die?" one of them asked. "Where is it running to?" The future. You feel the force of change in some of these weathery British pictures. Over the last few months I kept coming back to this room, and sitting here, further up from the Turners, looking at Constable's The Cornfield. We see an English country lane at harvest time where nothing is unusual, but everything is spectacular. Corn spills down an embankment, going to grass and ferns, going to pepper saxifrage or hog's fennel, dandelion and corn poppy, down to a stream. Giant trees reach up to the dark, gathering clouds. At their foot, a small boy lies flat on his front drinking from the stream. He wears a red waistcoat and has a tear in the left leg of his trousers. A dog with a marked shadow looks up and past him with its pink tongue out. The sheep in front of the dog are making for a broken gate that opens on to the cornfield. A plough is stowed in a ditch; the farmer advances from the field; and in the distance, which stretches for miles, you see people already at work. The picture has philosophical currency: people will still say it is an important part of what is meant by the term "British" - or, at any rate, "English". This is the country delegates sing about at the party conferences, the one depicted in heritage brochures and on biscuit tins, the corner that lives in the sentiments of war poetry, an image at the heart of Britain's view of itself. But here's the shock: it no longer exists. Everything in Constable's picture is a small ghost still haunting the national consciousness. The corn poppy has pretty much gone, and so have the workers. The days of children drinking from streams are over, too. And the livestock? We will come to that. Let me just say that a number of the farmers I spoke to in the winter of 2000 were poisoning their own fields. The Constable picture fades into a new world of intensive industrial farming and environmental blight. The Cornfield is said to show the path along which Constable walked from East Bergholt across the River Stour and the fields to his school at Dedham. Last October I made my way to Dedham. It was another wet day, and many of the trucks and lorries splashing up water on the M25 were heading to the coast to join a fuel blockade. On the radio a newscaster described what was happening: "The situation for the modern British farmer has probably never been so dire, and a further rise in the price of fuel could kill many of them off." Before leaving I had rung a pig farmer, David Barker, whose farm is north of Stowmarket in Suffolk. Barker is 50 years old. His family has been farming pigs in Suffolk for four generations; they have lived and worked on the present farm since 1957. He owns 1,250 acres and 110 sows, which he breeds and sells at a finishing weight of 95 kilos. Among his crops are winter wheat, winter-sown barley, grass for seed production, some peas for canning, 120 acres of field beans, 30 acres of spring oats and 100 acres of set-aside. "Five years ago I was selling wheat for £125 a ton, and now it's £58.50," Barker said. "I was selling pigs for £90, and now they're down to £65. And meanwhile all our costs have doubled: fuel, stock, fertiliser. There's hardly a farmer in East Anglia who's making a profit. The direct payments from Europe have declined also because they're paid out in euros.' "What about swine fever?" I asked, innocent of the epidemics to come. "There are over 500 farms that haven't been able to move pigs since August," he said. "Immediately, this becomes an agricultural nightmare. The pigs are breeding, the feed is extortionate, and you end up relying on things like the Welfare Disposal Scheme, where pigs are removed for next to nothing. Gordon Brown's bright idea: they give you £50 for a pig that costs £80 to produce." "What can be done?" The stormy weather was making his phone crackly. "Well, this government has no interest in farming," he said. "People in the countryside in England feel they are ignored and derided and, frankly, it appears that the government would be much happier just to import food. This is the worst agricultural crisis in dozens of years. We're not making any money anywhere. Take milk: the dairy farmer receives seven pence in subsidy for every pint; it takes between 10 and 12p to produce, and it costs 39p when it arrives at your door. A lot of farmers are giving up, and many of those who stay are turning to contract farming - increasing their land, making prairies, to make it pay." "Is that the only way to reduce costs?" "Yes, that. Or by going to France." David Barker used the word "nightmare" at least a dozen times during my conversation with him. He told me about a friend of his, another Suffolk farmer, who, earlier in the swine fever debacle, had sold his 250 pigs into the disposal scheme, losing £30 on each one. Barker himself was waiting for results of blood tests to see if his pigs had the fever. "If it goes on much longer it will ruin me," he said. When I arrived at Nigel Rowe's farm near Dedham, only the weather was Constable-like. Out of his window the fields were bare and flat. "European pig meat is cheaper to produce," he said, "because we have higher standards and higher production costs. As soon as foreign bacon gets cheaper by more than 10p per kilo, the housewife swaps. That is the rule." I asked him if he felt British supermarkets had been good at supporting bacon produced in Essex or Suffolk. "The supermarkets have been very clever at playing the different farming sectors off against each other," he said. "The Danish model is very centralised - they are allowed to produce and market something called Danish Bacon. We are very regional over here, very dominated by the tradition of the local butcher. Supermarkets want the same produce to be available in Scotland as you get in Sussex. Only the Dutch and the Danish can do that, and some of these foreign producers are so powerful - the Danish producers of bacon are much bigger than Tesco." Nigel has 2,000 pigs. But he is not making money. As well as working the farm, he has a part-time job as caretaker at the local community centre. "In the 70s we were all earning a comfortable living," he said, "and when I was at primary school in the 60s, at least 30 of my schoolmates were connected with farming. Now, in my children's classes, there are three. I had 120 acres and I had to sell it recently to survive. I also had to sell the farm cottage my mother lived in, in order to stay here. That's what I was working on when you came - a little house for my mother." He looked out of the window at the flatness beyond. "The arithmetic is simple," he said. "When I started in this game it took five tons of grain to buy the year's supply of fuel for the tractor. Now it takes 500 tons. What do you think that means if your acreage is the same? The government seems hell-bent on the old green and pleasant land, but they won't get behind the people who keep it that way." Nigel sat in his living room wearing a rugby shirt and jeans speckled with paint from his mother's new house. "They're not thinking straight," he said. "Our product needs to be marketed - branded, with a flag, which is presently not allowed. It's all wrong. We have to import soya as a protein source for our pigs now because we can't use other animal meat or bone fat. But this country imports tons of Dutch and Danish meat fed on bone fat." As we walked out of the living room, I noticed there were no pictures on any of the walls. We went outside to the pigsties. The rain was pouring down, the mud thick and sloppy on the ground, and one of Nigel's pigs was burning in an incinerator. As we looked out I asked him what had happened to the land. "The subsidies from the Common Agricultural Policy have got out of hand," he said, "because they are linked to production rather than the environment. Did you know the rivers around here are polluted with fertiliser and crap? We're seeing a massive degradation of rural life in this country. Bakers and dairies have already gone, onions have gone, sugarbeet is gone, beef is pretty much gone, lambs are going." Before we went into the sty, he asked me if I was "pig-clean". "I'm clean," I said, "unless the fever can come through the phone." Hundreds of healthy-looking pink pigs scuttled around in the hay and the mud. He picked one up. "Farming is passed down," he said, "or it should be. A farm is built up for generation after generation, and when it starts to slip and go - you feel an absolute failure. That's what you feel." We went around the farm and Nigel explained how things work. The notebook was getting very wet so I put it away. "You feel a failure," he said again, looking into the wind. "The other night I was at a meeting: 140 farmers at a union meeting paying tribute to four hill farmers under 45 who'd committed suicide." He leaned against the side of the barn. "We are no longer an island," he said. "Everything's a commodity." © Andrew O'Hagan. This is an edited version of an article that first appeared in the London Review of Books.

webTitle: Beware of religious links, PM is warned

fields.headline: Beware of religious links, PM is warned
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was warned yesterday by Labour party figures of the danger of mixing religion and politics in the drive to win votes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was warned yesterday by Labour party figures of the danger of mixing religion and politics in the drive to win votes.

As the prime minister prepared to address the Christian Socialist Movement on Thursday, where he is expected to say that religious organisations should get more involved in helping communities, the former deputy party leader Lord Hattersley said "evangelising" was dangerous and could alienate sections of society.

Martin O'Neill, chairman of the trade and industry select committee, said on BBC1's On the Record: "We could be in danger of reinforcing social divisions in the name of alternative forms of provision."

Downing Street yesterday said Mr Blair's speech had yet to be finalised.

A year ago, Labour attacked the Conservatives for exploring ideas adopted by "compassionate Conservatives" in the US, which would see faith-based groups taking over some social services roles from the state, such as education and unemployment programmes.

The Tories have not directly followed that policy example, but their leader, William Hague, has praised the ideas of Marvin Olasky, welfare guru to President George Bush, which give more responsibility to charities and faith groups and demolish the idea of state handouts.

Mr Bush has run into trouble with the initiative, as faith groups resist offers of government cash amid fears of being overrun with paperwork and regulation of their work.

There are also concerns in the US that the definition of a faith-based group is unclear, potentially including radical separatist groups, those who oppose rights for women or minorities, or controversial groups such as the Church of Scientology, Hare Krishna, and the Unification Church - the Moonies. The programme has been postponed.

The British government is interested in an increased role for faith groups in its quest to re-energise deprived communities, but figures including the chancellor, Gordon Brown, are keen to ensure that that does not mean an erosion of public welfare provision.

Faith groups, meanwhile, have argued that they often miss out on cash such as lottery funding because their work may be aimed at particular sections of the community or because they employ only staff with particular beliefs.

In Thursday's speech Mr Blair will develop the theme of how faith communities can help the disadvantaged, saying that churches have a role in providing continuity during periods of change.

While Mr Blair has spoken before of his personal faith and its influence on his politics, there are concerns in Downing Street that talk of religion could repel some voters, while others may be antagonised by any suggestion that Mr Blair is aligning Christian morality and centre-left beliefs.

Lord Hattersley gave a taste of the opposition Mr Blair could expect: "This is an agnostic nation. To evangelise on behalf of one point of view, whatever it is, might just alienate people of a different sort."

Mr O'Neill, MP for Ochil, added: "There are a lot of dedicated professionals who might find it offensive to be asked what their religion was first and then be considered for employment. It would be a dangerous precedent to set."

webTitle: Army digs grave for mass cull

fields.headline: Army digs grave for mass cull
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government yesterday dramatically stepped up its efforts to bring under control the escalating foot and mouth crisis with two new policies - burial for up to half a million sheep and slaughter on suspicion of the disease for new cases without the need to wait for laboratory tests.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, Kirsty Scott and Lucy Ward
fields.body:
The government yesterday dramatically stepped up its efforts to bring under control the escalating foot and mouth crisis with two new policies - burial for up to half a million sheep and slaughter on suspicion of the disease for new cases without the need to wait for laboratory tests.

The army began digging a mass grave on a disused airstrip in Cumbria licensed to take the bodies of up to 500,000 sheep. The sheep will be brought in convoys from heavily infected zones nearby to be slaughtered and buried in the trenches at Great Orton, near Penrith.

As Tony Blair today enters the week that will decide whether he can call a general election for May 3, the government was at pains to show it was coping with the crisis. Downing Street sought to portray Mr Blair as throwing his energies into tackling the crisis, "bashing the phones" and receiving regular updates from the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown.

Senior ministers yesterday indicated that, while the prime minister has not taken a final decision, county council elections are still likely to take place as planned.

But the crisis looked set to worsen - the disease spread to new areas of the country yesterday, ones particularly important for tourism.

East Lothian, near Edinburgh, nearly 100 miles from the nearest other outbreak in Scotland, and Broughton-in-Furness, on the edge of the Lake District national park, were named by the government deputy chief vet, Martin Atkinson, as particularly worrying. The Broughton outbreak had jumped a buffer zone set up to keep vulnerable tourist areas safe.

Mr Atkinson said Castle Douglas in Dumfries and Gal loway, at the opposite end of the county from existing outbreaks, and Northwich in Cheshire, and Nuneaton, Warwickshire, also confirmed cases in areas which had hoped to stay disease-free.

There were 52 new cases over the weekend, including 47 yesterday, bringing the total to 607, including one case in Northern Ireland.

Vets were authorised to slaughter on suspicion to speed up the killing once farmers had called to say they believed they had an outbreak. This is to fulfil Mr Blair's pledge to cut the time from diagnosis of foot and mouth to destruction of animals to less than 24 hours.

Officials from the Scottish executive confirmed that a vet made a clinical diagnosis of foot and mouth at a farm near Haddington in East Lothian at the weekend and all 180 sheep were immediately destroyed without waiting for test results. There were also suspicions about animals at a second farm in nearby Dunbar and tests were continuing. Neither farm was thought to have links with previously infected sites.

The news will be a grievous blow to farming officials who had hoped to contain the outbreak in Dumfries and Galloway, the only part of Scotland with confirmed cases. It will bring the crisis right to the doorstep of the executive, which has been accused of not acting decisively enough.

"There was no history of the disease in that area," said a spokesman for the executive yesterday. "We just have to keep monitoring, keep an eye on that area to see what happens. If there are more cases, that would be very worrying."

Wuffy McIntyre, a National Farmers' Union official from Dumfries and Galloway, said if the virus had spread north it would be a nightmare.

"If it is outside the south-west of Scotland, it is a huge worry. This place here is just a disaster. We're now talking about no livestock between Carlisle and Moffat."

The grave being dug in Cumbria, almost certainly the largest ever disposal site for animal carcasses, is designed to allow the mass cull of animals in infected areas and provide buffer zones.

Exactly how the government intends to do this is to be announced this week but already it has been decided that every farm next to an outbreak will be cleared. The government has a recommendation to kill every farm animal within two miles but up to now has shrunk from the idea of killing pedigree herds because of a backlash from farmers who fear the loss of bloodlines.

The government is already struggling to cope with getting rid of 580,000 diseased animals or those classed as "dangerous contacts."

webTitle: Gravediggers move in as panic grips the Lakes

fields.headline: Gravediggers move in as panic grips the Lakes
fields.standfirst:
Grim task of transporting backlog of decomposing animals to disused airfield for burial begins today

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Diggers churned tonnes of soil from Cumbria's first foot and mouth mass grave last night as the disease spread south to the Lake District national park, seriously threatening the ecology of the British countryside.
fields.body:
Diggers churned tonnes of soil from Cumbria's first foot and mouth mass grave last night as the disease spread south to the Lake District national park, seriously threatening the ecology of the British countryside.

Army bulldozers frantically hollowed a series of muddy pits at a disused airfield at Great Orton, near Carlisle, as the number of confirmed cases in Cumbria rose to 215. The graves - each 150 metres long, 15 metres wide and four metres deep - will serve as the first mass burial ground for the thousands of diseased carcasses that have lain festering on farms in Cumbria over the past few days.

Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, head of the army's operation in Cumbria, said the pit was licensed to bury up to 500,000 animals - first the backlog of carcasses, then live sheep from areas surrounding infected farms would be brought in and slaughtered humanely.

The grim task of transporting the backlog of decomposing animals to the site in covered lorries is expected to begin today.

The rotting carcasses will be taken from the farms and sealed in trucks to stop them spreading disease on their way to the airfield, and the wagons will be disinfected before leaving. The airfield will be scattered with lime to alter the soil's acidity to destroy the disease.

The live sheep earmarked for slaughter as part of the three-kilometre (two-mile) pre-emptive cull were due to be killed at the airfield later this week, Mr Birtwistle said.

"In the first part of the cull we have about 500,000 sheep to take out of farms live and bring to be slaughtered in the most humane way - it is an apocalyptic task, this is a mass problem," he said.

The slaughter had taken its toll on Cumbrian farmers' emotions. "I can't tell you how much - I have had farmers in tears," he added.

Jane Brown, coordinator of the Ministry of Agriculture's Cumbria operation, said she was encouraged that farmers were working with the ministry to ensure the burial of an imals went smoothly. The ministry said it intended to bury 200,000 at the Great Orton airfield.

South of Carlisle, the first case of foot and mouth in the Lake District national park prompted panic that breeds of sheep crucial to the region's ecology could be lost forever, turning the picturesque grasslands of the Fells into shrublands.

Meanwhile, in response to criticism about delays between farmers reporting potential foot and mouth and vets visiting the farm, and the subsequent order to destroy the animals, the ministry has decided on a policy of slaughter on suspicion.

Previously if there was a doubt that animals had foot and mouth samples were taken and sent to the laboratory, with a vet returning the following day. Now the animals will be killed at once and any doubts cleared up later when laboratory tests are through.

Martin Atkinson, the government's deputy chief vet, said more than 95% of cases were being killed on the diag nosis of the vet on the spot rather than waiting for confirmation. "The burden of proof has changed, it is of a much lower order than it used to be."

Despite this he said there were still bottlenecks in the system, particularly in Devon and Cumbria. Normally 15 vets are based in Exeter - now there are 147 but they are still struggling to keep pace. The shortage of vets is most acute in Cumbria, where the largest number of cases continues to rise. There are 1,200 vets on the ministry's books, five times more than at the beginning of the outbreak four weeks ago, but they are not all in the right place because some have private practices to run at the same time.

On Friday government advisers said the single most important factor in controlling the outbreak was to shorten the time between a farmer reporting the disease and the animal being slaughtered. At the time, the delay was 26 hours in Devon and much longer in Cumbria.

Yesterday the ministry had no new statistics on how long the process was now taking but Mr Atkinson said the ideal was to get to a farm within two to three hours of the report and have slaughtering begin immediately after diagnosis.

The government is still working on its three-kilometre buffer zones plan round each infection, and continues to take professional advice.

It is still considering an al ternative policy of vaccinating cattle in these areas and pedigree flocks.

"Vaccination could be species selected - say, all cattle - or for specialist herds. This policy is being worked out now," said Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister.

An announcement will be made this week.

fields.bodyText: Diggers churned tonnes of soil from Cumbria's first foot and mouth mass grave last night as the disease spread south to the Lake District national park, seriously threatening the ecology of the British countryside. Army bulldozers frantically hollowed a series of muddy pits at a disused airfield at Great Orton, near Carlisle, as the number of confirmed cases in Cumbria rose to 215. The graves - each 150 metres long, 15 metres wide and four metres deep - will serve as the first mass burial ground for the thousands of diseased carcasses that have lain festering on farms in Cumbria over the past few days. Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, head of the army's operation in Cumbria, said the pit was licensed to bury up to 500,000 animals - first the backlog of carcasses, then live sheep from areas surrounding infected farms would be brought in and slaughtered humanely. The grim task of transporting the backlog of decomposing animals to the site in covered lorries is expected to begin today. The rotting carcasses will be taken from the farms and sealed in trucks to stop them spreading disease on their way to the airfield, and the wagons will be disinfected before leaving. The airfield will be scattered with lime to alter the soil's acidity to destroy the disease. The live sheep earmarked for slaughter as part of the three-kilometre (two-mile) pre-emptive cull were due to be killed at the airfield later this week, Mr Birtwistle said. "In the first part of the cull we have about 500,000 sheep to take out of farms live and bring to be slaughtered in the most humane way - it is an apocalyptic task, this is a mass problem," he said. The slaughter had taken its toll on Cumbrian farmers' emotions. "I can't tell you how much - I have had farmers in tears," he added. Jane Brown, coordinator of the Ministry of Agriculture's Cumbria operation, said she was encouraged that farmers were working with the ministry to ensure the burial of an imals went smoothly. The ministry said it intended to bury 200,000 at the Great Orton airfield. South of Carlisle, the first case of foot and mouth in the Lake District national park prompted panic that breeds of sheep crucial to the region's ecology could be lost forever, turning the picturesque grasslands of the Fells into shrublands. Meanwhile, in response to criticism about delays between farmers reporting potential foot and mouth and vets visiting the farm, and the subsequent order to destroy the animals, the ministry has decided on a policy of slaughter on suspicion. Previously if there was a doubt that animals had foot and mouth samples were taken and sent to the laboratory, with a vet returning the following day. Now the animals will be killed at once and any doubts cleared up later when laboratory tests are through. Martin Atkinson, the government's deputy chief vet, said more than 95% of cases were being killed on the diag nosis of the vet on the spot rather than waiting for confirmation. "The burden of proof has changed, it is of a much lower order than it used to be." Despite this he said there were still bottlenecks in the system, particularly in Devon and Cumbria. Normally 15 vets are based in Exeter - now there are 147 but they are still struggling to keep pace. The shortage of vets is most acute in Cumbria, where the largest number of cases continues to rise. There are 1,200 vets on the ministry's books, five times more than at the beginning of the outbreak four weeks ago, but they are not all in the right place because some have private practices to run at the same time. On Friday government advisers said the single most important factor in controlling the outbreak was to shorten the time between a farmer reporting the disease and the animal being slaughtered. At the time, the delay was 26 hours in Devon and much longer in Cumbria. Yesterday the ministry had no new statistics on how long the process was now taking but Mr Atkinson said the ideal was to get to a farm within two to three hours of the report and have slaughtering begin immediately after diagnosis. The government is still working on its three-kilometre buffer zones plan round each infection, and continues to take professional advice. It is still considering an al ternative policy of vaccinating cattle in these areas and pedigree flocks. "Vaccination could be species selected - say, all cattle - or for specialist herds. This policy is being worked out now," said Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister. An announcement will be made this week. What's going on? webTitle: Web of fear widens as cities are declared infected zones

fields.headline: Web of fear widens as cities are declared infected zones
fields.standfirst:
Slaughter on smallholdings spreads alarm

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth is edging into an increasing number of cities. Along with the whole of Bradford, most of Preston and Wolverhampton, all Blackburn, Gloucester and Worcester, and the outskirts of Stoke and Birmingham, the north-west of Leeds has joined the urban areas officially classified as infected.
fields.body:
Foot and mouth is edging into an increasing number of cities. Along with the whole of Bradford, most of Preston and Wolverhampton, all Blackburn, Gloucester and Worcester, and the outskirts of Stoke and Birmingham, the north-west of Leeds has joined the urban areas officially classified as infected.

"It's horrible," said Chris Morris, vicar of Rawdon, a Leeds suburb where 75 cattle were slaughtered by Ministry of Agriculture vets at Westbrook farm at the weekend. "I have been talking to one of the family, and the tone was really beyond grief. Just numb." The congregation at St Peter's church, Rawdon, gave a bumper collection yesterday, the vicar said.

The parish faces extra bills this summer because of foot and mouth: the usual ploy of putting sheep in the churchyard to keep down the grass has been abandoned, with livestock movements in the area likely to be banned for months.

The disease appears to have jumped to a hilltop holding at Westbrook from similar high ground in Queensbury, a Bradford suburb five miles west, where the herds on a farm were slaughtered on March 7 and a nearby farm's 10 days later. Although still small, the infected pocket is matched by others in urban areas, including two cases each in Wolverhampton and Stoke, and others close to the Kentish ports, from Margate to Dover.

Economic effects include closure of abattoirs, one within a mile of the Leeds outbreak, and potentially damaging curbs on urban tourism, on top of the devastation of the holiday industry in rural areas and national parks. Sections of Leeds country way, a 65-mile footpath round the city, have been closed, along with an urban farm and bird garden at two summer attractions, Temple Newsam and Lotherton Park.

The network of smallholdings close to many cities, often supplying milk to dairy companies, makes similar damage to urban tourism almost certain. Weekend walk columns in city newspapers have started to suggest central parks and urban exploration.

webTitle: Match of the Day mag closes

fields.headline: BBC boots out Match of the Day magazine
fields.trailText: <B<10.30am: The BBC's Match of the Day magazine is to close just months before the corporation loses Premiership highlights, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC's Match of the Day magazine is to close just months before the corporation loses the rights to cover Premiership football highlights.

After initially denying the flaship publication was to be axed, BBC Worldwide has finally confirmed that the magazine will close after the May issue.

There are six editorial and one advertising sales job facing the axe, but a BBC spokeman said today every effort would be made to find alternative jobs within BBC Magazines.

The BBC said in a statement the magazine "was no longer commercially viable", as the size of the football magazine market had declined by a third since it launched in 1996.

The decision had been expected since the BBC lost the rights to screen Premiership football highlights to ITV in the last football rights auction.

fields.headline: Rent reforms 'racist'
fields.trailText: Government policy to restructure social housing rents has been attacked as indirectly racist because it could force landlords to discriminate against black and minority ethnic communities.
fields.body:
Government policy to restructure social housing rents has been attacked as indirectly racist because it could force landlords to discriminate against black and minority ethnic communities.

The claim was made in a new submission to the National Housing Federation race and housing inquiry and was backed by the Federation of Black Housing Organisations (FBHO).

Bill Payne, chief executive of Yorkshire housing society, warns the inquiry that rent reform could cause the housing corporation to breach the Race Relations Act because it is leading the implementation of the changes.

Over the next 10 years, housing associations and councils will have to overhaul their rents by linking them to property values. The plan is designed to put rents on a more rational footing to allow the government to introduce market-driven changes to housing benefit.

But the policy will force rents down in many areas, causing particular worries for housing associations whose viability is threatened by the changes. Mr Payne argues that rent reform will force housing associations to develop in richer, predominantly white areas, to protect their cash flows.

His submission says: "There will be a disincentive for registered social landlords to provide new housing in low value regeneration areas where larger family houses are needed. There will be a close correlation between these areas and areas with large black and minority ethnic communities."

"Rent policy may endanger the housing corporation, which will be asked to demonstrate under the Race Relations (Amendment) Act that any new policy is not indirectly discriminatory."

Harris Beider executive director of the FBHO agreed with the comments, and pointed out that black-led housing associations were set to lose out under the changes.

These tend to have higher rents because they developed at a time when a high level of private borrowing in addition to public grant was a requirement of building new homes.

Mr Beider said: "The corporation has spent a lot of time and money investing in black and minority ethnic housing associations, surely they don't want to waste that with a policy that has not been fully thought out."

"There is a danger that the policy is discriminatory, unless the housing corporation takes some radical and visionary action."

Anil Singh, chief executive of Bradford-based, black-led Manningham housing association, called for extra subsidy to allow organisations such as his to cut rents.

"The level of rents were determined by subsidy arrangements of the last government, just because the new government has a different attitude to rents it can't change the rents by edict without addressing the financial implications for landlords first."

He added: "This is going to stretch black minority ethnic housing organisations to the limit. I have got no objections to the principle of lower rents but, the question is, who is going to pay for it? If it means black tenants are going to get poorer quality housing services, surely that's a breach of the Race Relations Amendment Act."

fields.headline: Tempus confident thanks to European bias
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Marketing and media communications company Tempus is predicting a stable 2001 thanks to its small US presence. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Tempus Group, the marketing and media communications company, is predicting a stable 2001 thanks to its small presence in the volatile US market.

Chris Ingram, chairman of the group, said Tempus had "confidence" for the year ahead because only 11% of its revenue came from the US.

"While we are not immune to the effects of a slowdown in worldwide advertising growth, our European bias, increasing proportion of fee based income and distinctive position as a value added, strategic advisor, places us well ahead of our peers," said Mr Ingram.

Exposure to the US market is seen as the kiss of death for companies involved in the advertising industry, as a near-recession across the Atlantic wreaks havoc with companies' marketing budgets.

However, Tempus said it was well placed for 2001 after it decided to move away from its traditional role as a media agency and transform itself into an integrated client-led media and marketing group.

The strategic shift appears to be paying off, with Tempus today announcing pre-tax profits for last year had climbed 29% to £21.5m, with new business wins soaring 52% to £594m.

"Our new business performance in 2000 across the group was strong and the full effect of this will impact in the current year," added Mr Ingram.

Tempus was boosted by strong contributions from the three consultancy businesses it bought last year - Added Value, BrownKSDP and Outrider.

The companies are key to the much-hyped Tempus partners project, which manages clients' needs on a "tailormade" basis.

Tempus partners has already won business from Vodafone and Coca-Cola, which the parent group described as a "validation of our vision."

fields.headline: Grimsby rules UK
fields.trailText: Grimsby top, Runcorn bottom; those placings in today's survey of where the most profitable companies in Britain are based tell an interesting and overlooked story.
fields.body:
Grimsby top, Runcorn bottom; those placings in today's survey of where the most profitable companies in Britain are based tell an interesting and overlooked story.

Like the unremarked rise of the Humber ports to become the busiest in Britain (they overtook the Thames estuary last year), the figures show how a shift from east to west, not the familiar old north to south, is becoming a key feature of 21st century Britain.

When you go to Grimsby, you see long Scandinavian words, even longer German ones and almost unmeasurable Russian ones on piles of imports and exports in the docks.

You hear guttural Dutch from the businessmen who deal in bulbs and seeds for the great, black-earth farms of Lincolnshire. And while Japanese cars pour into Immingham's docks, almost as many reconditioned Ladas are shipped home to Russia from Hull.

We are a European nation now, not an imperial one, and much less of a transatlantic-looking one than a century ago, when Runcorn and Liverpool were our gateway to the world.

The clever geographical trick these days is to tilt the map of Europe gently to the right, and see how direct the sea routes are from the Humber (and the Tees and Tyne) to the heart of modern Europe. They point east - not to France, but Germany.

The change is welcome for a part of England which has felt largely out of the limelight since Henry IV landed at Ravenspurn (now underwater off the shifting sands of Holderness) and grabbed the throne from Richard II.

And the future looks promising, in spite of the huge preponderance of decision makers in London; because unlike the south east, this gateway to Europe is not snarling with frustrated traffic and clogged with jams.

The M180 to Grimsby via Scunthorpe is often, still, like a trunk road in the 1950s - a stretch of deserted tarmac on which you bowl merrily along. Not for much longer, maybe, with economic figures like today's.

But a European Community working group is already well into plans for an "outer outer London bypass", swooping from Hamburg across the North sea and via Hull to Dublin.

That will take in Liverpool and Runcorn en route, of course; and so, unlike the lop-sided north-south divide, the east-west split may prove in the long run to benefit both geographical points.

webTitle: Jury still out on Labour's campaign anthem

fields.headline: Jury still out on Labour's campaign anthem
fields.trailText: While Tony Blair tries to make up his mind about the date of the general election, staffers in Labour's Millbank headquarters are facing an equally difficult dilemma - which song to choose as the party's official campaign anthem.
fields.body:
While Tony Blair tries to make up his mind about the date of the general election, staffers in Labour's Millbank headquarters are facing an equally difficult dilemma - which song to choose as the party's official campaign anthem.

In 1997 New Labour soared to power on the back of D:Ream's Things Can Only Get Better. This time round, a senior party insider on the campaign team has confirmed that the choice has come down to two tunes: Primal Scream's Movin' On Up and Lifted by the British soul band the Lighthouse Family.

"They're both in the running," he said. "We tried one two weeks ago but still haven't made a final decision."

Lifted was played recently at a Labour party gala fund raising dinner in London.

The choice is between a radical option - Primal Scream's funky dub sound and chill out lyrics - and a safe one, the Lighthouse Family's feelgood soul tune.

The latter is certain to appeal more to middle England - but whether either will win back Labour's disillusioned heartland support is unclear.

Primal Scream's Movin' On Up hit the charts 10 years ago when it was associated with the ecstasy-fuelled acid house revolution of the early 1990s. It comes from the Scottish band's 1991 hit album Screamadelica.

The song's lyrics include the couplet: "I was blind, now I can see / You made a believer, out of me."

Primal Scream are signed to the Creation label, whose founder Alan McGee donated money to Labour's 1997 campaign but has now turned his back on the party.

Meanwhile the Conservative party and the Liberal Democrats have already made their choices.

The Tories have commissioned a song from composer Mike Batt after a row over the party's use of a Massive Attack song, which the band complained they had not been consulted over.

The tune, Heartland, will be used at election campaign rallies and to introduce leader William Hague.

Mike Batt is more famous for penning the lines: "underground, overground, wombling free/ the Wombles of Wimbledon, common are we".

"This shows the difference between the parties - the Tories have an awkward pre-pubescent feel to them with their Wombles song, whereas Primal Scream are very funky," said the Labour MP Paul Flynn.

Not to be outdone, the Liberal Democrats have their own tune, a cover of Boyzone star Stephen Gately's song New Beginning, unveiled at their spring conference earlier this month.

Labour is set to make a decision on which to use in the next few days. A spokesman for the party dismissed earlier reports that the campaign was dropping any proposals to use S Club 7 after the three male members of the band were caught smoking cannabis in a Covent Garden street last week.

The tune, Heartland, will be used at election campaign rallies and to introduce leader William Hague. "This shows the difference between the parties - the Tories have an awkward pre-pubescent feel to them with their Wombles song, whereas Primal Scream are very funky," said the Labour MP Paul Flynn. Not to be outdone, the Liberal Democrats have their own tune, a cover of Boyzone star Stephen Gately's song New Beginning, unveiled at their spring conference earlier this month. Labour is set to make a decision on which to use in the next few days. A spokesman for the party dismissed earlier reports that the campaign was dropping any proposals to use S Club 7 after the three male members of the band were caught smoking cannabis in a Covent Garden street last week. fields.headline: Breathe.com to close
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Great Universal Stores is preparing to close the internet service provider operations of breathe.com, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores is preparing to close the internet service provider operations of breathe.com, less than three months ago after it acquired the firm.

According to reports over the weekend, GUS will strip breathe.com's mobile internet access technology to boost its own online shopping operations.

Such a move would cast aside an internet access business said to have up to 400,000 registered subscribers.

Sean Gardner, breathe.com's managing director was unavailable for comment.

A spokeswoman for breathe.com returned from holiday to be confronted by the reports and has yet to be informed of the developments.

She insisted that any statements regarding the unit's closure will have come from parent GUS rather than the ISP.

In another development, breathe.com's servers have been down since Friday, disrupting its email service and preventing new subscriptions to its 'breathe easy' service.

Notes have been posted on the website over the past three days apologising for the disruptions.

Breathe.com was bought by GUS in January for £1.4m, after the ISP accumulated £50m debts, following a high-profile television advertising campaign.

After eating up £35m in 18 months, it called in the receivers in December last year.

webTitle: Inquiry urged on fuel plant gases

fields.headline: Inquiry urged on fuel plant gases
fields.trailText: A leading scientist has called for an inquiry into emissions from an oil refinery and a power plant, claiming they could be responsible for cancer, heart attacks and strokes among thousands of Scots.
fields.body:
A leading scientist has called for an inquiry into emissions from an oil refinery and a power plant, claiming they could be responsible for cancer, heart attacks and strokes among thousands of Scots.

Dick van Steenis said he has pinpointed a corridor of sickness between the giant BP Amoco refinery at Grangemouth and the Kilroot power station in Ulster.

Following his own investigations, he believes the effect of pollution from the two plants could be "devastating" within a 44-mile radius.

Representatives for both plants say they have a clean track record when it comes to pollution and comply with legislation on emissions.

Dr van Steenis, who has advised the House of Lords select committee on pollution, said he had mapped the pattern of emissions from the two plants which, he said, carry dangerous chemical particles across a wide area.

"If you look at a map of the patterns followed by plumes from these places it becomes abundantly clear that there's a problem," he said.

"The two plants could be responsible for the bulk of cancer cases in the areas they pollute. Cancer patterns can be di rectly linked to these plants and the line you can draw between them.

"Where the pollution grounds you are always going to have death and illness and in this case that means most of central Scotland."

Dr van Steenis said poor diet and lifestyle were not enough to account for Scotland's appalling record of ill health and the plant emissions might explain health anomalies like a higher than normal incidence of prostate cancer in East Lothian and Glasgow's poor mortality rate.

A spokesman for BP Grangemouth said the company had an open dialogue on issues such as pollution and a clean track record. He said a 10-year air monitoring programme had found nothing dangerous, and the plumes emitting from the refinery were water vapour.

A spokesman for Applied Electricity Services, which runs the Kilroot plant, said: "For environmental emissions from the plant, we have to comply with legislative limits. The plant operates well within these limits and our performance record is readily available in the public domain."

A Scottish executive spokesman said it would study Dr van Steenis's concerns carefully.

fields.headline: IC trouble ahead
fields.standfirst: Sixty staff at Trinity Mirror's IC Network were told to take a spot of gardening leave 11 days ago, while another 240 wait until April 15 for news of their fate.  Amy Vickers finds out why £43m wasn't enough to make it work
fields.trailText: March 26: Amy Vickers on why £43m wasn't enough to make Trinity Mirror's IC Network succeed.
fields.body:
Thursday March 15 was one of those cold and rainy mornings, not unlike every other miserable day in March. But for Trinity Mirror Digital staff it took an unexpected turn for the worse. As they trickled in to work, unaware of the fate that lay in store, they started to realise something more severe than the sale of the internet service provider ic24 was on the cards.

Suspicions were first aroused when Graham Mead, the recently appointed managing director of the IC Network, started calling senior staff in four at a time at 15-minute intervals between 8.30am and 9.30am. The look on their faces after their little chats with Mead said it all, according to the gathered onlookers, and it wasn't long until the awful truth came out.

A staff meeting was called for 9.30am where they were told that the rumours about the sale of the ISP side of the business were true. But the news that caused most ripples was that the members of the board had let their nerves about internet revenues get the better of them. They had decided to close the brand spanking new, and very expensive, websites icShowbiz and icSport post-haste, and redundancies would be inevitable. About 60 of them were immediately told to go off and garden (vacate the premises and await their fate) and security suddenly appeared from nowhere, in case anyone forgot the location of the door.

The remaining 240 were asked to stay for the time being and keep the flagship sites, ic24.net, Mirror.co.uk, DailyRecord.co.uk and the regional ic portals, icScotland and icBirmingham, to name a few, afloat. All 300 TMD staff were told that they will find out their fate on April 15.

The first definite casualty of the retrenchment was David Clarke, the affable managing director who joined Trinity Mirror just before the merger to launch the ISP and build up the new media division. Once his two years of work had been dismantled by the Trinity board last week and there was no longer an ISP to run, it was just a matter of time before Clarke left the company. He did on Thursday.

Clarke joined in April 1999 to launch the internet service provider ic24 and expand the new media department. He built what became Trinity Mirror Digital after the merger with Trinity. This is the 300-strong operation now being cut back dramatically with up to a third of staff poised for redundancy as Trinity Mirror tries to sell the ISP. Since Clarke's departure, Trinity stalwart Graham Mead, has taken control of what's left of the embattled new media division. Mead was keen last week to point out that Clarke's resignation was a mutual decision.

The actual number of redundancies and who should go is still being decided but Mead is insistent that the numbers are not likely to pass 100. "We've started a legal consultation with staff and we're taking a look at every single role. We can't be certain how many people this will affect but we will look after them properly," he says.

All staff know at this stage is that the regional websites will survive. This could mean the brand ic remains, or it could mean it gets phased out in the coming months for something more relevant to Trinity's core business. The problem lies in the fact that the ISP and the portal carry the same name and if a buyer emerges for ic24 it could be inappropriate for Trinity to continue to use the same brand for its flagship website.

The message put out by Trinity was that it had had a change of heart about its strategy to branch out into areas that weren't directly related to its core business. Instead, it will now reconfigure its aims to harness key assets: content from its papers and its technology platform.

Analysts are already starting to question whether a buyer will emerge for ic24, especially in this current climate where ISPs have plummeted in value and there is a marked decline in the number of companies focusing on the provision of internet access.

Lorna Tilbian, media analyst at WestLB Panmure, doesn't hold out much hope for Trinity finding an easy sale. "LineOne has been on the block for a long time. It's definitely not a good time to be selling ISP assets. If they can't sell it they're going to have to just close it down and write off the investment," she says.

Even though the ISP claims 250,000 users, it is highly unlikely that Trinity will recoup the £20m it has already invested in ic24. Estimates of its value vary, but should a buyer emerge, analysts expect it to fetch just over £10m.

Launched in April 1999, ic24 was seen as a sound investment at a time when every man and his dog wanted a piece of the ISP action. Geoff Stimson, the then boss of Mirror Media, the new media division of the Mirror Group before the Trinity merger, had spotted the direction in which the market was going very early on. He developed a strategy for the Mirror Group to be at the forefront of the free ISP revolution before Freeserve soared away with an unassailable market share.

Arguably, the ISP did well and won critical acclaim in its fledgling days for reliability but then unavoidably became embroiled in the free internet calls fiasco of 2000 - a strategy that ate away at the new media investment fund.

The spanner in the works came from News International which caught wind of the Mirror's plan to move into the internet access game and decided to upset the applecart by launching its own ISP.

It became a battle of wills. The entrenched cut-throat rivalry of the two of Britain's biggest red-tops had now entered cyberspace, and News International was pulling out all the stops to launch the Sun's ISP CurrantBun.com before ic24.

In the end CurrantBun.com pipped ic24 to the post by about a month, but Mirror Media saved face by telling press at the time that it would not be panicked by a service it thought was inferior.

Instead TMD focused its energies on expanding the ic network, which included a dozen regional websites and icShowbiz, icSport and icChoice. However, the launch of these websites was delayed by a number of "technical issues" when TMD initially picked the wrong content platform, Zip2, and had to go back to the drawing board when this technology didn't work as hoped.

Having invested £42.3m in 2000 in new media and only recouped revenues of £2.5m, Trinity has now capped spending at £25m this year, and £15m in 2002. Overall, it pledged to reduce the target for gross costs of digital operations between 2000-2002 from £150m to £90m.

Tilbian says this cost-cutting news was well-received in the City. "It came as a great relief and the stock has rallied. It's no surprise that they're cutting costs because the environment is so rough. It's not patience any more, it's money and the new back-to-basics strategy makes a lot of sense."

Once the bloodbath next month is over, Trinity Mirror will have a tough job ahead of it convincing the City that this strategy is right for the group.

fields.headline: One for mum
fields.standfirst: Change Mother's Day to a Monday public holiday. That would be one in the eye for commercialisation
fields.trailText: Change Mother's Day to a Monday public holiday. That would be one in the eye for commercialisation.
fields.body:
Mother's Day needs a re-launch without its commercial sponsors. It is supposed to make mothers feel valued but its commercialism means it isn't up to the job. As the woman who popularised Mother's Day in America knew, valuing the sacrifices mothers make doesn't go well with the idea of paying for what you get. Mothers do what they do because they think it's right, not because they expect something in exchange. According to the logic of commercialism, this sort of behaviour is incomprehensible: at best it is benignly dotty (hence the bizarre tongue-in-cheek tone of most greetings cards, which seem to have been written to humour a well-intentioned idiot).

We live in a world where governments and employers seem to think that we won't do anything unless we are given an incentive. Parenting is one of those things we do to be good people, but we need to have this sort of motivation validated to keep it going.

We need it confirmed that this more moral motivation is alive and well because without confirmation people will continue to opt out: why not outsource the job of being a mother to someone who can do it more efficiently while we concentrate on our core business of making money? We increasingly prefer to get other people to do our parenting instead of us. Very nearly half of all pre-school children have other carers as well as their parents. More than two-thirds of women with a child under five do some paid work (80% where the youngest child is between five and 10 years old).

Motherhood has suffered a huge drop in status since the 1950s and this means fewer people want to do it. There are twice as many child-free young women as there were a generation ago. As a result, we have a rapidly ageing population and even the people who have kids spend less and less time actually being mothers. They put it off until later in their lives and then they spend, on average, 45 minutes a day looking after their children or playing with them. In fact mothering takes less than 20% of the time the average woman spends watching TV (for fathers the figure is under 10%).

These figures will not surprise readers of Arlie Hochschild (The Time Bind, Henry Holt & Co) who shows how families squeeze in the demands of work by cutting down on the time spent parenting. The families studied by Hochschild regimented their kids according to strict time discipline, used technology to make parenting less intensive (who doesn't use the TV to babysit?), and lowered their general expectations of what families could actually do together.

Along with other sociologists, Hochschild shows that mothers feel undervalued and demoralised. Of course everyone is demoralised these days: there are demoralised teachers, demoralised doctors, not to mention the social workers who have been demoralised for decades. Demoralisation is all about not feeling valued and this certainly applies to social workers as much as to mothers, and with the same effects. It is no surprise that motherhood and the professions have other things in common. Even more so than the work of public-sector professionals, the contributions of parents cannot be valued in terms of inputs and outputs, in fact the outcomes cannot be reliably measured at all. Valuing motherhood means valuing something that cannot be cashed out.

The idea behind Mother's Day is to honour people for their attempt to be good people rather than to reward their contribution to society. To persuade people that parenting is a good idea we need to revalidate the logic of doing the right thing and this is where the relaunch comes in. The American version of Mother's Day (celebrated on the second Sunday in May) was thought up by Anna Jarvis in 1905 as a way of recognising the real value of motherhood.

The success of Mother's Day in America - 96% of consumers take part and buy, among other things, 132m cards (Hallmark Research) - suggests Anna Jarvis achieved all she wanted. But she actually spent the last 40 years of her life trying to put a stop to Mother's Day; indeed one of her protests against its commercialisation got her arrested for disturbing the peace.

The old English Mothering Sunday and Anna Jarvis's ideas were very similar: families and communities would get together in Church to "honour" mums. This is why it made sense to have Mother's Day on a Sunday, but of course only a tiny minority of us go to church now. It would be a potent symbol of the importance we attach to motivation that isn't commercial if we made Mother's Day a weekday public holiday. That would be one in the eye for commercial logic. Mother's Day on a Monday would be a perennial reminder that we value that other sort of motivation enough to take a whole day off from making money in order to celebrate it.

Ralph Fevre is the author of The Demoralization of Western Culture (Continuum, £13.99).
