fields.headline: EastEnders star gets TV drama role
fields.trailText: 11.45am: EastEnders actor Steve McFadden is to star in his first blockbuster TV drama as part of a bid to revive BBC1, writesLisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
EastEnders actor Steve McFadden is to star in his first blockbuster TV drama as part of a concerted effort by the corporation to revive the fortunes of BBC1.

In his first role outside Albert Square for a decade, the actor will star in Murder in Mind, a feature-length psychological thriller.

The deal gives McFadden the opportunity his former co-star Ross Kemp never received and is part of the BBC's effort to stop its home-grown talent switching sides.

Kemp quit EastEnders and defected to ITV in a £2m deal after his repeated pleas for a new challenge fell on deaf ears at the corporation.

McFadden plays one of Albert Square's best-loved characters, hardman Phil Mitchell. He is currently at the centre of one of the soap's biggest storylines after being shot on his doorstep.

The BBC's renewed drive in drama comes comes just weeks after it killed off Sunday night drama Ballykissangel.

At the time rivals at ITV including drama controller Nick Elliott warned the corporation needed to "have courage" and keep its best dramas on Sunday night.

The BBC's sense of impotence on Sunday nights was compounded by the corporation's decision to move one of its most successful dramas, Clocking Off, from a Sunday night to a midweek slot.

fields.headline: Drama leads out £253m new BBC1 schedule
fields.trailText: 12pm: BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey has unveiled a £253m spring/summer schedule, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey has unveiled a £253m spring/summer schedule with 20% more drama than in the same period last year.

The BBC1 drama line-up for spring/summer 2001 includes 14 new and returning shows and an extra £11m investment compared with last year.

The season also features Son of God, a documentary series presented by Jeremy Bowen that brings the story of Jesus to life, including a computer-generated impression of what he may have looked like.

Other new BBC1 shows include the Savages, a new Simon Nye sitcom starring Geoffrey Palmer; and Dog Eat Dog, a team gameshow hosted by Ulrika Jonsson.

Detectives, investigators, policing and suspense feature heavily in the new BBC1 drama line-up.

It includes the Whistle-Blower, a thriller from ER writer Patrick Harbinson starring Amanda Burton, Neil Pearson and Bill Paterson.

In a similar vein is Murder in Mind, a series of psychological TV film thrillers, one of which features EastEnders' Steve McFadden in his first role outside the soap in a decade.

A third new thriller, Messiah: the First Killings, stars Ken Stott as a detective hunting a serial killer in London.

Ricky Tomlinson stars as a Liverpudlian private eye in Nice Guy Eddie and Mersey Beat features Hadyn Gwynne as a north west-based police superintendent.

The Fabulous Bagel Boys stars Denis Lawson and former EastEnders actor Michael French in Glasgow-set drama billed as combining "investigative policing with the manic hubbub of the local deli".

In entertainment, Ian Wright takes over from Ant and Dec fronting the third series of Friends Like These, while Richard Wilson takes his first new BBC1 sitcom role since One Foot in the Grave with Other Animals.

BBC1 factual offerings include Ewan McGregor joining survival expert Ray Mears for a gruelling central American jungle journey in Trips Money Can't Buy.

Spring and summer sporting highlights will include the return of bigtime boxing to BBC1, with Lennox Lewis and Audley Harrison fights, as well as the channel's traditional coverage of Wimbledon, with John McEnroe again joining the commentary team.

webTitle: Orange Prize appoints a jury of men

fields.headline: Orange Prize appoints a jury of men
fields.trailText: A male jury will select its own alternative shortlist from the longlist for this year's Orange Prize, set up in 1996 to promote international fiction by women, which is announced today.
fields.body:
A male jury will select its own alternative shortlist from the longlist for this year's Orange Prize, set up in 1996 to promote international fiction by women, which is announced today.

The jury consists of the novelist Paul Bailey, the journalist John Walsh and Carl Newbrook, head of marketing at Waterstone's. Their deliberations will be published separately from the conclusions of the official judging panel, which includes Rosie Boycott, Kate Adie and Suzanne Vega.

The 2001 longlist ranges from big hitters such as Margaret Atwood and Jeanette Winterson to acclaimed first novels from Trezza Azzopardi, who was shortlisted for the Booker, and Helen DeWitt.

Rosie Boycott, chair of this year's judges, said: "We hope that this year's jury of men will throw up issues which will draw more attention to these terrific books." An academic will sit in on the deliberations of both sets of judges and use her conclusions as the foundation for a report on the impact of gender on reading habits.

Paul Bailey, chair of the male jury, added: "In an ideal world there would be no female or male readers. Instead, there would just be good readers." The results of this research and the choice of the male jury will not be made public until after the announcement of the Orange Prize shortlist on May 10.

The longlist in full

Dog Days, Glenn Miller Nights by Laurie Graham (Black Swan)

Dark comedy about an elderly woman on an estate yearning for a last shot at life.

The Blind Assassin by Margaret Atwood (Bloomsbury)

Multi-layered story of repression, sisterhood and science-fiction.

In the Blue House by Meaghan Delahunt (Bloomsbury)

Russian history in the first half of the 20th century focusing on Trotsky's exile.

From Caucasia, With Love by Danzy Senna (Bloomsbury)
Mixed-race sisters in a fractured activist family on the run from the FBI.

MotherKind by Jayne Anne Phillips (Cape)
A woman nurses her mother through terminal cancer while coping with her first child.

The.PowerBook by Jeanette Winterson (Cape)
Fluid tales of love, loss and indentiy in cyberspace.

The Last Samurai by Helen DeWitt (Chatto& Windus)
First novel about a child prodigy with an intellectually demanding mother, searching for his absent father.

Horse Heaven by Jane Smiley (Faber & Faber)
A sprawling satire on the world of horse racing.

Homestead by Rosina Lippi (Flamingo)
Epic portrayal of the 20th century focusing on different women in a remote Alpine village.

The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan (Flamingo)

An American woman's difficult relationship with her semi-assimilated Chinese mother.

The Wild by Esther Freud (Hamish Hamilton)

Trials and tribulations of stepfamilies in suburban England, seen from the child's point of view.

Hotel World by Ali Smith (Hamish Hamilton)

Five intersecting characters (one of them a ghost) seen on one night in a hotel.

Nowhere Else on Earth by Josephine Humphreys (Heinemann)

Life in an Indian settlement in mid-19th century North Carolina.

The Hiding Place by Trezza Azzopardi (Picador)
Domestic horrors among Cardiff's Maltese community in the 50s.

The Idea of Perfection by Kate Grenville (Picador)
Unusual romance between two mismatched eccentrics.

Fred & Edie by Jill Dawson (Sceptre)
Hovering between fact and fiction, study of a lovers' conspiracy in the 20s to dispatch the woman's husband.

Fish, Blood & Bone by Leslie Forbes (Weidenfield & Nicolson)
Thriller taking in Victorian botany, Jack the Ripper, family histories and Tibetan treks.

Ahab's Wife by Sena Jeter Naslund (Women's Press)
A hyper-literary spin on the world of Moby Dick, with a seafaring heroine married to Melville's Captain Ahab.

fields.headline: Writers go to war over their own words
fields.trailText: March 26: Why shouldn't writers get paid when we read their articles online, asks Jane Martinson?
fields.body:
Every time we hear a song on the radio, the songwriter receives a royalty. So why shouldn't writers get paid when we read their articles online?

A group of freelance writers are set to put that question to the US supreme court, the highest court in the land, on Wednesday. The answer handed down in the next few months could clarify the increasingly fraught world of copyright ownership in the digital age.

Although the court has no jurisdiction outside the US, the National Union of Journalists and others in the UK are watching events with interest. Under US and UK law, writing and other creative work is seen as a commodity and as such, it's for sale. Writers' unions on both sides of the Atlantic believe that they should profit more than they do from this commercial transaction. They are right.

Even if the supreme court supports them, there are further difficulties. The arguments over how to implement a legal ruling in the Napster case show how difficult it might be to implement any verdict.

At issue is whether a publisher retains the right to use a journalist's, or an illustrator's, or any other freelance's work, on the web or media databases.

Interest groups from libraries to software groups have all joined the debate. In true American fashion, each side has also lined up a roster of Pulitzer prize-winning writers and celebrity lawyers to argue the case in front of a supreme courtthat rarely bothers with the subject of copyright. Before the advent of the web and song-swapping service Napster, after all, copyright was an arcane and tedious area of the law.

The New York Times, and the other publishers included in this week's lawsuit, argue that publication online is simply another edition of the newspaper and that they have paid for that. Under the US copyright law passed in 1976 - when only a few military types and academics had heard of the web - publishers own any work published in the original editions or subsequent revisions.

Jonathan Tasini, president of the National Writers' Union in the US and one of six plaintiffs in the lawsuit, says publishers are stealing money from artists who have a right to benefit from their own work whenever it is used.

He has a point. A freelance contract for an article rarely includes any amount for its subsequent downloading on Lexis-Nexis, the database service, for $5 a go. Lexis-Nexis is one of the companies involved in the dispute alongside the NYT, Newsday and University Microfilms, which transfers archives onto CD-roms.

Tasini estimates that damages from the alleged copyright infringement could amount to billions of dollars. Most legal experts suggest that this figure is too high, but retroactive awards would be a nightmare for the media business.

As evidence of the industry's concern, most of America's big publishers - including the Washington Post, Dow Jones, Knight Ridder, Gannett and the National Geographic Society - have all filed legal briefs in support of the NYT and others in the case. They have hired Laurence Tribe, fresh from battling in the Florida recount swamps, and Kenneth Starr, the former special counsel.

One of the most powerful arguments put forward by this illustrious group is that defeat in this case would lead to the immediate removal of all unprotected freelance work from their archives. Tribe has called this potential destruction "not quite the burning of the Library of Alexandria". Tasini and others suggest that business logic would stop publishers selling an incomplete product.

In support of the freelancers are the US Register of Copyright, an official government agency, and the main library associations. Freelances such as the US author James Gleick, who presumably find it easier to negotiate terms than their less well-known brethren, have also lent their support to the cause.

In the seven years since the lawsuit was first filed, both sides have taken steps to improve their position irrespective of the outcome. It has become increasingly common for freelances to sign contracts in which they pass over their future digital rights in both the UK and the US, for example. The Guardian Media Group reached an outline agreement with freelancers two years ago - the first UK media group to do so - although the full details have still to be worked out.

For their part, writers' unions have developed a publication rights clearing house to refute the argument that tracking the use of an article would be next to impossible anyway. This author-run database has been hailed as the writers' equivalent of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers for musicians.

Under this system, each time you click on an article, the individual author is sent a cheque. One freelance writer has apparently been sent a cheque for $1,700 (£1,192) since the start of the clearing house. It's a start.

fields.headline: Best bus shelter award goes to...
fields.trailText: March 26: The media awards season seems to get longer, more trivial and gaudier with each turn of the calendar, writes Emily Bell.
fields.body:
This is the time of year when those with stout hearts, sharp swords and a nice frock look forward to walking on to a podium, as the world showers them with glittering prizes.

Awards season for the media, like Christmas, seems to get longer, more trivial and gaudier with each turn of the calendar. That is, of course, unless your shelves groan with gongs, in which case there is a warm glow of peer-group validation that hangs over your organisation with a heady aura. All stem from the Oscars - the blueprint for every awards ceremony from "best glazing salesperson in the East Midlands", to our very own Baftas.

Every creative discipline now has a raft of opportunities to sashay into the Grosvenor House Hotel or the Hyde Park Hilton, to wait with enormous anticipation for "The Best Campaign for a Bus Shelter" to be called and acclaimed. In fact, the pomp of the ceremony is usually inversely proportional to the greatness of the prize.

If you are lucky enough to have designed the best point-of-sale material for a petrol station, you are likely to be carried shoulder high through swaying crowds on a golden sedan chair to receive a platinum monolith ringed by rampant lions and unicorns. If, however, you receive the Turner prize, arguably Britain's most prestigious award for creative achievement, the Tate gallery director, Nicholas Serota, will stand on a wobbly box under kitchen-bright lighting while a small number of onlookers clap politely as a small envelope is handed over.

The press enjoyed its own Oscars last week with the British Press Awards, arriving in its usual hail of disco lights and thunderous techno. It would be easy and cheap to spend the rest of the column in an extended "we was robbed" tirade, but the fact is it wasn't really a "broadsheet year", with the tabs taking most of the top honours. Our own Emma Brockes picking up Young Journalist of the Year was highly pleasing, as it is just about the only category where there is no chance of the award being interpreted as Buggins' turn.

Although nobody in the press would openly admit it, we are all deeply grateful to Press Gazette for designing an evening where you can, if you so desire, spend many hours bitching and moaning, or celebrating, with your peers. But as we are often told, and were reminded again this year by a dour Michael Parkinson, it is OUR awards, where we celebrate the craft of journalism. Yet the style of the BPAs, like the profession it is meant to celebrate, has erred to the frustratingly inarticulate and bland.

Parky, a joke-free, joy-free zone, told us there would be no jumping up on stage by anyone other than winners, and no acceptance speeches. He could have added that there would be no commendations this year, no reading from the winning entries, no pictures of short-listed candidates and examples of their work. More depressingly, there was no citation for Auberon Waugh or John Diamond, no mention of the PCC's 10th anniversary, no reflection, funny or grave, on the state of the free press in the UK. No sobering reminders of the people who risk their lives to do our jobs in less pleasant places. No gravitas, no humour, no crossword. In fact, no working journalist, apart from the editor of PG, was allowed to utter a single syllable into the microphone all evening. It was the only awards ceremony I have ever been to where, far from being celebrated, the craft in question was comprehensively buried.

This may, of course, have been down to past years where tempers have frayed and fists flown, albeit in the bar afterwards. Sponsors were appalled and pulled out, apparently. But this year we even missed the alarming sight of the Sunday People editor, Neil Wallis, storming the stage to protest at, well, everything.

The organisers could even pace the evening and hand out prizes in two bitesize chunks so that individual awards arrived between the side of beef and fruit flan, with the big team awards and paper of the year coming at the end. This would avoid the small problem of creating an atmosphere of bar-room barracking before even the business journo of the year has risen to his feet.

Awards, of course, essentially don't matter until you win one. But the BPAs represent the one night of the year when the entire spectrum of the print community is gathered in one place. And if an industry really gets the awards it deserves then we should all feel a bit perplexed that the best of British is no more than a bun fight fuelled by cakes and ale.

 Emily Bell is editor in chief of Guardian Unlimited.
Emily.bell@theguardian.com

webTitle: How to download and install our Steve Bell screensaver

fields.headline: How to download and install our Steve Bell screensaver
fields.standfirst: Download our Steve Bell screensaver now, and make it a permanent feature on your computer's desktop
fields.trailText: The Steve Bell screensaver from Guardian Unlimited Politics brings together some of the most memorable political cartoons from the Guardian's famous cartoonist.
fields.body:
The Steve Bell screensaver from Guardian Unlimited Politics brings together some of the most memorable political cartoons from the Guardian's famous cartoonist.

The screensaver uses full-size, full-colour images, so it's a fairly large file to download - just over 1mb. This should take about 3-4 minutes to download using a typical 56k home-use modem (although it will be much quicker using a typical office or ADSL connection).

For the moment the screensaver is available for PCs only.

Installing the screensaver couldn't be easier - just follow these steps for a Windows PC (and if you have problems see our troubleshooting tips below):

1. Download the software. When you click on the download link below, you'll be shown a screen asking whether you want to open the file or save it. Choose 'Save file', and then select where you want to save it - saving it to your Desktop is probably the simplest option (Netscape users: the 'Save file' option is the default, so you just need to choose where to save it).

Download the software now

2. You now need to open the file in order to install the screensaver. To do this, just double-click on the file.

3. The screensaver will now be installed. To check it, simply right click anywhere on your Desktop and choose 'Properties'. On the next screen, click on the 'Screen Saver' tab.

4. The 'Guardian Politics Screensaver' should already be selected in the drop-down list of screensavers. If it isn't, just click on the down arrow to find it and select it.

5. Click 'Preview' to see your screensaver in action (remember, if you move your mouse or press the keyboard while viewing your screensaver, it will automatically quit the screensaver and return you to your normal computer environment).

6. If you want to change the amount of time your PC needs to be 'idle' before the screensaver kicks in, you can also do it here.

That's it!

Troubleshooting
If you have problems installing the screensaver as described above, try the following options.

First, check that the file has been saved by going to the Start menu. Select "find", then "files or folders". Enter the filename "guscreeninstallpc.exe" and click "Find Now".

If the file has been saved successfully it should appear in the list that will be displayed after the search has completed. Double-click on the file in the list. This will run the install routine.

The go to the Start menu. Select "settings", then "control panel", then the "display" option and click "screen saver".

Choose the Guardian politics screensaver and click "Apply".

As long as this is a Windows 95,98, ME, NT or 2000 PC this should work.

If you've got any comments about the screensaver, or are having trouble installing it or running it, send an email to userhelp@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Oscar fashion: The winners and losers

fields.headline: Oscar fashion: The winners and losers
fields.standfirst: Oscar fashion picture gallery
fields.trailText: Oscar night is as much about the frocks as the trophies. Winning is handy, obviously, because it gives you 45 seconds (or more if you're Julia Roberts) to show off your finery to the world. But the real battles are won or lost on the red carpet.
fields.body:
Oscar night is as much about the frocks as the trophies. Winning is handy, obviously, because it gives you 45 seconds (or more if you're Julia Roberts) to show off your finery to the world. But the real battles are won or lost on the red carpet.

The Academy Awards are all about the Hollywood pecking order: this is where a chosen few are admitted into the inner circle of celluloid aristocracy, and a whole lot more fresh-faced hopefuls get the door slammed in their faces. For this reason, Oscar night fashion is not just about looking beautiful: it's about looking beautiful, important and classy. No wonder the poor souls have to get up at 5am to start to get their make-up ready.

For Julia Roberts, this was her chance to show the world she has clout as well as charm. This is an actress who first dazzled the world in a hooker's lycra mini and won her first Academy Award as a brassy, lipglossed, Wonderbra-ed lawyer. For Oscar night, she went for old-fashioned allure: vintage black and white Valentino (subtext: classic glamour, and not just this year's hot thing, but here to stay) with elegant, grown-up hairdo in place of the tousled curls that rule at the box office.

Grown-up glamour was the theme of the night for actresses: long, feminine, curvy gowns, regal hairstyles, demure wraps and serious jewels. Sigourney Weaver in red Christian Dior, Catherine Zeta-Jones in corsetted, fishtailed black Versace and Marcia Gay Harden in ruby Randolph Duke all pulled it off.

Strapless, boned gowns not only have a graphic, dramatic shape that looks good in pictures, they are also very fashionable this season: corsetting has featured in recent catwalk shows by Gucci, Versace and Jean Paul Gaultier. Furthermore, they are ideal for showing off the fruits of an egg white and steamed fish diet: presenter Renee Zellweger, anxious to distance herself from her "fat" (size 12) role as Bridget Jones, wore a size 0 yellow boned gown so tight she could hardly walk.

Kate Hudson, tipped for a trophy and also as the night's hot fashion ticket, failed to pull off either. The one-off Chloe dress made for her by Stella McCartney verged on the fussy side, accentuated by a ringletted, princessy hairstyle: she would have looked much better in the simple, spaghetti strap Vera Wang number worn by her mother Goldie Hawn.

Jennifer Lopez, in Chanel, combined her trademark no-holds-barred sex appeal - a very sheer chiffon top - with a slightly frumpy full skirt. As a combination, it didn't really work. Angelina Jolie made a wise choice, a tuxedo-style white satin trousersuit by Dolce e Gabbana which looked sexy and stylish.

As for the men, the biggest winner looked, frankly, the biggest loser. Russell Crowe's ribbon bow-tie and strange Buddy Holly hair style were shown up badly by Tom Hanks, sleek in Gucci, Joaquin Phoenix in Armani, but most of all by Jamie Bell in black-on-black Christian Dior.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours agree that if voting changed anything, they would abolish it.
fields.trailText: Stefan Effenberg has admitted he fancies a move to England when his contract with Bayern Munich runs out in 2002. Speaking to 45 Minutes, Effenberg said: "Playing in England is always in my thoughts. It's not Italy or Spain that is attractive to me. The club must be in London, Arsenal is a good club but Spurs have always fascinated me."
fields.body:
Stefan Effenberg has admitted he fancies a move to England when his contract with Bayern Munich runs out in 2002. Speaking to 45 Minutes, Effenberg said: "Playing in England is always in my thoughts. It's not Italy or Spain that is attractive to me. The club must be in London, Arsenal is a good club but Spurs have always fascinated me."

Patrick Vieira has dropped hints about moving to Juventus. Earlier this season Vieira said he would never move to Italy after suffering racist abuse during Arsenal's Champions League match away at Lazio. But this weekend he told Italian newspaper Tuttosport: "I can't say I would never move to a side including Zidane and Trezeguet. My return in Italy is possible, but never to Lazio. I know that Juventus is a serious club, a club which protects the players."

Chelsea have joined the chase for Anderlecht's 6ft 8ins Czech striker Jan Koller. Anderlecht president Roger van den Stock said: "We have had two discussions with Chelsea about Jan. They are very interested in him and they have money to spend."

Newcastle and Sunderland are chasing Bastia striker Pierre Yves Andre, reports the Mirror. Andre, 26, is valued at £5m, but will be a free agent in the summer. The paper also claims that Newcastle have been linked with a £6m bid for Internazionale striker Hakan Sukur.

Aston Villa have told Besiktas not to bother following up their interest in Alpay. "He is happy here, we are happy with him and he is under contract," said Villa's secretary-director Steve Stride.

fields.headline: Ulster TV weathers advertising storm
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Ulster Television will escape the worst of the ITV advertising downturn this year, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Ulster Television will escape the worst of the ITV advertising slump this year, having missed the boom in dot.com spending over the past 12 months.

The company is one of the last standalone ITV franchises.

Announcing its full-year results, Ulster Television said it was not suffering from bad year-on-year advertising revenue figures because it had been largely ignored in the internet marketing frenzy.

"As we did not benefit from the substantial increase in dot.com advertising expenditure last year, we are less likely to be affected by any retreat that may happen this year," said John McGuckian, chairman of Ulster Television.

Ulster's advertising revenue increased by 6.4% in 2000, compared with ITV's 5% (the latter was hit by a drop-off in internet marketing at the end of the year).

The ITV advertising market is in recession, with revenues down by around 9% so far this year.

However, Ulster expects to increase its share of ITV advertising income in 2001 thanks to growing ratings and an advertising market that stretches to London, Belfast and Dublin.

Ulster's full-year results showed a surge in pre-tax profits - from £7.8m to £27m - although the figure included a £13.4m one-off payment from selling a stake in satellite giant Societe Europeenne des Satellites.

Turnover increased from £38m to £40.8m, a rise of 6.5%, with advertising providing £37.4m of that total.

Ulster has joined a consortium comprising Sky News, CBS, Bloomberg and Chrysalis in a bid to oust ITN from the ITV news contract.

The company said it expects to complete negotiations with the network by the autumn.

fields.headline: Coke boosts marketing spend by £350m
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Coca-Cola is to spend £350m more on marketing its brands this year than originally planned, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola intends to spend £350m more on marketing its brands this year than originally planned.

The money will be spent in the company's core brands in key markets, such as the US.

The massive push kicked off in the US last night with the launch of the first Diet Coke ad in two years.

The hunky Diet Coke man has disappeared but the underlying focus on sex hasn't. This time, however, the adverts are aimed at men as well as women.

Four adverts centre on the sexual energy between men and women by exploring what makes one person attractive to another.

For example, in one execution, a man talks about the sex appeal of his pregnant wife.

The adverts, which broke during the Oscars coverage alongside Pespi's new Britney Spears commercial, have the strapline "Diet Coke - that certain something".

The voices of some of the ceremony's attendees are heard in the advert - Renee Zellweger, Ben Affleck, Matthew McConaughey, Ed Burns and Ashley Judd narrate the commercials.

The adverts were created by Wieden & Kennedy in the US.

fields.headline: Sydney embraces postmodern 'palaces'
fields.standfirst: The ostentatious self-built homes of the suburbs are influencing commercial development in the city centre, says Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The ostentatious self-built homes of the suburbs are influencing commercial development in the city centre, says Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Sydney is in a state of permanent revolution. The developers have seized power and taken up tools. Despite the building industry supposedly teetering on the brink of recession, anyone who lives in the city centre is woken at 7am when the drilling of old buildings into dust commences.

Almost all the properties built by the myriad of sandy inlets and rocky outcrops that surround the city's dazzling harbour are in flux, constantly being demolished and reconstructed.

The developers' revolution has recently taken a racist turn. Last week, a local council announced it was deferring an application for a lavish $A9m (£3.1m) redevelopment of a plot of land on Point Piper, an eastern suburb so desirable that Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman had to settle for a place on neighbouring Darling Point when they bought into the city.

In lobbying for the approval of his lavish mansion, the developer, John Symond, sought to reassure the local council that his four-storey waterfront construction, complete with pool, gym, smoking room, steam room, library and two lily ponds "won't be a wog palace".

"Wog" in Australia does not have quite the explosive racist connotations it possesses in the UK. Part of the Australian vernacular, it refers to the large number of the country's south European immigrants, including Greeks, Italians, Turks and Serbs. Rather like "nigger" in the US, the term has been reappropriated by the people it was originally directed against.

Last year, Wog Boy, a comic look at a stereotypical second generation Greek-Australian (starring a second generation Greek-Australian), beat Crocodile Dundee's 12-year record for first weekend takings.

If "skippies", as south European Australians call Anglo-Saxon Australians, use the W-word it is still widely seen as racist. John Symonds, though, is the son of Lebanese migrants and the anger directed at his "wog palace" remark was more triggered by what it implied about south European Australians' taste in architecture.

If an Englishman's home is his castle, a south European Australian's house is his palace. The massive post-war immigration programme to Australia saw many poor European families realise their upwardly-mobile aspirations, buying up quarter acre plots of land and building their own homes.

Over the decades, these have been rebuilt in steadily more ostentatious hues, becoming substantial two-storey affairs replete with decorative balconies, mock-Roman columns, faux-Greek pillars and neo-Tudor double garages. They are status symbols, a sign of material progression to suburban Australia's barbeque-based idyll of the "good life".

Immigrant families have also defended the size of their homes by arguing that they, unlike the traditional Anglo-Saxon nuclear family, often take care of their grandparents or extended family in their house, while their children aren't booted out until the moment they marry. Sydney's palatial self-built suburban homes may be mocked as "wog palaces", but they are increasingly mirrored by commercial developments in the city centre and given a grander name: postmodernism.

Many in the architectural establishment are horrified. Several houses built by acclaimed modernist architect Harry Seidler in the 1950s and 60s have been recently demolished and replaced with a confusion of neo-Tuscan or "Fediterranean" developments, complete with massive security gates, ancient Mediterranean-style pillars and underground parking for seven or eight 4WDs.

Sydney is a relatively young city and does not venerate history. "If it ain't broke, don't fix it" is Greek to the city's ears. The "heritage" that remains is more often by accident than by design. What's old is ugly, what's new is beautiful. Soaring property prices have also made it easier and more profitable to knock something down and rebuild it than redecorate and refit it.

This tendency reached its apotheosis in the recent call by the mayor of Sydney for the demolition of the Museum of Contemporary Art, a fine sandstone block of a building with art deco interiors that sits opposite the Sydney Opera House on a historic piece of harbourside. The old building - and by Sydney standards old is something that was finished around the time the new British Library was started - isn't tall enough to be commercially viable.

The city's planning and regulatory bodies often despair at Sydney's inexorable march away from Anglo-Saxon development sensibilities. While south European settlers have renounced the lawn, introducing Sydney to the maintenance-friendly merits of concrete front gardens and decorative palm trees, money-grabbing property developers have renounced the tree.

With harbourside views behind the biggest house prices, astute developers have begun removing the prime obstacle to making a fast buck - trees. While some people have been hauled up in court after taking a chainsaw to dozens of suburban trees, others quietly drill holes in their trunks and tip poison in.

One council on Sydney's moneyed North Shore has even taken to hiring security guards to protect newly planted beachfront trees from ruthless developers.

Nothing is sacred in the relentless re-engineering of Sydney, especially not space. One former estate agent in the city recently launched plans to create up to 40,000 square metres of retail space by attaching a shopping mall with walkway to the underside of the harbour bridge.

The regulatory body in charge of the bridge was not amused. Perhaps there is only one waterfront space without a proposal for it to be fitted out with a Greco-Roman spa room and a marble mini-bar. The famous curves of the Opera House roof are just crying out for such a tasteful loft conversion.

fields.headline: Firefly unveils online division
fields.trailText: 11am: PR consultancy Firefly has launched an online PR division, Firefly Interactive, Julia Day.
fields.body:
PR consultancy Firefly has launched an online PR division, Firefly Interactive, to help its clients use the internet as part of their public relations campaigns.

The rise of e-PR follows companies' increasing use of the internet to communicate with their customers, and vice versa.

Recent examples of viral emails sent around the world by disgruntled consumers - such as the Nike "sweatshop" email - show how managing a company's reputation becomes increasingly difficult online.

"It is vital companies understand the nuances of the internet and use them to their advantage," said Kieran Moore, director of Firefly and Firefly Interactive.

"Reputations can be made or ruined in minutes and the opportunities for clients to reach out to their target audiences in innovative ways are huge.

"This takes an entirely different discipline to usual PR practices," Mr Moore added.

Firefly Intercative will offer clients online reputation management, media strategy advice, client positioning and electronic press office support.

It will also produce internet and interactive PR tools such as viral marketing, games, e-invites, microsites and text messaging solutions.

Firefly has tested a number of online projects for its clients, including several viral campaigns for yell.com, microsites for Motorola and ICL and media strategy planning with various companies.

Vanessa Magnani, a former account manager at the agency, will head Firefly Interactive.

Vanessa Magnani, a former account manager at the agency, will head Firefly Interactive.

fields.headline: What is libel for?
fields.standfirst: The prospect of Stephen Byers suing the Daily Mail has again spotlighted the unfairness of our libel laws, says lawyer  James Libson
fields.trailText: The prospect of Stephen Byers suing the Daily Mail has again spotlighted the unfairness of our libel laws, says lawyer James Libson
fields.body:
Two of the most theatrical of recent libel actions have concerned politicians: the Aitken and Hamilton cases against this paper. Now we have the prospect of a third with trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers bringing an action against the Daily Mail, Tom Bower and his publishers, over the serialisation of Bower's book about Geoffrey Robinson.

Is this going to be another hugely expensive, time-consuming action over the type of allegation that every politician should regard as part and parcel of public life? Should Byers even have the right to sue?

Most press comment has so far focused on the apparent attempt by him to use an extremely effective tool of the libel litigant - putting booksellers on notice of his claim and in that way bringing them into the loop of liability if his claim were to be successful. The ability to use this tactic, disgraced by Robert Maxwell, is at odds with a general respect for freedom of information and, in particular, with Article 10 of the European Convention of Human Rights which deals with freedom of expression.

One of the effects of Article 10 is to make it practically impossible for a claimant to obtain an injunction prior to trial which would prevent an allegedly defamatory publication from being published. Putting booksellers or newsagents on notice, however, has all the hallmarks of an injunction (preventing publication) without any of the risk. A party seeking an injunction is responsible for the bookseller's lost revenue if the claimant turns out to be wrong.

The introduction of the Human Rights Act seems to have made little difference. WH Smith is reported to have withdrawn the Bower book and any libel practitioner knows that the best way to remove a defamatory article on the internet is to put the internet service provider on notice under the same rule. Most ISPs pull the plug on the site or article very quickly.

The answer is to make the obligations associated with putting a publisher on notice the same as those associated with obtaining an injunction - so that if Byers does not sue or fails in his suit he should bear the burden of the profit WH Smith has lost in withdrawing the Bower book because of his unwarranted (as it then turns out) threat.

In the United States it would be practically impossible for Byers to bring a successful action. He would have to show malice on the part of the Daily Mail or Bower, a very difficult thing to do. The proponents of a US-type defence advocate a similar position should apply in England. They fail to recognise, however, the very different natures of the US and British press. In the US a public figure finds it much more difficult to sue for libel. And every American newspaper employs fact checkers for every story, books are more routinely read as a matter of course for libel, and there is a stronger respect for privacy.

The weakness of self-regulation in the UK and the consistent efforts to invade privacy by elements of the press make a US-type public figure defence unimaginable in England. In any case, if you start from the proposition that a person is entitled to protect their reputation (which must be right), why should they be deprived of that right simply because they are a public figure? And who is a public figure? It is difficult to argue that a politician who serves the public is less deserving of protection than, say, a soap star.

But even supporters of a public figure's unfettered right to sue recognise the current unfairness of the libel law. The reversed burden of proof, the unpredictability of juries and large damages do not serve the cause of free and open debate well. The effort and cost undertaken to defeat Aitken and Hamilton and the risk of losing would make newspapers think twice before undertaking such defences.

The choice, thankfully, is not between a fully fledged public figure defence and the status quo. In fact the status quo is considerably advanced since the end of the Aitken and Hamilton cases. There are two significant developments: the advance of the law of qualified privilege and the introduction of the Human Rights Act. These, properly applied, should negate the need for a public figure defence, operating more subtly to create the correct balance between open debate and the right to protect one's reputation.

Qualified privilege is not new but was extended in the case of former Taoiseach Albert Reynolds versus Times Newspapers. The effect of a successful QP plea is to defeat a libel claim unless the claimant can demonstrate that the publication was motivated by malice. Lord Nicholls set out 10 criteria which, if satisfied, would allow a defendant successfully to claim qualified privilege. These were all non-exhaustive, sensible examples of good journalistic practice such as the quality of the source of the information, the urgency of the matter and the tone of the article.

Most careful journalists should be disciplined enough to come within the ambit of the defence. The problem, though, is that whether or not QP applies is not explored until the trial itself. In other words, a newspaper raises the defence of qualified privilege but also has to prepare a full defence, in case the QP plea fails.

A full libel trial involves an investigation into whether the publisher can substantiate the truth of what has been published based on whatever material they can lay their hands on - whether or not they had it at the time of publication. It is this process that is so costly.

Much more sensible would be to have an early trial (before a judge) just on the issue of qualified privilege. If the newspaper wins, the matter goes no further. The publisher only has to prove that it took the reasonable steps set out by Lord Nicholls and the court would only look at the steps taken at the time of publication. Should a publisher be unable to satisfy the court of the steps it took at the time of publication, it should have no complaint in having to defend the action substantively. Whether or not the claimant is a public figure becomes irrelevant.

 James Libson is a partner at Mishcon de Reya

fields.headline: Jason and the arbitrators
fields.standfirst: The Express's appointment of million-pound snapper Jason Fraser raises some familiar questions about long-lens journalism and the PCC, writes Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: The Express's appointment of snapper Jason Fraser raises some familiar questions about long-lens journalism, writes Roy Greenslade
fields.body:
Jason Fraser, the new executive director of Express Newspapers, and his boss Richard Desmond are perfectly suited. Both of them are in denial. The former hates being called what he is: a paparazzo. The latter hates being called what he is: a pornographer.

Joining forces therefore is logical. The celebrity-stalking sneak photographer will provide juicy product for the man who, while claiming to have cleaned up his act, is in the process of trashing a newspaper.

Fraser's first contribution to the Daily Express since joining - pictures of actors Emma Thompson and Greg Wise with their baby daughter - was a classic illustration of his work and also the deceit which underlies his defence of it.

One of the pictures, taken while Thompson and Wise were on holiday in Cyprus, showed the couple with their daughter, Gaia, on a beach. Two more, one of which appeared on the front page, were of Thompson alone on the beach. A fourth showed Wise with Gaia in a hotel pool. They were taken by Mario Brenna, one of the most active of the various paparazzi marketed by Fraser through his agency. He rarely goes out on shoots nowadays, but he invariably provides the essential information on the whereabouts of his star victims, and then insists that his byline appears when the pictures are published.

When I have protested in the past about the use of these grainy, telephoto shots, pointing to the editors' code of practice which outlaws "the use of long lens photography to take pictures of people in private places without their consent", Fraser - and the papers which have regularly used his work - have offered two justifications.

First, sticking to the letter of the code, they say that public beaches are not private places. Even if the victims, again quoting from the code, believe they have "reasonable expectation of privacy" because they are thousands of miles from home and are not seeking publicity, they forfeit any protection by disporting themselves on a public beach.

Second, and here comes Fraser's favourite escape clause, is the suggestion that the supposed victims are complicit. They take part in the pretence that they have been snapped unawares for publicity reasons. That is why, according to Fraser, there have never been any complaints about his pictures to the press complaints commission.

Though I have little doubt that some people do indeed reach secret agreements with Fraser, and others are probably relaxed about being photographed, the suggestion of widespread complicity smears those who are genuine victims.

My firm understanding is that Thompson did not give any permission to any photographer to take the shots of her, and I would not be in the least surprised if she did make a formal complaint to the PCC.

Apart from the intrusion into her privacy - hotels are not public places - she might also consider a complaint under the clause which protects children being photographed "without the consent of a parent".

Even if she does complain, and even if she is successful in winning an adjudication, it would still rely on a narrow interpretation of the code and doesn't come close to ending the whole sordid nonsense of sneak photography.

Going on the precedent of last month's PCC adjudication following the complaint by Anna Ford about pictures of her which appeared in the Daily Mail and OK! magazine, the main picture of Thompson, Wise and their child would escape censure. Surely, that is unfair and entirely against the spirit of the code.

Ford's case is particularly relevant. She and her friend, the former astronaut, David Scott, were pictured sunbathing while on holiday in Majorca with her teenage children.

Ford explained: "We deliberately chose a small, unpretentious family hotel right at the end of the beach... away from the crowds." She believed, erroneously but sincerely, that the beach in front of the hotel was private. As far as she was concerned, and I agree, she therefore had "a reasonable expectation of privacy".

But the PCC found against her, stating that though it understood she and Scott were "uncomfortable at having been photographed... it could do nothing more than apply strictly the terms of the code".

That's an interesting phrase, is it not? It might just have been possible to have applied the code strictly on behalf of Ford by supporting her "reasonable expectation of privacy". More pertinently, I think the code needs rewording to stop the abuse. On the other hand, I realise the implications of finding in Ford's favour: if routine newspaper pictures of "ordinary members of the public" on a beach or in the street were allowed, it would suggest that celebrities were getting special protection.

Ford is now trying to obtain a judicial review of the PCC's decision. Her lawyer, Geoffrey Robertson QC, will have to convince a judge that the PCC has failed to follow its procedures correctly. Before he does that, he will need to show that the delay in going to court is justified.

I understand that the PCC is fairly relaxed about this unprecedented legal move, believing that it cannot be judicially reviewed. If it is, of course, the implications are far-reaching because it calls into question the validity of press self-regulation. Nor is this the only challenge the PCC is facing. In a separate development, two people are also hoping to obtain a judicial review because the PCC refused to adjudicate on their complaint.

Ann and Derek Taylor are the parents of two women, Lisa and Michelle, who were convicted in 1992 of murdering Alison Shaughnessy, wife of Michelle's former lover. Less than a year later, the sisters were freed after the court of appeal decided that "sensational, inaccurate and misleading" press coverage had seriously prejudiced their trial. He quashed the murder convictions, pointing out that the police's failure to disclose evidence also rendered the convictions unsafe. Indeed, all the evidence against them had been flimsy.

But in June last year, the Daily Mail carried a three-page so-called "damning dossier" by Jo Ann Goodwin headlined "Why I believe they are murderers". The article was based largely on the "evidence" of Bernard O'Mahoney, described as "a 40-year- old gangster who makes no secret of his background".

He had previously befriended the Taylor sisters and, after their release, had an affair with Michelle. After an acrimonious split with her, he later claimed that he had discovered a letter which proved Michelle's guilt, and that she had also confessed to him. Michelle vehemently denied this in a later court action.

In spite of this, Goodwin's article accepted O'Mahoney's version of events. According to investigative journalist Nick Davies, who has written widely about the case, her piece "essentially consisted of a highly partisan reworking of the prosecution case".

He and the Taylor family were outraged that the Mail had given the Taylors very little time to respond to O'Mahoney's allegations. Goodwin called Mrs Taylor the day before publication and had only a brief conversation with her. The result was a one-sided article.

Davies supported the Taylors' complaint to the PCC and was as astonished as they were when the commission announced months later, following several exchanges of letters, that it was not able to adjudicate.

It cited several reasons: it was unable to decide in a complex case where the truth lay, it was worried about overlapping legal moves, and it thought the proper course was for the case to be adjudicated by a court, as the Taylors could take libel proceedings.

Let's look briefly at those excuses, sorry reasons. No one was expecting the PCC to sit in judgment on a murder case. What was at issue was whether Goodwin and the Mail had published a fair and accurate article.

There were no legal moves, so that is a red herring. As for the idea of suing for libel, they had no money to do so. Later, the PCC announced it was refusing to accept their complaint because it came from a third party. Why weren't the Taylors told that at the outset? Anyway, they are named in the article and, as leading members of the Taylor 2 campaign, they are materially involved.

There is one further point which links the Taylors to Anna Ford and may well also affect Emma Thompson should she complain. The PCC makes much of the fact that it is not a court. It does not hold oral hearings. It does not have powers of investigation.

But I cannot help noticing - and there have been other cases I have championed where this has been the case - that when complaints are not upheld, or there is a failure to adjudicate, the PCC is inclined to offer a very narrow, overtly legalistic interpretation of the editors' code.

By sticking firmly to the wording as a defence of newspapers' activities, rather than applying the spirit of a code designed to help the public, the PCC is endangering its reputation.

What complainants are so concerned about is journalistic ethics. It's a denial of press freedom to ban the picturing of celebrities on public beaches. But does it mean that a well-known person can never be free from a prying camera? Where is the respect for private and family life accorded by the European Convention of Human Rights?

OK, so a journalist should have the freedom to write a heavily biased report accusing people of murder. But should it mean that papers bear no burden of responsibility, losing all sense of fairness?

After the hype of its tenth birthday bash, the PCC - and the editors' code committee - need to think deeply about their role.

It would be richly ironic, would it not, if a changed code outlawed the very pictures which have resulted in Jason Fraser's preposterous £1m appointment to the Express?

webTitle: Did pigswill cause foot and mouth?

fields.headline: Did pigswill cause foot and mouth?
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of cases of foot and mouth have been confirmed in Britain, and the disease has spread abroad. The government has now identified a new culprit: pigswill. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: Hundreds of cases of foot and mouth have been confirmed in Britain, and the disease has spread abroad. The government has now identified a new culprit: pigswill. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Why pigswill?
For countless generations, pigs have been fed waste food from human tables. In the days when foot and mouth was a rural fact of life, it didn't much matter. In our slightly more enlightened times, we have realised that feeding live animals with discarded bits of dead animals - particularly their own species - is not only disgusting, but dangerous.

Where does pigswill come from?
Restaurants, school canteens, airline discards - anywhere where humans eat and waste food on a large scale. The feeding of pigswill is now regarded by most farmers as hopelessly inefficient and outmoded. Only about 1% of producers continue to use it.

Is the practice unregulated?
No. Farmers are supposed to treat the swill by heating it to 100 degrees centigrade, to kill off potential infections. The suspicion is that some pig producers have been sloppy with the slops. Indeed, that could be the reason for the present crisis.

Has this come as a surprise to government?
More than three years ago, the government's own panel of agricultural experts advised a ban on pigswill. The advice was rejected by ministers, anxious not to impose new costs on hard-pressed farmers.

Is foot and mouth now out of control?
The agriculture secretary, Nick Brown, says no. He argues that the government has acted promptly to contain the outbreak, but concedes that more cases are likely to be reported, in animals now incubating the virus. These animals will no longer be allowed to spread the infection, given the tight restrictions on movements.

Are they the only animals that can spread the disease?
No. It can be carried by wild animals, including deer, rats and feral pigs.

How many animals have been condemned?
More than half a million, and counting. The army has been brought in - far too late, according to the Tories and other critics - to help with the grisly business of burying or burning the rotting carcasses of hundreds of thousands of destroyed animals.

He argues that the government has acted promptly to contain the outbreak, but concedes that more cases are likely to be reported, in animals now incubating the virus. These animals will no longer be allowed to spread the infection, given the tight restrictions on movements. Are they the only animals that can spread the disease? No. It can be carried by wild animals, including deer, rats and feral pigs. How many animals have been condemned? More than half a million, and counting. The army has been brought in - far too late, according to the Tories and other critics - to help with the grisly business of burying or burning the rotting carcasses of hundreds of thousands of destroyed animals. fields.headline: Granada says goodbye to G-wizz.net
fields.trailText:
8.30am: It makes TV's number one TV show, Coronation Street, but now Granada has discovered it isn't so simple on the internet and is pulling the plug on its internet brand G-wizz, writes Amy Vickers.
Useful link: g-wizz.net
fields.body:
It was where Coronation Street fans were supposed to congregrate. But 12 months on and £4m later, Granada has finally admitted viewers couldn't care less about their internet venture G-wizz.

The company is finally pulling the plug on the much-hyped internet service provider - the site today is advising users there are now just "two days to go".

The closure of the portal and internet service provider is an embarrassing climbdown for Granada, which spent £4m on marketing the brand last year.

It follows similar retrenchments by other media groups including Trinity Mirror and News International.

G-wizz was always seen a risky experiment as it moved Granada into the unfamiliar territory of internet access provision.

On Wednesday the company will close down the service and encourage users to subscribe to BT Internet.

The digital division of Granada Media has also finally admitted it has abandoned plans to take on BSkyB and OnDigital with a service providing internet access through the TV set.

The company had been expected to launch its Granada PowerChannel last July after investing more than £13.5m in the project.

It was a partnership with a an internet research group which subsidised the cost of the special set-top boxes which were in turn supposed to be distributed by Granada's rental network.

Granada however will now focus all its energies on programme-branded websites.

It has admitted that viewers do not make the connection between its top programmes including Coronation Street and G-wizz and will not concentrate on developing services with an obvious tie-in with its big programmes such as popstarsonline.net, Ccronationstreet.co.uk and ThisMorning.co.uk.

Its decision is part of a wider internet strategy to build up an ITV internet service.

In future it will work with Carlton TV to build up itv.co.uk.

In a tacit admission that ITV has failed to capitalise on its brand online, the two companies have decided to pool resources in an attempt to compete with bbc.co.uk which has become one of the most popular sites in the world.

Granada PowerChannel has been beset by technical problems since unveiling plans to develop a TV internet box last April.

The decision to axe the PowerChannel TV internet box has been known internally for some time, but this is the first time Granada has publicly admitted the plan.

Granada Broadband now has to demonstrate it can start to make money from new media ventures, having spent almost £20m in 2000 and recouped a little less than £1m. Just over £9m of this was spent on G-wizz alone.

Related stories

Oct 9: Royles lined up for PowerChannel push

fields.headline: NHS finances: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Steve Brown answers the important questions about the NHS budget. How much is it? Who gets it? And is it enough?
fields.trailText:
How big is the NHS budget?
In March 2000 the chancellor, Gordon Brown, unveiled a "historic" four-year, £19bn package of funding for the NHS that will bring the UK closer to the European average on health spending and, in theory, stem the damage of years of underfunding. He announced average real increases of 6.1% over the coming four years, which is claimed to be the longest period of sustained growth in the service's 52-year history. With this increase, the NHS budget will reach £68.7bn by 2003-04, some £19.4bn more than in 1999-00.
fields.body:
How big is the NHS budget?
In March 2000 the chancellor, Gordon Brown, unveiled a "historic" four-year, £19bn package of funding for the NHS that will bring the UK closer to the European average on health spending and, in theory, stem the damage of years of underfunding. He announced average real increases of 6.1% over the coming four years, which is claimed to be the longest period of sustained growth in the service's 52-year history. With this increase, the NHS budget will reach £68.7bn by 2003-04, some £19.4bn more than in 1999-00.

This massive cash injection follows a wretched winter crisis for the NHS, with ministers under fire over bed shortages, cancelled operations, overcrowded casualty departments, staff shortages, and a flu "epidemic". After being pressed on claims of NHS underfunding by TV interviewer David Frost in January, Tony Blair promised that the government would increase health spending up to the European average. In fact, despite the extra billions this target will be missed.

According to the Treasury, total health spending will rise to 7.6% of national wealth or gross domestic product by 2003-04. This compares with a current European average of around 8%: 9.6% in France; 10.7% in Germany; and 13.9% in the US.

Are the extra billions enough?
There is no doubt that the rise is significant, raising UK health spending per household from £1,850 in 1998-99 to £2,800 in 2003-04. However, it is unlikely to prevent calls for additional resources. Rising public expectations of the NHS, the pressure to fund the use of expensive new technologies and drugs, and staff pay demands will continue to put pressure on the NHS budget. The NHS also has to juggle investment with historical financial deficits in trusts and health authorities of up to £700m.

How is the NHS financed?
Over 90% of NHS spending is met from general taxation and an element of national insurance contributions. The remainder comes largely from the receipts of land and property sales and a small amount from charges.

This year the government has experimented with "hypothecated taxes", earmarking £300m from tobacco tax increases for the NHS. The NHS plan, published in summer 2000, concluded that "the way the NHS is financed continues to make sense" and rejected alternatives such as private insurance, social insurance, new charges and rationing.

Who gets the money?
The £54.2bn allocation for the NHS across the UK in 2000-01 translates into £44.2bn in England. Scotland will this year spend £5.4bn on health, Wales around £3bn and Northern Ireland's combined health and social services budget is just over £2bn.

 Over half of the hospital and community health services budget goes on providing acute services, the general term for medical and surgical interventions provided in hospitals.

 Mental health accounts for a further 12% while dedicated services for the elderly take a further 10% (although elderly people receive a lot more spending through other parts of the budget).

 Three areas, mental health, cancer and coronary heart disease, have been identified as clear priorities for investment.

 The vast majority of the English allocation, some £34.3bn, is distributed through the country's 99 health authorities in unified budget allocations, which were introduced in 1999 to break down some of the artificial boundaries between hospital and primary care funding.

 These allocations are then passed down to new primary care groups and primary care trusts, which in addition to overseeing GP services will commission hospital services.

 The largest proportion of each health authority's unified budget pays for services that are provided by trusts. But the budgets also cover GPs' staff, premises, computer and prescribing costs.

By bringing prescribing inside the unified budgets, drug costs are now "cash-limited" in an attempt to keep their expense down. In addition to their unified budgets, health authorities also administer a non-cash-limited family health services budget, which covers allowances and fees charged by GPs, and payments to opticians, dentists and pharmacists. For the current year this amounts to £4.2bn.

webTitle: Trials seek to counter resistant HIV virus

fields.headline: Trials seek to counter resistant HIV virus
fields.trailText: The UK is to take part in an international trial to find how to combat a possible resurgence of Aids in the west, as resistance grows to the drugs given people who are HIV-positive.
fields.body:
The UK is to take part in an international trial to find how to combat a possible resurgence of Aids in the west, as resistance grows to the drugs given people who are HIV-positive.

While HIV/Aids spreads across Africa, complacency has grown in the US and Europe because of the powerful if expensive medicines that are readily available.

But anti-retroviral drugs only suppress the virus; they cannot destroy it or prevent others getting it. Because the virus is prone to mutate, its resistance to some of the drugs used has steadily grown. If patients do not rigidly comply with the treatment, taking exact doses at precise times and sticking to dietary regimes, the virus mutates, the treatment fails, and the patient may become sick.

A combination of three drugs, known as highly active anti-retroviral therapy or Haart, is the norm. But with growing resistance to the drugs in the west, a major trial called Optima (options in management with anti-retrovirals) is to start in the UK, the US and Canada. It will test whether using a cocktail of five or more drugs is an improvement on three. It will further examine whether there is any benefit in taking a three-month total break from medication, to allow recovery from side effects and see whether the virus resumes responding to the original drugs.

There are an estimated 30,000 people infected with HIV in the UK; each year 2,500 more become HIV positive. Worryingly, it is thought that between a tenth and a quarter of the latter are being infected with a drug-resistant form.

"People are getting resistant virus from day one," said Mike Youle, director of HIV clinical research at the Royal Free centre for HIV medicine in London, who will be one of the investigators in the trial. "I've had four in the last two weeks. Lads turn up on my doorstep thinking [the Aids crisis] is all over and they don't have to worry about HIV, and they are inheriting resistant virus."

Very few now develop drug-resistant HIV by not taking drugs properly. "In the last year or so, things have become better in terms of being able to take fewer pills and easier dietary requirements." But there was an atmosphere of denial over drug resistance.

"We are very much in the situation with resistant strains that we were with HIV in 1991-92, when everybody said it was in America but not here," said Dr Youle. "Because it is not in our face constantly that people are ill and dying, there is a belief the treatment will last forever and there is no risk to the individual from catching HIV. We are in a honeymoon period and I believe it is an extended honeymoon period. What I'm concerned about is that people will acquire resistant virus.

"There may be people - and we are already seeing cases of young people with multi-drug resistant virus - coming to us sick and not able to respond to standard combination therapy. It is not something we can deal with effectively now."

Dr Youle's unit is funded by the medical research council, which is running the UK end of Optima. Beginning in June, 1,700 patients will be recruited to the trial, including 400 from the UK.

The difficulties of ensuring people get and take anti-retroviral drugs properly so that drug-resistant virus does not spread has been one argument advanced against provision of cheap Aids medicines in Africa. But simpler forms of the drugs, including pills combining more than one drug in a single dose, are becoming available. With the advent of ever larger combinations of more powerful drugs in the west, the moral pressure on pharmaceutical companies and western governments to get at least basic medication to some of the millions who are dying in Africa will become stronger.

Last week, the World Health Organisation and Unaids - the United Nations organisation fighting the epidemic - met Cipla, the Indian company that manufactures generics (cheap copies of patented drugs). They discussed Cipla's offer to provide a three-drug combination to developing countries at £400 a year per patient (or £230 to volunteer doctors of Médecins Sans Frontières). The same combination would cost £7,000 to £10,000 in the west.

The UN will consider whether to give the offer its approval. Although Merck and Bristol Myers Squibb have dropped prices of brand-name drugs to what they say is cost price or lower, they have not yet matched Cipla.

fields.headline: Hospital row fuels independent's challenge
fields.standfirst: After local council success of Health Concern campaigners, a retired consultant sets his sights on parliament
fields.trailText: Richard Taylor spent 23 years working at Kidderminster hospital in Hereford and Worcester. Now he paces its grounds pointing at buildings that are being gutted or mothballed.
fields.body:
Richard Taylor spent 23 years working at Kidderminster hospital in Hereford and Worcester. Now he paces its grounds pointing at buildings that are being gutted or mothballed.

The hospital is being down-sized under NHS plans that promise to raise standards of care. But the plans have evoked fierce resistance from a diehard band of campaigners who call themselves Health Concern.

Two years ago, Health Concern stopped the futile business of raising petitions and took to the ballot box.

It was a last resort and it worked. They won seven seats in elections to Wyre Forest district council, which covers the towns of Kidderminster, Stourport-on-Severn and Bewdley.

"I'll never forget the feeling when the first result came up," Dr Taylor recalled. "We suddenly realised that it was possible. That evening was absolutely electric."

Last year they took another 11 council seats, making them the largest member of the ruling Rainbow Alliance, and reducing the Labour vote to less than 20%.

Now Dr Taylor, 66, a retired consultant, is challenging Labour incumbent David Lock, who took Wyre Forest with a majority of nearly 7,000 in the 1997 landslide. Mr Lock is understandably anxious.

The MP, a junior minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, whose wife practises as a GP locally, accuses Health Concern of distorting the facts to whip up alarm among the voters of Kidderminster.

"Local people are not taken in by campaigners who try to pretend they know more about the health service than doctors, nurses and the health authority," he insisted.

Dr Taylor appeals to tradition, with all the patriarchal dignity of the old-style consultant.

"The hospital is woven into the fabric of Kidderminster life," he said. "There has been a hospital here since 1920. It has been supported by the people all the way through - the [hospital's] League of Friends has raised between £2.5m and £3m in the last decade."

Last September, Kidderminster's accident and emergency facilities were downgraded to a minor injuries unit. Its in-patient facilities were closed. This meant that any blue light emergency cases would have to travel 18 miles to Worcester royal infirmary.

In February that decision had fatal consequences when a pensioner, John Jones, who lived five minutes from Kidderminster hospital, had a heart attack.

The ambulance drove past Kidderminster's closed A&E on a 50 minute journey to Worcester, where Mr Jones was pronounced dead after 20 minutes.

The tragedy was grist to Health Concern's mill; a deeply emotive case that appeared to encapsulate the human cost of Kidderminster hospital's demise.

But while the loss of services at Kidderminster has made for politics with instant appeal, not all the facts stack up on Dr Taylor's side.

The hospital is being downsized for two reasons. The first is financial; in 1997, Worcestershire health authority was driven to reform all health services in the area to help resolve a multi-million pound deficit.

The reforms turned on axeing in-patient services at Kidderminster in exchange for building a state-of-the-art hospital that will open in Worcester next April.

The second reason was medical. Around 10 years ago, according to a consultant who worked there, junior doctors at Kidderminster were working well over 100 hours a week.

After years of campaigning, moves to reduce junior doctors' hours were brought in. But that made providing cover at the small hospital increasingly difficult.

Supporters of the changes say that providing the kind of intensive staffing levels needed for an accident and emergency department was rapidly becoming impossible.

A bigger regional centre also offered patients a wider choice of specialists familiar with the latest techniques in each field.

James Goodman, chairman of the Wyre Forest GPs' Association, said: "We didn't necessarily fully support the changes at the start of the process. But after a lot of negotiation we had to agree that it was the only effective way forward. It finally came down to staffing; the need to have more specialists, and the increasing problem of junior doctors' hours."

Turning the clock back now is impossible, he believes. The new Worcester facilities will be better and safer than the old Kidderminster hospital.

The case of John Jones was a "terrible tragedy", he concedes. "But these cases do happen. Even if Kidderminster had been open, the outcome might not have been different."

For all the arguments against him, Dr Taylor's campaign has the powerful emotional appeal of the outsider.

If elected, it will be a rare victory for a candidate without the backing of a big party machine, following in the footsteps of Martin Bell, who is at present Britain's only independent MP.

"I think we have started a revolt against the major party political system. If we achieve an MP we will send a signal to other areas to say that they can do something by having independent people running."

And he has indeed sent a signal. In Dudley, where Unison is about to embark on its 12th strike against a private finance initiative (PFI) scheme to redevelop the town's hospitals, campaigners are also turning to the ballot box.

Angela Thompson, a hospital catering worker and Unison branch secretary, threatens to dent Labour's majority by standing as a Socialist Alliance candidate against privatisation.

Back in Wyre Forest, Clive Joyce, editor of the local paper, notes that complaints from readers about the NHS have mushroomed since Kidderminster's A&E department closed.

Letters have flooded in bemoaning long waits on trolleys in the outdated facilities of Worcester royal infirmary.

This hospital's main buildings at Castle Street and Ronkswood in Worcester will also be replaced by the new PFI hospital, when it opens.

"They are not coping at Worcester," Mr Joyce said. "In the health authority's defence, they have had to bring the plan forward.

"It was intended to down grade Kidderminster when the new Worcester hospital comes on-stream in 2002.

"But by announcing that Kidderminster was virtually going to be turned into a cottage hospital, that led to a crisis in staffing. New staff didn't want to come. Staff working there wanted to work elsewhere."

And while the anger of the local paper's readers keeps the issue alive, Health Concern is poised to benefit.

Mr Lock insists: "The general election, whenever it comes, is not going to be a referendum on Kidderminster hospital.

"The voters need an MP who is going to represent them on benefits issues, on defence, on the whole wider issues of government."

He may be over-confident; on the doorsteps of Wyre Forest, the complex arguments for change are difficult to deliver.

"Save our hospital" is a much snappier sound-bite. It could be a close call.
