James Goodman, chairman of the Wyre Forest GPs' Association, said: "We didn't necessarily fully support the changes at the start of the process. But after a lot of negotiation we had to agree that it was the only effective way forward. It finally came down to staffing; the need to have more specialists, and the increasing problem of junior doctors' hours." Turning the clock back now is impossible, he believes. The new Worcester facilities will be better and safer than the old Kidderminster hospital. The case of John Jones was a "terrible tragedy", he concedes. "But these cases do happen. Even if Kidderminster had been open, the outcome might not have been different." For all the arguments against him, Dr Taylor's campaign has the powerful emotional appeal of the outsider. If elected, it will be a rare victory for a candidate without the backing of a big party machine, following in the footsteps of Martin Bell, who is at present Britain's only independent MP. "I think we have started a revolt against the major party political system. If we achieve an MP we will send a signal to other areas to say that they can do something by having independent people running." And he has indeed sent a signal. In Dudley, where Unison is about to embark on its 12th strike against a private finance initiative (PFI) scheme to redevelop the town's hospitals, campaigners are also turning to the ballot box. Angela Thompson, a hospital catering worker and Unison branch secretary, threatens to dent Labour's majority by standing as a Socialist Alliance candidate against privatisation. Back in Wyre Forest, Clive Joyce, editor of the local paper, notes that complaints from readers about the NHS have mushroomed since Kidderminster's A&E department closed. Letters have flooded in bemoaning long waits on trolleys in the outdated facilities of Worcester royal infirmary. This hospital's main buildings at Castle Street and Ronkswood in Worcester will also be replaced by the new PFI hospital, when it opens. "They are not coping at Worcester," Mr Joyce said. "In the health authority's defence, they have had to bring the plan forward. "It was intended to down grade Kidderminster when the new Worcester hospital comes on-stream in 2002. "But by announcing that Kidderminster was virtually going to be turned into a cottage hospital, that led to a crisis in staffing. New staff didn't want to come. Staff working there wanted to work elsewhere." And while the anger of the local paper's readers keeps the issue alive, Health Concern is poised to benefit. Mr Lock insists: "The general election, whenever it comes, is not going to be a referendum on Kidderminster hospital. "The voters need an MP who is going to represent them on benefits issues, on defence, on the whole wider issues of government." He may be over-confident; on the doorsteps of Wyre Forest, the complex arguments for change are difficult to deliver. "Save our hospital" is a much snappier sound-bite. It could be a close call.

webTitle: Where have all the ads gone?

fields.headline: Where have all the ads gone?
fields.standfirst: Stock market panic, global economic downturn and advertising on the slide - for those with memories of the 1990/91 media slump things are beginning to look dodgy. But, asks  Maggie Brown, do we in the UK have to catch cold simply because the US sneezes?
fields.trailText: Stock market panic, global economic downturn and advertising on the slide - for those with memories of the 1990/91 media slump things are beginning to look dodgy. But, asks Maggie Brown, do we in the UK have to catch cold simply because the US sneezes?
fields.body:
Last night's Oscars signalled much more than another glossy night out for the Hollywood elite. Worried eyes focused not on the shortlist for best picture, but the ad breaks between the speeches. News had seeped out that the broadcaster - ABC - was having trouble filling its premium ad slots in the biggest show of the year. As an illustration of the scale of the advertising downturn sweeping the US it could not have been more dramatic. If the make-up and shampoo commercials are deserting the Oscars then truly nothing is sacred.

Meanwhile, at an overseas sales conference, ITV's ad sales directors were trying to dispel alarmist talk that the full-blown contagion had spread to the UK by predicting a revival in the second half of this year.

But on Thursday, one of the country's largest radio groups, Capital Radio, issued a profits warning - confirmation that conditions were worsening. Ralph Bernard, chief executive of rival GWR, had to watch his own share price slide in sympathy, though the Classic FM operator is still showing double-digit growth. "I can't give you any predictions," he said last week, "I simply don't know."

There are all sorts of reasons why the ad market is suffering - the meat industry's planned campaign to tempt us back to the joys of a juicy steak is on ice due to foot and mouth; an election means a pause in the record levels of government-backed advertising, and the railway network has yet to reach the state where it is safe to woo travellers back. "And as storm clouds gather, companies go for softer areas, cut into their advertising budgets," Bernard says wearily.

The broadcasters are not alone in their fog. National Magazines managing director Terry Mansfield, whose portfolio spans from Good Housekeeping to Cosmopolitan, speaks candidly of "navigating without a map for the rest of the year". He says: "Cancelling of advertising really began after Christmas. A lot of businesses didn't have the best Christmas. The one certainty was ads for jewellery in up-market titles such as Harpers."

The crisis of confidence in the US cannot be denied [see Stefano Hatfield, right] but the real conundrum is this: if America sneezes, does the rest of the world catch a cold? Is the domino effect, which caused the massive media recession of 1990-91 [see panel above], striking again? And, if the UK isn't affected directly by the US downturn, is the industry busy panicking itself into a decline?

The irony is that nine years of unbroken advertising growth have created a false sense of security, and few saw a downturn coming. Adland is populated by youngish people who weren't around in the early 90s and have never known tough times. For Justin Sampson, managing director of the Radio Advertising Bureau, a sector which doubled its share of total ad revenue (now £535m) in 10 years, this is new territory. He says he has no idea how commercial radio will cope with the expected seizure. "I have very little experience of living through a recession. I was busy being an irresponsible 20-something last time, in 1991."

Publisher of the Economist, David Hanger, who is also world president of the International Advertising Association, says: "Last year just absolutely flew. The Economist was up 30% as banks chased e-commerce. In the States, it was the strongest year advertising had ever seen." Business Week was turning away ads.

"Suddenly in November," says Hanger, "The Wall Street Journal had a fall-off in the number of pages - a hint. We hadn't noticed it. Then it deepened - it depended on how involved you were with the dot.com bubble."

Martin Sorrell, who heads global agency WPP and is Britain's most prominent ad man, says: "It was bound to happen. The year 2000 was unsustainable." Last year, off the back of the dot.com boom, his company grew by 15%, excluding acquisition and profits were up by 20%. We're now seeing "the revenge of the brands", he says.

It's all timing, says Sorrell, but then adds: "The $64,000 question is whether the ripple effect of [US] interest rate cuts and tax cuts from Bush will also ripple out to Europe," - and thereby avert a serious fall.

Many take comfort from signs that the US has had it worse. Hanger, whose role spans the globe, says: "The UK is definitely behind [the US] but also it attracted less dot.com froth, so it won't have the same fall to make." It's this kind of thinking which is causing the uncertainty and confusion and leading some to argue that the industry is psyching itself into recession. Andy Barnes, Channel 4 director of advertising sales and marketing (revenue up 6% so far this year) says: "Two things have historically driven advertising. Company profit and consumer expectations. It was marvellous until six months ago, but whether you're going up a cliff or down over a cliff, you can't see it until it happens."

Yet there are reasons to be cheerful: in Europe far less personal wealth is directly invested in shares. In the UK, unemployment of under 1m means employers are still chasing key staff. And some media companies are still predicting growth: RTL, which controls Channel 5, last week forecast 3% ad growth this year.

The uneven impact so far - is the UK merely lagging behind the US or genuinely reprieved? - is demonstrated by what is happening in newspapers.

On March 15, Trinity Mirror's cheery chief executive Philip Graf reported advertising revenue from national titles was 9% higher in the first two months of the year, and from regional titles it was up 7% - though he excluded internet investments. Johnston Press, a regional operator, was also in perky form. Yet last week Independent Newspapers, with wider flung interests, spoke of uncertainty. Associated Newspapers, too, is trimming its editorial budgets by 10%.

And the advertising director of a major British newspaper group confided: "I'm feeling very, very nervous. I absolutely know we are going to be down on last year, but not by how much. I knew the bubble had to burst."

So what's the outlook for Britain's leading TV network? ITV, just like the US networks, was first to feel pressure last autumn. Neil Blackley, star media analyst of Merrill Lynch, justified his ranking last September by reporting the downturn which had started in July. Carlton and Granada have duly confirmed that in the four months to January, advertising was down 5%. Merrill Lynch's latest report says that during the first quarter of 2001, ITV advertising is down 7.7%, while the April fall could be anywhere between 15 and 20%. "We always believed 2001 would be down around 5-7% But this is far worse than expected."

But consider: last year during April, May and June, ITV recorded respective revenue jumps of 19.4%, 15.5% and 20.4% on the year before. After Euro 2000 is it surprising it went flat? And the bottom line is that ITV advertising revenue in February this year totalled £142m. In February 2000, fuelled by frothy dot.com madness, it was £148m and in 1999 it was £141m.

Hardly a collapse, suggests a sceptical Sorrell, who criticises "wild reports" designed to spread sympathy for the ITV companies. "I think they were trying to position ITV for their negotiations with the independent television commission. I take a cynical view of that."

Neil Blackley now says: "The second quarter will be the proving ground. Our concern is that it tends to be even worse than we thought." US multi-nationals, sellers of packaged goods, he observes, are "sitting on their hands". He expects an upturn for ITV starting in July and thinks that August could catch fire with the new Premier League season. But other media might not be so lucky. "The thing to watch is consumer spending and how that develops. There is a correlation between consumer spending and ad spending. If a cut is anticipated, the edict will go around the world: 'Sit on your hands'. It is pointless advertising if no one is buying."

My sense now, after two weeks of interviewing executives across the media spectrum, is of the ad world being on a knife edge. Big players in telecoms, motors, financial products, banks, could go either way, and the wisdom is divided. If the FTSE 100 collapses, do you try to advertise out of recession by arguing it's a good time to invest, or not?

The situation is complicated by uncertainty over how bad it might get. At present, it is wrong to think there is total gloom. Hewlett Packard announced a $50m marketing push last week to boost its image, using television and print. Julia Mee, brand advertising manager, says slowdown has forced an overall reduction, so it has cut its budgets in the US, and concentrated a reduced spend on Europe (Britain, France, Germany) to get impact. "A leader acts like a leader. Europe has high growth, big opportunities, so it's a great time to advertise and make a difference."

Who will be the casualties of the downturn? There is bound to be more caution about new launches and mergers between magazines and ad agencies, takeovers of radio stations, and, perhaps, a reduced investment in digital services. There will be more trimming of staff and budgets. At WPP, Sorrell says: "We are tightening our belts. It will be a tough period."

Terry Mansfield adds: "The explosion in the media over the last 10 years has been phenomenal." Magazines titles have grown from 6,725 consumer and business to 8,887, newspapers have spawned supplements, television channels mushroomed to 250, radio has three national commercial networks. "The media industry is exploding at such a rate it can't be sustained, it's not just dot.coms," Mansfield proffers. "In reality, the economy can't respond to the media on offer."

In his role as president of the international advertising association, David Hanger says that major advertisers are booking by the week rather than the year these days. "There is a lot of caution around. The campaigns are out there, approved, but they are not booking ahead. They are waiting, seeing what is happening to business, everyone is delaying."

Is it going to develop into another crash of the size of 90/91? "We just don't know. I was out with members of IAA last night and there was a genuine feeling of 'don't let's talk this one down, we're not wiped out yet'."

fields.headline: Consignia
fields.standfirst: The Post Office changes its name today to Consignia. Here's our guide to the best websites on the postal service's global aspirations
fields.trailText: The Post Office changes its name today to Consignia. Here's our guide to the best websites on the postal service's global aspirations.
fields.body:
1. The postal service formerly known as the Post Office will hereafter be known as Consignia. According to the company, the new name is designed to show that the Post Office does a lot more than just deliver mail.

2. The renamed organisation is also becoming a plc, a move described by chief executive John Roberts as a "major opportunity" for the business, and one which reflects its intention to operate in the global marketplace.

3. Let's wait and see. This announcement follows news last week that Postwatch, the consumer watchdog, has criticised the record of the Post Office in its delivery of first class mail. According to Postwatch, 2m letters a day are delivered late. However, the Post Office claims that the blame, as with so much in British life, lies with the weather and the railways. But then it would say that, wouldn't it?

5. The Postal Services Act 2000 opens the delivery of letters in Britain to anyone with a licence. This means that private operators, or foreign postal services, could organise collections and deliveries in the UK.

5. This could allow the Germans to take control of your post. And they have been known to overcharge.

6. The Post Office is heir to a tradition stretching back more than 4,000 years, to China, Persia or Rome, depending on who you listen to.

7. Indisputably though, the real revolution was the introduction of the penny black in 1840, which brought cheap, uniform postage to the masses, and, within 12 months, doubled the volume of mail delivered in Britain.

8. However, the service has been losing money (as well as your birthday cards) in recent years, even as deliveries have slowed, and branches have shut.

9. As anyone knows, the way to communicate these days is by email, or by ths blssd txt msgs (vwls nt allwd). Unless you're Dubya, who has decided to go back to pen and ink.

10. Late post has its place, though. Who can forget that it was the slow delivery of a letter which led to the tragic demise of Romeo and Juliet?

fields.headline: Sunday Best
fields.standfirst: The big media stories from the Sunday papers
fields.trailText:
Sunday Times
BBC director general Greg Dyke is considering selling off the corporation's magazine business including the Radio Times for £500m. He could also raise £450m by selling stakes in the BBC joint venture channels, UK Play and UK Gold. The Tories would welcome the sale but critics say the BBC shouldn't sell the family silver for short term gain.

Taking reality TV to new depths: A team of 24 men will live in a trench for two weeks for a new BBC reconstruction of the horrors of the first world war.

Tennis player Anna Kournikova now earns more through sponsorship than she does through her sport. The 19-year-old's £6.5m deal with terra lycos could help her double her current annual sponsorship income of £8.5m.

Observer
Right-on Rosie Boycott to become rival to right-wing Max Hastings, editor of the Evening Standard. She plans to launch a kinder, softer evening paper for London. Mr Hastings says he would welcome the competition.

Sunday Telegraph
The BBC will not be extending news coverage during the general election, fearing viewers will switch off.

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: Brand adventurers
fields.trailText: Brand adventurers
fields.body:
Brand adventurers are obsessed by all things new, be it TV channels or drinks. They are constantly improving their homes or gardens and always go to a different place for every holiday. In the UK, there are 1.8m of them, of both sexes and any age or social class. However, they are most likely to be young, with three-fifths under 35, and a fair number are students.

How can I spot them?

Brand adventurers like to stand out in a crowd, are keen to keep up with the latest fashions and believe that wearing a designer label improves their image. They often buy new brands just to see what they're like.

How do they keep up with what's hot?

Brand adventurers are big users of all media - they are 30% more likely than other adults to have satellite TV and they are frequent visitors to the cinema. They will never be far away from a magazine, or out of earshot of a commercial radio station. This group is also very advertising literate. They admit to noticing new advertising from TV to posters; even ads on taxis don't escape them.

On the TV?

If they are in, the TV will probably be on - their preferred viewing is varied, ranging from Big Breakfast in the morning to Eurotrash and other comedy late in the evening. Their TV schedule is a tale of a relentless quest for the latest "now show". "I always check out the new shows. I watch the soaps if the story line is good, but apart from that I'm flicking all the time - I hate to think I'm missing something," says one.

What are they reading?

They are heavy consumers of both quality and popular press - perhaps the only things that escape their attention are the mid-market newspapers. A third of Brand Adventurers read the Sun, and they are 40% more likely to read the Times than the average adult, 35% more likely to read the Guardian and 70% more likely to read the Observer. The most popular sections of the paper are the media and marketing section, the technology and computing articles and the style and fashion section.

Much conversation?

Comments such as: "The best thing in the world is to see as much of the world as possible. On my way home from the last trip I was thinking where I could go next year - I'm thinking of quitting my job so I can go travelling," are a bit of a giveaway.

 Data supplied by MediaCom

They often buy new brands just to see what they're like. How do they keep up with what's hot? Brand adventurers are big users of all media - they are 30% more likely than other adults to have satellite TV and they are frequent visitors to the cinema. They will never be far away from a magazine, or out of earshot of a commercial radio station. This group is also very advertising literate. They admit to noticing new advertising from TV to posters; even ads on taxis don't escape them. On the TV? If they are in, the TV will probably be on - their preferred viewing is varied, ranging from Big Breakfast in the morning to Eurotrash and other comedy late in the evening. Their TV schedule is a tale of a relentless quest for the latest "now show". "I always check out the new shows. I watch the soaps if the story line is good, but apart from that I'm flicking all the time - I hate to think I'm missing something," says one. What are they reading? The most popular sections of the paper are the media and marketing section, the technology and computing articles and the style and fashion section. Much conversation? Comments such as: "The best thing in the world is to see as much of the world as possible. On my way home from the last trip I was thinking where I could go next year - I'm thinking of quitting my job so I can go travelling," are a bit of a giveaway.  Data supplied by MediaCom

webTitle: The Heat is on, but Emap is out in the cold

fields.headline: The Heat is on, but Emap is out in the cold
fields.standfirst: The City is gunning for Emap, and with £600m in debts and doubts over its US business, it may be forced to take radical action, says  David Teather
fields.trailText: The City is gunning for Emap, and with £600m in debts and doubts over its US business, it may be forced to take radical action, says David Teather
fields.body:
The front cover of a research note circulating in the City last week showed surgeons in an operating theatre, scalpels poised over a reclining image of the Emap logo. The title of the research note was "corporate liposuction".

Apart from exposing the frustrated tabloid-hack ambitions of the author, it neatly summed up the prevailing view of the magazines and radio business in the square mile - Emap is in need of radical surgery.

After a decade of aggressive expansion during which the business became a stock market darling, Emap has hit the buffers. The company will attempt to reassure investors that all is well with a trading update tomorrow, but it will need to work hard to convince them.

The update is expected to highlight some clear hits. Heat, the group's entertainment weekly, has caught fire in circulation terms, reaching 230,000 in recent weeks. FHM, the leading men's monthly, has also shown there is still room for growth in its domestic market. In the US, the lad mag that leapfrogged Loaded is selling 830,000 copies.

But for investors the broader picture is more worrying. The group's US business is struggling, radio has nowhere to go under current ownership regulations, and debts are about £600m. There have been reports of low morale and the group faces, along with the rest of the media sector, an advertising market that is at best uncertain. The Emap share price, which was £17.50 about 14 months ago, is now around £7.

The City is baying for blood. Whether it be the sale of the US business, Petersen, which Emap acquired just over two years ago, or the disposal of the company's business-to-business magazines, there are few without an opinion of where the scalpel should cut. Some reports are suggesting that Kevin Hand, Emap's chief executive, has been given six months to turn around the group or face a putsch. In the current unforgiving climate in stock markets, investors are impatient for change.

Hand, 47, has a strong record. A former advertising salesman, he was shipped off to Paris by Emap in 1994, unable to speak a word of French. There, he built the company from scratch into the second biggest consumer publishing group in France behind Hachette. But his destiny will be more closely linked to the US business. The $1.2bn acquisition of Petersen in December 1998 is being seen as the turning point for Emap, the moment when the company began to look vulnerable. At the time Hand described Emap and Petersen as "twins separated at birth".

Analysts appeared to agree that it was the right target, but even at that time argued that Hand had overpaid. He has found it difficult to shift that suspicion, and critics pounced when, in the first half, profits from the US business fell by 23% to £17m.

The US group, whose portfolio includes Hot Rod, Dirt Rider, Sport, Teen and Guns'n'ammo, has suffered hardest from a drop in advertising from the automotive sector. Ford, in particular, shifted spend from specialist magazines onto the internet.

Emap is clearly reviewing the group's structure. The recent arrival of finance director Gary Hughes from Scottish Media Group has contributed to a strategic rethink. "The purchase of Petersen in the US has gone a little slower than we would have liked and therefore we are working really hard to make up that ground, and that is our intent," Hand told the Guardian last month. "But if we cannot see a way forward then we have no intention of publishing purely for vanity. We are not going to be in there at all costs."

The sale of the US business would be a clear sop to the investment community - the suggestion of a sale sparked a rare 10% rise in the share price last month. But the disposal of Petersen would be humiliating for Hand. With the advertising market sunk, this would be the worst time to seek a buyer. It would probably fetch less than £450m, leaving Emap with a £400m loss on its investment.

A sale would see the company joining the rollcall of British businesses that have failed to break the US. For Emap it would also remove the central plank of the strategy it has pushed for the past 18 months - the development of global brands based on the FHM model. Last year, Hand committed a £20m budget to FHM in the US for its first three years. Petersen was also seen as the platform for growth in a market where no one publisher has a market share of more than 10%, and which is ripe for consolidation.

The problems, though, have not been confined to the US. When announcing last results, Emap admitted a restructuring of its advertising salesforce around genres such as music or health had caused disruption to revenues. Media buyers are cynical about selling across brands and different types of media, but Emap insiders claim the strategy is beginning to bear fruit.

The other problem is that the UK magazine business is essentially mature, which means slower growth - making it all the more important that the likes of Heat demonstrate that Emap can still launch successful titles. More established titles on the slide include Sky, Red and Arena.

In radio, where its assets include Kiss FM, regulations prevent further expansion, although it is understood at least to have escaped the advertising downturn that has stricken Capital.

Emap has already retrenched on the internet. In November, it cut its spending forecast for web-based services from £250m over the next three years to £120m, an investment that still looks high in the current climate. It has homed in on eight targets for the cash, including online versions of FHM, music monthly Q and the construction trade titles.

If the company does alight on its business magazines as a candidate for sale, it would at least be putting them into a market where there will be no shortage of buyers. The business division, which includes titles such as Retail Week, Drapers Record and Broadcast, would fetch between £500m and £700m, enough to pay off the group's debts. Insiders suggest that if action is taken, however, it is more likely to be in the US.

Hand has maintained that the "pressure" to take action is not as tangible as some in the City would like to suggest, and the calls for change are more a reflection of analysts' herd-like mentality. He said last month that the company was not actively seeking buyers for the US business. The same, he said, was true of the company's business magazines division, which was first rumoured to be for sale at the end of last year. "We are running both businesses as we run all of our businesses all of the time, which means keeping options open."

A third way for Emap may to be find a joint venture partner in the US to reduce its exposure to the market while still being able to share in the potential upside of FHM. But the clamour for change is likely to be self-fulfilling, even taking the more generous view that Emap isn't quite in the crisis that the City believes it to be.

webTitle: Pair jailed for pocketing cancer cash

fields.headline: Pair jailed for pocketing cancer cash
fields.trailText: A charity watchdog has called for tighter regulations of "street donations" after two trustees of a children's cancer charity who ran their operation "as a business of ripping off the public" were today jailed for theft.
fields.body:
A charity watchdog has called for tighter regulations of "street donations" after two trustees of a children's cancer charity who ran their operation "as a business of ripping off the public" were today jailed for theft.

Deborah Munro, 39, a mother of five boys and Ian Dyke, 37, a father of two, received nearly £250,000 in street donations in a year and gave just £5,000 to the Hands of Hope Children's Cancer Fund.

The pair were convicted of stealing vast amounts of money from the charity between November 1997 and December 1998.

In passing sentence, Recorder Guy Hungerford said: "These offences involved a grave breach of trust. Many people here and abroad benefit from the charitable impulse of people giving money to charity.

"By stealing from charity you remove and weaken public confidence and may therefore prevent or lessen the money prescribed to other charities.

"You were both party to stealing money from a charity. Money didn't go to children with cancer but to others."

A spokesman for Charity Check, a charity watchdog based in London, said after the hearing: "This case highlights a major national scandal. One of the most disturbing features of the case was that the local authorities and supermarkets that allowed the Hands of Hope to collect, did so in accordance with charity commission advice.

"This case offers the clearest illustration of why the official system does not work and something must be done."

Munro, of Beckton, east London, who was found guilty of three charges of theft, collapsed in the dock and wept as she was sentenced at Oxford Crown Court to two-and-a-half years in prison for each count. The sentences were to run concurrently.

Dyke, of Manningtree, Essex, who was found guilty of one count of theft at their three-week trial last month, was sent to prison for 15 months.

During the trial, the jury heard how the pair, who were trustees of the registered charity in Ilford, Essex, stole cash given by members of the public to their team of street collectors throughout the south of England.

Records kept by the two gave "a completely false picture of the scale of the collections" and made it impossible to say "exactly how much money was stolen", the prosecution said.

Nigel Daly, prosecuting, said: "The collectors were not volunteers, but employees. This wasn't a charity, this was a business of ripping off the public in the name of people giving to a children's cancer charity.

"It was a business with a turnover in excess of £250,000 a year. Less than £5,000 in that year actually went to children's cancer relief. Only £11,000 went into the charity's bank account."

He added: "Huge amounts went elsewhere. The thefts were from members of the public who thought they were giving money to the charity."

A joint investigation by the charity commission and Thames Valley police showed that Munro and Dyke made hundreds of collections at shopping centres throughout the south of England, including areas of London, Essex, Berkshire and Oxfordshire.

Records seized by detectives showed they planned to fan out their operation in the coming years to the north of the country.

A single day's collection at the Dartford Crossing in London netted the pair more than £3,000 which the prosecution said "gives some idea of the generosity of the British public".

Munro, of previous good character and Dyke, who had been jailed for dishonesty 16 years ago, declined to give any evidence in their own defence during the trial.

In mitigation, Munro was today described "as a hapless dupe" of Dyke's.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Carole Stone
fields.trailText: Carole Stone
fields.body:
Newspapers:

The Daily Mail, the Guardian, and the Daily Telegraph on a cheapo subscription. My husband Richard always grabs the Mail first and reads out all the outrageous bits. I'm always amused by my friends who say they'd never write for the Daily Mail and then they do. I also read the Church of England newspaper.

Magazines:

The Week because I can't resist the wonderful pictures of the country cottages that I kid myself I'd like to live in. Prospect and The New Statesman are delivered, and as a media freak I buy Broadcast and Press Gazette. Last thing at night I read out loud to Richard from Reader's Digest.

Books:

Richard always reads me the classics in bed at night because it's the first time around for me. We're reading Can You Forgive Her? by Anthony Trollope.

Television:

I watch Blind Date regularly as I've got the same nose as Cilla Black before she had it done. I feel a special bonding. She could be me! I met her the other day and told her. Being married to a former Panorama reporter I have to watch the programme, even though these days it's on far too late and on the wrong night. If I'm home, I watch the evening news but I'm furious that the BBC and ITV are now head to head at 10pm.

Films:

I can honestly say that I seldom leave the cinema feeling that those hours are justified. It's time spent missing the opportunity to meet new people.

Radio:

I wake up to the Today programme and while in the bath I get in a rage about Thought For The Day. It rarely makes sense even though I do have a religious faith. On Saturdays I try and catch Any Questions. As a former Radio 4 girl, I do feel guilty when I find myself tuning into Magic FM.

Adverts:

I've racked my brains and all I can say is PG Tips and the monkeys.

New Media:

I don't surf the net very much at all. I think email is marvellous, but the personal contact will never die!

 Carole Stone's new book Networking - The Art Of Making Friends is available now, published by Vermilion

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Heather Rabbatts
fields.trailText: Heather Rabbatts
fields.body:
Favourite website?

Well, this is a slightly partisan answer because I'm a governor of the BBC, but I do think the BBC news site is very good. It's been the leader in translating news which it gathers through traditional media and puts it online in an accessible way. It's an unusual trick that not many people have pulled off.

Last online purchase?

Air tickets from EasyJet. It was late at night, it was easy and accessible.

Most recent technological faux pas?

My biggest difficulty is controlling my son's mobile telephone bill.

Ever been in a chat room?

No. I like talking to people as opposed to talking in cyberspace.

Main news source on web?

Reuters and FT.com. You can flick between them and get a very complete picture as opposed to reading a paper which only gives you one view.

Most useful websites?

UK government sites. The DTI and Number 10 sites are both good. I can find out what the government is sponsoring and how they are trying to take forward the area of endeavour my business is involved in.

Which site is least likely to succeed?

Websites which try to be wholly dependent on advertising won't succeed. Often you're just bombarded with adverts and you can't even see what the site is supposed to be about. Also, I think people want a tactile experience when they buy certain things, so while you might buy functional things over the web, I don't think that whole designer clothing thing is going to work. Time spent on the web?

I'll use it for a couple of hours a day, but I'm not someone who surfs the web as a pastime.

Least useful site on the web?

There was one which enabled you to put your boyfriend or girlfriend on it and then flirt with them online. I thought the pleasure of flirting was in the real human interaction.

Do you use a screensaver?

No. I've got a very functional relationship with technology. It isn't about being entertained.

Most irritating thing about web?

Information overload and too many emails. When people used to send telegrams across the world, they crafted their words carefully, but now that we have email we've become so much more sloppy. We should maintain certain disciplines about how we use the technology.

Do you still bother with old media?

There are intrinsic qualities in the experience of old media which I want to maintain, like holding a book and turning the pages.

 Heather Rabbatts is the chief executive of www.impower.co.uk

fields.headline: Do the right thing
fields.standfirst: Cash-strapped dot.commers can now log on to a website which will help them   market their business properly. Maybe it is a bit late for some, says Alastair Ray
fields.trailText: Cash-strapped dot.commers can now log on to a website which will help them market their business properly. Maybe it is a bit late for some, says Alastair Ray
fields.body:
As the pricking of last year's dot.com bubble prompts bloodshed on the stock market this year and threatens to knock on to the global economy, many internet start-ups must be wondering where it all went wrong.

But how could they have done it better? Figures from ACNielsen MMS show some £76m was spent promoting 31 different brands in the 12 months ending March 2000. How many of them remain on the tip of the tongue?

According to Tom Robinson, client director at marketing consultancy Addison, where some of the start-ups went wrong is that they failed to communicate the full range of values that a brand needs to win a place in consumers' hearts. "A true brand is the complete intertwining between the strategic and the emotional," he says. "What a lot of dot.coms did was too focused on the emotional and no one understood the strategy of what they were trying to do, they were sort of half-baked brands."

A further problem was that in trying to create a brand very quickly, they failed to realise that it can take time to build customer loyalty. "You have an experience with something and what generally happens is the reinforcing of that experience over time that enables you to have some sort of emotional relationship with that brand," he explains. But in an age when you can do more and more things on the web, it was only a matter of time before marketers started putting their thinking online. If you can buy everything from a car to a baby via the internet, why shouldn't a website be able to tell you how to develop a marketing strategy?

So, for the demographically illiterate and targeting unaware, the new website to log on to is www.virtualarchitecture.org. All you have to do is reveal a few details about your business, its stage of development, answer some questions about the service you plan to provide and, hey presto, out comes some simple, easy to understand advice.

Is your concept "simple and unique"? In which case your marketing strategy might include public relations and ads to announce your arrival. Or is it a complex idea being pitched into a crowded market? In the latter case brand building will be crucial and require long-term investment and continuity of message.

The site also provides an assessment of whether your current proposition is important to consumers, or whether they're likely to be quite happy to continue going down the shops thank you.

Admittedly it's fairly simple, but the need to create such a website goes a long way toward highlighting some of the failures of the marketing industry in the middle of last year's dot.com gold rush.

www.virtualarchitecture.org is the brainchild of Glyn Harper, managing director of the Virtual Marketing Agency, who suggests that as much as 50% of the dot.com's advertising spend has been wasted - in some cases 100%. And he admits that, in the wake of such poor results, marketing firms have acquired a reputation akin to snake oil salesmen.

He argues that by forcing entrepreneurs to think about marketing issues, perhaps for the first time, the virtual architecture site can assist the development of their business and hone their thinking, even if they never use the Virtual Marketing Agency's services.

The Virtual Marketing Agency offering allows clients to use a network of well known specialists - including creative network red cell, new media agency syzygy and Media Audits - if it is considered appropriate. The aim is to reduce costs by only providing the services that a business requires rather than having to sign up a raft of specialists on expensive retainers.

"Start-up organisations would love to buy in a marketing team, but being a small start-up they have got to be focused on fixed costs," Harper adds. "They're in a catch-22 situation in that they know that they need to put in the rigorous thinking in order to get the marketing right but they do not know how to do it."

It's a view that's echoed by Claire Owens, managing director of Stopgap, a recruitment agency specialising in short-term contracts, who says pulling in someone on a temporary basis can have many advantages for all kinds of new businesses, not just dot.coms.

"Until you know absolutely what level of expertise you need, you can bring someone in almost as a trial position," she says, adding that the needs in the launch phase may be very different to the long-term requirements of the company.

"A lot of these companies think they need a marketing director but actually once they get the strategic aspects sorted out, they need an implementation manager," she says.

For new media start-ups housed in incubators there may be the opportunity to access marketing expertise in other ways. David Hart, director of marketing at Brainspark, which houses 15 start-ups in the same building, says companies can take part in informal marketing forums as well as being able to access Brainspark's own expertise.

A further advantage of being based in the same building as other start-ups is that there is likely to be access to someone who may have experience of a particular form of marketing, be it direct mail or public relations. "There are quite a broad range of skills within the building," he says. "There will be someone who will say, 'actually I did this for four years'."

The new emphasis on finding the correct marketing strategy reflects the wider sea change in attitudes about the way dot.com companies should develop their businesses.

"Last year people thought they could get away with skimping on the foundation work of a marketing plan because the impetus of dot.com would carry them along," says Harper. "This year people realise that the fundamentals of marketing apply as much to dot.coms as they do to any other business. We are now seeing advertising that looks as though it's written to a brief."

It's a view that's backed up by Jonty Summers, marketing manager at Razorfish UK, who agrees that the gold rush mentality is now very much a thing of the past. "The back of the envelope business plan is dead," he says.

fields.headline: Royal Mail unveils new advertising slogan
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Royal Mail is dropping its famous 'I saw this and thought of you' advertising slogan after five years, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Royal Mail is dropping its famous "I saw this and thought of you" advertising slogan after five years in favour of a more serious image.

A £5.5m nationwide TV ad campaign kicks off on April 2 with the strapline "Nothing gets through like a letter".

The aim of the campaign is to increase the use of the mail amongst 25 to 45-year-old women, who, according to Royal Mail, are the core letter-writers.

The adverts, which will run in bursts throughout the summer, aim to highlight the way letters help people keep in touch with their loved ones.

One execution features a heartbroken lover writing to her partner. Another is about a dad using humour and irony to send advice to his daughter who has just left home for university.

But the humorous "I saw this and thought of you" strapline will not disappear entirely. It will still be used on poster adverts.

"We believe the "Nothing gets through like a letter" campaign will stimulate more mail usage by using characters and situations our customers can relate to, reinforcing the understanding that letters provide an ideal way to express your deepest feelings to the people close to you," said Rosena Robson, head of advertising at Royal Mail.

The campaign was created by Bates UK, Royal Mail's advertising agency.

fields.headline: Birth of the blues
fields.standfirst: Stefano Hatfield  looks at why US advertising revenues are plummeting
fields.trailText: Stefano Hatfield looks at why US advertising revenues are plummeting
fields.body:
Blame the chads! Just when you thought you had heard the last of those pesky paper indentations which had the world focused on Florida last November, it now seems they have come to symbolise the ushering in of America's first downturn in a decade.

As much as any single moment, the 37-day delay between election day and Al Gore throwing in the towel for the second time crystallised a gnawing unease previously subdued. While the world sniggered, Americans experienced a long-forgotten sensation: economic insecurity.

The signs had been there since the Nasdaq began its long, painful descent into realism last March. Until the last quarter of 2000, however, this was still a stock market recession. Most media companies remained bullish, hopeful that even 2000's extraordinary numbers could be beaten this year.

But stock markets hate uncertainty. When the election failed to produce a president, people not only stopped buying stocks, they suddenly stopped buying anything else. Heading the list of unsold items, as it always does in downturns, was advertising space.

Random indicators detail the butterfly effect's spread. A crucial statistic in retrospect was the Internet Advertising Bureau/Price Waterhouse Coopers Internet Ad Revenue Report, which for the first time since its inception in 1996 recorded a 6.5% drop in spend in the third quarter.

Suddenly in November, the magazines which had ridden the boom of the new economy - The Industry Standard, Red Herring and Wired - all saw pages drop. The telephone book sizes of the first half of the year became a distant memory. Lay-offs in the autumn at Red Herring, and in December at internet ad company DoubleClick, were not exactly a surprise, but the speed of the turnaround was stunning.

Nowhere is the slump more evident than at BusinessWeek. It took $100m of new business in 2000, doubling 1999's figure, but up to a third of that was dot.com related. It is now 40% down over the same period last year. It is not alone.

Magazine publishers are feeling the repercussions of over-stretch. Future, publisher of Business 2.0, is struggling. Now Emap is believed to be touting at least part of Emap USA (formerly Petersen) for sale. But then even in the white heat of 1998 that $1.2bn acquisition raised eyebrows.

Two other recent acquisitions were also received with a sharp intake of breath, suggesting a little sanity might return: in December Interpublic made Donny Dutsch more than $200m richer when it acquired his agency, unknown outside the US. Then over Christmas, Gruner & Jahr spent $350m on Fast Company magazine!

The picture is not entirely bleak. Although cable television experienced a 3.9% drop in the last quarter of 1999, network television was still growing. There are signs that old-economy advertisers are filling the airtime vacated by dot.coms.

While GM and Daimler-Chrysler cut hundreds of millions of dollars from their "upfront" airtime commitments, others such as IBM are spending heavily. Fox is cautious at the moment, but other network executives point out that even half of last year's record growth is still pretty good going.

Meanwhile, the stock prices of the big advertising groups have performed creditably. Interpublic's share price even managed to rise after the True North acquisition was announced.

There is scarcely a major agency in the US that has not made redundancies. But all insist they will grow this year, citing non-traditional advertising services, and continuing growth outside the US. It is hard to believe that they will not be hit hard, but they do all deserve credit for restructuring their businesses since the last recession.

Underlying all these developments is a fundamental change in the economic hierarchy that makes marketing even more important to corporate America's future prosperity. One worldwide CEO said this week: "Who would have thought anyone would care about consumer confidence 10 years ago?" It's clear that because of the growth in individual share ownership a stock market recession can no longer be confined to the stock market.

Since last March, the Nasdaq is down 63% and over three trillion dollars of wealth has disappeared. The consumer confidence index has fallen consistently since October. Although consumer spending has not yet quite slumped, as many observers feared, that's three trillion that will not be spent on new cars and personal computers this year. Smart advertisers will spend through the recession. But for many corporations the ad budget is easy to cut as it shows immediate short-term benefits to the P&L.

What's more, with even the pillars of the new economy such as Yahoo! in trouble, and weekly stories of job cuts splashed across the papers, there are now tangible reasons for consumers to feel insecure. All those forecasts that were predicting 4-6% growth this year are currently being revised downwards as a soft landing gets harder by the week. Those chads have a lot to answer for.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global

Haven't we been here before?

by John Dugdale and Maggie Brown

Advertising:
Advertising expenditure fell by 15% between 1989 and 1991. Eighty jobs disappeared every month in adland in the worst of the crash as clients slashed spending. Even directors' salaries were cut. "The extravagances of the 1980s - the long lunches and telephone number salaries - are already things of the past," the FT reported in April 1991.

Agency receiverships kept pace with redundancies, and big names were humiliatingly forced to admit to Thatcher-era hubris. With its shares plummeting, Saatchi and Saatchi only survived the slump thanks to a rescue package.

Broadcasting:
Plans for Channel 5 were postponed, due to fears that a depressed TV advertising market would destroy it. Rupert Murdoch's Sky took over its rival BSB (and became BSkyB) in November 1990, but the slump nearly brought Murdoch's entire empire down: bankers agreed to reschedule $8.2bn debts in January 1991. TV ad revenue was down 17% year-on-year in January 1991, and ITV companies slashed jobs - 750 at Thames in two years, 500 at LWT. Also down were budgets: C4 cut its back by £14m, with a drastic knock-on effect on indies. In commercial radio, the downturn similarly led to falling revenues and job losses. Originally due in 1991, the first national station (Classic FM) was delayed until 1992.

Press:
National newspaper advertising revenue fell by 11% in 1990 and 12% in 1991, causing papers to cut jobs, sections and pagination. The biggest impact was on Sunday titles, where the Correspondent was launched in autumn 1989, the worst possible moment, and folded a year later. "Broadsheets rather than tabloids were in the firing line," recalls Independent founder Andreas Whittam Smith, and the Indy was weakened by launching its Sunday title in January 1990. Growing losses ended the dream of a paper run by journalists, forcing the company to bring in foreign investors.

Magazines:
120 titles died in 1990, and more than 200 in 1991. Among the casualties were The Listener, style mag Blitz and Marxism Today. Even in the depths of the recession, though, there were new launches - Dazed & Confused was born late in 1991.

fields.headline: Batting for sport
fields.standfirst: Critics like it and listeners love it. So why has Radio 5 Live got an image problem? Controller Bob Shennan tells  Matt Wells  he's got the answer - and why Kelvin MacKenzie has lost the plot
fields.trailText: Critics like it and listeners love it. So why has Radio 5 Live got an image problem? Controller Bob Shennan tells Matt Wells he's got the answer - and why Kelvin MacKenzie has lost the plot
fields.body:
Radio 5 Live is a rare breed at the BBC: a success story. It is praised inside and outside the corporation; Greg Dyke is a listener, even MPs like it. The new controller Bob Shennan has amassed an impressive bank of sports rights, and dusted out the presenter broom cupboard. Audience figures are steadily rising. And as if to confirm its exalted status, Kelvin MacKenzie is calling for it to be privatised.

Government ministers regularly appear on the network, Nicky Campbell's "nation's conversation" phone-in show is seen as the gold standard, the breakfast show with Julian Worricker and Victoria Derbyshire is a combination of pace and intelligence that provides a real alternative to news listeners who can't be bothered with Radio 4, and the drive- time offering with Jane Garvey and Peter Allen is a daily gem. Sports coverage is acclaimed, the quality of commentary unrivalled.

"It has a fantastic tone of voice. There's no pomposity about Radio 5 Live. It talks to people as equals, and sounds like a family of broadcasters who are interested in both sport and news," says Shennan.

The station, then, should be riding the crest of this wave, shouting its success from the rooftops. The trouble, it seems, is that the BBC has been completely taken aback by this success, and doesn't really know what to do next.

Seven years after its launch there is a sense that Radio 5 Live is still unsure of its identity. Apart from Campbell and Richard Littlejohn, its presenters are still unknowns. The station has an impressive 5.5m listeners - up on the previous quarter, but down from a peak of around 6m - and there are not as many Sony nominations this year.

Its fundamental image problem stems from its split personality as a news and sport network. BBC audience research shows that almost a third of people in the country have never heard of 5 Live - and some of those who claim to know about the station think it is a music network.

The BBC has never really quite decided what Radio 5 is for. At its conception, sport was an add-on. Indeed, for most of its life it came under the news and current affairs umbrella.

Now, however, its controller is the former BBC head of sport, and the station has been transferred into the radio family. In the eight months since he took over, his image of the station is becoming clear. He has cleared out "anomalies" - axed the media show Paper Talk, sacked Andrew Neil from his Sunday breakfast show and discontinued the Saturday satirical series The Treatment.

Shennan has devoted most of his attention to sport: every weeknight is now a sports night, starting at 7pm. He has placed Ian Wright and Mark Bright in The Treatment's old slot between the mid-morning Saturday news and sports mix of Adrian Chiles and the main sporting action of Saturday afternoon.

Some disgruntled voices say he is busily stripping out all the character from Radio 5, homogenising the output so that listeners will have even less idea of what the station stands for. There are mutterings from staff: some suggest darkly that while Shennan may be able to add a few hundred thousand to the listening figures, he's not a visionary.

Visionary or not, he is certainly not a revolutionary, preferring change by evolution. He denies the charge of homogenisation, saying he has brought "clarity and logic" to the schedule. He promises plenty more "quirk" - there is a Saturday night media and entertainment show to come, presented by travel news reporter Caroline Faraday, and a sports quiz show with former Sky presenter Helen Chamberlain. A new entertainment correspondent, Phil Williams, has been appointed from Radio 1 with a brief to cover showbiz "properly". Election coverage will be comprehensive, but not overwhelming.

And while change has been gradual so far, there are a number of radical shake-ups planned. Shennan will not give details, but it seems that big names are being talked about. The Guardian understands that Frank Skinner is being lined up to replace Mellor as presenter of a football phone-in show, former ITN political editor Michael Brunson has been approached to do regular work, and Brian Alexander is about to move from the 10pm slot - which he has presented with mixed critical success - to present the weekend breakfast programme alongside Shelagh Fogarty. The gap left by Alexander means that Fi Glover, a favourite with listeners and critics, will finally get a permanent home on the network.

There are more plans for sport: there will be a cricket show presented by Jamie Theakston, and a dedicated Formula One programme - something 5 Live has never developed, even though it holds the rights to the sport. And while Shennan insists he is committed to news - it makes up almost 80% of the station's output - his greatest victory has been to secure (very expensive) premier league commentary rights for a further three years.

While the proportion of sport to news has remained largely unchanged, there is an impression that sport has gained ground simply because it has a greater focus, and the "news camp" in the station is worried.

The overall budget for news has just been cut, if only slightly, and the station's marketing campaign is focused exclusively on sport. The news judgments of Shennan's management team have sometimes been questioned; it had to be pointed out recently that while it might have been a good idea to take Tony Blair's speech live from the Labour Spring conference, the station would have to give similar coverage to those of William Hague and Charles Kennedy - which fell in the middle of football matches. While Shennan talks the news game, praising the 5 Live Report and pointing to the recent decision to clear the schedules for a themed debate evening on race, news staff say fears are yet to be allayed.

And then there's Kelvin MacKenzie, swishing his gladiatorial sword.

The TalkSport boss claims that Shennan is turning Radio 5 into a sports network in all but name. Dyke and Shennan are "fire-hosing" taxpayers' money at sporting rights, he claims, wasting tens of millions of pounds simply to corner a market and drive out competition. "In America, where there are anti-trust laws to curb predatory behaviour, Greg Dyke would be in jail, as would a number of radio executives. Here in Britain they're on the loose, ripping off the taxpayer and squandering his money, crushing the competition, cheating the sports fan and openly bragging about it," MacKenzie told the Broadcasting Press Guild recently.

He has a point. In Australia, if broadcasters amass rights to events they cannot find time to transmit, they must give them up for a dollar apiece.

Shennan dismisses MacKenzie wearily. "I've heard all this before. I think his argument is pretty transparent. What is the BBC supposed to do? It's criticised for being the dozy old BBC, losing the plot if we lose sports rights; if we go for them, we are killing the competition."

So 5 Live will forge ahead. Shennan reckons that sport is a crucial method of driving listeners to the rest of the station's output, and believes sports rights deliver value to the licence-fee payer: without them, there would be little to offer. Others question the strategy: while sports rights are crucial, they point out that sports audiences are falling while those for news are rising. Most of the new listeners to 5 Live in the past year came in through the breakfast and drive-time programmes. "The idea that you can drive listeners from sport to the rest of the output is at best defensive, it's protecting what you've got," says one senior journalist.

But Shennan believes that sport is what makes 5 Live stand out - and he will not bow to MacKenzie. "Sport is hugely important for us. It makes us the key player in football on radio. We are being commercially astute but we are not bludgeoning anybody by overpaying. The record is stuck, Kelvin has lost."

The new controller Bob Shennan has amassed an impressive bank of sports rights, and dusted out the presenter broom cupboard. Audience figures are steadily rising. And as if to confirm its exalted status, Kelvin MacKenzie is calling for it to be privatised. Government ministers regularly appear on the network, Nicky Campbell's "nation's conversation" phone-in show is seen as the gold standard, the breakfast show with Julian Worricker and Victoria Derbyshire is a combination of pace and intelligence that provides a real alternative to news listeners who can't be bothered with Radio 4, and the drive- time offering with Jane Garvey and Peter Allen is a daily gem. Sports coverage is acclaimed, the quality of commentary unrivalled. "It has a fantastic tone of voice. There's no pomposity about Radio 5 Live. It talks to people as equals, and sounds like a family of broadcasters who are interested in both sport and news," says Shennan. The station, then, should be riding the crest of this wave, shouting its success from the rooftops. The trouble, it seems, is that the BBC has been completely taken aback by this success, and doesn't really know what to do next. Seven years after its launch there is a sense that Radio 5 Live is still unsure of its identity. Apart from Campbell and Richard Littlejohn, its presenters are still unknowns. The station has an impressive 5.5m listeners - up on the previous quarter, but down from a peak of around 6m - and there are not as many Sony nominations this year. Its fundamental image problem stems from its split personality as a news and sport network. BBC audience research shows that almost a third of people in the country have never heard of 5 Live - and some of those who claim to know about the station think it is a music network. The BBC has never really quite decided what Radio 5 is for. At its conception, sport was an add-on. Indeed, for most of its life it came under the news and current affairs umbrella. Now, however, its controller is the former BBC head of sport, and the station has been transferred into the radio family. In the eight months since he took over, his image of the station is becoming clear. He has cleared out "anomalies" - axed the media show Paper Talk, sacked Andrew Neil from his Sunday breakfast show and discontinued the Saturday satirical series The Treatment. Shennan has devoted most of his attention to sport: every weeknight is now a sports night, starting at 7pm. He has placed Ian Wright and Mark Bright in The Treatment's old slot between the mid-morning Saturday news and sports mix of Adrian Chiles and the main sporting action of Saturday afternoon. Some disgruntled voices say he is busily stripping out all the character from Radio 5, homogenising the output so that listeners will have even less idea of what the station stands for. There are mutterings from staff: some suggest darkly that while Shennan may be able to add a few hundred thousand to the listening figures, he's not a visionary. Visionary or not, he is certainly not a revolutionary, preferring change by evolution. He denies the charge of homogenisation, saying he has brought "clarity and logic" to the schedule. He promises plenty more "quirk" - there is a Saturday night media and entertainment show to come, presented by travel news reporter Caroline Faraday, and a sports quiz show with former Sky presenter Helen Chamberlain. A new entertainment correspondent, Phil Williams, has been appointed from Radio 1 with a brief to cover showbiz "properly". Election coverage will be comprehensive, but not overwhelming. And while change has been gradual so far, there are a number of radical shake-ups planned. Shennan will not give details, but it seems that big names are being talked about. The Guardian understands that Frank Skinner is being lined up to replace Mellor as presenter of a football phone-in show, former ITN political editor Michael Brunson has been approached to do regular work, and Brian Alexander is about to move from the 10pm slot - which he has presented with mixed critical success - to present the weekend breakfast programme alongside Shelagh Fogarty. The gap left by Alexander means that Fi Glover, a favourite with listeners and critics, will finally get a permanent home on the network. There are more plans for sport: there will be a cricket show presented by Jamie Theakston, and a dedicated Formula One programme - something 5 Live has never developed, even though it holds the rights to the sport. And while Shennan insists he is committed to news - it makes up almost 80% of the station's output - his greatest victory has been to secure (very expensive) premier league commentary rights for a further three years. While the proportion of sport to news has remained largely unchanged, there is an impression that sport has gained ground simply because it has a greater focus, and the "news camp" in the station is worried. The overall budget for news has just been cut, if only slightly, and the station's marketing campaign is focused exclusively on sport. The news judgments of Shennan's management team have sometimes been questioned; it had to be pointed out recently that while it might have been a good idea to take Tony Blair's speech live from the Labour Spring conference, the station would have to give similar coverage to those of William Hague and Charles Kennedy - which fell in the middle of football matches. While Shennan talks the news game, praising the 5 Live Report and pointing to the recent decision to clear the schedules for a themed debate evening on race, news staff say fears are yet to be allayed. And then there's Kelvin MacKenzie, swishing his gladiatorial sword. The TalkSport boss claims that Shennan is turning Radio 5 into a sports network in all but name. Dyke and Shennan are "fire-hosing" taxpayers' money at sporting rights, he claims, wasting tens of millions of pounds simply to corner a market and drive out competition. "In America, where there are anti-trust laws to curb predatory behaviour, Greg Dyke would be in jail, as would a number of radio executives. Here in Britain they're on the loose, ripping off the taxpayer and squandering his money, crushing the competition, cheating the sports fan and openly bragging about it," MacKenzie told the Broadcasting Press Guild recently. He has a point. In Australia, if broadcasters amass rights to events they cannot find time to transmit, they must give them up for a dollar apiece. Shennan dismisses MacKenzie wearily. "I've heard all this before. I think his argument is pretty transparent. What is the BBC supposed to do? It's criticised for being the dozy old BBC, losing the plot if we lose sports rights; if we go for them, we are killing the competition." So 5 Live will forge ahead. Shennan reckons that sport is a crucial method of driving listeners to the rest of the station's output, and believes sports rights deliver value to the licence-fee payer: without them, there would be little to offer. Others question the strategy: while sports rights are crucial, they point out that sports audiences are falling while those for news are rising. Most of the new listeners to 5 Live in the past year came in through the breakfast and drive-time programmes. "The idea that you can drive listeners from sport to the rest of the output is at best defensive, it's protecting what you've got," says one senior journalist. But Shennan believes that sport is what makes 5 Live stand out - and he will not bow to MacKenzie. "Sport is hugely important for us. It makes us the key player in football on radio. We are being commercially astute but we are not bludgeoning anybody by overpaying. The record is stuck, Kelvin has lost."

webTitle: Web firm plans new issue to raise £1m

fields.headline: Web firm plans new issue to raise £1m
fields.trailText: A dot.com company that helps businesses understand public sector grants is set to brave the icy waters of the new issue market. By Neil Hume.
fields.body:
A dot.com company that helps businesses understand the complex world of public sector grants is set to brave the icy waters of the new issue market.

J4b will today announce plans to list on the junior Ofex market and raise £1.17m through an offer of 3.9m shares. At the sale price of 30p, this will value the year-old company at £3.2m.

Although the UK grants market is worth an estimated £5bn annually, information is notoriously difficult to come by and only 7% of eligible businesses have bothered to apply for assistance.

This is where J4b claims to come in. It has developed a website that offers information on nearly 4,000 public sector grants, with services such as online application forms and expert advice for applicants. It is planning a grant alert service through which users will be e-mailed about grants applicable to their businesses.

The company, which is not forecast to make a profit until 2003, aims to generate revenue through advertising and value added services such as online applications. It will use the proceeds of the flotation to expand within the UK and Europe.

webTitle: Radio 4? 5 Live? Never heard of them

fields.headline: Radio 4? 5 Live? Never heard of them
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: BBC research shows that millions of people are simply unaware of the existence of Radio 4 and 5 Live, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
They are home to the oldest soap, the most influential news programmes and the widest range of sports broadcasting, but internal BBC research shows that millions of people are simply unaware of the existence of Radio 4 and 5 Live.

Asked to name a selection of radio stations at random, more than half of listeners fail to name Radio 4, and two-thirds do not pick out 5 Live.

Even when they are asked specifically whether they are aware of Radio 5, the seven-year-old news and sport network, a third say they have never heard of it. Some of the rest think it is a music station.

When asked specifically about Radio 4 recognition rises, but only in the same way.

Bob Shennan, the controller of 5 Live, says the station needs more distinctive personalities. Apart from Nicky Campbell, who presents a critically acclaimed daily phone-in show in which the prime minister and chancellor have taken part, the station's presenters are not particularly well known.

Radio 4 is less worried about its profile: among its target audience the station performs well, and has been perceived to have increased in strength under the present controller, Helen Boaden. She has built upon the strength of the Archers and Today with innovations such as the broadcast last Boxing Day of an entire Harry Potter book.

In an attempt to raise awareness of Radio 5 Live, Mr Shennan has embarked upon a big-name recruitment spree. It is understood that the comedian and football fan Frank Skinner is being lined up to replace the former Tory minister David Mellor as presenter of a weekly football phone-in programme; Simon Mayo has been lured from Radio 1 to present the daily afternoon programme; and the former ITN political editor Michael Brunson has received a tentative approach to work for the station.

Mr Shennan conceded that the station's profile was relatively low. But audience research shows that while the presenters are not stars, they are liked by listeners. "It's one of the secrets of our success," Mr Shennan said. "Listeners like the 'noise' they make, and their company. It does make it difficult to stand out, though. Nicky stands out, but we need to stand out a bit more."

Some at Radio 5 are wary of Mr Shennan's sports background: although sport is hugely important to the station, news makes up three-quarters of its output. Mr Shennan, who was the corporation's head of sport until he took over at 5 Live last year, says he wants to boost the profile of the station's news. "It's one of my frustrations that we don't get the credit for news," he said.

Mr Shennan also plans major changes to the existing presenter line-up: Brian Alexander, who hosts the late-night programme, is expected to move to the weekend breakfast slot with Shelagh Fogarty, a 5 Live newcomer, after the Sunday breakfast host Andrew Neil was dropped at the end of last year.

Alexander and Fogarty will front the programmes on Saturday and Sunday, and are expected to bring the same sort of relaxed style that characterises the daily breakfast programme with Julian Worricker and Victoria Derbyshire. Fi Glover, who fronts the satirical news show Sunday Service with Charlie Whelan and Andrew Pierce, will replace Alexander in the late-night slot.

fields.headline: Raspberry awards for Travolta film
fields.trailText: So stiff is the competition that they are probably the most difficult film awards to win. But the film Battlefield Earth which starred John Travolta has managed almost a clean sweep of Golden Rapsberries in recognition of its profound awfulness.
fields.body:
So stiff is the competition that they are probably the most difficult film awards to win. But the film Battlefield Earth which starred John Travolta has managed almost a clean sweep of Golden Rapsberries in recognition of its profound awfulness.

In the eve of Oscar ceremony in Santa Monica, the film based on the novel by Scientology founder L Ron Hubbard took almost every Razzie. Only Madonna, who won worst actress for The Next Best Thing, and the Blair Witch Project sequel, disturbed Battlefield Earth's progress to glory.

"It was actually a cake walk for jurors. 'Battlefield' was truly wretched," said Golden Raspberry Foundation founder John Wilson.

The Razzies, which are gold-painted raspberries, go to the films and actors voted the worst of the year by 535 foundation members.

Razzies for Battlefield Earth included Worst Picture, and John Travolta won Worst Actor and Worst Screen Couple along with anyone sharing the screen with him in Battlefield Earth.
