webTitle: Escape route from the mean streets

fields.headline: Escape route from the mean streets
fields.trailText: Waseem Hussain says he has been bad since he was about eight years old. He was always messing about, fighting and swearing. After exclusion from a number of schools, Waseem took his trouble out on to the streets of Rotherham.
fields.body:
Waseem Hussain says he has been bad since he was about eight years old. He was always messing about, fighting and swearing. After exclusion from a number of schools, Waseem took his trouble out on to the streets of Rotherham.

Hanging around in gangs, Waseem, 16, started looking for fights every day. But he never seemed to get caught. One day, though, the scale and violence of Waseem's offences escalated.

"I was in the bus station and I followed this lad in the toilets and I punched him twice. After that it started getting more serious. I thought I liked it then, getting into trouble. Put it this way, I enjoyed it, it felt powerful," he says, admitting that the severity of the offences increased. "I put the boot in as well."

Waseem says he has been caught for between 10 and 12 offences and admits to "at least another seven or eight on top of that".

He goes on: "I was in Worcestershire one day and this lad, I saw him, he were running and I asked him what has he done and he said "I nicked something off a bus". The police came and he told the police that I did it. The next day I saw him and I told him "let's go for a joint". I took him into the subways and said to him "this is for grassing me up". I was stamping him, I kicked his face and when they found him he was unconscious. I got arrested and they found forensic evidence, they found his blood on my trainers."

Waseem was given a detention training order of eight months, four months of which he spent inside Wetherby young offenders' institution. He says: "I was still having fights in there. I did one month in segregation. My problem magnified then because I was meeting the same crew. When I came out of prison, my offences started to change and I was messing about with cars and knives. Being in prison made me more interested in cars. Then I started carrying a lock knife."

Waseem is the perfect example of what the government classes as a hardcore persistent young offender, one of the 3% of young offenders reckoned to be responsible for up to 25% of crimes. He is also a boy whose crimes escalated to a terrifying degree after his time in prison. He says he could have easily used that lock knife.

Waseem is sitting in an office in the Rotherham intensive support supervision advocacy programme, a place he hopes will make him think twice about ever picking the lock knife up again. He is one of 22 young offenders who have had to come to this project since it started last August. The project's aim is to prevent reoffending by young offenders who have broken the law on more than three occasions by offering support and help with their difficulties. The Rotherham project also has a dedicated police officer known as a "tracking officer" who keeps a very close eye on all the offenders.

The Rotherham project is a blueprint for the government's intensive surveillance and supervision programme to be launched on Wednesday. While the Rotherham pilot has not used electronic surveillance, its tracking officer checks up on the young offenders all the time. PC Bill Thomas is with the Rotherham project. He says it works: "It's fair to say that Waseem's offending has not been on the same level of escalation. Waseem has had problems with his anger and we have been working on his self-esteem. But since he has been on the programme, he has become a little bit more mature and is making more informed choices.

"So far, we have not completely excluded offending from Waseem's life but we have reduced the seriousness and the impact of it. Waseem was very much a lad who was destined to do a lot of time because he was so chaotic. Within the project, he has got a little bit more structure and he is calmer and perhaps his future has changed."

As a tracking officer, Mr Thomas uses his intelligence-collating skills garnered from his police work to make sure that his offenders feel them breathing down their collar. If they don't turn up at the programme when required, he goes out and finds them and hauls them back in - if they persist with this behaviour they find themselves back in the criminal justice system without the project's support.

"In real terms my role is about getting to know people like Waseem, about his family, about his habits, his environment, what his expectations are. I will then devise a plan on how we can incorporate all of those and at the same time work within the confinements of the law. If it does go wrong, I pull him up and maybe have to deal with his family and the situation in the neighbourhood if that becomes a problem," explains Mr Thomas. "It should make a marked impact on some people's lives. We have had youngsters who have been on the project who have not been back inside. One young man has never reoffended and has got a steady job."

Simon Perry, manager of Rotherham youth offending services, says the Rotherham project (based on a successful American one) is a sort of blueprint but adds that it is not required that the new programmes across the country replicate it.

"What we know is that there's a very small group of very hard to reach, socially excluded children who don't go to school, don't work, are very often homeless, very often victims of abuse and often involved in drug taking. A significant number are involved in persistent offending and because of that the more socially ostracised they become. And young people commit a disproportionate amount of crime. It is incredibly difficult to engage these chil dren," he explains. "There is a greater chance that they will become potentially violent, criminally offending adults. Because they are difficult to engage, we have to take longer over doing it and that's where the word intensive is appropriate."

The Rotherham project has a social worker, police officer, probation service officer, a volunteer coordinator and three development workers who work with housing, drugs and alcohol, and employment issues. It also uses volunteer mentors from within the community to work with offenders. Jackie Key, the project manager, says she has dealt with 22 offenders involved mostly in assaults, burglary and car crime. "The majority are white and male, a proportion are mixed race or Asian children and we have had two females. A lot of them want to stop reoffending but their life circumstances have stopped them from doing that."

Even in the short term, she says, the Rotherham project seems to be working. Prior to the young people coming on the programme, the number of offences they committed was 156. While on the programme the number of offences they committed was 28. The average number of weeks of the programme is 14.3; the average number of offences committed by young people prior to the programme is 7.09, while on the programme it is 1.36.

fields.bodyText: Waseem Hussain says he has been bad since he was about eight years old. He was always messing about, fighting and swearing. After exclusion from a number of schools, Waseem took his trouble out on to the streets of Rotherham. Hanging around in gangs, Waseem, 16, started looking for fights every day. But he never seemed to get caught. One day, though, the scale and violence of Waseem's offences escalated. "I was in the bus station and I followed this lad in the toilets and I punched him twice. After that it started getting more serious. I thought I liked it then, getting into trouble. Put it this way, I enjoyed it, it felt powerful," he says, admitting that the severity of the offences increased. "I put the boot in as well." Waseem says he has been caught for between 10 and 12 offences and admits to "at least another seven or eight on top of that". He goes on: "I was in Worcestershire one day and this lad, I saw him, he were running and I asked him what has he done and he said "I nicked something off a bus". The police came and he told the police that I did it. The next day I saw him and I told him "let's go for a joint". I took him into the subways and said to him "this is for grassing me up". I was stamping him, I kicked his face and when they found him he was unconscious. I got arrested and they found forensic evidence, they found his blood on my trainers." Waseem was given a detention training order of eight months, four months of which he spent inside Wetherby young offenders' institution. He says: "I was still having fights in there. I did one month in segregation. My problem magnified then because I was meeting the same crew. When I came out of prison, my offences started to change and I was messing about with cars and knives. Being in prison made me more interested in cars. Then I started carrying a lock knife." Waseem is the perfect example of what the government classes as a hardcore persistent young offender, one of the 3% of young offenders reckoned to be responsible for up to 25% of crimes. He is also a boy whose crimes escalated to a terrifying degree after his time in prison. He says he could have easily used that lock knife. Waseem is sitting in an office in the Rotherham intensive support supervision advocacy programme, a place he hopes will make him think twice about ever picking the lock knife up again. He is one of 22 young offenders who have had to come to this project since it started last August. The project's aim is to prevent reoffending by young offenders who have broken the law on more than three occasions by offering support and help with their difficulties. The Rotherham project also has a dedicated police officer known as a "tracking officer" who keeps a very close eye on all the offenders. The Rotherham project is a blueprint for the government's intensive surveillance and supervision programme to be launched on Wednesday. While the Rotherham pilot has not used electronic surveillance, its tracking officer checks up on the young offenders all the time. PC Bill Thomas is with the Rotherham project. He says it works: "It's fair to say that Waseem's offending has not been on the same level of escalation. Waseem has had problems with his anger and we have been working on his self-esteem. But since he has been on the programme, he has become a little bit more mature and is making more informed choices. "So far, we have not completely excluded offending from Waseem's life but we have reduced the seriousness and the impact of it. Waseem was very much a lad who was destined to do a lot of time because he was so chaotic. Within the project, he has got a little bit more structure and he is calmer and perhaps his future has changed." As a tracking officer, Mr Thomas uses his intelligence-collating skills garnered from his police work to make sure that his offenders feel them breathing down their collar. If they don't turn up at the programme when required, he goes out and finds them and hauls them back in - if they persist with this behaviour they find themselves back in the criminal justice system without the project's support. "In real terms my role is about getting to know people like Waseem, about his family, about his habits, his environment, what his expectations are. I will then devise a plan on how we can incorporate all of those and at the same time work within the confinements of the law. If it does go wrong, I pull him up and maybe have to deal with his family and the situation in the neighbourhood if that becomes a problem," explains Mr Thomas. "It should make a marked impact on some people's lives. We have had youngsters who have been on the project who have not been back inside. One young man has never reoffended and has got a steady job." A significant number are involved in persistent offending and because of that the more socially ostracised they become. And young people commit a disproportionate amount of crime. It is incredibly difficult to engage these chil dren," he explains. "There is a greater chance that they will become potentially violent, criminally offending adults. Because they are difficult to engage, we have to take longer over doing it and that's where the word intensive is appropriate." A lot of them want to stop reoffending but their life circumstances have stopped them from doing that." Even in the short term, she says, the Rotherham project seems to be working. fields.headline: Turner prize
fields.standfirst: Anthea Turner must have breathed a sigh of relief at surviving Celebrity Big Brother with her credibility intact. Can she put the bad news of the last year behind her?
fields.trailText: March 26: Having survived Big Brother, can Anthea Turner put the woes of last year behind her? Maggie Hyde looks to the stars.
fields.body:
Anthea Turner must have breathed a sigh of relief at surviving Celebrity Big Brother with her credibility intact and even modestly restored. Can she finally put the bad news of the last year behind her?

She is a butterfly Gemini and her horoscope (12.30pm, May 25 1960, Stoke-on-Trent) shows spick and span Virgo rising - hence all that cleaning in the Big Brother house.

Venus, planet of beauty, marriage and sweeties, is exactly on her Midheaven career point. This has brought her success but it is right next to a devilish fixed star known as Caput Algol. The old astrologers linked this with beheading, which is what Anthea's critics seem to want to do to her now. She has certainly lost her head in handling her PR.

From last June until this March, Saturn, planet of come-downs, has been crossing this area, bringing toe-curling humiliations, especially the Snowflake choccie bar incident at her OK! wedding to Grant Bovey. Too tacky, even for the tabloids.

The next twist on Saturn's downward slide came when her revelations of beatings by former partner Bruno Brookes got no sympathy and were treated as another PR ploy. Her autobiography also got the media thumbs-down.

So where do her true talents lie? Born on a New Moon in the sign of the Gemini Twins, she has the best and the worst of its qualities. Chatty and bright, Gemini is a natural media sign and is at its best networking and communicating, at its worst when it's in wheeler-dealer, tricks and porkies mode.

It is all too easy for this sign to cast itself, and be cast as, light and superficial. As Anthea says of herself, "I am the middle of the road, light entertainment, family-viewing girl next door. Sorry! That's who I am."

But the Gemini Twins are constituted in opposites - light and dark, shallow and deep, all and nothing. But above all, they are ruled by androgynous Mercury, the mischievous trickster planet.

She has the youthfulness and bright eyes of the typical Gemini but this can be the Peter Pan sign that hates to grow up. The archetypal puer or puella, Gemini is the "eternal youth", who abhors the sober world of age, duty and commitment. Like Gemini Bob Dylan, it must stay "forever young". Quite a problem for Anthea, now she has turned 40.

In Celebrity Big Brother, the housemates touched on the idea of the "persona" or mask, a much-used concept in Jungian analysis. It is our public face, and celebrity image is inevitably constituted around it, but over-identification with the mask carries the danger of losing the individual behind.

Anthea's bright, Tinkerbell persona is tied in with Pluto rising at her birth and, in mythology, when this lord of the underworld ascends, he wears an invisible helmet. This casts a shadow across her relationships, concealing her authenticity and her darker, deeper Twin.

While Saturn lingers in Gemini this year, Anthea needs to remain ultra cautious about her image. Spring and early summer 2002 bring a catalyst period when Pluto progresses square to her Sun, and this is trouble if she remains constituted only in a brittle public persona.

But Geminis are adaptable and can turn their hand to many things, so Anthea does have the possibility of reinventing herself. Perhaps then we will stop using her as a hook on which to hang our own media projections.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Bacardi breezes in with cat's eye view
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Bacardi Breezer cat goes clubbing again in a new advert for the pre-mixed drink, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The nightclubbing Bacardi Breezer cat was too busy filming the movie Stuart Little II in Los Angeles to appear in a new advert for the drink.

So the new Bacardi commercial has been filmed as if we are seeing through the cat's eyes.

The advert, which breaks on Channel 4 tomorrow, has Tom Cat the funky feline going clubbing again, this time with a posse of human mates.

This time we see all the action from the cat's eyes, so we only get a glimpse of his face reflected in a fish tank at the end of the advert.

The final frame was taken from footage shot for the first Bacardi advert, which saw Tom sneaking away from granny's flat to spend the night grooving on the dancefloor with a bevy of gorgeous girls.

The commercial helped Tom Cat achieve cult status in the UK after the tabloids discovered he had been played by the three Los-Angeles based cats who starred in the hit film Stuart Little.

The moggies, Merlin, Magoo and Murphy, were flown from LA to Prague to film the commercial, and were paid a total of £600,000 to star in the £4m advertising campaign.

The cats are now hard at work on the follow-up movie to Stuart Little, about a mouse adopted by a family and could not fit filming the new Bacardi advertising in to their demanding schedules.

But a spokeswoman for Bacardi said they will be back soon to star in a new advertising campaign.

fields.headline: Slaughter of new dot.com ventures
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Another week, perhaps another battering in the value of technology shares. Last year's downward trend in tech stocks shows no sign of slowing -more like the opposite - and it has been tempting for us to link what we are seeing in the markets with our own experience a couple of weeks ago in the US.
fields.body:
Another week, perhaps another battering in the value of technology shares. Last year's downward trend in tech stocks shows no sign of slowing -more like the opposite - and it has been tempting for us to link what we are seeing in the markets with our own experience a couple of weeks ago in the US.

It was a real eye-opener. We obviously knew that many UK internet businesses were fighting for survival following the drying-up of investment funds and the low valuations of the new media economy. We were also aware that this was partly a consequence of negative events in the wider global economy, particularly in the US, where the deadly financial virus which struck the dot.coms originated. However, we did not expect to see so much evidence of widespread start-up slaughter and such hopeless cases.

Here's a couple of examples. We met with some US businesses operating in the same sector as ourselves. The first was already struggling to raise funding for survival beyond the summer. The second company became insolvent during the short time we were in the US.

We also attended a web conference in New York. Some of the delegates there had been made redundant in the short period between booking for the conference and attending it.

But it was the opinion of the heavyweight speakers that proved the best draw. Sergey Brin, the founder of Google, the leading internet search engine, made it clear that his company was not dependent on advertising-based revenues - presumably to fend off comparisons with competitor Yahoo!

Instead he saw Google as a technology company offering internet service providers high speed search engines.

Then there was Merrill Lynch's star internet analyst, Henry Blodget, who admitted he was significantly late in spotting the sustained nature of the market downturn.

Not everything discussed in the conference was doom and gloom - there were fascinating debates on the future of wireless and mobile technology, as well as the music industry.

However, the contrast with our previous visit to the US, almost exactly a year earlier, was marked. Many of the companies that appeared then to be hogging every available piece of billboard space and TV slot no longer exist.

The US remains ahead of the UK in the commercial development of the internet in many respects. The fact that the US internet sector remains unhealthy suggests that the same sector here still has some way to go before turning the corner.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of rools.com, an online payments service for teenagers

webTitle: G2: Libby Brooks meets Mary Whitehouse

fields.headline: Quite contrary
fields.standfirst:
She is 90 and lives in an Essex nursing home, but Mary Whitehouse, the self-appointed scourge of TV's libertines, is still a force to be reckoned with

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: She is 90 and lives in an Essex nursing home, but Mary Whitehouse, the self-appointed scourge of TV's libertines, is still a force to be reckoned with.
fields.body:
On Wednesday mornings, the hairdresser visits. And at lunchtime, the dining room of the Essex nursing home is a sea of high set curls. Mary Whitehouse surveys the wispy throng with a gimlet eye, then leans across the table. Her huge bead necklace swings precariously close to the plate of brown stew and swedes boiled senseless. "Some of these dears don't have much hair to do," she whispers.

Now 90, the woman who has devoted her life to safeguarding the morals of the nation - whether the nation liked it or not - remains quite contrary. She insists that the television in the day room is switched off when she wants to read her newspaper.

Earlier, Whitehouse receives me in her room. She is lying on her bed with the Daily Telegraph over her knees, open at the letters page. She has written the word "cataracts" in the margin in capital letters. She is immaculately dressed, her high apple cheeks professionally powdered. She has to keep her legs up, she explains, as a result of a fall she had six years ago. She tugs down one of her pink crocheted socks to reveal the ruby welts across her shin. She is in a lot of pain. She cannot walk without her frame.

Though she clasps my hand hungrily, she is not a cuddly soul. Crusaders seldom are. Battling with the unholy trinity of foul language, sex and violence on television over four decades, she employed a suspicion of nuanced debate, which she successfully coupled with a fulsome talent for self-publicity. For Whitehouse, there was never any difference between pornography and Dennis Potter. Expletives were counted, not contextualised. Self-appointed, but remarkably effective, she has been called the original spin doctor.

There were times during the 80s when she appeared to terrify the BBC hierarchy. For all those who mocked, she had the ears of the influential. Since launching her Clean Up TV campaign in 1964, she has enjoyed audiences with prime ministers, the Pope and Cliff Richard. She was instrumental in Margaret Thatcher's decision to establish a taste and decency watchdog specifically for broadcasting.

Now president emeritus of the National Viewers and Listeners Association, which she founded in 1965, at the age of 55, she watches only the news. Whitehouse began her lobbying career while in the unlikely post of head of sex education at a secondary school in Telford. After bringing up her three sons she had returned to her teaching at the height of the Profumo scandal, and one day found three girls with two boys up to no good behind the bike sheds. "I said, 'What on earth do you think you're doing?' and they said, 'Well Miss, we seen how well them girls did, Mandy Rice Davis and Christine Keeler, so we thought we'd have a go.' 'Where did you see what they did?' 'On telly last night.'"

She slams her hands on to her thighs, freshly outraged. The influence of the box in the corner was direct and obvious, she says. So she and a friend started a petition. They organised a public meeting at Birmingham town hall. The Times wrote an article about it. And the country was first introduced to Mrs Whitehouse - a handbaggy, horn-rimmed icon of mumsy disgust, preaching her certainties from whatever platform was offered to her.

Certainties became her. Her force came from moral rather than intellectual argument; her objections were nebulous and kneejerk, steeped in a biblical terror of the corruption of innocents. Notable targets included Alf Garnett ("a gross insult to the Queen"), EastEnders ("this bi-weekly violation of the sensitivities of us all") and Jackanory ("completely irresponsible"). She was sustained, she says, by "a deep sense that what we were doing was right and important ... I love children and when I see them being exploited or put in danger I'm ready to fight for them."

As ever, attempting to engage her in reasoned debate is like trying to climb a glass wall. Did she genuinely believe that those programmes put children in danger? "Of course, not only on a sexual level, but also the violence. I am convinced that the violence in our society now has its roots in the violence we see on television. It was Sir Hugh Greene who said that television is the most powerful medium for teaching and I believe that to be true."

But surely some of that violence is a reflection of what's already happening in society? She disagrees, naturally. Nor does she accept, unsurprisingly, that the sensitive portrayal of sexuality can educate and inform. "I can't say, speaking personally, that I had to wait to see sex on television before I knew what it was," she adds, with a hint of a smirk.

Last week, the newly appointed chair of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, Lord Dubs, insisted that the watchdog would not be influenced by "mini-campaigns and petitions". "The National Viewers and Listeners Association can be as vocal as they want," he added. "But if one letter comes from their general secretary now, that's one letter. It's the same as if Joe Bloggs writes a letter." Whitehouse is unimpressed. "Well, he'd better find another job," she says tartly. "Nobody's going to take him seriously once they've seen that. I certainly wouldn't."

The NVLA - recently rebranded Mediawatch-UK - has been unusually meek since Whitehouse ceased daily involvement. Its membership remains mysterious, though it has reportedly slumped to 7,000. It was, according to Michael Grade, "an unaccountable and opaque organisation that had influence way beyond what it should have done". It was also, essentially, a one-woman show, though that one woman would always imply that she was speaking for a swathe of similarly outraged viewers. And perhaps that was her appeal - that she spoke with a single voice to a gentler, more uniform, time, when people like her knew best.

According to Whitehouse, the organisation is thriving, though she doesn't see the need to change its name. "It does represent a great number of people. I've spoken all over this country and the heart of my message has always been: whenever you see a programme, if it's a good one you like or a bad one you feel is irresponsible, then write, make your voice heard."

These days, she sits uncomfortably. Immobility frustrates her. As she takes me down to lunch, veering perilously along the corridor on her wheeled frame, she mutters a sporting litany: "First XI hockey team you know, tennis too, lovely red carpet."

Her mind is well preserved: the picture is distinct, though sometimes the contrast isn't so sharp, and there are occasional fade-outs. Her conversation is disjointed but direct. "[My husband] Ernest died on the 26th of August last year, when we'd been here just about a week."

What happened, I ask. "You mean why did he die?" she corrects. "He was 86, and he didn't have anything specific, he just really quietly ..." She drifts off. "He was in another bedroom, and at six o'clock one morning they came and woke me up and said, 'You ought to be with him'. So I went to his room, and I sat and held his hand. I held it for 12 hours, until six o'clock that evening. Then the nurse came in and put her arms round me, and she said, 'I think you must go, Mary.'" She tells it like a story she is used to.

They had been married for 60 years. "We never had a row, because we thought alike on so many things, and as far as the work was concerned he was 100% with me." Did it ever feel like he was in her shadow? She laughs delightedly. "That's where he wanted to be! He didn't come with me to Australia or the States [where she travelled on speaking tours]. He'd stay at home with the children."

Her room is dominated by a large framed photograph of the couple, set to the left of a dusty portable TV. The walls are covered with cards and snapshots. In one corner are the photographs she took of the plants in her garden before they sold the house. Her favourite was the peach tree. The pink blossoms grew straight out from the bark.

It is not for her to judge her public achievements, she tells me. "I was successful professionally, I was a wife, I was a mother and I found that I could get on my feet and say what I wanted to say. I just get on with whatever I think's got to be done."

The conversation is becoming rickety now. She tells me I'm wearing her out. Then suddenly she vaults across the bed and roots around in a cupboard. She volleys a brown box in my direction. It's her CBE. How did she feel when she got it? "Overcome really, with the Queen ..." She points to the place on the wall where the day is recorded - her with her granddaughter Cathy.

She doesn't think much of the current government's regulation policy, she blusters, although one senses that she hasn't been following the debate as forensically of late.

Does she have any regrets? She laughs. "I think I could have been a nicer person." Was she difficult to live with? "I'm tempted to say I wasn't there all that much to be lived with. But I had a lot of friends, and my family were very loving."

And does she have friends here in the nursing home? She looks incredulous. "It depends what you mean by friends," she qualifies. "They sleep most of the time. They're all old and many of them are handicapped. But they're all very friendly. It couldn't be nicer really."

For Whitehouse, there was never any difference between pornography and Dennis Potter. Expletives were counted, not contextualised. Self-appointed, but remarkably effective, she has been called the original spin doctor. There were times during the 80s when she appeared to terrify the BBC hierarchy. For all those who mocked, she had the ears of the influential. Since launching her Clean Up TV campaign in 1964, she has enjoyed audiences with prime ministers, the Pope and Cliff Richard. She was instrumental in Margaret Thatcher's decision to establish a taste and decency watchdog specifically for broadcasting. Now president emeritus of the National Viewers and Listeners Association, which she founded in 1965, at the age of 55, she watches only the news. Whitehouse began her lobbying career while in the unlikely post of head of sex education at a secondary school in Telford. After bringing up her three sons she had returned to her teaching at the height of the Profumo scandal, and one day found three girls with two boys up to no good behind the bike sheds. "I said, 'What on earth do you think you're doing?' and they said, 'Well Miss, we seen how well them girls did, Mandy Rice Davis and Christine Keeler, so we thought we'd have a go.' 'Where did you see what they did?' 'On telly last night.'" She slams her hands on to her thighs, freshly outraged. The influence of the box in the corner was direct and obvious, she says. So she and a friend started a petition. They organised a public meeting at Birmingham town hall. The Times wrote an article about it. And the country was first introduced to Mrs Whitehouse - a handbaggy, horn-rimmed icon of mumsy disgust, preaching her certainties from whatever platform was offered to her. Certainties became her. Her force came from moral rather than intellectual argument; her objections were nebulous and kneejerk, steeped in a biblical terror of the corruption of innocents. Notable targets included Alf Garnett ("a gross insult to the Queen"), EastEnders ("this bi-weekly violation of the sensitivities of us all") and Jackanory ("completely irresponsible"). She was sustained, she says, by "a deep sense that what we were doing was right and important ... I love children and when I see them being exploited or put in danger I'm ready to fight for them." As ever, attempting to engage her in reasoned debate is like trying to climb a glass wall. Did she genuinely believe that those programmes put children in danger? "Of course, not only on a sexual level, but also the violence. I am convinced that the violence in our society now has its roots in the violence we see on television. It was Sir Hugh Greene who said that television is the most powerful medium for teaching and I believe that to be true." But surely some of that violence is a reflection of what's already happening in society? She disagrees, naturally. Nor does she accept, unsurprisingly, that the sensitive portrayal of sexuality can educate and inform. "I can't say, speaking personally, that I had to wait to see sex on television before I knew what it was," she adds, with a hint of a smirk. Last week, the newly appointed chair of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, Lord Dubs, insisted that the watchdog would not be influenced by "mini-campaigns and petitions". "The National Viewers and Listeners Association can be as vocal as they want," he added. "But if one letter comes from their general secretary now, that's one letter. It's the same as if Joe Bloggs writes a letter." Whitehouse is unimpressed. "Well, he'd better find another job," she says tartly. "Nobody's going to take him seriously once they've seen that. I certainly wouldn't." The NVLA - recently rebranded Mediawatch-UK - has been unusually meek since Whitehouse ceased daily involvement. Its membership remains mysterious, though it has reportedly slumped to 7,000. It was, according to Michael Grade, "an unaccountable and opaque organisation that had influence way beyond what it should have done". It was also, essentially, a one-woman show, though that one woman would always imply that she was speaking for a swathe of similarly outraged viewers. And perhaps that was her appeal - that she spoke with a single voice to a gentler, more uniform, time, when people like her knew best. According to Whitehouse, the organisation is thriving, though she doesn't see the need to change its name. "It does represent a great number of people. I've spoken all over this country and the heart of my message has always been: whenever you see a programme, if it's a good one you like or a bad one you feel is irresponsible, then write, make your voice heard." These days, she sits uncomfortably. Immobility frustrates her. As she takes me down to lunch, veering perilously along the corridor on her wheeled frame, she mutters a sporting litany: "First XI hockey team you know, tennis too, lovely red carpet." Her mind is well preserved: the picture is distinct, though sometimes the contrast isn't so sharp, and there are occasional fade-outs. Her conversation is disjointed but direct. "[My husband] Ernest died on the 26th of August last year, when we'd been here just about a week." What happened, I ask. "You mean why did he die?" she corrects. "He was 86, and he didn't have anything specific, he just really quietly ..." She drifts off. "He was in another bedroom, and at six o'clock one morning they came and woke me up and said, 'You ought to be with him'. So I went to his room, and I sat and held his hand. I held it for 12 hours, until six o'clock that evening. Then the nurse came in and put her arms round me, and she said, 'I think you must go, Mary.'" She tells it like a story she is used to. They had been married for 60 years. "We never had a row, because we thought alike on so many things, and as far as the work was concerned he was 100% with me." Did it ever feel like he was in her shadow? She laughs delightedly. "That's where he wanted to be! He didn't come with me to Australia or the States [where she travelled on speaking tours]. He'd stay at home with the children." Her room is dominated by a large framed photograph of the couple, set to the left of a dusty portable TV. The walls are covered with cards and snapshots. In one corner are the photographs she took of the plants in her garden before they sold the house. Her favourite was the peach tree. The pink blossoms grew straight out from the bark. It is not for her to judge her public achievements, she tells me. "I was successful professionally, I was a wife, I was a mother and I found that I could get on my feet and say what I wanted to say. I just get on with whatever I think's got to be done." The conversation is becoming rickety now. She tells me I'm wearing her out. Then suddenly she vaults across the bed and roots around in a cupboard. She volleys a brown box in my direction. It's her CBE. How did she feel when she got it? "Overcome really, with the Queen ..." She points to the place on the wall where the day is recorded - her with her granddaughter Cathy. She doesn't think much of the current government's regulation policy, she blusters, although one senses that she hasn't been following the debate as forensically of late. Does she have any regrets? She laughs. "I think I could have been a nicer person." Was she difficult to live with? "I'm tempted to say I wasn't there all that much to be lived with. But I had a lot of friends, and my family were very loving." And does she have friends here in the nursing home? She looks incredulous. "It depends what you mean by friends," she qualifies. "They sleep most of the time. They're all old and many of them are handicapped. But they're all very friendly. It couldn't be nicer really."

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • And so it came to pass that the Yahoo gerbil, the little fella that adorns Channel 5's 9pm movie sponsorship slot, was christened Warren. In the spirit of web democracy, the cute rodent's name was decided by a user poll at Yahoo.co.uk/gerbil from a selection of chosen names. But wait, whatever happened to the name Richard - a clear leader before the URL was press released, but nowhere to be seen a few days into the stunt? Wonder why. Could it be that the name Richard was deemed slightly inappropriate given the urban legend of a gerbil and a certain hunky Hollywood movie star? Surely it's not that obvious.
fields.body:
 And so it came to pass that the Yahoo gerbil, the little fella that adorns Channel 5's 9pm movie sponsorship slot, was christened Warren. In the spirit of web democracy, the cute rodent's name was decided by a user poll at Yahoo.co.uk/gerbil from a selection of chosen names. But wait, whatever happened to the name Richard - a clear leader before the URL was press released, but nowhere to be seen a few days into the stunt? Wonder why. Could it be that the name Richard was deemed slightly inappropriate given the urban legend of a gerbil and a certain hunky Hollywood movie star? Surely it's not that obvious.

 The lengths that folk will go to in order to get the perfect shirt. Andy Broughton-Braithwaite, managing editor of BT Openworld, has taken to shopping in pubs and thinks nothing of going up to strangers and literally buying shirts off their backs. Last week's item was a mod shirt (yes, ABB is still living in the 60s, unable to escape a charming mod obsession) that the student in question bought for a fiver from a charity shop (where else). Flash Andy paid a king's ransom of £80 - quite a mark-up I think you'll agree, but peanuts for a high-flying Openworld exec. "I just had to have it," raves ABB, "Paul Weller had one." So that's alright then, but pity the poor and, by this point, half-naked student who chose hard currency over warmth on a freezing cold night.

 Never one not to applaud dexterity, diary would like to congratulate Neil Crofts, the erstwhile strategic management guru at Razorfish, on a splendidly creative email signature. The confident "change agent" (the new word for a dot.commer in-between jobs) describes himself in electronic missives as a "futurist visionary; public speaker and writer". But that's not all, Crofts feels the urge to list his attributes, which are: "Leadership; inspiration; passion; energy; authenticity." Who needs to pay for PR when us sucker diarists are amused enough to take the piss, even if it inadvertently borders on a free advertisement? I'll waive the fee this time.

 A case of missing persons has been reported over at showbiz gossip site Peoplenews.com. Word reaches diary of the disappearance of Olly Figg and Olivia Stewart-Liberty (parties editor and features editor) who seem to have been abducted and replaced by aliens posing as work experience people. At least they've disappeared from the increasingly scantily-clad "about us" page. Cynics expect it's not long now before the receptionist is running the show - or maybe Peoplenews.com boss Jane Procter's infamous dog which may or may not be called Kenzo.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Media Monkey's diary
fields.trailText: • The effects of the foot and mouth crisis spread yet further. Monkey's deep throats in the corridors of power say that uncertainty over the timing of the election is preventing the government from making a decision on the BBC's planned new services. This is bad news for Greg Dyke and his merry band of channel controllers, who are pressing ahead as if permission had been granted, and preparing for the launches of BBC3 and 4 this autumn. Our man in the broadcast politics know says the government will not give the thumbs up to the fancy plans until after the election, preferring to have something "hanging over the BBC to ensure good behaviour". How very cynical.
fields.body:
 The effects of the foot and mouth crisis spread yet further. Monkey's deep throats in the corridors of power say that uncertainty over the timing of the election is preventing the government from making a decision on the BBC's planned new services. This is bad news for Greg Dyke and his merry band of channel controllers, who are pressing ahead as if permission had been granted, and preparing for the launches of BBC3 and 4 this autumn. Our man in the broadcast politics know says the government will not give the thumbs up to the fancy plans until after the election, preferring to have something "hanging over the BBC to ensure good behaviour". How very cynical.

 The Royle Family won another well-deserved Royal Television Society award on Tuesday night, picked up at the Grosvenor House bash by star and co-writer Craig Cash. But Monkey suspects that Cash has been playing the hapless Mancunian mobile DJ, Dave Best, for too long, for in a display of extreme doziness, Cash had lost the award by Wednesday. It could be anywhere between Park Lane and Soho House. Thieves can claim amnesty by posting it to Monkey's awards lost property service, c/o the Guardian.

 Elsewhere on the awards circuit, Monkey could swear that at the British Press Awards he heard the dulcet tones of Sindy editor Janet Street-Porter loudly claiming full responsibility for the Independent's sponsorship of innocent family portraits (or vile kiddy porn, © the News of the World). Does Janet feel that editor-in-chief Simon Kelner has overlooked her key role? Could her, frankly rather wilful, display of flesh be related to this lack of appreciation? Is all well in paradise?

 From BBC Online's forum - the place where you the user can chat to the powerful - comes a once-in-a-lifetime chance to quiz Hello! editor Phil Hall on "the power of celebrity". On reading through the blurb, Monkey became very excited about the seductive and yet tragically fickle nature of fame, and anxious to ask Phil's views on paying C-list celebs vast amounts of cash to photograph them in a hotel room. Shame then, that under a smiling pic of the man himself, come the lines: "Due to unforeseen circumstances this Forum has been cancelled. Please accept our apologies". Celebrities are fickle indeed.

 Staying with the BBC's web offerings, after members of S Club 7's recent brush with the law over possession of cannabis, the BBC's online team chose its words carefully when reporting the update. The news item reads: "The trio released a joint statement." Could someone be having a laugh?

 Bad news for anyone with a thing about local radio DJs in golfing jumpers: Alan Partridge will have a Canadian wife, Armando Iannucci revealed last week, in the next series. And for The Day Today fans: prospects of a much-talked-of return now look close to zero ("We talk about it every six months, but you feel 'what if it's crap?'").

fields.headline: Serbs re-enter buffer zone
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Exactly two years after Nato launched its 78-day bombing campaign against the Serbs, Belgrade's army and police units yesterday moved to take control of the Nato-imposed buffer zone separating Kosovo from Serbia proper.
fields.body:
Exactly two years after Nato launched its 78-day bombing campaign against the Serbs, Belgrade's army and police units yesterday moved to take control of the Nato-imposed buffer zone separating Kosovo from Serbia proper.

The deployments, made with Nato's blessing and aimed at suppressing a local Albanian guerrilla insurgency while insulating the region from the Albanian-Macedonian conflict across the border put Serb forces in control of most of the three-mile wide buffer zone from where they were expelled by Nato as part of the Kosovo war peace terms in 1999.

The Yugoslav army chief of staff, General Nebojsa Pavkovic, who was promoted to his post by the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, after commanding the 1998-99 campaign against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians, shook hands with Nato officers as he inspected the deployment of his troops.

Yugoslav troops first moved into the buffer zone 10 days ago in the south as part of a Nato-agreed deal aimed at sealing the border with Macedonia and preventing Albanian guerrillas there being supplied from Kosovo.

Yesterday Albanian gunmen injured a Serb police officer in an incident near the town of Presevo, and two Serb soldiers died and eight were injured in a tent fire in the same area.

The Yugoslav deployment of more than 2,000 police and army troops are proceeding carefully under Nato eyes. But no Serb troops have yet moved to towns controlled by the guerrillas, who have exploited the local vacuum of the past 20 months to make areas inside Serbia no-go zones for Serbs.

The Serb forces are moving in while negotiations continue with local Albanian leaders, including representatives of the guerrillas.

fields.headline: Inexperienced force limits Skopje's options
fields.standfirst: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Eighteen Macedonian soldiers cowered behind a wall. Their captain could be heard shouting into a mobile phone: "Gentlemen, we're under fire and surrounded on all sides. Can you send an armoured personnel carrier? Can you get us back to barracks?"
fields.body:
Eighteen Macedonian soldiers cowered behind a wall. Their captain could be heard shouting into a mobile phone: "Gentlemen, we're under fire and surrounded on all sides. Can you send an armoured personnel carrier? Can you get us back to barracks?"

Four hours into the Macedonian offensive to capture guerrilla-held positions on wooded hillsides above Tetovo, the incident was sad evidence of the army's overall weakness as it attempted the biggest operation in its 10-year history.

Most men in the desperate platoon were reservists pressed into service over the last few days. "I'm scared. I just want this to be over so I can go home," Rade, 25, said shortly before the volley of rapid rifle fire sent us running for cover. "We don't know if there are snipers with guns in the houses round here. We were supposed to go up the hill."

For several days the army has been using houses owned by Macedonian civilians to hide its own snipers on upstairs floors facing the hillside. In their panic the soldiers thought an Albanian sniper may have opened up on them from a nearby house, although it seemed more likely the shooting had come from the hills.

Officially the army has around 15,000 men - including some 1,400 reservists called up last week. Western diplomats put the number of "combat-capable" soldiers at no more than 1,200. They include 350 special forces known as the Wolves.

"The conscripts come in for nine months' service and you can't train a man to be a proper soldier in so short a time," a western analyst said.

Around 30% of the conscripts are Albanian and about 10% are Roma, Turks and other minorities.

Some officers have genuine experience. The captain of the cowering platoon had served for 20 years, including two in action with the Yugoslav army against Croatia in the early 1990s. The government can also call on 350 special police and 450 gendarmes trained in riot control and paramilitary operations.

Two Ukrainian-supplied helicopter gunships arrived in Macedonia on Friday and were promptly pressed into action at the weekend, firing rockets at guerrilla targets in the hills. Two transport helicopters from Ukraine also flew in and two more are on their way.

Before their arrival, the Macedonian air force had one helicopter left in service. Its stable-mate flew into power lines and was destroyed 10 days ago.

The guerrillas are thought to have around 800 men, who are operating in sympathetic Albanian villages in well placed high ground. Many have combat experience from Kosovo. They are equipped with Kalashnikov semi-automatic rifles, mortars, Chinese-made machine guns, anti-tank launchers and sniper rifles.

Britain sent 13 officers, mainly from the Royal Marines, last week to discuss with the Macedonian defence ministry what help could be given.

Even the Macedonian opposition has warned the government not to go for a military solution. It criticised President Boris Trajkovski's decision to issue a 24-hour ultimatum to the gunmen to withdraw or face an all-out assault.

"Now we think the government is in a worse position, Radmila Sekarinska, vice president of the Social Democratic Union, said.

"If they mount a big offensive up the hill one can debate whether it will work since the army cannot hold any positions they occupy for very long or even overnight.

"If they do nothing they erode what people believe and expect from state institutions," she said.

The army is also in a weak position because one of Tetovo's main ethnic Macedonian districts lies just below guerrilla-held positions.

Remarkably many people from Tetovo were still in the city until yesterday's offensive although they were staying indoors.

"We can't leave because my mother is too ill to move," said a retired Macedonian carpenter whose house stands at the foot of the hill. He and his wife have barricaded the front windows and sleep in the kitchen..

"The extremists are using our weekend cottage in the vineyard just 200 yards away up there," he said, gesturing over to the house.

"We have two fears," he added. "One is that the extremists come down from the hills and slit our throats and the other is for our two sons who are in their twenties. The army may call them up."

Its stable-mate flew into power lines and was destroyed 10 days ago. The guerrillas are thought to have around 800 men, who are operating in sympathetic Albanian villages in well placed high ground. Many have combat experience from Kosovo. They are equipped with Kalashnikov semi-automatic rifles, mortars, Chinese-made machine guns, anti-tank launchers and sniper rifles. Britain sent 13 officers, mainly from the Royal Marines, last week to discuss with the Macedonian defence ministry what help could be given. Even the Macedonian opposition has warned the government not to go for a military solution. It criticised President Boris Trajkovski's decision to issue a 24-hour ultimatum to the gunmen to withdraw or face an all-out assault. "Now we think the government is in a worse position, Radmila Sekarinska, vice president of the Social Democratic Union, said. "If they mount a big offensive up the hill one can debate whether it will work since the army cannot hold any positions they occupy for very long or even overnight. "If they do nothing they erode what people believe and expect from state institutions," she said. The army is also in a weak position because one of Tetovo's main ethnic Macedonian districts lies just below guerrilla-held positions. Remarkably many people from Tetovo were still in the city until yesterday's offensive although they were staying indoors. "We can't leave because my mother is too ill to move," said a retired Macedonian carpenter whose house stands at the foot of the hill. He and his wife have barricaded the front windows and sleep in the kitchen.. "The extremists are using our weekend cottage in the vineyard just 200 yards away up there," he said, gesturing over to the house. "We have two fears," he added. "One is that the extremists come down from the hills and slit our throats and the other is for our two sons who are in their twenties. The army may call them up." What's going on? fields.headline: Tanks force Albanian retreat
fields.standfirst:
Tanks force Albanian retreat

Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian tanks and infantry seized a key ridge above the city of Tetovo yesterday after artillery and helicopter gunships bombarded ethnic Albanian rebel positions and nearby villages in their biggest offensive since Albanian gunmen launched their revolt 12 days ago.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele in Tetovo, Peter Beaumont in Sipkovica, and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Macedonian tanks and infantry seized a key ridge above the city of Tetovo yesterday after artillery and helicopter gunships bombarded ethnic Albanian rebel positions and nearby villages in their biggest offensive since Albanian gunmen launched their revolt 12 days ago.

Plumes of flames and smoke from burning houses rose into the sky when the attacks started shortly after dawn, and troops fanned out through the northern districts of Tetovo.

At the height of the artillery barrage, dozens of explosions echoed around the mountains and the city every minute, with smoke rising from nearby Albanian positions.

Reporters saw six armoured personal carriers (APCs) followed by groups of 15 soldiers behind each vehicle climbing the road which rose from the north-west of the city.

Three hours later two tanks advanced up the same slope.

By nightfall the army had driven through the village of Gajre and was holding ground beyond it. Across the small river, which bisected the wooded hillsides, three more tanks were seen inching forward with their cannons firing towards Lavce, once a main guerrilla stronghold.

The guerrillas poured machine-gun and sniper fire on the ascending troops, and the army reported that one member of the special police was wounded, as well as four ethnic Albanian civilians.

Insisting this was not the long-promised, all-out offensive, Georgi Tiandafilov, a spokesman for Macedonia's defence ministry, said: "This is one of the last phases of the operation that we have taken for the complete expulsion of the terrorists from Macedonian territory."

The Macedonian government claims the gunmen are from Kosovo and that their emergence amounts to foreign aggression.

But Ali Ahmeti, the political leader of the gunmen who have formed a self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA), was born in Macedonia, as were many of the guerrillas interviewed by reporters in recent days.

Macedonia has been under strong pressure from the west not to risk civilian casualties, but the government insists it must liberate its territory.

"To have the country's second city under siege for 12 days does great damage to inter-ethnic relations," Antonio Milososki, a government spokesman, said. "We have to restore a sense of order before we can have political dialogue."

In Gajre, six houses were in flames and people hid in basements for most of the day as the army pushed aside makeshift barricades and took up positions beyond the village.

Reporters saw three gunmen with rifles still in the village after the army's APCs drove through. The village of Selce, where the guerrillas had their local headquarters, suffered massive damage from shell and rocket fire, according to a local school teacher reached by mobile phone.

No army troops had entered the village, he said, and people were determined to stay in their homes.

"I've been inside all day but I know the house next door was destroyed," he said.

Between 10 and 20 civilians were lightly injured. The village's two Albanian doctors were tending to them.

"We have food for now, but after seven days I don't know," the schoolteacher said.

In London, defence sources said priority, as far at Nato troops was concerned, should be given to reinforcing the Kosovo side of the Macedonian border. Britain has sent a 10-man team of military advisers to Macedonia to help provide intelligence on the movement of Albanian guerrillas, and tactical advice about how to deal with them.

While applauding action taken by Macedonian forces against the rebels, Nato and the EU are deeply concerned about the danger of triggering a backlash among Macedonia's ethnic Albanians, who make up about 30% of the country's population.

Britain, which has about 3,300 troops in Kosovo, is prepared to bolster patrols on the Kosovo side of the border with Macedonia.

Germany, which has about 5,000 soldiers in Kosovo, has agreed to send an extra 130 soldiers, who will be based in Prizren, in southern Kosovo. There are now more than 40,000 troops in the Nato-led international peacekeeping force in Kosovo.

Publicly, both of the main Albanian parties in Macedonia have called on the gunmen to lay down their arms and go home.

The same demand was made by Kosovo's Albanian leaders after heavy pressure from European Union officials.

Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, is due in Skopje today.

His presence is designed to reinforce the message to the government to show restraint because it is winning the diplomatic battle.

"Our concern is that innocent civilians may suffer," a western diplomat said.

webTitle: Elements add cruel twist to livestock dilemma

fields.headline: Elements add cruel twist to livestock dilemma
fields.standfirst:
New born animals cannot be moved indoors

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: New born animals cannot be moved indoors
fields.body:
The bodies are laid out in the mud, a pathetic miniature version of the mounds of carcasses piling up on farms across Devon. Like the thousands of other sheep that have died since foot and mouth arrived in the county four weeks ago, Hazel and Graeme Butt's lambs did not stand a chance.

But it was not foot and mouth or the slaughtermen who killed them; it was the movement restrictions imposed across the country by Maff in a vain attempt to contain the infection. Dropping from their mothers in the biting cold of night on to a field turned into an shin-deep bog by constant rain, they were claimed by hypothermia within minutes.

These were not unhealthy lambs, just unlucky. The Butts had done everything right. They had separated out the 20 breeding ewes who would require most care - the ones expecting triplets or lambing for the first time - and put them into the best field, rich with grass.

By the time they were due to lamb, they should have been back in sheds at the Butts' farmyard seven miles away at Highhampton - sheds with straw, running water, medicine and where the couple could be on hand 24 hours a day to tend them properly. Then foot and mouth hit, the restrictions were imposed and the sheep were trapped.

"They are wet when they come out," said Mr Butt, who celebrated his 33rd birthday fighting to save his stock on Saturday. "They fall on to this mud and then they are getting blasted by that cold wind, and they are not going to last 10 minutes. If we could have had them in the barn up to their knees in straw, they definitely would have lived."

Across the country, hundreds of thousands of animals untouched by foot and mouth directly are facing the same fate. It is a cruel twist to an already horrific chain of events that the infection hit at this time of year, when farms are teeming with new life.

Add to that the rain, sleet and freezing winds of the past two weeks and the result is suffering on a scale overlooked by the official foot and mouth slaughter statistics. Already 18 lambs have been born on the Butts's small field; seven have survived. "With the weather this bad it's getting to be like the trenches of the first world war out there," said Ian Johnston, of the local farmers' union. "If farmers were keeping their animals in this state under normal circumstances, they would be prosecuted in a minute."

The government has now announced a slaughter scheme on welfare grounds for animals trapped in horrendous conditions by the movement restrictions. Compensation will be available to farmers forced to slaughter their breeding sheep and cows.

For Mrs Butt's father, Eddie Williamson, that is cold comfort. He has 199 breeding ewes trapped in a bare, sodden field near Halwill Junction, almost 10 miles from his farm. In two weeks they are due to start lambing, but Mr Williamson doubts they will last that long.

"The vets have been out looking at them every couple of days, and the wool is already starting to come out. That is a sign that they're not getting enough food. Breeding ewes need a lot of food in the last month, and we can't get enough food to them."

Across the road Dennis Jones is suffering the opposite problem. His breeding animals were already indoors when the movement restrictions were imposed. They are still there, 500 sheep, 200 cattle and still only halfway through lambing and calving. The death toll has been high here, too: in these cramped conditions it is infections such as E coli that are the killers.

"Normally they would have a day or so indoors after giving birth, then we would move them into the field across the road, but Maff have said no way," said Mr Jones.

Back at the Butts' field, the couple have enjoyed a stroke of luck. They happened by just as a first-time mother was about to lamb. The lamb was delivered on to the mud and immediately moved to a makeshift pen with warm straw. But that is as much as the couple can do for them.

"It goes against all your natural instincts to walk away and leave them, because we know that another could lamb any time," said Mrs Butt. "But we know that there is always something going on with the other animals as well, and we can't be everywhere."

webTitle: US moots lifting of air ban

fields.headline: US moots lifting of air ban
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US is considering lifting the 10-year ban on commercial flights to Iraq, state department sources say. The idea is being discussed as part of a new sanctions package which would "make it possible for almost everything to go into Iraq", apart from military equipment and "dangerous dual use" items.
fields.body:
The US is considering lifting the 10-year ban on commercial flights to Iraq, state department sources say. The idea is being discussed as part of a new sanctions package which would "make it possible for almost everything to go into Iraq", apart from military equipment and "dangerous dual use" items.

US officials recognise that the air embargo has allowed campaigners to discredit sanctions by sending high-profile humanitarian flights to Baghdad. In the last few months the humanitarian content of many flights has been little more than tokenistic.

Officials had been hoping to announce a revised sanctions package before the Arab summit but say various countries, including Britain, are still writing position papers.

Despite the planned relaxation on imports, Washington is determined to retain UN controls on all Iraq's revenues. US officials also say there will be "no significant modifications" to the military no-fly zones over northern and southern Iraq, which they call fully justified.

Although Mr Powell and the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, are said to "see eye to eye" on sanctions, US talk of allowing commercial flights has surprised British officials, who have been working on an alternative plan which would merely establish internationally agreed rules for humanitarian flights to Iraq.

webTitle: Analysis: The battle over the US judiciary

fields.headline: Judgment daze
fields.standfirst:
The battle for control of the American judiciary is being waged by Federalists in the White House who represent a radical rightwing agenda

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The battle for control of the American judiciary is being waged by Federalists in the White House who represent a radical rightwing agenda.
fields.body:
It does indeed sound like the "vast rightwing conspiracy" Hillary Clinton complained about at the height of the Monica Lewinsky affair, except that the Federalists are not a secret society. They meet openly and even have a website.*

But members played a leading role both in President Clinton's impeachment and in the Florida legal offensive which brought George Bush to power. A leading light is the supreme court judge who did most to steer the decision in Bush's favour. As a group they are poised to transform the American legal system.

The Federalist Society for Law and Public Policy plans to unleash a legal counter-revolution which will turn back the clock on affirmative action, environmental standards and other forms of government regulation. Founded in 1982, the group set as its goals the ideological conquest of the nation's law schools. Two decades on, it has achieved an extraordinary degree of success. The Federalists' law school chapters now offer graduates a faster route to the top, through clerkships in high-profile chambers and a powerful career network, than the mainstream professional body, the American Bar Association (ABA).

They scored their greatest triumph last week when President Bush stripped the ABA of its role as a vetting agency in the appointment of federal judges. The ABA had first been assigned the task by President Eisenhower as a means of setting minimum professional standards for the judiciary around the country. But in the eyes of the Federalists the ABA has merely been enforcing a status quo built around the New Deal and civil rights legislation introduced by Democrat administrations.

The Federalists have now taken the ABA's place in all but name. In President Bush's first week, a task force was set up in the White House to rush through nominations for the 100 (out of a total of 862) federal judgeships in appeals and circuit courts. The courts settle great debates (Roe v Wade over abortion, Brown v the Board of Education over desegregation, not to mention Bush v Gore over the presidential election). So it is hard to exaggerate the importance of these judicial appointments. Almost every member of the White House vetting panel is a Federalist.

Many are veterans of earlier campaigns, such as Brett Kavanaugh, the young lawyer who served as chief investigator for Kenneth Starr, President Clinton's inquisitor and nemesis and another key member of the Federalist Society. Mr Starr in turn got the job of independent counsel from David Sentelle, a conservative circuit judge and early Federalist member. The lawyers acting for Paula Jones in her sexual harassment suit against the president and for Linda Tripp, who handed over secret tapes of Monica Lewinsky, were both Federalists.

Other members of the White House legal team played prominent roles in the battle of Florida last autumn, when Bush lawyers succeeded in halting a manual recount of the vote and drove the dispute to the supreme court, which famously handed victory to George Bush.

The Bush cause was argued by Ted Olson, the head of the Washington chapter of the Federalist Society, who is now solicitor general. It was supported most fiercely on the supreme court by Antonin Scalia, one of the moving spirits behind the formation of the Federalists and a regular attraction at the society's seminars and retreats for ambitious lawyers.

The Federalists represent one of two radical rightwing agendas (the other is Christian ultra-conservatism) which hitchhiked on the Bush campaign, and now influence policy out of all proportion to their support among the public at large.

The society draws inspiration from a libertarian interpretation of the writings of James Madison, the founding father, who occasionally ful minated against the power of central government. The Federalists today see the evil hand of centralism in any form of federal regulation, whether it be affirmative action for minorities, rules against sexual harassment, or environmental emissions standards. They believe the legal profession is dominated by a form of "orthodox liberal ideology which advocates a centralised and uniform society".

During the first 100 days of the Bush administration, the influence of Federalist ideology has been apparent in the rapid dismantling of workplace safety standards, the decision not to impose carbon dioxide emission standards and the plans to open up the Alaskan National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. The fact that the energy and interior secretaries, Spencer Abraham and Gale Norton, are both senior Federalists no doubt played a role. James Bopp, another Florida veteran, is leading the legal fight against campaign finance reform.

The battle for control of the judiciary is not over entirely. The Federalists in the White House have been working through the night for the past few weeks in a frantic effort to find 100 ideologically acceptable judges before a senator (probably the 98-year-old Strom Thurmond) dies and robs the Republicans of their one-seat majority.

Even before that, congressional approval of Federalist nominations are not a foregone conclusion. Moderate Republicans shrink from the society's ideological purity. But to the extent that the Federalists succeed, the US will become a very different country.

 Julian Borger is the Guardian's correspondent in Washington DC.

julian.borger@theguardian.com

* The Federalist Society website
