But in the eyes of the Federalists the ABA has merely been enforcing a status quo built around the New Deal and civil rights legislation introduced by Democrat administrations. The Federalists have now taken the ABA's place in all but name. In President Bush's first week, a task force was set up in the White House to rush through nominations for the 100 (out of a total of 862) federal judgeships in appeals and circuit courts. The courts settle great debates (Roe v Wade over abortion, Brown v the Board of Education over desegregation, not to mention Bush v Gore over the presidential election). So it is hard to exaggerate the importance of these judicial appointments. Almost every member of the White House vetting panel is a Federalist. Many are veterans of earlier campaigns, such as Brett Kavanaugh, the young lawyer who served as chief investigator for Kenneth Starr, President Clinton's inquisitor and nemesis and another key member of the Federalist Society. Mr Starr in turn got the job of independent counsel from David Sentelle, a conservative circuit judge and early Federalist member. The lawyers acting for Paula Jones in her sexual harassment suit against the president and for Linda Tripp, who handed over secret tapes of Monica Lewinsky, were both Federalists. Other members of the White House legal team played prominent roles in the battle of Florida last autumn, when Bush lawyers succeeded in halting a manual recount of the vote and drove the dispute to the supreme court, which famously handed victory to George Bush. The Bush cause was argued by Ted Olson, the head of the Washington chapter of the Federalist Society, who is now solicitor general. It was supported most fiercely on the supreme court by Antonin Scalia, one of the moving spirits behind the formation of the Federalists and a regular attraction at the society's seminars and retreats for ambitious lawyers. The Federalists represent one of two radical rightwing agendas (the other is Christian ultra-conservatism) which hitchhiked on the Bush campaign, and now influence policy out of all proportion to their support among the public at large. The society draws inspiration from a libertarian interpretation of the writings of James Madison, the founding father, who occasionally ful minated against the power of central government. The Federalists today see the evil hand of centralism in any form of federal regulation, whether it be affirmative action for minorities, rules against sexual harassment, or environmental emissions standards. They believe the legal profession is dominated by a form of "orthodox liberal ideology which advocates a centralised and uniform society". During the first 100 days of the Bush administration, the influence of Federalist ideology has been apparent in the rapid dismantling of workplace safety standards, the decision not to impose carbon dioxide emission standards and the plans to open up the Alaskan National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. The fact that the energy and interior secretaries, Spencer Abraham and Gale Norton, are both senior Federalists no doubt played a role. James Bopp, another Florida veteran, is leading the legal fight against campaign finance reform. The battle for control of the judiciary is not over entirely. The Federalists in the White House have been working through the night for the past few weeks in a frantic effort to find 100 ideologically acceptable judges before a senator (probably the 98-year-old Strom Thurmond) dies and robs the Republicans of their one-seat majority. Even before that, congressional approval of Federalist nominations are not a foregone conclusion. Moderate Republicans shrink from the society's ideological purity. But to the extent that the Federalists succeed, the US will become a very different country.  Julian Borger is the Guardian's correspondent in Washington DC. julian.borger@theguardian.com * The Federalist Society website

webTitle: Escape route from the mean streets

fields.headline: Escape route from the mean streets
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Waseem Hussain says he has been bad since he was about eight years old. He was always messing about, fighting and swearing. After exclusion from a number of schools, Waseem took his trouble out on to the streets of Rotherham.
fields.body:
Waseem Hussain says he has been bad since he was about eight years old. He was always messing about, fighting and swearing. After exclusion from a number of schools, Waseem took his trouble out on to the streets of Rotherham.

Hanging around in gangs, Waseem, 16, started looking for fights every day. But he never seemed to get caught. One day, though, the scale and violence of Waseem's offences escalated.

"I was in the bus station and I followed this lad in the toilets and I punched him twice. After that it started getting more serious. I thought I liked it then, getting into trouble. Put it this way, I enjoyed it, it felt powerful," he says, admitting that the severity of the offences increased. "I put the boot in as well."

Waseem says he has been caught for between 10 and 12 offences and admits to "at least another seven or eight on top of that".

He goes on: "I was in Worcestershire one day and this lad, I saw him, he were running and I asked him what has he done and he said "I nicked something off a bus". The police came and he told the police that I did it. The next day I saw him and I told him "let's go for a joint". I took him into the subways and said to him "this is for grassing me up". I was stamping him, I kicked his face and when they found him he was unconscious. I got arrested and they found forensic evidence, they found his blood on my trainers."

Waseem was given a detention training order of eight months, four months of which he spent inside Wetherby young offenders' institution. He says: "I was still having fights in there. I did one month in segregation. My problem magnified then because I was meeting the same crew. When I came out of prison, my offences started to change and I was messing about with cars and knives. Being in prison made me more interested in cars. Then I started carrying a lock knife."

Waseem is the perfect example of what the government classes as a hardcore persistent young offender, one of the 3% of young offenders reckoned to be responsible for up to 25% of crimes. He is also a boy whose crimes escalated to a terrifying degree after his time in prison. He says he could have easily used that lock knife.

Waseem is sitting in an office in the Rotherham intensive support supervision advocacy programme, a place he hopes will make him think twice about ever picking the lock knife up again. He is one of 22 young offenders who have had to come to this project since it started last August. The project's aim is to prevent reoffending by young offenders who have broken the law on more than three occasions by offering support and help with their difficulties. The Rotherham project also has a dedicated police officer known as a "tracking officer" who keeps a very close eye on all the offenders.

The Rotherham project is a blueprint for the government's intensive surveillance and supervision programme to be launched on Wednesday. While the Rotherham pilot has not used electronic surveillance, its tracking officer checks up on the young offenders all the time. PC Bill Thomas is with the Rotherham project. He says it works: "It's fair to say that Waseem's offending has not been on the same level of escalation. Waseem has had problems with his anger and we have been working on his self-esteem. But since he has been on the programme, he has become a little bit more mature and is making more informed choices.

"So far, we have not completely excluded offending from Waseem's life but we have reduced the seriousness and the impact of it. Waseem was very much a lad who was destined to do a lot of time because he was so chaotic. Within the project, he has got a little bit more structure and he is calmer and perhaps his future has changed."

As a tracking officer, Mr Thomas uses his intelligence-collating skills garnered from his police work to make sure that his offenders feel them breathing down their collar. If they don't turn up at the programme when required, he goes out and finds them and hauls them back in - if they persist with this behaviour they find themselves back in the criminal justice system without the project's support.

"In real terms my role is about getting to know people like Waseem, about his family, about his habits, his environment, what his expectations are. I will then devise a plan on how we can incorporate all of those and at the same time work within the confinements of the law. If it does go wrong, I pull him up and maybe have to deal with his family and the situation in the neighbourhood if that becomes a problem," explains Mr Thomas. "It should make a marked impact on some people's lives. We have had youngsters who have been on the project who have not been back inside. One young man has never reoffended and has got a steady job."

Simon Perry, manager of Rotherham youth offending services, says the Rotherham project (based on a successful American one) is a sort of blueprint but adds that it is not required that the new programmes across the country replicate it.

"What we know is that there's a very small group of very hard to reach, socially excluded children who don't go to school, don't work, are very often homeless, very often victims of abuse and often involved in drug taking. A significant number are involved in persistent offending and because of that the more socially ostracised they become. And young people commit a disproportionate amount of crime. It is incredibly difficult to engage these chil dren," he explains. "There is a greater chance that they will become potentially violent, criminally offending adults. Because they are difficult to engage, we have to take longer over doing it and that's where the word intensive is appropriate."

The Rotherham project has a social worker, police officer, probation service officer, a volunteer coordinator and three development workers who work with housing, drugs and alcohol, and employment issues. It also uses volunteer mentors from within the community to work with offenders. Jackie Key, the project manager, says she has dealt with 22 offenders involved mostly in assaults, burglary and car crime. "The majority are white and male, a proportion are mixed race or Asian children and we have had two females. A lot of them want to stop reoffending but their life circumstances have stopped them from doing that."

Even in the short term, she says, the Rotherham project seems to be working. Prior to the young people coming on the programme, the number of offences they committed was 156. While on the programme the number of offences they committed was 28. The average number of weeks of the programme is 14.3; the average number of offences committed by young people prior to the programme is 7.09, while on the programme it is 1.36.

Waseem thinks the project works. He is less violent but he hasn't stopped offending completely yet. He says it is difficult. "I think I want to stop but sometimes it's a thrill, a buzz. But I am trying."

webTitle: EU eyes key role in Korean peace

fields.headline: EU eyes key role in Korean peace
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: Seeking to extend its global reach, the European Union is to mediate in the slow-moving peace process between North and South Korea and attempt to fill the gap created by US disarray over policy towards the divided peninsula.
fields.body:
Seeking to extend its global reach, the European Union is to mediate in the slow-moving peace process between North and South Korea and attempt to fill the gap created by US disarray over policy towards the divided peninsula.

Sweden's prime minister, Goran Persson, the current holder of the EU presidency, plans to travel to Pyongyang and Seoul to advance reconciliation and defuse the nuclear threat posed by Kim Jong-il's hermit kingdom.

The ambitious move breaks a long tradition of European deference to US policy in Asia and is part of a wider pattern of EU assertion on the global scene. "The aim is to express support for the process started by the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, at ending one of the last conflicts with origins in the second world war," Mr Persson said at the end of the Stockholm summit.

Diplomats made clear that the union wanted to take advantage of negative signals from Washington since the Bush administration took power in January. Neutral, non-Nato Sweden is well-placed to orchestrate this move.

"It's becoming clear that the new US administration wants to take a more hardline approach toward North Korea," said Sweden's foreign minister, Anna Lindh. "That means that Europe must step in to help reduce tension between the two Koreas, not least because the outside world is so worried about North Korean missiles."

Before President Bill Clinton left office, the US seemed close to an agreement that would have curbed North Korea's long range missile programme and strengthened safeguards to thwart the production of plutonium for nuclear weapons.

But George Bush's new administration has demanded a reassessment of the proposed deal, calling the North Koreans "untrustworthy".

South Korea is worried that backtracking by the US would undermine its "sunshine" policy of peaceful reconciliation with the North, which began with a dramatic summit meeting last summer. Worryingly, North Korea has hinted it might abandon its moratorium on missile testing and resume plutonium production.

Mr Persson said he planned to travel to both Korean capitals before the end of May. He will be accompanied by the EU's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, and by Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner. Their mandate is to achieve "early results" that could lead to a new summit between the two Korean leaders and lay down a timetable for reunification.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Nottingham city council says it was entirely wrong to state, as we did in an article headed Speed traps and goldmines, page 19, G2, March 19, that "speeding cameras" in the city were being removed because they were no longer bringing in enough money in fines. The council insists that no cameras are being removed and that it is the intention to introduce more. The city's road safety service manager pointed out that between them the city council and the Highways Agency had invested £300,000 in the scheme with no intention of recovering the money. The purpose of the scheme was to reduce the number of accidents and this it had done very successfully. Serious and fatal accidents over the first nine months had fallen by 52%. Sorry for getting that wrong.
fields.body:
Nottingham city council says it was entirely wrong to state, as we did in an article headed Speed traps and goldmines, page 19, G2, March 19, that "speeding cameras" in the city were being removed because they were no longer bringing in enough money in fines. The council insists that no cameras are being removed and that it is the intention to introduce more. The city's road safety service manager pointed out that between them the city council and the Highways Agency had invested £300,000 in the scheme with no intention of recovering the money. The purpose of the scheme was to reduce the number of accidents and this it had done very successfully. Serious and fatal accidents over the first nine months had fallen by 52%. Sorry for getting that wrong.

In a column on page 20, March 23, we said Leah Betts died in 1995 after taking ecstasy in a club in Essex. In fact, it was at a party at her home there, and not at a club.

We referred to Ken Spours, of the Institute of Education, London, as Ken Spores in an article headed Generation exhausted, page 2, Guardian Education, March 20. Apologies.

In a report about donations to political parties by life peers, page 11, March 20, we wrongly referred to Lord Smith of Gilmorehill. That should have been Baroness Smith, to whom we apologise.

In a report about a proposed napalm test in 1969-70, page 10 of early editions, March 21, we said the RAF base of El Adem was south of Tripoli. We meant to say south of Tobruk.

In a report headed Dons move for Danish striker, page 30 (Sport), March 23, we said that Arsenal won the League Cup in 1994. We should have said 1993. In 1994 it was won by Aston Villa.

The UK (and European) premiere of Aaron Jay Kernis's Second Symphony was a performance in Symphony Hall, Birmingham, on May 11, 1995, played by the CBSO under Hugh Wolff, and not the performance at the Barbican, London, reviewed on page 18, March 20.

One of the names in the acknowledgements with the Our readers' reads column in the Editor, page 22, March 23, should have been P(eter) Bailey (not Bailer). Sorry.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

BT has been considering a rescue rights issue to raise as much as £10bn - twice the size of previous expectations.

The Hatfield crash could cost Railtrack £1.2bn as train operators demand huge extra payments for lost business. To date, Railtrack has offered £400m to the operators who have rejected this as "feeble".

Investors in Royal & Sun Alliance may be asked to bail out a subsidiary of the insurer which has been hit with a £700m bill for guaranteed annuity rates - the same type of investment which brought Equitable Life to its knees.

BAe Systems has held exploratory talks with the US aerospace group Honeywell over buying parts of its avionics business. Honeywell is trying to merge with General Electric in the US and is expected to sell a number of businesses in order to gain regulatory approval.

Sunday Business

A debt reduction plan at BT next month will be the cue for chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield to resign. He is likely to win a £2.5m pay-off.

The department of trade will finally publish its inquiry into Robert Maxwell's flotation of Mirror Group Newspapers this week. His two sons, Kevin and Ian, will resist moves by the DTI to have them disqualified as company directors.

Shares prices are close to hitting their lows and will rally later this year, according to a poll of leading City fund managers.

Scottish & Southern Energy is considering a £1.5bn bid for Seeboard, the regional electricity company owned by Ohio-based utility AEP.

Sunday Telegraph

Lush, the natural cosmetics company, is plotting a £175m bid for Body Shop , the health stores group founded by Anita Roddick.

Tom Knight, chief executive of Blacks Leisure, has hired accountants KPMG to help him put together a bid to take the sportswear retailer private.

Great Universal Stores is preparing to close the ISP arm of breathe.com, less than a month after buying the internet services provider from the administrators.

Sunday Times

Sir Bob Geldof's online travel business Deckchair.com, is to merge with AIM-listed rival World Travel Holdings in a £10m deal.

A £300m sale of Superdrug, the health and beauty retailer, hangs in the balance, as Dutch retailer, Kruidvat, refuses to pay the price wanted by owner Kingfisher .

BT 's institutional investors are to urge non-executive directors to back or sack chairman Sir Iain Vallance and chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield.

Interest rates in Britain, North America and Europe are set to come down as concerns about falling stock markets and the slowing US economy grow.

Mail on Sunday

Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery is claiming more than £18m to cover the cost of its failed attempt to take over the National Lottery.

Railtrack will this week end months of speculation by naming Sir John Parker, chairman of gas group Lattice, as its new chairman.

IoS

Goldman Sachs is plotting a break-up bid for magazine publisher Emap. The US investment bank has approached a number of leading figures in the media world to see if they will back an offer.

Allen Yurko, chief executive of Invensys, is under pressure from the City to step down after the company delivered its second profits warning in six months.

AGMs Gresham computing.

Friday

Interims Leeds Sporting. Finals Costain Group, Guiton Group, Huntingdon Life Sciences, Miller Fisher, Sopheon, Television Corporation.

webTitle: Phoenix effect will work well for us all

fields.headline: Phoenix effect will work well for us all
fields.trailText: Unless this is the crash to end all crashes, there will be a day when it's all over. History suggests that eventually the storm will abate, calm will return to world financial markets and things will start to get better.
fields.body:
Unless this is the crash to end all crashes, there will be a day when it's all over. History suggests that eventually the storm will abate, calm will return to world financial markets and things will start to get better.

And when they do, we may find the world faces new and unusual challenges. After two decades in which mass unemployment has been a feature of western societies, it is likely that the next 20 years will see a return to full employment, and the result will be to change the dynamics of work, education and society. The balance between jobs and home life, the structure of our working lives, the way we educate may all be about to change.

This notion is based on two main premises - that the world economy is not about to enter a 30s-style slump and that the relationship between unemployment and inflation has reverted to that seen in earlier epochs of industrialisation.

The first conjecture is impossible to prove or disprove: there are those who believe that Armageddon is just around the corner, but even after the events of the past few weeks that still looks like the remotest of prospects.

The second premise is supported by what happened in the British and US economies in both the 1980s and 1990s, when expansionary policies led to a considerable fall in unemployment without inflationary pressure emerging. This is the precise opposite of what we were told would happen by those economists who argued that macro-economics was dead.

More technically, they turned the idea of the Phillips curve on its head. Phillips said a bit more inflation could be traded for a little less unemployment. Milton Friedman and his chums said this was untrue. The Phillips curve was in the long run a vertical line. That meant, according to the believers in a natural rate of unemployment, that any attempt to boost demand would lead to higher prices not more jobs.

Severe inflation

As the years roll by, it is clear that natural-rate analysis was true, but only for the specific conditions of the late 1970s. Western countries have been prone to bouts of severe inflation, but only normally in times of war. For the most part, the competitive pressures of a market economy have kept prices in check. This was true for a prolonged period in the 1980s, when unemployment fell sharply without a rise in inflation; it was true for an even longer period in the 1990s and - given the intensified competitive pressures associated with globalisation - will be true again in the future.

The theory may say that the long-run Phillips curve is vertical, but as the graph of UK performance since the early 70s show, the only period when the theory translated into practice was in the mid-70s. The cost of ridding Britain of inflation in the 1980s was a colossal increase in unemployment, but after that there was a short period in the late 80s and a longer period from 1993 to 2000 when the line is horizontal.

That's not to say that policymakers can simply go for growth and forget all about inflation. If economies are over-stimulated it does cause inflationary pressure, manifested either through a pick-up in the cost of living or in a disguised way through a worsening current account or unsustainable booms in asset prices. It happened in Britain with the Lawson boom of 1988 and it happened in the US in the first half of last year.

But there is no intrinsic reason why economies should not enjoy long periods of low unemployment and low inflation. Despite all the gloom and doom, the good news is that we have it in our grasp to return to an era of full employment.

As the Institute for Public Policy Research said last week, we are not there just yet. There are still 68 local labour markets with employment rates below 70%, compared to a national average of 75%. Direct action - and that means creating jobs as well as making people more employable - will be needed if the employment rate is to reach 80% nationwide, and nowhere be below 70%.

Again, let us assume that is can be achieved. How will that change things? The first thing jobs for all will do is to make us a happier country. Andrew Oswald at Warwick University is Britain's leading expert on the economics of happiness and his joint research with Rafael Di Tella of Harvard Business School and Robert MacCullough of the University of Bonn shows that unemployment is far more costly in terms of wellbeing than inflation. (Although it could, of course, be argued that rising inflation leads to higher unemployment in the end anyway).

Their estimates indicate that people would trade off a 1 percentage point increase in the unemployment rate for a 1.7 percentage point increase in the inflation rate. The conclusion from this research is clear: once you've got unemployment down, keep it down.

Secondly, a full employment economy --if sustained - would change the balance of power in the workplace, allowing us to re-think the way we manage our time. Prof Oswald has also found that job satisfaction in tBritain varies markedly over an individual's working life, and is lowest when people are trying to cope with the joint pressures of holding down a job and bringing up a family. This leads to stress, guilt, anxiety, and less productive workers.

In terms of high unemployment, employers call the shots. Employees may yearn to be at home with their children, but stick around for fear of upsetting their boss. In terms of low unemployment, it is the employers who have to make the concessions.

During the 1950s and 1960s, the battle between capital and labour was over money; in the next 20 years it will be about leisure time and workplace flexibility that means more than the ability of employers to hire and fire at will. The more progressive employers are already showing some recognition of the need to keep their staff happy, but there is a lot further to go.

As Prof Oswald's research shows, the happiest groups of workers are the young and the old, precisely the groups of workers who have been under-utilised in the past 20 years. Employers only really want prime-age workers in their 20s, 30s and 40s, and make their lives miserable by working them too hard. This is madness. With a decrease in the number of jobs requiring hard, physical labour and an increase in longevity, it should be possible to spread our working time over a larger number of years, with the highest concentrations of activity at the beginning and the end rather than in the middle.

Shakespeare

Finally, the nature of education will have to change. The shortage of jobs, particularly for the young, in the past quarter of a century has meant that there has been an obsession with turning out the sort of pupils that "business wants". Why teach children Shakespeare when they need to know how to write a letter asking for a job? Why bother with Wordsworth when what employers want is somebody who knows how to send an e-mail?

But in full employment world, there is the chance for education to do something different, to prepare children for life rather than work. With more and more people having to cope with ageing parents, it seems quite a good idea to study King Lear. With the tension between growth and the environment, an intimate knowledge of the Romantic poets may be more useful than being able to surf the net. Full employment allows society to ask some questions that need answering. Perhaps that's why it's never been all that popular.

fields.headline: C&W sells off £6bn Optus
fields.standfirst: Vodafone misses out on Australian operator
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless will add to its £4bn cash pile today when it announces that it has sold its controlling stake in Optus, Australia's second largest telecoms operator, to Singapore Telecommunications.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless will add to its £4bn cash pile today when it announces that it has sold its controlling stake in Optus, Australia's second largest telecoms operator, to Singapore Telecommunications.

The cash and paper bid, which saw off a rival offer from Vodafone, is likely to value Optus at around A$ 17bn (£6bn) and will increase the pressure on C&W's chief executive, Graham Wallace, to return some cash to shareholders.

Investors have been pressing for a share buyback or a special dividend since a bungled profits warning wiped 20% wiped off C&W's share price a couple of weeks ago.

It is thought that more than half the payment for C&W's 52.5% holding will made in cash.

Vodafone was yesterday trying to mask its disappointment in losing the long-running battle for control of Optus. Announcing it was pulling out of the auction, Vodafone said it wanted to grow a profitable business in Australia but that the proposed deal "did not meet" its return criteria.

But the sale to SingTel, 78% owned by the Singapore government, is a blow to its ambitions in the region. Vodafone wanted Optus for its mobile phone arm. A deal would have left it with a 40% share of the Australian mobile phone market.

SingTel's offer is thought to have triumphed primarily because it presented few regulatory problems but also because of its composition.

Vodafone's bid faced opposition from the Australian regulators who were concerned that it might create a damaging duopoly. Although Vodafone sought to clear the way for its offer by presenting the regulators with a plan to transfer 1m of its mobile telephone customers to a rival, it still risked being blocked. The SingTel deal is expected to be waved through by local regulators.

C&W is also thought to have looked more favourably on SingTel's offer because of its big cash element.

C&W sold its controlling interest in Hongkong Telecom to Pacific Century Cyberworks for £4.2bn in cash and 450m PCCW shares last year, but got its fingers burnt when PCCW's stock price collapsed in the aftermath of the deal. Vodafone would have funded the acquisition by issuing shares in its Vodafone Pacific arm.

The sale of Optus marks the latest step in the transformation of C&W into a business-focused internet and data services company. Mr Wallace is said to be keen to hang on to some cash to fund expansion.

webTitle: Arts: New documentary on Hoxton's artists

fields.headline: Pop goes the easel
fields.standfirst: Headline-hogging hedonism helped make east London the capital of the European art scene. But are Tracey Emin and her chums now too trendy for their own good, asks  Tim Cumming
fields.trailText: Headline-hogging hedonism helped make east London the capital of the European art scene. But are Tracey Emin and her chums now too trendy for their own good, asks Tim Cumming.
fields.body:
In a memorable scene from the first episode of New EastEnders, a new BBC documentary series about the artists in London's Hoxton, Philippe Bradshaw shows viewers around the unconverted women's toilet that used to be his studio. Later on he is filmed in a new space in a former office building in nearby Bethnal Green, where he is assembling an installation destined for Paris and based on Fragonard's The Swing. As his model eases herself into position on set, Bradshaw talks about living apart from his partner and their four-year-old son: he sees life as an artist as incompatible with family. "It's quite a selfish environment, which just serves its own purpose, which is to produce The Work."

Bradshaw is in the ascendant, and one senses he is open all hours, working the circuit as vigorously as any glamour model. If Tracey Emin is the pearly queen of the New EastEnders, then Bradshaw is a prince in waiting. He is a member of the new aristocracy. The hedonism his new life requires is as artful as his Fragonard.

Emin is filmed at the Lux cinema in Hoxton Square as a group of Turkish musicians play the theme tune from The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. It's for a 60-second movie sponsored by Becks, the beer of choice at many a private view. Bradshaw probably drinks it, and he makes art out of what he drinks. At the opening for his show in Bethnal Green - "an inventory of everything I drank" - he urinates over his own installation of empties, then turns to the camera, laughing, as the credits roll. Rents are high, price matters. Bradshaw is on a roll, and there is no room for doubt.

In the same episode we follow work on British Wildlife, a new silhouette sculpture by Tim Noble and Sue Webster. The sculpture is made from a collection of stuffed animals. "My dad got ill recently, and died," explains Noble. "We had to clear his house out. He was an artist and had a lot of stuffed animals that I think he'd stolen from a museum. We took the stuffed animal collection and decided to do something with it."

From Noble's inheritance they fashion their trademark double silhouette projected on to the gallery walls. At the opening night, the camera observes Noble discussing the piece and his father's legacy. "Maybe he's up in heaven looking down," says his companion. Noble laughs, looks up and gives the finger. They both laugh and then Noble turns his head and says to no one in particular: "I hope so ... "

Filmed by Simon Chu and Mary Sackville-West over the past six months, New EastEnders is a hugely entertaining cinema-verite take on how the art world operates - which is more or less in zero gravity. There is a strange sense of weightlessness at the heart of the Britart phenomenon, as if it's trapped in its own hall of mirrors. Now Hoxton is sufficiently well-known for a documentary to be made about it, the community that made the area what it is is being priced out. With the West End moving east, and East End prices moving west, Hoxton's artists have been prised from their most famous installation: Hoxton itself.

Inevitably the artists, dealers and curators who agreed to be filmed define what we see of their world, but New EastEnders reveals more than its participants are aware. The series covers four major themes: the artist, the gallery, the show and the market. Shot on a shoestring, the films approach their subject with a candid-camera invisibility. Each episode threads three or four strands together; it could be a young artist looking for a dealer, or a dealer looking for Charles Saatchi, or the curator of Apocalypse facing his first bad press. It's all about context over content. There is no intrinsic value system, and the documentary offers a detached account of what is going on in Hoxton. Like the ladder standing in the Chapman brothers' freshly whitewashed gallery, its status depends entirely on who put it there, whether they call it art - and whether we believe them. It is all potentially significant, and it is all equally weightless.

As if to underline this, a Godardian soundtrack of extraneous noise swells and falls through each episode. Victoria Miro opens the doors to her new gallery to the cacophonous hammering and drilling of her East End crew of artisans, which gives way to the gallery dinner and the murmur of West End diners, the generic buzz of the private view spilling out on to the street, and the indifferent drone of London's traffic. These noises off signal how close to chaos and brass tacks the art world always is. For the underlying theme of the series, from the opening montage of gallery and estate-agent signs to Michael Landy's anti-monumental Break Down in the last episode, is commodity.

The New EastEnders appear acutely aware of their commodity value; some translate it into real money, which in turn translates into more work. Noble and Webster, and Jake Chapman in his guise as Britart's Victor Meldrew, disparage the production-line ethos their work inspires in dealers east or west. Freeze veteran Matt Collishaw, meanwhile, admits to being "only really happy when you conceive the idea. You have an orgasm of conception, and after that it is just work, and boring."

Collishaw stands out because he says exactly what he wants to do and the problems he faces in achieving it. Another memorable figure is Hoxton estate agent James Goff. At the beginning of the first episode he takes a young artist from Nottingham, Laura White, to view a studio on Charlotte Road, "the Bond Street of Shoreditch". It costs £20,000 a year to rent. He smiles: "It's all part of this artists' culture thing, isn't it, the little garret and working away ...?" Look further east, he tells her, and a bemused White nods. It's time for her to face some home truths. Hoxton is not a place to begin a career: you have to come ready-made.

Noble and Webster live next door to Goff. They are Hoxton's leading brand, using their celebrity the way Carl Andre used his bricks. They featured as "conceptualists with attitude" in an episode of the BBC documentary Living With the Enemy, and attitude is their sharpest tool. At one point in New EastEnders, Webster is heard saying, "I hate being a part of any community. I don't want to be part of a crowd," at the same time as she draws up a guest list of 350 for her birthday party and the opening of British Wildlife. In the art of Noble and Webster, celebrity is its own reward.

At the other end of town, metaphorically, Sandy Simeonides installs his sculptures in the dead of night in Hoxton Square. He has no gallery to represent him, and his dawn-chorus private view is a small group of drunks shouting down from the railings: "Oi, come back you bastard! Give us more art! We want some fucking art!" The next day Noble and Webster come across Simeonides's work in cruel daylight. It doesn't look anything like it did the night before. "Is it a TV aerial?" asks Sue, barely breaking her step before walking out of shot. The camera lingers for a moment, and from somewhere a disembodied voice says meekly but not convincingly, "It's art ... "

 The first episode of New EastEnders is screened on BBC2 on April 2.

Each episode threads three or four strands together; it could be a young artist looking for a dealer, or a dealer looking for Charles Saatchi, or the curator of Apocalypse facing his first bad press. It's all about context over content. There is no intrinsic value system, and the documentary offers a detached account of what is going on in Hoxton. Like the ladder standing in the Chapman brothers' freshly whitewashed gallery, its status depends entirely on who put it there, whether they call it art - and whether we believe them. It is all potentially significant, and it is all equally weightless. As if to underline this, a Godardian soundtrack of extraneous noise swells and falls through each episode. Victoria Miro opens the doors to her new gallery to the cacophonous hammering and drilling of her East End crew of artisans, which gives way to the gallery dinner and the murmur of West End diners, the generic buzz of the private view spilling out on to the street, and the indifferent drone of London's traffic. These noises off signal how close to chaos and brass tacks the art world always is. For the underlying theme of the series, from the opening montage of gallery and estate-agent signs to Michael Landy's anti-monumental Break Down in the last episode, is commodity. The New EastEnders appear acutely aware of their commodity value; some translate it into real money, which in turn translates into more work. Noble and Webster, and Jake Chapman in his guise as Britart's Victor Meldrew, disparage the production-line ethos their work inspires in dealers east or west. Freeze veteran Matt Collishaw, meanwhile, admits to being "only really happy when you conceive the idea. You have an orgasm of conception, and after that it is just work, and boring." Collishaw stands out because he says exactly what he wants to do and the problems he faces in achieving it. Another memorable figure is Hoxton estate agent James Goff. At the beginning of the first episode he takes a young artist from Nottingham, Laura White, to view a studio on Charlotte Road, "the Bond Street of Shoreditch". It costs £20,000 a year to rent. He smiles: "It's all part of this artists' culture thing, isn't it, the little garret and working away ...?" Look further east, he tells her, and a bemused White nods. It's time for her to face some home truths. Hoxton is not a place to begin a career: you have to come ready-made. Noble and Webster live next door to Goff. They are Hoxton's leading brand, using their celebrity the way Carl Andre used his bricks. They featured as "conceptualists with attitude" in an episode of the BBC documentary Living With the Enemy, and attitude is their sharpest tool. At one point in New EastEnders, Webster is heard saying, "I hate being a part of any community. I don't want to be part of a crowd," at the same time as she draws up a guest list of 350 for her birthday party and the opening of British Wildlife. In the art of Noble and Webster, celebrity is its own reward. At the other end of town, metaphorically, Sandy Simeonides installs his sculptures in the dead of night in Hoxton Square. He has no gallery to represent him, and his dawn-chorus private view is a small group of drunks shouting down from the railings: "Oi, come back you bastard! Give us more art! We want some fucking art!" The next day Noble and Webster come across Simeonides's work in cruel daylight. It doesn't look anything like it did the night before. "Is it a TV aerial?" asks Sue, barely breaking her step before walking out of shot. The camera lingers for a moment, and from somewhere a disembodied voice says meekly but not convincingly, "It's art ... "  The first episode of New EastEnders is screened on BBC2 on April 2.

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst: 8. Rick Mather
fields.trailText: 8. Rick Mather. Wonder: Kaufmann house, US. Blunder: Centre Point, London
fields.body:
Wonder: Kaufmann house, US
Blunder: Centre Point, London

I like buildings that use their context in an elegant and beautiful way. The Kaufmann house in Palm Springs, California, achieves this in the way it relates to the surrounding desert. Rather than cutting it off, it opens up and engages with the desert. When built in the 1940s to the designs of the Austrian émigré architect, Richard Neutra, the house was on the edge of the desert - but the suburbs have since encroached on this setting.

The design was radical for its time. It led the way to that west coast idea of "indoor outdoor" living. The lower level of the house presents blank walls to the street, but at the back, glass walls slide open to terraces, pool, garden and desert views. The view is even better from the rooftop living room, which is covered but protected on the sides only by aluminium louvres. These can be adjusted to catch the evening breezes, or cut out the low afternoon sun.

In the city the test of any tall building is how it meets the ground. Sadly, many high buildings with beautiful tops fail at the bottom. These are my least favourite buildings. Pedestrians are all too often presented with blank walls, ventilation grilles, parking structures, windy paved areas or inappropriate suburban gestures such as grass and bushes. Gestures like these kill the city.

Centre Point in central London is an example of a building that doesn't meet the ground well. However it is old enough to have a period charm of its own so I wouldn't like to see it changed.

Cities need buildings that create street fronts with activities for people to use and enjoy - shops, cafes, bars, galleries. With the rash of towers being proposed for London we should be particularly vigilant in checking that these new buildings all have user-friendly bases, ones that give life and to the surrounding streets.

 Rick Mather is an architect.

webTitle: Terrorists 'helped by CIA' to stop rise of left in Italy

fields.headline: Terrorists 'helped by CIA' to stop rise of left in Italy
fields.trailText: US intelligence services instigated and abetted rightwing terrorism in Italy during the 1970s, a former Italian secret service general has claimed.
fields.body:
US intelligence services instigated and abetted rightwing terrorism in Italy during the 1970s, a former Italian secret service general has claimed.

The allegation was made by General Gianadelio Maletti, a former head of military counter-intelligence, at the trial last week of rightwing extremists accused of killing 16 people in the bombing of a Milan bank in 1969 - the first time such a charge has been made in a court of law by a senior Italian intelligence figure.

Gen Maletti, comannder of the counter-intelligence section of the military intelligence service from 1971 to 1975, said his men had discovered that a rightwing terrorist cell in the Venice region had been supplied with military explosives from Germany.

Those explosives may have been obtained with the help of members of the US intelligence community, an indication that the Americans had gone beyond the infiltration and monitoring of extremist groups to instigating acts of violence, he said.

"The CIA [Central Intelligence Agency], following the directives of its government, wanted to create an Italian nationalism capable of halting what it saw as a slide to the left and, for this purpose, it may have made use of rightwing terrorism," Gen Maletti told the Milan court. "I believe this is what happened in other countries as well."

The general has been living in South Africa for the last 21 years as a fugitive from Italian justice. He has been sentenced to 14 years imprisonment for leaking a secret service document to the press and last year received a 15-year sentence for obstructing justice. He was granted a special 15-day immunity from arrest to enable him to give evidence at the trial for the bombing of a bank in Milan's Piazza Fontana, the atrocity that inaugurated the "strategy of tension", a series of bombings intended to shift the country's political centre of gravity to the right.

"The impression was that the Americans would do anything to stop Italy from sliding to the left," Gen Maletti said during an interview at his Milan hotel.

"Don't forget that [former US president Richard] Nixon was in charge and Nixon was a strange man, a very intelligent politician but a man of rather unorthodox initiatives."

The CIA supported SID, the Italian defence intelligence service, financially, but Gen Maletti's US counterparts were rarely willing to share information. There may have been good reason for the American caginess. In a posthumous memoir published last year, the wartime resistance hero Count Edgardo Sogno described how he visited the CIA station chief in Rome in July 1974 to inform him of his plans for an anti-communist coup.

"I told him that I was informing him as an ally in the struggle for the freedom of the west and asked him what the attitude of the American government would be," Mr Sogno wrote. "He answered what I already knew: the United States would have supported any initiative tending to keep the communists out of government."

Despite contacts with his CIA counterparts, no word of the Sogno plot was uttered. "I, for one, didn't know about the Sogno thing. I knew Mr Sogno was being investigated by a Turin magistrate but I didn't know he had such important contacts with US agencies in the United States and Italy," Gen Maletti said. "Clearly, Sogno had great confidence in the complicity of the American service."

The lucid 79-year-old general, whose English is almost perfect, has spent his retirement in South Africa painting and writing his memoirs, which are due to be published soon. He admits to feeling nostalgic for his homeland.

But the judges who convicted him in absentia last year were far from convinced of his gentlemanly qualities. In their written verdict they said he had obstructed an investigation into a 1973 attack on the interior minister by withholding crucial information from the magistrates.

Four members of the public were killed and 45 injured when an anarchist, Gianfranco Bertoli, hurled a grenade into a crowd outside police headquarters in Milan. Bertoli, according to the judges, was really a man of right-wing sympathies and a long-standing SID informant, codenamed Negro. Gen Maletti's men were warned in advance of the attack on the minister, Mariano Rumor, but took no action to prevent it and failed to pass on their information on Bertoli even after the killings.

Gen Maletti's role at the heart of the complex intrigues makes him an illuminating witness. Italy must clarify the mysteries of that time if it is to recover its national dignity and sovereignty, he said.

"Among the larger western European countries, Italy has been dealt with as a sort of protectorate. I am ashamed to think that we are still subject to special supervision."

webTitle: 'Twin fireballs' turn up heat on Arab talks

fields.headline: 'Twin fireballs' turn up heat on Arab talks
fields.standfirst:
Israeli-Palestinian conflict and Iraq pose new challenge as 22 leaders meet

Special report: Iraq
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestine has almost always been the raison d'être of Arab summitry and it will again head the agenda when the leaders of 22 Arab states convene here tomorrow. Iraq is on the agenda too. President Saddam Hussein will not be there, but he will cast a baleful and divisive shadow on the event.
fields.body:
Palestine has almost always been the raison d'être of Arab summitry and it will again head the agenda when the leaders of 22 Arab states convene here tomorrow. Iraq is on the agenda too. President Saddam Hussein will not be there, but he will cast a baleful and divisive shadow on the event.

The Israeli-Palestinian conflict on one hand, Iraq and the Gulf on the other, constitute the two great zones of Middle East crisis. "There is a clear and present danger", the former US ambassador to the UN, Richard Holbrooke, warned recently, "that the most dangerous situation in the world today - the Middle East and Iraq - could metastasise into a single fireball." President Saddam's pledge to send thousands of volunteers to fight alongside the Palestinians "could create the most serious threat to world peace since the Cuban missile crisis" of 1962, he said.

Never have the two zones been so closely and malignantly intertwined. Two things contribute to this. One is the Palestinian intifada, now in its sixth month, and the consequent rise to power in Ariel Sharon of all that is most intransigent and belligerent in Israeli society. The other is the new Republican administration in Washington and its apparent conviction that Iraq and the Gulf is the more important of the two crisis zones.

For the Arab leaders, Palestine alone is headache enough. They are supposed to hold "ordinary" summits once a year, but thanks to the divisions that beset them following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, they did not manage that for a decade. But quite suddenly, with the outbreak of the intifada, Palestine regained that potent centrality in the region's politics and psychology that it had appeared to be losing.

Demonstrators took to the streets from the Atlantic to the Gulf; solidarity with the Palestinians was their main theme; but disgust with the inaction and incompetence of Arab regimes was a close second. It roused the kings and presidents to hold an emergency summit in Cairo last October.

The only practical measure the summit took was to establish a $1bn (£700m) fund to support the intifada. If, at the time, this and other resolutions, such as a call for international protection for the Palestinians, fell well below popular expectations, their implementation since then has invited even greater derision.

The Islamic Development Bank, responsible for the disbursement, says it has delivered $23m of the $1bn to the occupied territories; Palestinians put the figure at $3m. Meanwhile, according to the UN, the Palestinian economy has sustained losses of $1.15bn, unemployment has soared to 38% and about 1m inhabitants have fallen below the poverty line.

Arab governments, invoking the corruption of the Palestinian Authority, say they want to be sure the aid goes to the right hands. But, as the Jordanian newspaper al-Rai asked: "Has the rampant corruption in the Arab world ever held up the payment of employees' salaries? Don't let those who hold the money in the Arab world pretend that they have forfeited one night's heavy gambling, one evening's generous entertaining or one villa in Europe for the sake of the intifada."

However, as the Arab leaders meet again they cannot but be aware that, with the rise of Mr Sharon, the situation has worsened since their last encounter.

"We are back to polarisation between Arabs and Israel," a columnist in Cairo's al-Ahram newspaper wrote. "The collapse of the peace process has brought the whole region perilously close to the brink of war, not as a function of conscious decision but as a result of the situation spiralling out of control, even by mistake."

President Bill Clinton made the quest for Middle East peace his overriding ambition; Iraq, and all its complications, became a nuisance and diversion from it. George Bush has reversed these priorities. He, or at least influential figures in his administration, really do want to implement the Iraqi Liberation Act - whereby the US will help the Iraqi opposition to bring "representative" government to Iraq - to which Mr Clinton paid mere lip service. President Saddam, not Mr Sharon, is the problem on which all must "focus and unite". And, as a vital part of that, there must be a revival of the Gulf war coalition under which the previous President Bush drove the Iraqi leader from Kuwait.

This suits Mr Sharon, though he wants more. On his inaugural visit to the US, he sought to promote the notion that Yasser Arafat, far from being the partner for peace that till now the US and Israel had considered him to be, had reverted with a vengeance to his original "terrorist" self. If the Palestinian leader has any natural partner, it is President Saddam, the Israeli right argues. The two sustain and reinforce each other. And along with others - Iran, Hizbullah, Hamas - they constitute a threat to Israel, the US and the whole moderate peace-seeking camp.

The US does not go along with all of that. But it has ceded a substantial amount of what Mr Sharon wants. It agrees that there can be "no negotiation under fire", a way of saying that Palestinian violence is not a normal response to occupation, and that "leaders have a responsibility to denounce violence" - a way of saying that Mr Arafat condones the attacks on Israelis. Nor will the US force peace on the parties: they must settle matters between themselves - a pro-Israeli position, in that without external assistance the Palestinians cannot hope to dent a balance of power overwhelmingly in Israel's favour.

Partisanship

Many Arab regimes would agree with the US that President Saddam is a menace, though far less to Israel than to themselves. But they contend that nothing nourishes this menace like the Israel-Palestinian conflict and the partisanship which the US displays there. Nothing else furnishes the Iraqi leader with such opportunities for self-aggrandisement, for turning himself - the prime wrecker of Arab and Palestinian causes - into their foremost champion again.

"We know that his propaganda is often stupid, that all his talk of mobilising millions of volunteers is demagogy," a Jordanian politician said. "But in the absence of anyone else even thinking in military terms, he does impress the ordinary man - and makes the other leaders look submissive and cowardly."

So it is that these leaders feel under almost as much pressure to rehabilitate the Iraqi leader as they do to support the intifada. Ironically, Egypt and Jordan, the two Arab states which have made peace with Israel, have led the way in this. It is only the opposition of the Gulf states, who do regard President Saddam as a greater menace than Mr Sharon, that will keep the summit from bringing him into the fold. It is one thing for the US, with help from its Arab friends, to impede his rehabilitation. It is quite another to expect them to join in a campaign to bring him down. Reviving the Gulf war coalition, said the Saudi newspaper al-Watan, "is like trying to sell goods whose sell-by label expired long ago".

So the harder Mr Sharon smites the Palestinians - and probably in due course Hizbullah and the Syrians too - and the more the Americans besiege and imperil President Saddam, the more likely it becomes that this gambler, who invaded Iran and then Kuwait, will escalate from belligerent words to belligerent deeds and, with Israel-Palestine as his arena, stage the last great, pre-emptive gamble of his tumultuous career. A Middle East fireball indeed!

fields.headline: Secrets of a massacre
fields.standfirst: Diaries reveal Nazi slaughter of Italian ex-allies
fields.trailText: Italian newspapers yesterday published harrowing eyewitness accounts of the second world war massacre of thousands of Italian soldiers on the island of Cephalonia by their former German allies.
fields.body:
Italian newspapers yesterday published harrowing eyewitness accounts of the second world war massacre of thousands of Italian soldiers on the island of Cephalonia by their former German allies.

The killings, described in the diaries of two German soldiers, provided part of the grim historical backdrop to Louis de Bernières' novel Captain Corelli's Mandolin.

The German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung first published the accounts last week and they were the subject of a documentary broadcast last night by the German television network ZDF. "The conspiracy of silence in Germany has been broken for the first time," said the Milan daily Corriere della Sera.

Some 9,500 men of the 11,500-strong Italian force were killed by the Germans between September 12 and 22, 1943, and 5,000 are believed to have been executed after surrendering. President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi paid tribute a month ago to the soldiers who chose to die fighting after Italy signed an armistice with the allies on September 8, leaving the troops on Cephalonia without orders. "Their deliberate choice was the first act of the resistance, of an Italy free from fascism," the president said at ceremony on the island.

The executions are described in the diary of Alfred Richter, a corporal in a German Alpine regiment, who stumbled on their bodies. "All bear the signs of a shot to the head, so they were killed by the 98th [regiment] after they had surrendered." he wrote.

Later Corporal Richter came upon an Italian artillery position overrun by his comrades: "The gunners are lying on the ground, killed by gunshots, crushed by boots. It must have happened only minutes ago. Under that pile of bloody bodies there is one that trembles and still breathes."

In the town of Frangata, the corporal sees two companies of Italian soldiers who have surrendered and are confident that they will be spared. Instead they are handed over for execution, platoon after platoon. "We stay in the town for two hours, during which the sound of the bursts of machinegun fire is incessant and the cries can be heard even from within the houses of the Greeks. Everyone is shot, without regard for rank or role, even the medics and the chaplains."

In a scene that could have come from de Bernières' novel, soon to be released as a film starring Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz, an Italian soldier saved his life by breaking into song. webTitle: British warrant issued in French arms row

fields.headline: British warrant issued in French arms row
fields.standfirst: Allegations of corruption reach back to Mitterrand era
fields.trailText: The cascade of French corruption investigations has been extended to Britain where a provisional arrest warrant has been issued by Bow Street magistrates against a Russian-born multi-millionaire believed to be at the centre of one of the scandals that has mired some leading political names from the Mitterrand years.
fields.byline: David Pallister and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
The cascade of French corruption investigations has been extended to Britain where a provisional arrest warrant has been issued by Bow Street magistrates against a Russian-born multi-millionaire believed to be at the centre of one of the scandals that has mired some leading political names from the Mitterrand years.

Arcadi Gaydamak, 49, who carries French, Israeli, Canadian and Angolan passports, is wanted for questioning by Paris magistrates about a £450m allegedly illegal arms deal with Angola in the early 1990s. The scandal led to the arrest in December of Jean Christophe Mitterrand, son of the former president.

An international arrest warrant has also been issued for Mr Gaydamak for "fraud, abuse of trust and trafficking in influence". But Scotland Yard was specifically alerted by the French authorities because he has had the right of residence in Britain since 1995.

Mr Gaydamak, however, has been living in Israel for the past two years. In a telephone interview with the Guardian last week, he insisted that the deal and his involvement in it was a legitimate transaction between the governments of Angola and Russia. "I am not a fugitive," he said.

Mr Gaydamak's one-time associate, Pierre Falcone, a Franco-Brazilian arms dealer, is under arrest in Paris on the same charges. He is the director of a number of British companies linked to Brenco International, the company which gave £1.3m in alleged bribes to Mitterrand's son. Mr Gaydamak said this money was paid in 1998 and had nothing to do with the arms deals three years before.

The investigation widened last week when Jacques Attali, a former adviser to Mitterrand and former head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was put under criminal investigation for allegedly receiving £150,000 from Mr Falcone to help with a £44m tax claim against the arms deals. Mr Attali, who has been released on bail, claims the money was a consultancy fee from the Angolan government for banking advice.

Mr Gaydamak said that he and Mr Falcone were both given Angolan citizenship in the early 1990s with the status of officials in the Angolan ministry of external affairs.

"My main activity is supplying of materials for the oil fields and trading in oil, particularly in Angola," he said.

It was at a time when the Angolan government desperately needed military equipment. The rebel movement Unita had returned to civil war, but the purchase of lethal weapons was prohibited under the 1991 Bicesse Accords.

Mr Gaydamak said the Angolan government decided to buy combat helicopters and ammunition from Russia using a Slovak company, ZTS-OSOS, in which a Russian state-owned enterprise had a large shareholding. The payment would be in oil through an account at the French bank Paribas. Both he and Mr Falcone were given authority to control the bank account and to sign contracts on behalf of ZTS. "Everyone knew about the operation and everything was legal," he said. "Our profit was the difference between the price we fixed for the oil and the price we sold it."

But it was that profit - allegedly in excess of £50m - which raised questions about the financial affairs of both men and led to the money-laundering and tax avoidance inquiry headed by investigating magistrates Philippe Courroye and Isabelle Prevost-Desprez.

The inquiry has thrown a spotlight on the pair's extensive international interests and powerful connections.

Arcardi Gaydamak was born in Moscow but left the then Soviet Union for France in 1972 at the age of 19. In 1976 he started a translation and interpreting business which put him in contact with a number of high-ranking business and political figures in France and the USSR - which would be useful in his later career.

In 1990 he launched into the far more lucrative business of international trading, primarily in metals but also in arms. He says he met Mr Falcone in 1992, or early 1993, and the two men soon began doing business together in Latin America. In 1996 he was awarded France's order of merit by President Jacques Chirac, purportedly for his work in helping French agricultural concerns to win contracts in Russia. In fact, the decoration was for Mr Gaydamak's intervention in secur ing the release of two French pilots captured by Serb forces in former Yugoslavia in 1995.

Mr Gaydamak says high-level French officials, including the former interior minister Charles Pasqua, asked him to intervene and that the operation cost him several million francs.

In 1997 he was involved in freeing four French aid workers being held in Dagestan. For his services he won the support of senior figures in French intelligence including Raymond Nart, the then deputy head of DST, the French equivalent of MI6.

In Israel, Mr Gaydamak has teamed up with Russian/Israeli businessman Lev Leviev. Their Africa-Israeli Investments holding company now has the exclusive rights through a joint venture with the government to market Angolan diamonds and owns the assets of TotalFinaElf in the US - a $400m deal that included an oil refinery in Texas and the franchise for 1,700 filling stations.

But not all has been plain sailing. After the French international arrest warrant was issued in December, Mr Gaydamak resigned from an influential post as president of the Russian Rossiyski Kredit Bank.

Mr Falcone has some equally unusual connections. In the early 1990s he was the official agent for the main French export agency, Sofremi, and held a monopoly on the supply of food to the Angolan army through a Brazilian subsidiary.

In London the secretary of Mr Falcone's Brenco Ltd is Henry Guderley, a chartered accountant. He is also the chief financial secretary of a Utah-based health food company, Essante, owned by Mr Falcone's wife Sonia.

It emerged last month that Essante had given $100,000 to Republican Party funds which were returned to avoid embarrassment. Mrs Falcone has personally given $6,000 to Republican candiates, according to electoral commission records. Mr Falcone remains in custody in Paris. Last week the Angolan president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos confirmed that he had been instrumental in helping the country to acquire arms from eastern Europe.

As for Jean Christophe Mitterrand, who investigators believe used his privileged position as France's Africa adviser between 1986 and 1992, he is out on £500,000 bail, one of the highest in French legal history. According to his lawyer, the money he received in a Swiss bank account from Brenco Ltd was invested in a fishing factory in Mauritania.

webTitle: Portugal bus deaths fuel fury over roads

fields.headline: Portugal bus deaths fuel fury over roads
fields.trailText: Just three weeks after a busload of 60 daytrippers disappeared over the edge of a collapsed bridge into the river Douro, Portugal saw 14 pilgrims killed at the weekend as a coach fell down a 100ft precipice beside a notoriously dangerous road.
fields.body:
Just three weeks after a busload of 60 daytrippers disappeared over the edge of a collapsed bridge into the river Douro, Portugal saw 14 pilgrims killed at the weekend as a coach fell down a 100ft precipice beside a notoriously dangerous road.

The accident at Vimeiro, 135 miles north of Lisbon, revealed, once again, the disastrous state of Portuguese roads, as one of the EU's poorest countries struggles to raise its infrastructure to the levels of fellow member states.

The victims had been on an outing to the Roman Catholic shrine at Fatima. Witnesses said the bus driver lost control of the vehicle in torrential rain on what police described as a "very dangerous road".

It is known locally as "the death route" and nine people have already died on the same stretch this year. The accident came just days after a "drive-slow" protest by a group calling itself "the users and survivors" of the road, to complain about safety.

Portugal has a road deaths level three times higher, proportionally, than Britain's. Greece is the only EU country with a worse record.

Campaigners said yesterday's accident and the earlier bridge collapse at Castelo de Paiva, which the government admitted was its fault, were proof of official negligence.

"It is time to stop talking and do something. We should not be constantly forced to witness such terrifying events," Manuel Ramos, head of the Portuguese Road Users' Association, said.

Two years ago newspapers revealed that 15,000 official cars, or nearly half the government stock, had no insurance. Government officials and police often blame the terrible driving of Portuguese motorists for the country's accident rate. The interior minister, Fernando Gomes, caused a scandal last year by claiming his countrymen drove so badly they were not worthy of European-standard roads.

A study last year indicated that four out of five motorway drivers broke the country's speed limits.

Police have recently set up "zero tolerance" roads in order to stop speeding and reduce the number of deaths. Saturday's accident took place on one of those roads.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Sharon defiant as settler shot
fields.body:
Sharon defiant as settler shot

Palestinian gunmen shot and seriously wounded a Jewish settler near Yitzhar on the West Bank yesterday as the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, prepared to meet a US fact-finding group investigating the rising violence.

Sharon has called the fact-finding committee, which Palestinian president Yasser Arafat and Israeli foreign minister Shimon Peres met last week, a "historic mistake".

Reuters, Jerusalem

More Picassos seized by police

Four men have been arrested for allegedly trying to sell two paintings, believed to be Picassos, to undercover police in Istanbul.

Six Picassos have been seized in Turkey in the past year. They are believed to have been taken from Kuwait in the Gulf War.

Hair apparent at beard contest

More than 250 men gathered in south-west Germany at the weekend for the 10th annual world beard and moustache championships.

Participants from 15 countries paraded their whiskers in front of a jury.

Reuters, Schömberg

Saudis move to ban Pokemon

Saudi Arabia's mufti, the country's religious authority, has banned the children's game Pokemon for its alleged association with gambling and Jewish symbols.

AFP, Riyadh

Secret agents sent gifts in jail

French politicians sent wine and cognac to French agents jailed for bombing the Rainbow Warrior, New Zealand government papers have revealed. The former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, and an unnamed French legislator sent the gifts just after the men admitted manslaughter. Greenpeace photographer Fernando Pereira died in the bombing in July 1985.

AP, Wellington

fields.headline: Villagers caught in the storm
fields.standfirst:
Civilians hide in shelters as shells fall

Macedonia
fields.trailText: The trail of blood led down the cobbled narrow lane towards the mosque. A short distance away stood a house with its red tiled roof gaping where a shell had entered, injuring four ethnic Albanian civilians.
fields.body:
The trail of blood led down the cobbled narrow lane towards the mosque. A short distance away stood a house with its red tiled roof gaping where a shell had entered, injuring four ethnic Albanian civilians.

No one was killed, but the 5,000 villagers in rebel-held Sipkovica are not counting on being so lucky next time.

On the main road snaking up the hillside below the village, Macedonian armoured personnel carriers were fighting their way up the little hanging valley, which holds the main guerrilla base in the town of Selce and nearby Sipkovica.

Entering the village, a fighter of the ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army, his face sunburned from manning his position in the mountains, strolled by in fatigues. We asked to speak to him but he drew a zip across his mouth and walked on. His colleagues were down a slope of orchards where some of the fiercest of the clashes with Macedonian forces took place yesterday around the village of Gajre. It was identifiable by plumes of dense white smoke, and fires visible through the trees.

While the NLA was fighting, the women and children of Sipkovica were sheltering in cellars. In one house was Nayo, who had recently returned from his home in England to fetch his 13-year-old daughter, Brevina, and bring her to safety. Now he is trapped in the village, too scared to go to Tetovo and unwilling to attempt the 12-hour walk over the snow-covered Shar mountains to the safety of Kosovo.

Brevina, her 80-year-old grandmother, mother and other relatives crouched in a darkened basement, its only window - at ceiling level - blocked off by stacks of wood to protect them from shrapnel.

In the five days since the village first came under fire, the family's neighbours have also been gathering at night to sit around the stove on the mattresses that Nayo has spread on the floor.

Brevina was brought forward, a slight and pretty girl with an ashen worried face. "I am very scared," she said.

"They started shelling at six o'clock this morning," Nayo said. "We could see the village of Lavce hit by over 20 shells. They are shelling from the ski station and from the mountain opposite as well. We saw helicopters come in three times to lead the attack.

"People don't want this. We just want to live our lives. If you ask me - am I scared? - I have to say I was scared two hours ago. Now I'm not frightened. I only have one life, what else can I do. This is reality."

Like everyone in the village he was aware how close the Macedonian forces were. "They will come here and they will fight," he said. "Then they will destroy this village and my house to show the world how strong they are. I don't want to fight. What have I to fight with - with my empty hands? But if I had a weapon I would fight. I am so shocked by this".

"I believed that Macedonia would never have a war. I thought Macedonians and Albanians could talk it out."

webTitle: Election boost for German opposition stronghold

fields.headline: Election boost for German opposition stronghold
fields.trailText: Germany's conservatives held on to the richest state of Baden Württemberg yesterday, defying predictions that the opposition party was about to lose its traditional stronghold.
fields.body:
Germany's conservatives held on to the richest state of Baden Württemberg yesterday, defying predictions that the opposition party was about to lose its traditional stronghold.

The Christian Democratic Union (CDU) won 45% of the vote, according to exit polls, compared with 41.3% in the last election five years ago.

Baden-Württemberg, which is viewed as the epitome of German post-war success, had looked in danger of falling out of the conservative grip after almost half a century.

The conservatives had been unsettled by internal rows over party funding, and threatened by the ruling Social Democrats' (SPD) charismatic woman candidate, Ute Vogt.

The results are likely to secure, at least for the time being, the position of Angela Merkel who took over as national CDU leader last year, promising a new start after a slush-fund scandal centring on the former chancellor Helmut Kohl.

Edmund Stoiber, the eurosceptic prime minister of Bavaria and leader of the CDU's sister party, the CSU, has made no secret of his ambition to replace Ms Merkel as the main challenger to Chancellor Gerhard Schröder at next year's general election.

fields.headline: Lonely as a cloud
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District.
fields.body:
Tarn Hows, the most popular tourist "honey pot" in Lakeland, was completely deserted the other day with mine the only car and not a single walker. The weather was perfect - unbroken sunshine all day, cloudless, blue skies and patches of snow on the fells - but nobody around to enjoy it. The terrible scourge of foot and mouth had cleared the countryside.

There was no restriction on driving down and past the tarn, although all car parks were closed, but you were not allowed off the tarmac on to the paths. Tarn Hows is a place I usually avoid, because of the crowds, but it is, although an artificial creation, one of the most beautiful corners in Lakeland - especially when you have it to yourself. From the top of the hill leading down to the tarn, the craggy, east face of Wetherlam, almost filling the western sky, seemed to soar like an Alpine peak above the woodlands ringing the tarn, while a couple of swans decoratively cruised the mirrored waters.

Previous visits, begun nearly 80 years ago, were mostly for the skating when the sheltered tarn, surrounded by snowbound fells, seemed a winter paradise. We lunched, the other day, in a lofty, country inn which looked across at the sunlit Fairfield Horseshoe, and then, from Tarn Hows, drove round Coniston Water, with its many memories dating back to boyhood days.

We passed, in turn, Arthur Ransome's "Wildcat Island", the place where Donald Campbell somersaulted to his death and, on the other side of the lake, the site of our old, wooden hut from where, before the war, we explored the climbs on Dow Crag. Happier, less troubled days.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

A1 Dawn French made her Shakespearian debut in

(a) Twelfth Night

(b) A Midsummer Night's Dream

(c) The Taming of the Shrew

(d) Shakespeare in Love II: The Divorce

A2 Bottom is

(a) Where you start

(b) A rude word

(c) A Shakespearian character

(d) Where I always come in the darts tournament

A3 Drop the Dead Donkey was

(a) Cockney rhyming slang

(b) A topical C4 comedy series

(c) Drugs lingo for taking ecstasy.

(d) A knacker's yard in Stoke

A4 The winner of last year's Rear of the Year award was

(a) Chris Rea

(b) Denise Van Outen

(c) Graham Norton

(d) Very pert

A5 Fat bottomed girls ...

(a) tell Jerry Springer all about it

(b) should eat less lard

(c) you make the rockin' world go round

(d) take up more room on the bus
