fields.headline: Picks of the week
fields.trailText:
If you're only going to see one thing this week: The Bogus Woman

Kay Adshead tells it like it really is in this powerful story about an African journalist and refugee who is put through the mill of the British asylum system. An Edinburgh hit about Britain's abuse of human rights that Jack Straw should be forced to see and respond to. New Vic Studio, King Street, Bristol (0117-987 7877) Mon & Tue 7.30pm, £8.
fields.body:
If you're only going to see one thing this week: The Bogus Woman
Kay Adshead tells it like it really is in this powerful story about an African journalist and refugee who is put through the mill of the British asylum system. An Edinburgh hit about Britain's abuse of human rights that Jack Straw should be forced to see and respond to. New Vic Studio, King Street, Bristol (0117-987 7877) Mon & Tue 7.30pm, £8.

Pop

Monday: Low

An American, and incidentally two-thirds Mormon, three-piece, Low work quietness to its limits to beautiful effect. Their new album Things We Lost In The Fire further showcases their closely-harmonising husband-and-wife vocals. Concorde 2, Madeira Drive, Brighton (01273-207241) 8pm, £8-£9.

Wednesday: Nebula

Just one of the many thousands of American bands to have taken their influence from a heady cocktail of marijuana, Black Sabbath and a general concept of "the desert", the Californian Nebula still maintain a few, heavily struck, chords of individuality. Roadmender, Lady's Lane, Northampton (01604-604222) 8pm, £7.

Thursday: I Am Kloot

Although considered part of the New Acoustic Movement, Manchester's I Am Kloot are one of the least comfortable protagonists of the form. A wild-eyed committment shines from the eyes of the often-certifiable frontman, John Bramwell, and an edgy, prurient lyricism makes them all the weirder. Portland Arms, Chesterton Road, Cambridge (01223-357268) 8.30pm, £5.

Friday: Alfie

Following on from their appearance on the NME Carling Tour, a certain flakiness seems to have been pruned from Alfie's self-proclaimed "bumbling folk", and with this new proficiency in tow, to the ranks of talented Mancunians in woolly hats, they are a welcome addition. Louisiana, Wapping Rd, Bristol (0117-926 5978) 8pm, £6.
John Robinson

Classical

Monday: Magic Manon

Jules Massanet's Manon, inspired by Abbe Prevost's Manon Lescaut, is a fascinating and sympathetic musical portrait of this most compelling musical heroine. One of two shows offered by English Touring Opera, tonight is the Magic Flute, with Manon tomorrow. Haymarket Theatre, Belgrave Gate, Leicester (0116-253 9797) 7.30pm, £10-£15.

Thursday: Centre Stage

Part of a series of lunchtime concerts which give players from the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra a chance to perform chamber music: here Schubert's Octet in F. CBSO Centre, Broad Street, Birmingham (0121-780 3333) 1.10pm, £5. Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra

Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra

Wayne Marshall conducts Gershwin's jazzy piano concerto from the keyboard in a programme that also includes Borodin's second symphony and Ravel's Mother Goose suite. Repeated in Cheltenham on Friday. Great Hall, Exeter University, Exeter (01392-493493) 7.30pm, £8-£25.

Nutcracker Suite

The Russian Symphony Orchestra comes to Nottingham with a popular programme that includes Mussorgsky's Pictures At An Exhibition, Scriabin's piano concerto, and Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker Suite. Royal Concert Hall, Theatre Square, Nottingham (0115-989 5555) 7.30pm, £9-£20.

Friday: Ronald Smith

Not many pianists can be bothered with Charles-Valentin Alkan. His music belongs to the same school of intellectual pianism espoused by Liszt and Busoni, and demands huge stamina and a formidable technique. Ronald Smith is one of the few, here giving a recital in which Alkan's Le Festin d'Esope is surrounded by Chopin, Schubert and Liszt. St George's, Great George St, off Park St, Bristol (0117-923 0359) 7.30pm, £3-£10.
Christopher Lambton

Theatre

Passports To The Promised Land

Felix Cross's musical is about those who came to Britain in search of a better life. The music is always better than the drama, but the evening has such tongue-in-cheek good humour and it brings its protagonists' personal histories so vividly alive, that you can't help feeling well disposed towards it. Northcott, Stocker Road, Exeter (01392-493493) 7.30pm, £9-£15.

Coriolanus

Tobacco Factory's productions of Lear, Dream and Measure for Measure have been models of clear, simple storytelling, bringing Shakespeare urgently alive. So it is almost a sure thing that Andrew Hilton will pull it off with this tale of a soldier at war with himself. Tobacco Factory, Raleigh Rd, Bedminster, Bristol (0117-902 0344) Thur-Sat 7.30pm, Sat mat 2.30pm, £9-£15.

King John

Northern Broadsides already has an acclaimed version on the road. Now the RSC offers the brilliant Guy Henry as the king desperate to keep his throne. The Swan, Waterside, Stratford Upon Avon (01789-403403) 7.30pm, Wed only 7pm, Sat mat 1.30pm, £12-£34.

Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral

Bollywood comes to the stage with Tamasha's delightful musical, featuring romance, comedy, melodrama, tears and song. It is impossible not to enjoy yourself at this heartfelt, witty and imaginative evening. Bristol Old Vic, King Street, Bristol (0117-987 7877) Mon-Thur 7.30pm, Fri 8pm, Thur and Sat mat 2.30pm, £5-£22.50.
Lyn Gardner

Exhibitions

Charlotte Cornish

Inspired by her travels to Mexico and Macau, Cornish has created a series of abstract paintings that sit firmly in the John Hoyland, Albert Irvin tradition. Cambridge Contemporary Art, Trinity St, Cambridge (01223-315606) until 31 March, free.

Vanities And Virtues

Political satire, anti-Catholic propaganda and a few bloodthirsty battles thrown in for good measure - 17th-century printmakers were never short of inspiration. Here are some of the most sophisticated examples from engravers such as Lucas Vorsterman, and the diarist John Evelyn. National Museum and Gallery, Cathays Park, Cardiff (029-2039 7951) until 20 May, free.

Elenor Antin

Conceptual artist Eleanor Antin has been a prominent presence in the New York and Californian art scene for nearly 40 years. Born in the Bronx and the daughter of a Polish actress, Antin is a multimedia artist who uses fictional characters and narrative to question notions of identity. Arnolfini, Narrow Quay, Bristol (0117-929 9191) until 13 May, free.

A470

Eight Welsh artists have been commissioned to make work about the A470, the only road to run the entire length of Wales. Oriel Mostyn Gallery, Vaughn St, Llandundno (01492-879201) until 12 May, free.
Jessica Lack

Cinema

Best In Show

In this little gem of a comedy, director and co-writer Guest tells the story of the "Mayflower Dog Show", following the fraught lives of the key competitors and their tremulous, talented pooches. A nimble, agile, quick-witted, intelligent little film. (12) (Christopher Guest, 2000, US) Christopher Guest, Parker Posey. 90 mins ****

Blackboards

Can there be a more remarkable talent in world cinema than this young Iranian director, who has followed up her much-admired debut The Apple with this jewel of a film? It uses the unforgiving landscape of the Iran-Iraq border as the backdrop for a human tragicomedy, at first baffling, then diverting, then deeply engaging. (U) (Samira Makhmalbaf, 2000, Iran) Said Mohamadi, Bahman Ghobadi, Behnaz Jafari. 84 mins *****

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

2001 has got off to the best start possible with this fantastic film. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is a martial arts movie in a traditional Chinese action idiom which manages to be both electrifyingly exciting and sweetly romantic. (15) (Ang Lee, 2000, China/US) Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi. 120 mins *****

Requiem For A Dream

With utter mastery of technique, this adaptation of Hubert Selby Jr's novel shows an engaging young man's descent into heroin addiction, at the same time as his elderly mother gets hooked on diet pills. Chilling, and diamond-hard. (18) (Darren Aronofsky, 2000, US) Ellen Burstyn, Jared Leto. 102 mins ****

State And Main

Mamet's new work is an amiable comedy about a Hollywood crew invading a Vermont backwater. Hoffman plays an idealistic young dramatist who has sold his soul to the movies - specifically Macy's fast-talking director, into whose mouth pop comic jewels by the dozen. (15) (David Mamet, 2000, US) Alec Baldwin, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, William H Macy. 102 mins ***
Peter Bradshaw

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you.
fields.body:
 Don't let the fact that both brothers are safely in the ground fool you: the Kray twins are back with a vengeance. On Thursday, BBC1 screens its notorious deathbed interview with Reggie. You may remember the tabloid frenzy that erupted before Christmas, with various parties demanding that the BBC shelve the documentary after it was revealed that the terminally ill gangster was paid 200 "big boys" to participate. Not to be outdone, Channel 5 begins its series Hard Bastards on 27 March: profiles of some rather unpleasant characters from in a book by Kate Kray, Ronnie's wife. All we need now is a repeat of Monty Python's Doug and Dinsdale Piranha sketch and we've got the set.

 Meanwhile the BBC attempts to do to Jesus what it has already managed for dinosaurs with Son Of God, a new profile of The Chosen One. Highlights include digitally recreated versions of Bethlehem, capturing the atmosphere of the places in the Messiah's time. Incidentally, we're not suggesting that religion doesn't get the respect it deserves these days on television. But did the Beeb really have to broadcast the opening programme on 1 April?

 Jeremy Paxman presents the final of University Challenge on 2 April. After six years perfecting a superb Mr Nasty persona, it can surely only be a matter of time before he takes over from the Anne Robinson.

 Gary Rhodes - once the bright young thing of British cooking - takes over a revamped MasterChef on 3 April. Is this the fate awaiting all erstwhile bright young things? Jamie Oliver: take note.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Chinatown | Ravenous | Live Tennis
fields.body:
Films

Casper
(Brad Siberling, 1995)
5.30pm, The Studio

Warmhearted ghost story that has exorcist Bill Pullman contracted to clean out a haunted mansion by nasty heiress Cathy Moriarty and stooge Eric Idle. But Pullman's teenage daughter (Christina Ricci, in one of her striking early roles) takes to lonely Casper - an impressively rendered, computer generated ghost.

The Cruel Sea
(Charles Frend, 1953)
7pm, Carlton Cinema

Classic wartime adventure aboard a British corvette patrolling the north Atlantic in the second world war - a cold and forbidding place even without the German fleet. Eric Ambler's screenplay, from Nicholas Montsarrat's novel, encompasses both the tedium of long weeks at sea and the courage of men under fire. Jack Hawkins is the war-weary skipper, leading the likes of Stanley Baker, Donald Sinden, Denholm Elliott.

Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me
(Jay Roach, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

Yeah, baby, yeah, he's back: the psychedelically challenged superspy returns for a second duel with Dr Evil. Since the fizzy formula of the original International Man Of Mystery - crass jokes, spy-spoof buffoonery and swinging 60s stupidities - proved so potent at the box office, there seems little reason to change it. So Roach again directs, Mikes Myers again plays both Powers and his nemesis (plus the gruesome security man, Fat Bastard), while Heather Graham's Felicity Shagwell replaces Liz Hurley's Vanessa Kensington as the sexy sidekick. Great - but excruciating - fun.

Chinatown
(Roman Polanski, 1974)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Near faultless recreation of film noir, set in a dazzling 30s Los Angeles shaded by the themes of evil and corruption that seem to resonate in the Polanski psyche. Jack Nicholson is private eye JJ Gittes, Faye Dunaway the femme fatale, as a murder at a dam starts a tortuous trail towards lecherous old John Huston. Scriptwriter Robert Towne invests Gittes with a Chandleresque nobility.

Ravenous
(Antonia Bird, 1999)
10pm, Sky MovieMax

Forget Ridley Scott's toothless Hannibal: for a really unspeakable portrait of murderous cannibalism, this is the genuine article. Director Bird has fashioned a hilarious, bloody, gothic Western in which a small band of soldiers at a remote, snowy army outpost in the high Nevadas, circa 1847, are picked off by Robert Carlyle's demonic Colquhoun. It's a superb portrait of a gleeful maneater, with Guy Pearce as the horrified Captain Boyd, headed for a final showdown.

Sports

Live Tennis
5pm, British Eurosport/ONsport1

The best tennis players in the world get together for the Ericsson Open. But while it may be one tournament there are two broadcasters, with British Eurosport showing the women and the men on ONsport1. To add to the confusion, the men are playing their third round today while the women are on the fourth.

fields.headline: The old ones are the best
fields.standfirst: Historical documentaries are all the  rage. Why the sudden obsession with our own past? By Maggie Brown
fields.trailText: Historical documentaries are all the rage. Why the sudden obsession with our own past? By Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
We're told that history is written by the victors. Not any more. These days, it's told by those who happened to have cameras to hand. And if they were colour cameras, then so much the better.

The past three years have proved that large audiences on mainstream channels can be attracted by a certain sort of history programme. ITV's unexpected success in 1999 with World War Two In Colour, and the follow-up Britain At War, made a crucial breakthrough in peaktime because they were drawing on rarely seen colour archives. Then BBC1's Finest Hour last autumn movingly recalled the Battle of Britain through individual testimonies, though the makers dispensed with archive footage in favour of telling real stories, often with reconstructions.

The same mainstream approach, human interest stories to the fore, returns tonight with an ambitious if broad-brush stab at post-war social history. Yet Time Of Our Lives differs in a crucial aspect from these and other recent themed histories, including Channel 4's hit Elizabeth (about Queen Elizabeth I) and Simon Schama's History Of Britain. For it traces the changes wrought in ordinary lives by peacetime prosperity and social mobility. In some ways it is a high-risk project for ITV because it does not contain the kind of footage that has a proven track record of wowing audiences.

BBC Timewatch's biggest ever audience (4.3 million), recalls Laurence Rees, creative head of history for the BBC, was Hitler's Secret Weapons. At the other end of the spectrum, lightweight nostalgia programmes that look at popular culture through pop and video clips, find it possible to "do" 1982 without mentioning the Falklands War. "The history of history programmes on television tells us that the audience are interested in archive footage", says Rees. "But it's no guarantee that a programme will do well." "If we can bring an audience to Time Of Our Lives I know they will enjoy it", says David Liddiment, the programme director of ITV.

But is television really the right medium through which to tell stories stretching back more than a couple of decades? Adrian Wood, the film archivist who thought up World War Two In Colour, thinks so. "Actual footage and colour film in particular enables the viewer to identify with people. I remember going through archive footage of the refugees from the fall of Paris and the faces looked so very similar to those refugees caught in Bosnia-Herzegovina at the time."

But the simple idea behind Time Of Our Lives, devised by an independent production company, RDF, is to see postwar changes - the rise of feminism, the birth of the National Health Service, the increase in divorce - through the personal histories and verbal testimonies of three families, neatly divided into upper, middle and working class.

This is fairly conventional stuff: the (inevitable) decline and fall of the traditional upper class is supposedly represented by the fate of the Scottish Corbetts, an aristocratic family, shaken from the top of their tree by mismanagement, and the fatal liaison of the eldest son and heir with a transsexual model, April Ashley. The present Lord Rowallan talks of losing his castle, his possessions and his two wives. But by the third and final programme, he is remarkably happy with wife number three, running a show-jumping stable at a farm salvaged from the estate, while his son and heir is working as a west London estate agent.

One of the main criteria for selecting the families - the essential "casting" without which no "real people" shows on television ever proceed - says the show's producer Malcolm Clark, was the availability of film footage. For the middle-class doctor's family, the Ashworths from Didsbury, home movies were available from the late 50s. The Rowallan clan had starred in a BBC Scotland series in 1973. As for the engaging working-class family, the industrious East End Beardsells who achieve modest prosperity, buying shares and their council house and going on foreign holidays, Clark says: "We knew there wouldn't be any of them. Cameras were expensive, so we had to search for footage to illustrate their lives." One family member, Dora, describes her pride in making a converted Nissan hut into her first family home, as a news reel illustrates the shed-style houses.

Later Dora became a feted shop steward at the Ford Motor Company, heading a strike of women workers for fair pay, and was invited to lead a group onto the BBC's Terry Wogan show. In the 1990s, her story centres on how she briefly falls out over class with her daughter, who works in the City and married into a wealthier family - cue video footage of a white wedding in a marquee.

But Clark says: "Most important, more than the footage, was their stories. They had to be strong, they had to be representative of their class, but also have lively memories of what had happened.

"This series is about things we are familiar with, and, as a society, we underplay the changes. Yet when you put them all together, and look back over nearly 60 years, you realise how utterly things have changed. We find it hard to believe that we and our parents have in fact lived through amazing times. In part, this series is a celebration of how well we are doing."

At times the portentous music, swooping introductory camera work and laboured narration seem to load too great a significance on the highly selective accounts given by the three families, who are never allowed to demonstrate too much complexity. But, as Clark adds, he didn't pay any of the families to participate. "No one asked. It is amazing how much goo will you get for making a history."

All somewhat different from the worries about World War Two In Colour, and indeed other war series. Since there is no Japanese or Russian-shot colour footage of military engagements, the action is portrayed through American eyes and, (on the Russian front), from a German perspective. "Also, it is true that all the archives of Nazi and Russian engagements are shot by totalitarian regimes", adds Rees. "But at the end of the day, the debate, like all history, is the same: whatever the medium, be suspicious of the sources."

Wood says: "What we are doing is accessible history programmes for a large audience. I think these programmes also attract younger people who are mystified by it all. And it is hard to be a tourist in the Mediterranean and be more than 200 miles from a British war grave."

 Time Of Our Lives, 10.20pm, ITV.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Work In Progress | Look Back In Armour | It's My Story
fields.body:
Each morning this week Ken Arnold, a museum curator, offers an glimpse of the unseen efforts that underpin major exhibitions. He is currently preoccupied with a show for 2003. In Work In Progress (10.0am, Radio 3) he explains why the Phantom Museum is already occupying most of his waking hours. It will contain the wonderfully eclectic collection of medical equipment acquired by the Edwardian philanthropist Sir Edward Wellcome. Exhibits include anatomical drawings, African fetishes, and early x-ray machines.

Our obsession with the past is also explored by the American humourist Joe Queenan. In Look Back In Armour (11.0am, Radio 4) he joins a couple of historians and some of the enthusiasts who devote their leisure to the accurate recreation of historical events. One devotee uses most of his free hours producing authentically-crafted armour: another has become highly-skilled in medieval dressmaking.

Nigel Wrench has been wandering round North London to discover how deeply the area has been stirred by simmering Mediterranean passions. Green Lanes is the main artery slicing through Stoke Newington, centre of the capital's two Cypriot communities. Wrench discovers in It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4) that the tranquil atmosphere of adjacent Greek restaurants and Turkish barber shops is real enough. But there are deep animosities slumbering below the surface.

fields.headline: What big teeth you've got
fields.trailText: Natural World | The South Bank Show | Two Jags: The John Prescott Story
fields.body:
You learn something new every day. Sunday's new nugget of knowledge was that making cheese in Transylvania isn't easy. The shepherds who take sheep up to graze in the Carpathian Mountains and then milk them three times a day to make the cheese have to do all of that AND watch out for the wolves and bears. And they have to do all of this for little payment in old-fashioned money in often freezing temperatures.

Yet, as Natural World (BBC2, Sunday) explained, the shepherds who watch their flocks by night don't detest the predators with whom they share the mountainside. They don't call for their extermination or hunt them into extinction. They are remarkably sanguine about the beasts who sometimes carry off one of their charge, and this relationship was at the captivating heart of the consistently ambitious Natural World. With the workings of the ominously named Carpathian Large Carnivore Project (does Dracula count as a large carnivore?) and elegant footage of wolves - the most handsome of animals - also on display, this was a considered and charming documentary.

The same cannot be said of The South Bank Show (ITV, Sunday). Sorely disappointing, its subject Bill Bryson remained strangely unknown at the end of the hour. For a flagship arts programme - in a fleet of one sailing under an ITV banner - there was irritatingly little satisfying analysis of his work or his success (other than someone in a bookshop offering the profound "He's really funny"). The flimsiest of biographical details were offered and not much more was teased out. Even those who delight at his work must have found the whole thing hardly worth the effort. Instead, The South Bank Show was an hour- long advertisement for Bryson's writing, Roy Hattersley's diatribe notwithstanding, and one which didn't even advertise the product all that well.

As you might expect, Two Jags: The John Prescott Story (Channel 5, Sunday) wasn't an in-depth, intelligent biography of the deputy prime minister (and someone whom the Carpathian Large Carnivore Project would more than willingly electronically tag, until they found out he's a bit of a toothless beastie). While not introduced by a couple of lap dancers, it nonetheless followed the house style at Channel 5 by employing The Most Annoying Voiceover In Television.

That breathlessly excited, showbizzy narrator who would say "Tony Blair is the Prime Minister" in a way that made it sound like a saucy revelation was working overtime with this bog standard look at Le Prescott's life. "He worked on a cruise ship!"; "He's working class!"; "He has a wife called Pauline!" Such incisive commentary, Michael Cockerell better watch his back. Clearly researched by an illiterate chimp, what Two Jags: The John Prescott Story did have going for it was Prescott himself, who was altogether rather jolly and seemed ever-so-nice for a politician.

A documentary which screamed "Accompanied by a book and a CD of music from the series", Walk On By (BBC2, Sunday) was nevertheless a glorious confection. Telling the story of popular song, jazz was the focus for this accomplished, why-didn't-someone-think-of-this-before programme. In its examination of the symbiotic relationship between Louis Armstrong and Bing Crosby, the rise of the singer to the cost of the big band which Crosby exemplified, and the appearance of Frank Sinatra (who looks awfully like Jamie from EastEnders), Walk On By also showed flashes of American social history. As such, it was quite delightful.

In tackling such a huge project, it would have been understandable if Walk On By rattled along with little more than nods in the direction of some singers and songwriters, but all things considered, its pace didn't mean a sacrifice of subject matter. There was quite a dazzling array of talking - and singing and playing - heads, all of whom were employed skilfully and judiciously. Syncopated stuff.

And now, the end is near (to coin a phrase), let us say well done to John Cleese, who deserves a bit of a handshake for putting up with Elizabeth Hurley for the duration of the populist but far from dumb The Human Face (BBC1, Sunday) without lunging for her in a murderous style. Not just a pretty face.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: A woman's work is never done
fields.trailText: For Richer For Poorer
fields.body:
Growing up, and into journalism, John Pilger was never the role model. The late Martha Gellhorn it was, always, for her bravery in the day job (she was active in the pacifist movement, and then reported on the Spanish Civil War and the rise of Hitler) and her private life. She married Hemingway; that always scored her more brownie points than any assignment.

So it was with crushing disappointment that I endured the adaptation of her novel For Richer For Poorer, the Saturday Play (Radio 4). It was lovingly and smartly done by people, I'd guess, as much in Gellhorn-awe as me. But what a stinker, what an anti-feminist piece by one of the women whose lives made it all possible for those of us following on.

It's a comedy of manners set in the 1940s, and there are some fine swipes at the class system and the vacuity of many upper-class women of the time. One worries only about "trying to find tennis knickers that are in any way flattering to a woman approaching 40". But its real target is Rose Anwell, a woman from humble origins determined to climb to the top of the political ladder via her soft, sweet husband Alan, a "brainless and beautiful" backbencher.

He sounds as if he'd be happier in The Archers than in any position of political power, but Rose drags him from his passions (farming and reading bedtime stories to his children) to transform him into Colonial Secretary. Her stop-at-nothing ambition and his decency are so generously ladled into the play as to make Rose not just misguided but power-crazed and cruel. Why Gellhorn should have wanted to create this scenario is beyond me.

So Alan reads to his children, and they say "Mummy's always cross with us"; he says "I hardly ever see the children"; Rose tells her son "only crybabies are afraid of the dark." When her sister Violet ("dreary, blasted Violet") comes to dinner, heartbroken as she suspects her husband is having an affair, Alan is sympathetic, Rose is on the phone all evening to Downing Street.

After one too many taunts, Alan has had enough. Heroically he asks "what of our lives is of my choosing?" and declares he is going back to farming. Rose divorces him and marries Lord Tippington, old but very powerful.

To the last minute, I kept hoping for something to reveal this a spoof of anti-feminist attitudes. But no, all we are left with is an image of Alan, happy with his cows, and Rose, happy in her social ascent but heartless, and a warning to us all.

Her stop-at-nothing ambition and his decency are so generously ladled into the play as to make Rose not just misguided but power-crazed and cruel. Why Gellhorn should have wanted to create this scenario is beyond me. So Alan reads to his children, and they say "Mummy's always cross with us"; he says "I hardly ever see the children"; Rose tells her son "only crybabies are afraid of the dark." When her sister Violet ("dreary, blasted Violet") comes to dinner, heartbroken as she suspects her husband is having an affair, Alan is sympathetic, Rose is on the phone all evening to Downing Street. After one too many taunts, Alan has had enough. Heroically he asks "what of our lives is of my choosing?" and declares he is going back to farming. Rose divorces him and marries Lord Tippington, old but very powerful. To the last minute, I kept hoping for something to reveal this a spoof of anti-feminist attitudes. But no, all we are left with is an image of Alan, happy with his cows, and Rose, happy in her social ascent but heartless, and a warning to us all.

fields.headline: Driving us mad
fields.standfirst: It's no accident that every other programme these days involves a car. Is the BBC's latest exploration of Britain's love affair with wheels a worthy addition to the range?
fields.trailText: It's no accident that every other programme these days involves a car. Is the BBC's latest exploration of Britain's love affair with wheels a worthy addition to the range?
fields.body:
Whatever the quality of a movie or television programme of the past, it risks looking ridiculous when the characters get into a car. Driving scenes have dated more than most other aspects of entertainment. Watching an actor clutching a fake steering wheel while footage of receding hedgerows and houses is projected on a screen behind them makes us laugh, now that producers can attach a camera to a truly moving car and accurately reproduce the windscreen view.

Like all breakthrough devices, the technology is probably over-used. There are times when every television programme seems to be a road movie. It's routine now for current affairs presenters to deliver their links at the wheel: you keep wanting to shout "look at the road". And after the docu-soap Driving School (with Maureen of the eternal L-plates), and Motorway Patrol, and other compilations of bad-driver footage, the generic traffic jam is lengthened by Mean Streets (BBC1), which promises to assess "Britons and their driving skills". Just as the word "news" essentially means bad news, so driving programmes are unlikely to include much footage of people executing perfect three-point turns.

The most frightening driver in the opening programme is Malcolm, who began motoring in 1933, before tests were introduced. This historical accident resulted in non-qualified drivers being allowed on the roads and in turn resulted in car accidents. There are few such drivers left now, and on this evidence, it's surprising that Malcolm has lasted to be one of them.

When the driving assessor - sent by the old man's doctor to see if his licence should be taken away - asks Malcolm to read a number plate in the distance, you seriously wonder whether he can even see the car. His hands shake so uncontrollably that, reading his test report, he looks like a theatre stage-hand flapping the thunder-sheet. When the assessor returns to the house for a second appointment, a bewildered Malcolm reacts as if he's a burglar.

Malcolm's infirmity is so considerable and distressing that you feel uneasy watching, like rubber-neckers at the car crash he is surely heading for. The BBC production guidelines warn against filming people who may not be capable of understanding what such exposure means, and Malcolm must have been a tough decision in this respect. But the scene in which he finally cleans out his car before retiring it is deeply pow erful: a moment of real bereavement, in a culture in which wheels have largely replaced feet.

While exceptions can be made in America for the Seinfields and the Tyler Moores, it's usually dismaying when the star of a British comedy has the same name on both the fictional and factual sides of the cast list. In the sitcom Lee Evans - So What Now? (BBC1), the comedian identified in the title plays a bloke called Lee.

In the rest of the show, there's a Steven playing a Stuart, a Sophie being a Heather and a Stewart submersed in the role of a Terry. (You keep wondering if the real Stewart auditioned for the part of the fictional Stuart. Then, as later credits show that Lee wrote it with a Stuart, it's tempting to speculate why Stuart didn't simply play Stuart, though perhaps he admits he can't act.) Lee, however, is attempting a character called Lee.

This always seems to me an unwisely frank admission that no acting will be taking place, a fear further encouraged here by the unusual decision to place a star's name in front of a sitcom title in the manner of a pop album. The assumption is that viewers are tuning in to see the twisty-faced slapsticker from There's Something About Mary and Mouse Hunt and it's silly to interpose anything as distracting as a newly imagined character.

But then the plot doesn't bother much with disguising the fact that we've seen it before as well. This is a flat-share comedy in which Lee and Stuart, loveless and homeless men, become the tenants of a nymphomaniac single woman.

Evans's basic shtick is a Mr Bean who speaks dialogue but, on this occasion, you keep hoping he'll explore silent comedy. The best comedy is observational, but the observation here seems mainly to be taking place in a rear-view mirror. Lee's job - writing ringing tunes for mobile phones - is undeniably modern, and there's an attempted gag about a woman having thrush, but most of the other references have the feel of the 1950s, when Lee Evans's comic hero, Norman Wisdom, was at his peak.

Lee (or should that be "Lee"?) twice refers to the "box room" in his flat. This is a world in which men are tormented by ancient and fierce landladies, and in which husbands arrive home to find that their disgruntled wives have left a packed suitcase of their possessions at the door. It's a surprise that no blushing vicars or women in voluminous spotted bloomers come round for tea.

The direction mainly consists of leaving spaces for Evans to do his faces. He does them efficiently, but most viewers will be making them back at him. This show in which Lee is playing Lee is so bad that the comedian really ought to change his name. I'm thinking of the witness protection programme.

 Mean Streets, Wednesday, 8.35pm, BBC1. Lee Evans - So What Now?, Monday, 8.30pm, BBC1.

fields.headline: David McTaggart
fields.standfirst: Campaigner who led from the front in making Greenpeace a worldwide organisation
fields.trailText: David McTaggart, who has died in a car crash aged 68, was the man who built Greenpeace into a worldwide organisation. He was seen by many in the environment movement as a tenacious hero, and a pioneer of non-violent direct action.
fields.body:
David McTaggart, who has died in a car crash aged 68, was the man who built Greenpeace into a worldwide organisation. He was seen by many in the environment movement as a tenacious hero, and a pioneer of non-violent direct action. Others, notably the French government, treated him at times like a terrorist.

Despite his extraordinary flair in gaining publicity for the causes he believed in, McTaggart was an intensely private man. He rarely talked about himself and when he did some of the stories were so surprising it was hard to believe them, yet he had amazing contacts, astonishing adventures and successes - notably stopping the French continuing atmospheric testing on nuclear weapons in the 1970s, and a seven-year campaign, ending in 1991, to save Antarctica from mining.

He was born in Vancouver, British Columbia, and nothing about his early life gave a hint of what was to follow. He said his family had a long history of Scottish Calvinism, although apart from a strong work ethic and an absolute belief in non-violence the rest of the family ideals seem to have passed him by. He smoked heavily, often drank a lot, and his language was peppered with expletives even when mixing with senior diplomats and politicians. He had at least two wives and a number of daughters, finally fathering a much wanted son when in his early 60s.

McTaggart's teens were spent skiing, playing tennis, squash and golf. He particularly excelled at badminton, becoming three times Canadian national champion, the first time while still a junior. He had left school at 17, went into the construction business and for 20 years built up a very large business, first in Canada and then in the United States. All this came to an abrupt end when an explosion wrecked a ski lodge he was building in Bear Mountain, east of San Francisco. Several workers were hurt in the accident and he blamed himself - paying out a considerable part of the fortune he had amassed in compensation.

This accident changed his life. He abandoned his wife and children, bought a yacht, the Vega, and set off on a trip round the Pacific to find out about himself - as he put it.

Three years later he was still travelling rather aimlessly when he answered an advertisement asking for volunteers to sail to Mururoa to protest at the French government still doing atmospheric nuclear tests, when the rest of the world had already agreed to go underground.

The advertisement was placed by Greenpeace, a fledgling organisation that, using Quaker techniques, had originally protested against US tests in the Canadian Pacific but had no volunteers in the southern hemisphere.

The next bit of the story, told in McTaggart's long out of print book Greenpeace III, Journey into the Bomb, reads like a Boys Own adventure. By his own account he was more annoyed by the French government's unilateral decision to close part of the Pacific to all shipping than about the issue of nuclear testing, but his encounters with the French changed all that.

Despite every effort of the New Zealand government to stop him leaving, and a cat and mouse game with the French navy, he succeeded in holding up the tests by sailing within a few miles of the about to be detonated bomb, daring them to kill him. His tiny yacht was eventually rammed and taken in tow by a minesweeper, an action the French tried to pass off as a rescue.

It was a lesson in propaganda he was not to forget. The yacht was boarded again and he was badly beaten by French commandos, nearly losing the sight of an eye. The French tried to claim he had an accident, but the graphic photographs on a film taken by a fellow crew member and smuggled out in her vagina showed the French lied and gave McTaggart worldwide publicity. The French abandoned atmospheric testing.

Although in his mid-40s, McTaggart set about creating a Greenpeace in Europe, finding like-minded people and setting up national organisations. The British branch started in 1978 and was run by Peter Wilkinson, a former Friends of the Earth campaigner. By 1979 Greenpeace was unified across the Atlantic and McTaggart was running it - remaining chairman until 1991.

The swashbuckling David and Goliath image of Greenpeace, with idealistic campaigners in tiny rubber boats placing themselves between whaling boats and the whales, or ships dumping nuclear waste and the ocean, appealed to the public. McTaggart made sure that where his boats went film crews went too.

The most astonishing miscalculation by the French in 1985, when they sent two secret service agents to sink the Greenpeace flagship in New Zealand on the eve of a new trip to Mururoa, transformed Greenpeace into a huge organisation. Money poured in from all over the world and it was able to run a fleet of ships and dozens of campaigns at once.

McTaggart held on to the reins of power for another five years but the organisation became too big and too bureaucratic for his rough and ready style of management. Although he remained immensely influential, Greenpeace pushed him aside.

Despite these changed circumstances he continued to campaign and attended every International Whaling Commission meeting. His job as he saw it was to lobby behind the scenes with the people he knew, and until his death he ran an organisation called the Third Millennium Foundation. Its latest project was a Caribbean-wide convention to protect the marine environment.

McTaggart lived at Paciano in Italy, where he grew olives, but still travelled to campaign. In 1995 he sailed with three others back into the Mururoa test zone and went into hiding on the atoll to frustrate the underground tests. When discovered, he spent three weeks as part of a protest peace flotilla outside the exclusion zone, long after Greenpeace's two big ships, the Rainbow Warrior and the Greenpeace, had been boarded and captured by French marines. His reward, bobbing about in the Pacific once more, was to see the French finally abandon all testing in the Pacific - a victory that took 22 years to achieve.

David McTaggart, environment campaigner, born June 23 1932; died March 23 2001

fields.headline: Michele Hanson
fields.standfirst: Who's for heavyweight mutilation?
fields.trailText: Daughter and her friend came to stay last week and left behind a copy of a girlie magazine. I haven't read one for decades, so I leafed through it. What a fright.
fields.body:
Daughter and her friend came to stay last week and left behind a copy of a girlie magazine. I haven't read one for decades, so I leafed through it. What a fright. I remember this was always rather a bold and saucy magazine, but now I don't know quite what to call it. It put my mother right off her hot cross bun.

The horror was in the detail, not just the harping on about bums, bosoms, penises and testicles, but the minutiae of what one is to do with them. I did spot one bit of sensible advice - "Do not bite testicles" - but then I gave up.

It was much too rude for me and rather a worry. Are the Daughter and her chum taking all this to heart? Are they obeying the magazine's instructions? And not just the A-levels in how to fiddle with men's bits but, even worse, the acres of adverts for cosmetic surgery.

I had no idea surgery was so popular, living mainly indoors with the dog and my mother as I do. I realised that film stars and the flobby elderly perhaps went for it in a big way, but here was my own child and her peers being targeted. There was I worrying about Daughter's piercing and sunbeds when there is heavyweight mutilation available out there to anyone, at bargain prices: have your inverted nipples sucked out, your flab sucked away, a chunk of bum or thigh sliced off, some extra bosom stuffed in.

Last week, for the first time, I plucked my moustache. This was a sad moment for me and a painful one. I could only manage a bit at a time without almost fainting. But imagine being hacked about and sewn up like a quilt. Can it be worth it?

I read out a mild bit of the magazine to Fielding, but he went queasy and begged me to stop. Bodily functions have never been his forte. However, he does have a chum who's had a face lift. She looks as if she has just passed through a wind tunnel and seems to be permanently surprised. And Mrs Fielding has heard some tragic stories - hideous scars after tummy tucks, big bobbly bits growing after cellulite removal, breast implants going lumpy in the cold and seeping silicone.

I partly blame that magazine. Obviously one's body is no longer a temple. I wish it were.

fields.headline: Algerian's record battle against extradition
fields.standfirst: Doubts over French law keep Home Office pondering
fields.trailText: A 31-year-old Algerian, believed to be the longest serving remand prisoner in Britain, has spent nearly five and a half years in jail fighting a politically sensitive extradition request from France for alleged terrorist offences.
fields.body:
A 31-year-old Algerian, believed to be the longest serving remand prisoner in Britain, has spent nearly five and a half years in jail fighting a politically sensitive extradition request from France for alleged terrorist offences.

Rachid Ramda, a category A prisoner in Belmarsh high security prison in south London, is wanted on charges of being involved in a series of bomb attacks on the Paris Metro during the summer of 1995 in which 10 people were killed and more than 200 injured. It is alleged that while living in London as a journalist, he was the financier for the Algerian Armed Islamic Group (GIA) which claimed responsibility for the bombings.

But as part of his defence his lawyers have launched a comprehensive assault on the French criminal justice system and anti-terrorist laws, both of which have been extensively criticised by international human rights organisations.

Home Office officials have spent the past 18 months agonising over what they call his "complex and voluminous representations".

The system, his lawyers allege, is institutionally racist, with Muslim defendants denied basic rights. The anti-terrorism court in Paris, the cour d'assises spéciale pour les affaires de terrorisme, is accused of lacking fundamental safeguards for a fair trial. Appeals are not allowed except on a point of law. There is no provision for the seven-judge panel to stay a prosecution because of pre-trial publicity.

In Ramda's case the minister of justice said in a widely-reported statement that he had played a role "essential to the bombing campaign", a remark criticised in the London high court by Lord Justice Pill in Ramda's first application for habeas corpus.

The representations also claim that the catch-all charge against Ramda, of taking part in a criminal conspiracy relating to terrorism, has been ridiculed by human rights observers as the equivalent of a medieval witchhunt. It attracted particular obloquy after the fiasco of the Chalabi trial in 1999 when 138 Muslims accused of supporting the GIA were prosecuted en masse under the same charge. The trial was criticised by Amnesty International on a range of grounds as violating international fair trial standards.

At the end of the appeal procedure last year 55 of the accused had been acquitted and compensation awards of 2m francs were made. None was found guilty of violence.

One of the acquitted complained to the European court of human rights about the length of time he spent in prison on remand. In the judgment the French courts were castigated for lack of diligence.

Finally, the French government is accused of complicity with the Algerian regime. Last month a former Algerian army officer, Habib Souaidia, published a book claiming that the Algerian troops are as guilty of civilian atrocities as the Islamist militants. It led to a statement by prominent French and Algerian intellectuals which said: "For too long the French government has supported Algerian policy which aims at nothing less than the eradication, both political and physical, of any opposition whatsoever."

Ramda arrived in Britain in 1992 and became the editor of the GIA newsletter El Ansar. He was arrested on November 4, 1995, following the detention in Paris of Boualem Bensaid, the GIA's alleged coordinator in France. Bensaid was sentenced to 10 years on the broad conspiracy charge and for 30 years for a failed attack in 1995 on the Lyon to Paris TGV.

The evidence against Ramda is largely based on money transfers from London to Bensaid and intercepted telephone calls.

French frustration at the delay in resolving the case was reflected in the third international arrest warrant being issued against him in January. A spokesman for the French embassy in London said regular requests were made to the Home Office about the progress of the case.

A Home Office press officer said the representations were being given "detailed" consideration. "We have been in close touch with the French authorities and we received a response in mid-February. We hope to complete our work with the minimum of delay."

The trial was criticised by Amnesty International on a range of grounds as violating international fair trial standards. At the end of the appeal procedure last year 55 of the accused had been acquitted and compensation awards of 2m francs were made. None was found guilty of violence. One of the acquitted complained to the European court of human rights about the length of time he spent in prison on remand. In the judgment the French courts were castigated for lack of diligence. Finally, the French government is accused of complicity with the Algerian regime. Last month a former Algerian army officer, Habib Souaidia, published a book claiming that the Algerian troops are as guilty of civilian atrocities as the Islamist militants. It led to a statement by prominent French and Algerian intellectuals which said: "For too long the French government has supported Algerian policy which aims at nothing less than the eradication, both political and physical, of any opposition whatsoever." Ramda arrived in Britain in 1992 and became the editor of the GIA newsletter El Ansar. He was arrested on November 4, 1995, following the detention in Paris of Boualem Bensaid, the GIA's alleged coordinator in France. Bensaid was sentenced to 10 years on the broad conspiracy charge and for 30 years for a failed attack in 1995 on the Lyon to Paris TGV. The evidence against Ramda is largely based on money transfers from London to Bensaid and intercepted telephone calls. French frustration at the delay in resolving the case was reflected in the third international arrest warrant being issued against him in January. A spokesman for the French embassy in London said regular requests were made to the Home Office about the progress of the case. A Home Office press officer said the representations were being given "detailed" consideration. "We have been in close touch with the French authorities and we received a response in mid-February. We hope to complete our work with the minimum of delay."

fields.headline: Hell for leatherbacks
fields.standfirst: Turtle conservation scheme launched
fields.trailText: An attempt to save endangered marine turtles was launched yesterday by the environment minister, Michael Meacher, in London. The Marine Conservation Society's turtle programme aims to protect the creatures in waters around Britain and its overseas territories.
fields.body:
An attempt to save endangered marine turtles was launched yesterday by the environment minister, Michael Meacher, in London. The Marine Conservation Society's turtle programme aims to protect the creatures in waters around Britain and its overseas territories.

MCS species policy officer Peter Richardson said: "Few Britons know that the world's largest marine turtle, the leatherback, regularly frequents UK waters.

Leatherback turtles migrate vast distances from their nesting beaches in the Caribbean to arrive in British waters during the summer in order to feed on jellyfish, their favourite prey. Scientists estimate the global leatherback population to be as low as 25,000.

The creatures, so called because of their leathery shell, face a variety of threats at their tropical nesting beaches and at sea.

Leatherbacks mistake floating litter such as balloons and carrier bags for jellyfish and eat them. Once ingested, plastic can block the turtle's gut, leading to slow death by starvation.

Press Association

webTitle: Doctor suspended after mistakes in patient tests

fields.headline: Doctor suspended after mistakes in patient tests
fields.trailText: A health trust yesterday apologised to hundreds of patients who had to have their cases reviewed after a doctor made mistakes while checking test results. Dr Georg Brox was a consultant histopathologist who studied slides and samples to diagnose conditions including cancer.
fields.body:
A health trust yesterday apologised to hundreds of patients who had to have their cases reviewed after a doctor made mistakes while checking test results. Dr Georg Brox was a consultant histopathologist who studied slides and samples to diagnose conditions including cancer.

He worked at Crawley hospital in West Sussex, and East Surrey hospital in Redhill between January and April last year, when concerns were raised by a fellow doctor.

Checks were carried out on all 1,780 tests by Dr Brox and it was found that nine patients had received the wrong treatments, including drugs they did not need. A further 10 patients had not been called back for more tests at the right time.

No-one has died and no-one's condition has been made worse as a result of the doctor's failures, a trust spokesman said yesterday.

Dr Brox was sent for assessment at a large teaching hospital after concerns were first raised, and his professional performance was found to be below standard.

He was immediately suspended and an external review by the Royal College of Pathologists also concluded his work was "unacceptable".

He has been reported to the General Medical Council, and all NHS trusts in Britain have been alerted about him. As Dr Brox is a German national and qualified in that country, the German authorities have also been notified.

A trust spokesman said his qualifications and his language skills met requirements for work in a British hospital.

Trust chief executive Ken Cunningham said: "Any misinterpretation by a histopathologist, which affects patient treatment, is a matter of deep regret and great concern.

"But in this particular case I believe our system of checks and balances worked well in picking up this problem and dealing with it."

Mike Stone, spokesman for the Patients' Association, welcomed the trust's decision to suspend the doctor.

"The hospital has done the right thing by suspending him and has taken appropriate measures to protect patients," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Britons 'given jail beating'
fields.body:
Britons 'given jail beating'

Two Britons accused of drug crimes in the United Arab Emirates told a court yesterday they had been beaten in custody.

But a police chief told the court that Danielle Mallouf, 28, from London, and Stacey Simpson, 25, from Leeds, had made statements willingly.

£2,000 fine for sweetening river

Sweet maker Trebor Bassett has been fined £2,000 by magistrates for pumping cooling water contaminated with sugar back into the River Medway at Maidstone, Kent. Its factory, Kreemy Works, broke an undertaking with the environment agency over using the water as a result of a technical failure.

Trainspotter's delight

The National Railway Museum in York is to get its first foreign exhibit - the driving coach from a Japanese electric Shinkansen or "bullet train" that goes at up to 187mph and launched a new era in rail travel in 1964, when British Rail still had steam engines.

Sleep warning to obese drivers

Medical researchers today warn lorry drivers who are overweight to seek help if they think they might have sleep apnoea - heavy snoring at night and excessive sleepiness or fatigue during the day. An RAC survey found 34% of drivers doing 20,000 miles a year or more confessed to having fallen asleep at the wheel.

Bedroom chums for Michael

Singer Michael Jackson has 17 lifesized dolls, dressed to look like real adults and children, in his bedroom for "company". The claim is made by his interior decorator, Charmian Carr, in an ITV documentary tomorrow on the children in The Sound of Music. Carr, who was Liesl Von Trapp, said she became friendly with Jackson because he was a fan of the film.

Four share £20m jackpot

Four tickets shared Saturday's £20m lottery jackpot, with winning numbers 6, 25, 31, 32, 42 and 43; bonus ball 38. There were no lottery extra winners; numbers were 11, 24, 35, 38, 41 and 43.

webTitle: Former top policewoman to face charge of assaulting taxi driver

fields.headline: Former top policewoman to face charge of assaulting taxi driver
fields.trailText: Alison Halford, formerly Britain's highest ranking woman police officer, is to be prosecuted for allegedly attacking a taxi driver outside her home, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Alison Halford, formerly Britain's highest ranking woman police officer, is to be prosecuted for allegedly attacking a taxi driver outside her home, police said yesterday.

North Wales police launched an investigation into the alleged assault in January after a formal complaint was made against the former Merseyside assistant chief constable, who is now the Labour Welsh assembly member for Delyn.

A police spokesman said yesterday: "We can confirm that a woman has been reported for summons in connection with an alleged common assault and public disorder.

"She will be appearing at a magistrates court at a later date."

Ms Halford, 60, who was the first woman in the country to rise to the rank of assistant chief constable, was accused of assaulting Mold taxi driver Martin Blake during a disagreement about her dog outside her home in Ewloe, north Wales.

She had heard that the crown prosecution service had decided there was a case for her to answer at the end of last week, a Wales Labour party spokesman confirmed.

He said the party would not comment on the case but added that Ms Halford had always "denied the allegations very vigorously".

The Welsh assembly had noted the fact that proceed ings are taking place, a spokeswoman said, adding: "It would not be appropriate to comment at this time until we know the outcome of the court case."

Ms Halford, who spent 30 years as a police officer, famously fought and won a sex discrimination case against Merseyside police in 1992.

In 1997 she won a phone-tapping case against the home secretary and the government in the European court of human rights.

She hit the headlines again in December 1999 after causing uproar in the Welsh assembly chamber when, during a debate, she told the Tory chief whip, David Davies, he had "one of the nicest bottoms I have seen".

fields.headline: Pioneer Concorde pilot dies aged 77
fields.trailText: The Concorde test pilot Brian Trubshaw, who became every schoolboy's hero after taking the aircraft on its maiden British flight, has died aged 77.
fields.body:
The Concorde test pilot Brian Trubshaw, who became every schoolboy's hero after taking the aircraft on its maiden British flight, has died aged 77.

The short hop from Filton, Bristol, to RAF Fairford in Gloucestershire in Concorde 002 on April 9, 1969, heralded the age of supersonic commercial air travel and made him a household name.

His love affair with Concorde continued for the rest of his life, and he was a staunch defender of the aircraft after the fatal crash of one of the fleet in Paris last year.

On the decision to ground the fleet he said: "It's easy to jump in and ground aeroplanes. It's not so easy to un-ground them. But I don't believe there's a technical problem that can't be overcome."

A painting of Concorde was displayed at his home near Tetbury, Gloucestershire, where he died on Saturday. "I'm still impressed to think of all those people having their roast beef and champagne behind you while you're cruising at a speed slightly faster than a rifle bullet," he said last year.

Concorde's current chief pilot, Mike Bannister, said: "Brian's dedication to aviation, particularly the development of new aircraft, will remain a legacy for years to come."

Howard Berry, spokesman for Concorde's joint-manufacturer BAE Systems, said Mr Trubshaw "gained fame not just in the UK but abroad as well".

Last night a British Airways spokesman said: "Everyone in BA who worked with him could not help but be inspired by his continued enthusiasm and joy for Concorde."

Recalling the day he made history, Mr Trubshaw had said: "It was an awesome experience for myself and my crew. Deep down we were full of emotion, but there was little sign of it as we settled down to our task."

After he joined the RAF in 1942 his flying abilities were rated as exceptional, and after service as a bomber pilot he joined the prestigious King's Flight in 1946.

He was released from the RAF on the understanding that he joined Vickers-Armstrong as a test pilot on V-bombers.

In 1962 the British and French governments agreed to develop a supersonic transport aircraft, and he was selected to be a test pilot.

He retired as general manager and director at the British Aerospace works at Filton in 1986, but remained an aviation consultant.

He did not marry until he was 50. His widow, Yvonne, has a terror of flying.

webTitle: Barristers at war with Irvine over fees cut

fields.headline: Barristers at war with Irvine over fees cut
fields.standfirst: Lord chancellor to offer QCs £125 an hour for legal aid cases
fields.trailText: Barristers are fighting the lord chancellor over his plans to cut defence QCs' legal aid rates in the most expensive criminal cases from £300 or more an hour to £125.
fields.body:
Barristers are fighting the lord chancellor over his plans to cut defence QCs' legal aid rates in the most expensive criminal cases from £300 or more an hour to £125.

Lord Irvine is determined to reduce the burden to the taxpayer of the 1% of cases -mainly fraud, murder and drugs cases lasting more than 25 days - which consume 40% of the legal aid budget for crown court cases.

Under the current system, barristers submit a bill at the end of the case for whatever they think their work is worth. Costs judges in the courts decide whether to allow the bill in full or knock something off.

Lord Irvine believes the costs judges are often too generous and the cost to the taxpayer too uncertain. The Bar Council has told him that costs judges regard hourly rates of £300 plus as reasonable for defence QCs.

The Bar says the serious fraud office pays prosecuting QCs between £125 and £215 per hour, and the crown prosecution service between £120 and £175 an hour.

For barristers defending in fraud cases, Lord Irvine proposes average hourly rates of £125 for QCs, £100 for juniors (non-QCs) supported by a more junior barrister, and £70 for juniors acting alone. For non-fraud cases, QCs will be paid £105 an hour and leading juniors £85.

These rates will amount to a 40% cut for defence lawyers and 25% for prosecutors, the Bar claims.

As part of the crackdown on fees, Lord Irvine recently intervened in court assessments of fees in two of the most expensive fraud cases of the 1990s - the Maxwell case and the prosecution of Abbas Gokal, who was convicted of fraud after the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.

In January the courts ordered four QCs - Michael Hill and Clare Montgomery from the Maxwell case and Colin Nicholls and Philip Hackett, who defended Gokal - to hand back a total of £90,000 in legal aid fees.

The Lord Chancellor's Department has also passed on to the Bar Council the names of more than 100 barristers reported by the courts for over-charging.

All have had their legal aid bills cut by at least 50% in the last two years.

Mark Stobbs, head of professional standards at the Bar Council, said: "It was clear to us that in the vast majority of cases there was no element of dishonesty or incompetence. There were about 30 which we thought we ought to look at further." Those found guilty of dishonesty could be fined, suspended from practice or disbarred.

Over the last few months the Bar has fought a hard battle with the lord chancellor on two other fronts: over his plans to introduce a range of set fees for family work and to extend a similar scheme already used for criminal trials of under 10 days to those lasting from 11-25 days.

Lord Irvine originally proposed to cut family barristers' fees by 15-20% but the Bar persuaded him to make a number of changes, limiting the cut to only 5%. Barristers, who claim the cuts will be much deeper for the more complex cases, are angry that they coincide with increases of 10-25% for family law solicitors to stop them deserting legal aid family work.

The extended criminal scheme for cases lasting up to 25 days, which was due to come into force next month, has been postponed while officials deal with objections by the Bar's negotiating team.

The annual report of the Bar's complaints commissioner, published today, says 84 of the 569 complaints against barristers in 2000 came from the Bar Council itself, compared with only 15 of 431 in 1996. The increase results from a continuing drive against barristers who fail to pay for insurance against negligence claims and "those barristers who are alleged to have overcharged for their services in criminal legal aid cases", the report says.

The report discloses that a new power to suspend from practice barristers who are thought to be a danger through illness, alcoholism or drug abuse has been used in three cases. Two of the barristers have been suspended pending disciplinary proceedings and the third case is still unfinished.

fields.headline: The office boys for central government
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley is right in emphasising the loss by local authorities of all functions except that of office boy for central government (The Hattersley reports, March 22, 23 and 24).
fields.body:
 Roy Hattersley is right in emphasising the loss by local authorities of all functions except that of office boy for central government (The Hattersley reports, March 22, 23 and 24). This tells citizens that voting in local elections is a waste of time, and leaves them with nothing to do but vote every four or five years for a central administration. This does not even listen to MPs who, because councillors have been sidelined, are little more than overburdened social workers whose excessive constituency work distracts them from their main tasks of calling government to account and taking part in legislation. This may suit government but is not good for democracy.

The choice between directly elected mayors and the style of cabinet government we have in Westminster is a bleak one; neither option is likely to strengthen democracy. The scarcity of first-rate councillors and professional officers flows from the transfer of responsibility elsewhere. For councillors, a further impediment is the burden of too much committee work.

We need national politicians with time to deal properly with national issues, and a lively local democracy with real powers, run by councillors in close touch with their electors.
Roger Crudge
Bristol

 Roy Hattersley's insightful reports on the changing state of local government accept councils as instruments of central government. Yet much of our decline could be blamed on over-centralisation, with too much Treasury control.

The sagas of the dome and infrastructure projects such as the London Underground, epitomise how we have failed to invest in upgrading our infrastructure, while still going for grand projects.

The challenge should be to devise financial instruments, such as bonds, that encourage local authorities to make better long-term decisions. It is only when they can exercise real authority that they will be able to attract better people.
Nicholas Falk
London
n.falk@urbed.co.uk

 It is a depressing symptom of political decline that you can illustrate an article by Roy Hattersley with a photo of a memorial to Thomas Attwood, who died in 1856 and is best known for his theory of expanding the money supply to deal with unemployment, a century before Keynes and light years beyond Hattersley in radical thinking, for which Birmingham was once synonymous.
DBC Reed
Northampton
dbcreed@talk21.com

 Roy Hattersley fails to notice the impact on councillors of Labour's local government reforms. Councillors who are not cabinet members are politically excluded. Scrutiny (ie select) committees have no power, no resources and no support. A mayoral system replaces teamwork, at which local government is quite good, with personality politics.

I've just realised - it's the Westminster system applied to the town halls.
John Garrett
Norfolk county council

fields.headline: Just games
fields.trailText: Your coverage about computer game players being "more intelligent" is misleading (Zap! Go to the top of the class, March 24).
fields.body:
Your coverage about computer game players being "more intelligent" is misleading (Zap! Go to the top of the class, March 24). The study highlighted in the Home Office report was carried out nearly 15 years ago.

The field of computer games has changed dramatically since then and most people who played computer games at that time would have probably been more affluent (which may have accounted for a more intelligent sample). My own reviews of the literature have concluded that there is no evidence that moderate computer game playing is in any way detrimental to children but that very excessive players are most "at risk" from social, psychological and medical consequences.
Dr Mark Griffiths, Reader in psychology
Nottingham Trent University

fields.headline: It's that song again
fields.trailText: Sylvia Henderson's version of the Itma song is better, but still not quite right (Letters, March 24).
fields.body:
 Sylvia Henderson's version of the Itma song is better, but still not quite right (Letters, March 24). The penultimate line was not "When troubles brew, it is his cue", but "When trouble's brewing, it's his doing".
John Cooper
Nottingham

 A £50,000 marble statue of Thatcher for the House of Commons (Commons resists Thatcher statue, March 24)? I wonder if we could hire the Taliban to extend their experience with a more worthy modern example?
IJ Gibson
Ullapool, Ross-shire
ijgibson@globalnet.co.uk

 Today I received a heart-warming letter from David Blunkett, thanking me, on the occasion of my retirement, for my work as a teacher. I left teaching in 1980. What a man! What a memory!
Tony Green
Hebden Bridge, W Yorks
tony@craggvale.plus.com

 I would like to congratulate the Russians on the successful ditching of the Mir space station. It was a spectacular metaphor for the excellence achieved by scientists and engineers in the Soviet Union despite the severe limitations imposed by the communist system. And Stan Labovitch (Letters, March 24) is mean-minded.
Dick Bentley
Southampton

 If BT are in such a terrible financial mess, and things get worse, will they have to call in the receivers?
Richard Kimberley
Wirral, Merseyside

fields.headline: Inundated priests
fields.trailText: Although I heartily support Robert Drury's desire to see an end to the archaic proscription of who is eligible to verify passport applications (Letters, March 24).
fields.body:
 Although I heartily support Robert Drury's desire to see an end to the archaic proscription of who is eligible to verify passport applications (Letters, March 24), I would also welcome an end to the prejudice which labels only priests as capable of extreme audacity and makes the writer incapable of spotting sarcasm.
Rev Stuart Miller
Southampton
stuart.miller@ukgateway.net

 Robert Drury's unjustified snipe about priestly "audacity" aside, my colleague David Jennings (Letters, March 22) need not worry about being inundated with passport applications.

As priests we see most of our parishioners too rarely to put hand on heart and say we've known them for two years. I foresee a sudden rise in church attendance just before the holidays. Hallelujah!
Rev Steve Parish
Warrington
steve@bloovee.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Meat eaters have hearts too
fields.trailText: There's something which AC Grayling hasn't understood about livestock farming (The last word on meat, March 24).
fields.body:
 There's something which AC Grayling hasn't understood about livestock farming (The last word on meat, March 24). It's true that animals are reared for eventual death (a fate which we all share) but the process is not conducted without care and even a kind of love.

As an evident vegetarian, Grayling might like to ponder on the difference between harvesting fine, healthy carrots for the market and having a man in protective clothing come in to destroy them with weed killer.

Waves of human distress are making themselves felt all over the country at the barbarity of what is going on, but there's no price on emotion. All of us who live in rural places are part of a sickening anxiety which comes closer to the central being than money ever can.
Alison Prince
Isle of Arran

 AC Grayling might well have sound moral arguments against meat-eating, but his health argument rests upon a conjuring trick. He conjures up repulsive pictures of millions of wriggling bacteria. Selecting suitably value-laden terminology to describe micro activities could put us all off kissing, wine-drinking and even touching Grayling's philosophy texts.
Peter Cave
London
petercave@cwcom.net

 It is not true that "two people can be fed from an acre of land on which livestock are run, as against 20 if it is cultivated for grain" if that acre is in the Scottish mountains or other areas unsuitable for cultivation. No meat-producing animals grazing in such places means no one fed from thousands of acres. Meat (and milk and cheese) can be produced from places where no crops can grow.

Man is designed to be a meat-eating animal. We do not have the flat teeth of grazing animals that let them grind down the hard, cellulose cell walls of plants nor the specialised stomachs of ruminants that harbour bacteria to ferment the resulting mush.

The fact that man is a rough, nasty, meat-eating animal has always caused problems for those who would rather see him as a spiritual being fallen from some state of grace that could be restored if only such base instincts as sex and meat-eating could be given up - hence the long and multicultural association between celibacy, vegetarianism and religious communities.
R Campbell
Earlston, Berwickshire

 We are dairy farmers in Devon. We have an organic farm and a pedigree herd of Jersey cows. Our herd is closed, which means that all the animals have been born and raised on the farm. Over the years we have built up a deep personal relationship with the animals. We know all 170 of them by name. The latest calf is called Daffodil.

Why can't we vaccinate her? It would take two to three weeks to give her the protection that she needs. The longer we delay the less likely she is to be protected before the virus spreads to our farm, as it surely will.

We have taken all the precautions we can against foot and mouth, and now we just wait. Last weekend we breathed and tasted coal smoke for two whole days, and wondered what else was carried on the air, or by birds, foxes or deer.

Our understanding of vaccination is that the earlier we do so the better, and the greater the chances of success. If a change in policy is left too late the animals will have been infected anyway and vaccination will have no effect. It will be too late for Daffodil since foot and mouth kills the newborn.

Someone must have the courage to say "no more". We do not think that vaccination now will cure all our problems or that things will be easy. But the current levels of slaughter are madness.
Veronica, Colin and Eileen Ayers
Clawton, Devon

 I find astonishing the idea that the conduct of elections might risk spreading foot and mouth disease. I've lived in an isolated location for 30 years. Before that I was a part-time political agent in Derbyshire and then a candidate in Cheshire's Nantwich Division for the 1959, 1964 and 1966 general elections. In none of those places have I seen any sign of any party showing any interest whatever in a closer approach to voters in isolated homesteads than it could secure by sending material to them through the post. And voters themselves may now vote by post if they wish.

We have to have an election sometime in the next 12 months with no guarantee that foot and mouth will be under control even then. Meantime a multitude of emerging problems patently requires the urgent and undivided attention of all our politicians. The national interest anyway demands that we get this election out of the way as soon as possible.
David Green
Castle Morris, Pembrokeshire

 The really good thing about voting by post is that you do it early; then when the canvassers call, you can just say, "Sorry, already voted".
Alan Iwi
Abingdon, Oxon

 Are the officials at Maff the same that advised the previous administration on how to handle BSE? Perhaps a mass cull is required at Maff?
Tim McGuirk
Watford
