fields.headline: Shanghai's children: fostering hope
fields.standfirst: Care for Children is working hard to find permanent homes for children in care in China. Felicity Collier, chief executive of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, reports on the progress being made
fields.trailText: Care for Children, is working hard to find permanent homes for children in care in China. Felicity Collier, chief executive of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, reports on the progress being made
fields.body:
In 1998 I was invited to visit Shanghai with a colleague so that BAAF could lead a conference for foster carers and orphanage officials.

The invitation came from Robert Glover, who had long been a member of BAAF, having worked as a social worker in Norfolk and Guernsey.

It allowed us to visit the charity he had set up, Care for Children, which works with the Shanghai provincial government to place children from institutions in foster families in the community.

The visit to Shanghai gave me an insight into a different world - where commercial enterprise and western influence had transformed a heavily populated country teeming with cyclists and pedestrians and where the collision of the old and the new had created a warmth and vibrancy which was genuinely infectious.

But as we were escorted around the historic city, we also caught glimpses of the inevitable poverty of the hugely populated urban areas.

We talked about children and family life to everyone we met, while remembering that we were in a country where the "one child, one family policy" had both transformed the economy and caused international outrage.

My most distinctive memory was a taxi driver who told us how immoral it was to have more than one child - immoral because the end result could have been starvation and death for millions of people.

It is easy for us to criticise, but who knows what the UK would have done if faced with the consequences of a population explosion of similar proportions?

We visited the Shanghai Welfare Institution, where we were welcomed courteously but - following documentary The Dying Rooms which exposed appalling conditions in some of China's orphanages - with caution.

Our passport was Rob Glover, who had gained enormous respect from government officials and was greeted with shrieks of glee from the children who clung to his side hoping for a game of football.

Small children, many disabled, sat in rows at their computers (donated by commerce) and in some of the classrooms toddlers chanted rhymes.

The most moving sights were the baby wards, with rows of cots and swaddled infants lying quietly in lines. It was not an easy visit and it certainly had a profound impact on all of us but it did demonstrate that progress will only be made if we can work alongside the Chinese government. It is only 40 years ago that we too had rows of babies in our childcare institutions.

In Shanghai, Care for Children has moved more than 260 children into foster families, where they really do appear to be thriving.

British and Chinese society may be different in many ways, but the pressures on families and the need to raise money to help children who are waiting for a permanent home are major challenges for both countries and ones that are vital for the welfare all our children.

Last weekend a small group of British social workers, lawyers, adopters and foster carers flew out to Beijing to join Rob Glover and his colleagues from Care for Children on a trek across the Great Wall. Adventure challenges are an increasingly common fundraising initiative and ours is a very small beginning - just 20 trekkers.

But it signals something special - a transcontinental commitment to improving the lives of children.

If you would like to sponsor any of the trekkers as they walk the Great Wall this week in aid of BAAF and Care for Children or would like information on the China Trek 2002, please contact Angela on 020 7593 2000.

fields.headline: Gently does it
fields.standfirst: They may be low on drama, but Sheffield's Millennium Galleries have elegance in spades. By  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: They may be low on drama, but Sheffield's Millennium Galleries have elegance in spades. By Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
It is refreshing to find a new building that weaves its way subtly through a city rather than making a grand, theatrical statement. This is exactly what the new Sheffield Millennium Galleries and Winter Garden promise to do. The architects, Pringle Richards Sharratt, whose first big project this is, are shaping a cluster of intelligent civic buildings that will join hitherto disconnected city streets and squares, and thus provide new routes through Sheffield's centre. The galleries will bring together clear-spirited, clean-cut architecture with high-quality art of every sort. It may prove to be a template of how to develop ambitious new buildings - shopping centres and offices as well as museums and art galleries - bang in the middle of cities.

The public art galleries open next month and the Winter Garden, a roofed-over city park, in about a year's time. Work is progressing fast as the finely cast prefabricated concrete sections of this group of buildings are bolted together. Here is a city building project exhibiting grace and good manners even before completion. It deserves to succeed.

The galleries will house temporary exhibitions, some shipped in from the Tate, the Victoria and Albert Museum and other major institutions. They will also be home to the Ruskin Gallery (the collection of John Ruskin's Guild of St George, which sponsored workmen to produce craft objects in the late 19th century), and new Metalwork and Craft and Design galleries reflecting Sheffield's historical place at the centre of the British steel industry.

Set near the existing cultural complex comprising the Crucible and Lyceum theatres, and the Graves Art Gallery and Central Library, the galleries insinuate their way gently through a part of the city centre that had become ragged and unsightly by the 1990s. One of the nastiest buildings here was the 1970s eggcrate-shaped city council office, which has been demolished to make way for the centre.

Running the length of the Millennium Galleries is a covered street - the Avenue - from where the exhibition spaces can be accessed. Daylight pervades the galleries. There is no sudden transition between the outside, the Avenue and the galleries; instead the levels of daylight fall ever so gently as visitors, or those just passing through from one side of the city centre to the other, walk under the glazed barrel vaults of the Avenue and the galleries.

Subtle lighting comes from daylight which bounces off reflectors set around the perimeter of each vault. What this means is that the ceilings will be painted gently rather than scorched by the sun even in the height of the summer. And artificial light is only really needed when the sky is overcast or at night when the lights turn on automatically and very gradually.

Two further refinements make the galleries special. First, all services - heating, ventilation equipment and so on - are concealed underground: here is a modern architecture free of exposed ducts, tubes and plumbing. As a result the galleries, despite being very much of our time, have an almost classical feel about them - lofty spaces recalling the basilicas of ancient Roman cities. The administration offices are tucked away in a separate Georgian town house alongside the new buildings: the gallery is entirely freed of clutter, technical and bureaucratic.

Second, all the galleries, and the Winter Garden, are gained from one level - the Avenue. Planned in an easy, democratic manner, the Sheffield galleries should attract audiences with relatively little effort. Though as the sad fate of the city's National Centre for Popular Music shows, no amount of investment in entertaining or even profound architecture can make up for a lack of curatorial direction or lacklustre content.

There have been several missed opportunities over the past decade to thread big new buildings, and especially museums and galleries, through old town and city centres. Institutions, no matter how benevolent, like to make a splash with their buildings. Today most museums want to do what Frank Gehry did for the Guggenheim in Bilbao. Yet this highly theatrical building occupies what was effectively an empty docklands site; it can afford to be a noisy neighbour.

Not so, for example, the Tate St Ives. Arguably this is too cumbersome a building for the picturesque, raggedy, sea-washed Cornish resort. It might have been better off as a loose-fit group of modest-looking galleries winding their way through a part of the town, making easy connections to flanking lanes and offering unexpected views of the Atlantic between stirring seascapes. The Tate might, in other words, have offered a kind of artistically heightened walk through a delightful seaside town. The Sheffield galleries are an attempt to do this in the far more muscular landscape of South Yorkshire.

There is of course a much grander precedent for buildings like this. The English medieval cathedral was, typically, a poetic meeting of several minor buildings - chapter house, cloister and so on - gathered around the great stone ship of the main body of the church. For example, Wells cathedral in Somerset is grand and imposing when seen from its west front. But to enter it, and stroll through it and its associated buildings, is like walking through a curious and beautiful covered city with many different routes around it.

More coolly rational examples of buildings that thread through city centres are the great shopping galleries that were built in Milan and Naples in the late 19th century. These imposing arcades with their shops and cafes were to become the model - albeit in a distorted and bloated form - of the modern shopping mall. It comes as no surprise to see the architects' drawings for the Sheffield Millennium Galleries making reference to the Galleria Vittorio Emmanuele in Milan.

The highlight of the complex for most people is most likely to be the Winter Garden. Its sequence of high pointed roofs is gothic in inspiration, a fine foil to the essentially classical galleries it soars above. It will have benches, kiosks, and pavement cafes around its edge and a central space in front of the galleries for entertainments. But, say the architects pointedly, "it is definitely not a covered shopping mall."

It is encouraging to see that buildings of distinction are emerging that have no need to scream, "Look at me!" There's the Millennium Seed Bank in Sussex, the exciting, yet essentially gentle Eden project in Cornwall and now these Millennium Galleries and Winter Garden in South Yorkshire. Here and there, subtlety is beginning to replace bombast - and we'll be much better off for it.

But, say the architects pointedly, "it is definitely not a covered shopping mall." It is encouraging to see that buildings of distinction are emerging that have no need to scream, "Look at me!" There's the Millennium Seed Bank in Sussex, the exciting, yet essentially gentle Eden project in Cornwall and now these Millennium Galleries and Winter Garden in South Yorkshire. Here and there, subtlety is beginning to replace bombast - and we'll be much better off for it.

fields.headline: Inspections 'fail to deliver'
fields.trailText: The government faces calls for an overhaul of its best value local authority inspection regime as new research shows many councils believe the process eats up precious resources while failing to improve services.
fields.body:
The government today faces calls for an overhaul of its profuse local authority inspection regime as new research shows many councils believe the process eats up precious resources while failing to improve services.

A survey from the Local Government Association (LGA) finds that authorities in England and Wales are largely supportive of the principles behind the government's policy, believing that inspections can act as a catalyst for raising standards.

But the research sends out a clear signal that bodies such as the education inspectorate, Ofsted often fail to translate this potential into concrete improvements, with just 45% of the councils surveyed saying that inspections had led to better services.

Just a quarter thought inspections led authorities to become more innovative, and nearly all those surveyed claimed the inspection process eats up time and money.

LGA chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham said: "Local people have a right to expect excellence of their public services. I am pleased this survey clearly demonstrates widespread support among local councils for external inspection.

"But after the inspection teams have left it is vital the process actually delivers tangible improvements for people on the ground."

The association is calling on the government and the inspectorates to develop a better understanding of how to secure service improvements; to better join up their inspections, and to consider whether successful councils should be less heavily audited.

The survey's results will be particularly worrying for the year-old best value inspection service (BVIS) that councils rated the body least likely to improve services.

The LGA found that less than 40% of authorities thought best value inspections would lead to better performance, a figure that is slightly behind that for the housing inspectorate, and falls significantly behind Ofsted's rating of nearly 60%.

The social services inspectorate (SSI) tops the rankings, with more than two-thirds believing its inspections had led to better performance.

SSI chief inspector Denise Platt said: "I make no excuse for the fact that external scrutiny can be a challenging process. After all, the role of the inspection team is to make sure that the services provided meet the agreed standards.

"However, it is important to remember that the SSI is also there to support councils in their efforts to improve."

More than 60% of councils said, however, that both the BVIS and housing inspectorates would act as catalysts for improvement.

BVIS head Dr Wendy Thomson pointed out that the LGA survey was conducted last autumn, when many councils had not been inspected for best value.

She added that an as yet unpublished BVIS survey indicated that 77% of respondents thought their services would get better as a result of the inspection process.

The survey casts serious doubt over whether the inspection teams that are sent into councils have the skills necessary to judge local government services - only a third of authorities believe the inspectorates have well-qualified staff.

Just one in 10 councils felt there was effective coordination between the different inspection regimes.

The LGA questioned half the chief executives of councils in England and Wales.

fields.headline: Hail to a fragile alchemy
fields.standfirst: Steven Gerrard has the expressive presence to drive England to new heights - if he can stay fit
fields.trailText: Five or six minutes into the match at Anfield on Saturday, Steven Gerrard thundered into a challenge with Jari Litmanen. The Finn must be harder than he looks. For once the strapping young English midfield player got up second and only after prolonged treatment. As he was led along the touchline and prodded back into the fray by his attendant physio, Gerrard puffed out his cheeks and grimaced. His home crowd held its breath, anxious to see what damage had been done to their cherished prodigy.
fields.body:
Five or six minutes into the match at Anfield on Saturday, Steven Gerrard thundered into a challenge with Jari Litmanen. The Finn must be harder than he looks. For once the strapping young English midfield player got up second and only after prolonged treatment. As he was led along the touchline and prodded back into the fray by his attendant physio, Gerrard puffed out his cheeks and grimaced. His home crowd held its breath, anxious to see what damage had been done to their cherished prodigy.

Already, in the first two minutes of the match, Gerrard had produced two moments of majestic invention. Receiving from Paul Scholes in the opening seconds, he transferred the ball with a geometrically exquisite first-time pass to Steve McManaman. On it went to Michael Owen and then to Andy Cole, whose attempted return came back off a defender and gave him the opportunity for an instant drive which veered narrowly wide. Gerrard's second prominent contribution, a minute or so later, consisted of a lethal long ball down the right wing to David Beckham, whose instant whipped cross was punched away by Antti Niemi.

After he returned to the pitch, Gerrard's performance was much reduced both in quality and in quantity for the remainder of the half. Apart from a couple of curiously misplaced passes, there was a definite slide into anonymity. Both he and Paul Scholes were lying too deep, sitting just in front of the back four and allowing the tireless Litmanen to dictate the zones in which the game was to be played.

Fortunately for everyone, Gerrard appeared as much refreshed as anyone by Owen's equalising goal. He reappeared for the second half in much better fettle, the range and force of his play apparently restored. He played an important part in the winning goal, made a crucial interception when Jarkko Wiss threatened the England penalty area after 75 minutes, and later drew a yellow-card foul from Petri Pasanen.

Afterwards Sven-Goran Eriksson was non-committal on the question of the nature of the medical attention Gerrard had received during the interval. Had he received an injection? "Not as far as I know," the coach said. "You would have to ask the doctor. I saw him on the massage bench and doing exercises. He had hurt himself, but he didn't say anything to me at half-time." Gerrard himself unconvincingly ascribed his recovery to a slug of Lucozade, and his withdrawal yesterday from the squad travelling to Albania came as no surprise.

It is, Eriksson quietly observed, "a difficult situation for him and for us and for Liverpool". When an individual player is so evidently important to a team's fortunes, serious decisions have to be made. Diego Maradona, Trevor Francis and Ronaldo are just three virtuosi who were patched up and sent out time and again without proper consideration of their long-term welfare.

What makes Gerrard different is that his game is based on power and energy. He is not a highly strung greyhound subject to constant tweaks and twinges. The long-striding muscularity and instant decisiveness are enough to tempt comparisons with Duncan Edwards, although the remoteness of Edwards's era and the subsequent evolution of the game render such a thought no more than the expression of a romantic yearning for a truly dominant player in the centre of England's midfield.

This is not irrelevant, since what Eriksson's team lacked on Saturday, particularly while Litmanen was in charge of the game's shape, was what the Americans call the "go-to guy", the player whose permanent availability, all-round competence and instinctive understanding of the geography of the game make him the nodal point of the side.

Scholes is too much of an old-fashioned inside forward to become such a figure. McManaman, too, has other virtues. A fully mature Joe Cole could be the answer. So could Beckham, if he moves inside on a permanent basis, as he showed by the manner in which he dispossessed Wiss to start the move that produced Owen's equaliser - a wonderful amalgam of sheer grit and balletic delicacy, topped off by a perfectly weighted pass wide to Gary Neville. Gerrard, however, is the best bet for this vital role, once his body has adapted to the extra inches and pounds he has added in the last year.

In a way his contribution to the side is reminiscent of that made by Iain Balshaw to Clive Woodward's England rugby XV this season. Woodward already had a talented and reliable full-back in Matt Perry, but was prepared to stand him down in favour of a riskier and more expressive player whose presence added an extra dimension to the team, as Balshaw's explosive running has done. Nicky Butt performed extremely well in Gerrard's position against Spain a month ago and will no doubt be required to do so again in Tirana on Wednesday, but Eriksson is clearly aware that the insertion of Gerrard changes the complexion of the whole side and allows the possibility of an ascent to another level.

The fluent interplay currently characterising Woodward's team came to mind again on Saturday during the construction of England's win ning goal. As Gerrard's quick ball set McManaman running at the Finland defence, drawing opponents towards him while two team-mates hared into position outside, readying themselves for the pass which Scholes flicked on to Beckham, the lines of running and timing of delivery were as clinical as anything seen in recent times from the likes of Wilkinson, Catt and Greenwood.

Here was an example of the midfield getting ahead of their own forwards in the construction of a successful attack - and not just one or two of them, but all four. Like their equaliser, in which Andy Cole redeemed a poor first touch with an unselfish ball to Owen, and the intricate work of Beckham and Scholes which led to Cole's spurned chance after 68 minutes, these were signs of a team growing in stature.

From time to time in recent years England have shown similar flashes of accomplishment, notably in the first half against Holland at Wembley in 1993, against the same opponents on the same ground three years later, and, for an hour, against Portugal last summer. For Graham Taylor, Terry Venables and Kevin Keegan, these moments were little more than a series of mirages. Why should Eriksson's experience be any different?

It could be said that even in their most unsatisfactory moments on Saturday, when they were penned in their own half and the lines of communication between midfield and attack had been ruptured, at least they kept their basic shape, so that Eriksson needed only to make a few adjustments at half-time to help them move the balance of the play into their opponents' territory. That was genuinely encouraging. And if leaving Gerrard at home this week primarily represents a gesture of good faith towards Gérard Houllier, then it may also turn out to be an investment in a better future.

fields.headline: Eriksson puts wheels back on
fields.standfirst: Roadshow rolls on to Albania as England splutter back to life with victory of resolve, maturity and good fortune
fields.trailText: Now England have become a repertory company touring the provinces it would be as well if they remembered their lines while trying not to fall over the props. At Anfield on Saturday they just about made the final curtain safely, but it was a close-run thing.
fields.body:
Now England have become a repertory company touring the provinces it would be as well if they remembered their lines while trying not to fall over the props. At Anfield on Saturday they just about made the final curtain safely, but it was a close-run thing.

The victory over Finland was achieved because the juvenile lead, David Beckham, suddenly grew into his captain's armband, and an old stager, David Seaman, responded adroitly to his cue. As a result England will set off for Tirana today confident of beating Albania on Wednesday with rather more to spare than was the case with the Germans in Leverkusen on Saturday night.

At Anfield, however, had Seaman's sense of anticipation at Anfield not found him hurtling towards the near post in time to keep out Jari Litmanen's late header, England's chances of qualifying would be not so much thin as anorexic.

In such fleeting moments lies the difference between triumph and despair. Today England might just as easily be reflecting on their shortcomings as counting their blessings. So it was not surprising to find Sven-Goran Eriksson reluctant to join in the inevitable joy mixed with relief that greeted victory.

As England's coach observed: "At the end we suffered, but sometimes in football the victory is better because of it." Maybe so, yet Michael Owen's terse comment that "the performance was not very good yet we managed to churn out a win" was equally apt.

For Eriksson the principal satisfaction will lie in knowing that he has established an early beachhead in his team selection. This is no small achievement. After England's worst start to a World Cup qualifying tournament and with the squad in disarray once Kevin Keegan resigned following Germany's 1-0 win at Wembley in October, Eriksson had to carry out emergency roadside repairs.

Maybe he has yet to find his best components but at least the moving parts have coughed and sputtered back into life. There was even the possibility of that rarest of events, an unchanged England team, for the Albania game. However Liverpool's Steven Gerrard pulled out yesterday with a sore back, although all along it has been assumed that the young midfielder's recurring problems would not permit him to play in Tirana. Nicky Butt, briefly a substitute at Anfield, should now move in alongside Paul Scholes.

The mere fact that a ready-made replacement is on standby is a tribute to the speed with which Eriksson has restored common sense to the selection process. With his uncomplicated approach there should be a better chance of Eriksson's initial side settling down quickly, which in turn should allow a team of some worth to evolve.

Getting a captain's performance out of David Beckham is not a bad way to start. Just when Anfield was wondering whether Teddy Sheringham would have to come on to take hold of a game that was slipping away, the captain proved worthy of his pips.

Previously Beckham had only wandered vaguely into the middle from the right wing, but now, with an air of exasperation, he seized the ball in the Finland half and played it out to Gary Neville, who neatly sidestepped Harri Ylonen near the byline before passing low to a third Manchester United man, Andy Cole. His indifferent touch ruled out a shot but he fed the ball into Michael Owen, whose crisp half-volley brought the scores level.

Five minutes after half-time a typically strong run from Steve McManaman in the inside-left position threw Finland's cover on to the back foot. From his pass Scholes's quick thinking found Beckham in space to his right and, though the angle was acute, his shot, taking a slight deflection off Sami Hyypia's toecap, gave Antti Niemi no chance.

Without a doubt the day belonged to Beckham. "I hope that Alex Ferguson will rest him once more," said Eriksson, with his tight little smile. But for Seaman, however, the Finland captain Jari Litmanen would have stolen the show and the three points on his home club ground.

Until Beckham intervened the ease with which Litmanen found space and opened gaps threw into stark relief England's apparent lack of such a commanding figure. Two minutes before England drew level his exquisite first-time pass sent Jonatan Johansson clear of Rio Ferdinand for a shot that Seaman somehow plucked out of the air.

This was as crucial a save as his later effort. A second Finnish goal then and England's game, such as it was, would surely have been up. They had fallen behind shortly before the half-hour through a chapter of accidents. Rio Ferdinand failed to mark Aki Riihilahti at a corner, allowing the midfielder a free header that was deflected past Seaman off Gary Neville's knee.

Though Ferdinand and Sol Campbell had good moments individually, England's back four too obviously lacked the sort of authority that Martin Keown or Gareth Southgate might provide.

Eriksson was less concerned with individual faults than the failure, after a bright start, of the team as a whole to move themselves and the ball at a sufficiently high speed to disturb a side dedicated to containment and counterattack.

"We had to play quickly - quick balls and quick running - if we wanted to get in behind Finland, that's what I told them at half-time," he explained. "If you don't play one-touch football, if you want two, three or four touches, it will always be difficult.'

Andy Cole's one-touch play is usually excellent, his aim, for England, less so. "There's always a first time in life," was Eriksson's reply on Friday when reminded of Cole's failure to score in 11 previous internationals. But his miss from eight yards in the 70th minute after Scholes had put him clear prompted some to feel once more that for Cole time is fast running out.

webTitle: England 'not that impressive' says Albania coach

fields.headline: England 'not that impressive' says Albania coach
fields.trailText: England's victory may have been greeted with euphoria at Anfield but the performance did not leave Albania's coach, Medin Zeka, quaking in his boots.
fields.body:
England's victory may have been greeted with euphoria at Anfield but the performance did not leave Albania's coach, Medin Zeka, quaking in his boots.

"Although it was an important win for them and Beckham scored a very good goal, I did not think all of their football was that impressive," he said. "While I am not going to say that we will definitely win against them, we can win, especially playing in Tirana."

Zeka, who watched the game at Albania's team hotel before his side's 2-1 defeat to Germany in Leverkusen, added: "Beckham is a very good player, and the strikers Michael Owen and Andy Cole are dangerous too. But we showed that we can compete against top countries. It was heartbreaking for the players to lose the way they did after performing so well."

You do not, of course, have to be an Albanian to construct a conspiracy theory for everything bad that happens in life. But it is certainly not a disadvantage.

Thus when Germany secured their win with an 88th-minute goal from their substitute Miroslav Klose that looked clearly offside, Zeka and his players regarded it as another example of a powerful country being allowed to oppress a small one.

Suggesting they had lost another game of political football, the striker Igli Tare, who plays for Brescia in Serie A, said: "It always seems to happen that the big nations get decisions like that against us. We played really well and then right at the end, boom! It feels so unfair because all our players are certain it was offside."

Tare, a giant of a striker with a smaller man's touch, will attempt to vent his anger on England's defence in Tirana on Wednesday, and he has promised his skilful side will be even more adventurous than they were in Leverkusen.

He said: "We have to play for the victory but it will not be that easy for us because you can see that England are a lot more motivated under their new coach. I know Sven-Goran Eriksson from Italy and he is a very knowledgeable man."

Although they will be helped by the absences of Albania's captain Rudi Vata, who exerts a Tony Adams-style influence, and Edvin Murati, a clever winger, England will do well to leave Tirana with three points.

Eriksson will have been impressed by the performance of Bledar Kola in midfield, who scored with a left-foot volley against the Germans.

Geri Cipi also showed that he can fill the captain's sweeper role, though he appears to like too many touches, and Arian Xhumba's lack of discipline on the left side of a defensive three will encourage David Beckham to stay wide.

The goalkeeper Foto Strakosha also looked suspect and was at fault for Germany's first goal. But Albania are a neat, tidy, side who only lost 2-1 in Finland in their opening game and should have got a point against Germany to add to their three against Greece.

If things get tight in Tirana, England will just have to hope that the conspiracy theorists are proved correct again.

"Although it was an important win for them and Beckham scored a very good goal, I did not think all of their football was that impressive," he said. "While I am not going to say that we will definitely win against them, we can win, especially playing in Tirana." Zeka, who watched the game at Albania's team hotel before his side's 2-1 defeat to Germany in Leverkusen, added: "Beckham is a very good player, and the strikers Michael Owen and Andy Cole are dangerous too. But we showed that we can compete against top countries. It was heartbreaking for the players to lose the way they did after performing so well." You do not, of course, have to be an Albanian to construct a conspiracy theory for everything bad that happens in life. But it is certainly not a disadvantage. Thus when Germany secured their win with an 88th-minute goal from their substitute Miroslav Klose that looked clearly offside, Zeka and his players regarded it as another example of a powerful country being allowed to oppress a small one. webTitle: Beckham talks up the nation as Kop roars its approval

fields.headline: Beckham talks up the nation as Kop roars its approval
fields.trailText: Most fans must have thought they were more likely to see Tord Grip doing a streak than they were to hear chants of "One David Beckham" rolling down from the Kop. But the sound of Anfield singing the England captain's praises was a mark of just how impressive the match winner was.
fields.body:
Most fans must have thought they were more likely to see Tord Grip doing a streak than they were to hear chants of "One David Beckham" rolling down from the Kop. But the sound of Anfield singing the England captain's praises was a mark of just how impressive the match winner was.

In the event there was no need for Victoria and Brooklyn to have stayed away, a decision the Beckham family reached out of fear that his performance would be affected by worry over the reception which might await his wife and son.

The Manchester United player may find Liverpool's crowd less accommodating when he returns with his club on Saturday, but for those who feel that he is loathed and hopelessly out of form this was an afternoon which changed a few minds. The Londoner who confesses he is not a natural leader is apparently thriving on the role which comes with the armband.

"He's more assured and it's a necessity when you're made the England captain," said Beckham's close friend and club-mate Gary Neville. "All of a sudden you've got to take on more responsibility and it's not a problem for him.

"At 26 he's seen most things in football. There's not a lot that he's not seen: World Cups, European Championships, massive games for United. Sometimes at 25 or 26 you need that extra challenge, that extra motivation.

"Giving him the England captaincy will certainly have given him that and he can be England captain for years to come. Tony Adams and Alan Shearer retired and why not start afresh? The whole squad is a lot fresher, to be honest."

Beckham's captaincy reflects the tone set by Sven-Goran Eriksson, being less about ranting and raving than quiet encouragement and respect. The midfielder still left with a sore throat - "He was talking to me the whole time," Steven Gerrard said - and while he heads to Albania hoping lozenges are readily available, England fans will be praying simply that the captain inspires the team again.

"There's been a lot of negative talk about David in the last two or three weeks," said Neville. "The situation sur rounding him is always hyped up. But it's never as bad as it seems and did he look like a player who was lacking in confidence? That was one of the best games I've ever seen him play for England."

Beckham agreed with that, and if he is going through a crisis then every England player should have one too. The captain described the Kop's reaction as "unbelievable" and admitted he had needed this performance after the recent doubts. "This was a great way to respond," he said.

The only bad news for Beckham is that his desire to play in the centre is surely on hold. "David is probably realising that Paul Scholes and Steven Gerrard are being groomed to play together in the middle," Neville said. "He's probably a victim of his own quality. If he wasn't such a great crosser he'd probably be moved inside, but you've seen why we have to have him on the right."

Beckham's second England goal, and his first since his free-kick against Colombia at France 98, followed a calm message from Eriksson at the interval. "The manager told us we had to be more direct, to get it forward more quickly," Michael Owen said, and there was a little extra from the Swede.

"The boss told us at half-time to think about Japan and South Korea," Rio Ferdinand said. "If those words can't spur you on I don't know what will."
